fields.headline: Hitches and Horlocks
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man who had a fiver on the Millennium Bug breaking the Pentagon, picks out a few potential Cup upsets
fields.trailText: Forget Brazil for the bulk of your weekend bets and look instead to the mud and thunder of the FA Cup.
fields.body:
Forget Brazil for the bulk of your weekend bets and look instead to the mud and thunder of the FA Cup. I'm hopeful that my pre-third round recommendations (Sunderland at 20-1 and Arsenal at 9-2) will both emerge victorious, making your ante-post slips the envy of your friends and family.

Keep those on the backburner and concentrate instead on Manchester City v Leeds. This one looks like a draw, even though the last thing both sides need is a replay. Rest assured, there will be goals. City have scored in all but one of their last 17 games and are certain to tear into their visitors from the start, so it might be wise to wager that first goal scorer will be wearing a blue shirt. Midfielder Kevin Horlock is the pick of the bunch. He's already scored 5 first goals this season and looks like value at the 10-1 or bigger.

Things aren't all rosy for the Blues however. South Africa have allowed Lucas Radebe to stay on in England an extra day before heading off for the African Nations Cup, which will worry Joe Royle, as will the flu bug that has swept through Maine Road this week. However City have caught Leeds on a bit of a downer and can force the stalemate at a best priced 9-4. One goal apiece looks about right.

Sheffield Wednesday's home tie against Wolves is very interesting. Most observers will hold up the Owls' draw against Arsenal on Monday as evidence that Danny Wilson has turned the corner with the Premiership stragglers - and perhaps they've got a point. But the Gunners are traditionally and predictably poor at Hillsborough, so the result didn't come as much of a surprise.

For my money, the Yorkshire side still have plenty to prove and their defence - as Alan Hansen soberly highlighted on Match of the Day - still leaves cavernous holes. Wolves can capitalise. The Division One visitors are unbeaten at Hillsborough over a run of six games so risk the shock at a best priced 7-2 with Stanley. Wednesday will have enough on their plate just trying to stay up for the rest of the season, and will not relish a strength-sapping Cup run with the relegation axe hanging over them.

Then, of course, there's the World Club Championships. Manchester United are generally expected to see off Vasco da Gama in Group B and go on to win the tournament outright. If all goes to plan England then hosts the 2006 World Cup and David Beckham goes to Italy for a record £100million. Can it really be that easy?

No. When United face Vasco da Gama in the Maracana on Saturday night they will have to deal with Edmundo 'the Animal' and Romario 'the Bloke Who Sometimes Pretends He's Swinging a Baby'. On home territory, Vasco da Gama must have the edge, even though United showed they have the ability to win against decent opposition miles from home by beating Palmeiras in the World Club Cup. Stick your money on the Vasco boys to lift the World Club crown at a best priced 11-4.

Recommended bets

Manchester City v Leeds - draw
Sheffield Wednesday v Leeds - away win

fields.headline: Beckham off but United survive
fields.standfirst: Yorke 82 | Montecinos 15
fields.trailText: Dwight Yorke spared Manchester United's blushes and his own here last night when he equalised eight minutes from time two minutes after having a penalty saved. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer put him through, having come on in a triple substitution by Sir Alex Ferguson a few minutes beforehand.
fields.body:
Dwight Yorke spared Manchester United's blushes and his own here last night when he equalised eight minutes from time two minutes after having a penalty saved. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer put him through, having come on in a triple substitution by Sir Alex Ferguson a few minutes beforehand.

But Yorke was never going to be the real villain for United. Shortly before half-time David Beckham was sent off for a reckless challenge. Shortly after it Necaxa, too, had a penalty saved.

It was hardly the opening United can have wanted. They were looking for an impressive performance to disseminate some of the anger at their behaviour off it. The club have been widely criticised here and at home for their reluctance to open up to the media and even the Football Association is thought to be worried by the ill-feeling with the 2006 World Cup bid in mind.

The FA's executive director David Davies said he sympathised with the pressures United were under, particularly before their first game. "I'm confident that by the end of the tournament Manchester United will have left the Brazilian public with a favourable impression," he said.

"That's the time to the judge them, once the competition has finished." Sadly the tournament has not started auspiciously. Just as huge areas of the Morumbi Stadium in Sao Paulo were unoccupied on the first night, so the Maracana felt embarrassingly cavernous as United and Necaxa took the field.

It was a sign of how this competition is viewed by the Brazilian public, 100,000 of whom will turn up to watch a championship derby here. Doubtless it will be full when Vasco play United tomorrow. But Fifa might be wondering about the true worth of their new pet, which has cost around $45m (£27.6m) to stage.

The few thousand who had turned up were at least treated to the full-strength United side. Quite what Jaap Stam, Mark Bosnich and others made of Fifa's decision to play the national anthem for United beforehand was anyone's guess. Only five of the team were British.

With the sun blazing and the atmosphere akin to a bad day at Cowdenbeath, the game initially had the feel of a pre-season friendly. Necaxa had made it clear their plan revolved around forcing the pace to exploit United's unfamiliarity with the conditions. And in side quarter of an hour they had the lead.

Alex Aguinaga, their Ecuadorian playmaker, was the creator. His burst through the centre of the field was ended illegally by Stam, and Cristian Montecinos curled the free-kick over the wall with his left foot and into the corner of the net. Bosnich barely moved.

That at least sparked United into life, although they managed little with their possession. A slow pace did not seem to suit their style and Dwight Yorke wanted too much time when given a rare sight of goal by Andy Cole's cross.

As a poor game was drifting towards half-time David Beckham gave it the lift Ferguson least needed with a show of the petulance which has plagued him in the past. His thigh-high tackle on Jose Milan in the 42nd minute was reckless and unnecessary, a display of mounting frustration, and he could have no argument when the Argentinian referee Horacio Elizondo sent him off. After his experiences at France 98, Argentines are probably not his favourite people.

His fate lies in the hands of Fifa's disciplinary committee but he can expect at least a two-match ban. The Vasco da Gama fans, arriving in their droves for the game against South Melbourne, could not contain their delight.

After surviving a couple of scares immediately after the interval United tried to rediscover the resilience which brought them to this championship in the first place. But it was asking a lot in these conditions to conjure a victory and only Bosnich's reflexes kept them in the game.

First he flung himself to his left to prevent Montecinos scoring again from close range. Even more impressively, in the 57th minute he saved a poor penalty by Aguinaga after Mikael Silvestre had pushed Montecinos to the floor.

In the 70th minute United finally forced Hugo Pineda into his first save, the goalkeeper coming off his line to block a shot by Keane with his left arm.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Bosnich; G Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin (P Neville, 73min); Beckham, Keane, Butt (Solskjaer, 73), Giggs; Cole (Sheringham, 73), Yorke.

Necaxa (2-4-2-2): Pineda; Almaguer, Lopez; Higareda, Vigna (Ambriz, 80), Cabrera, Milan; Perez, Aguinaga; Delgardo, Montecinos (Vasquez, 77).

Referee: H Elizondo (Argentina).

fields.headline: Breast cancer screening
fields.standfirst:
Breast screening is a waste of time, says study
Mammograms explained: graphic
Leading feminist Angela Phillips responds to the Danish scientists claims
fields.trailText: Why was breast cancer screening introduced?
fields.body:
Why was breast cancer screening introduced?

Breast cancer is the most common cause of death among British women under 50. It's estimated that one in eleven women will develop it by the time they reach the age of 85.

Women with advanced breast cancer usually have to undergo a mastectomy - the surgical removal of their breast. But if the cancer is detected early enough, radiotherapy and chemotherapy may be enough to put it into remission.

Screening was introduced in 1988 for women between 50 and 64, and in 1998 1.2 million had mammograms. Of those, 5.9 per 1000 had cancer. While all women are encouraged to check their breasts regularly for lumps or abnormalities, growths of less than 15mm can't be detected by touch. The great advantage of screening is that it spots any growth at a very early stage. Of the 6,914 cancers detected by mammogram in 1998, 2,419 would otherwise have gone unnoticed.

What happens during a breast scan?

A woman's breasts are X-rayed to produce a mammogram. You can see some examples, both benign and malignant, at Oxford university's online mammographic image database.

How much does the programme cost?

In 1998 it cost £37 million, or roughly £25 for each woman.

Has the number of deaths fallen since it began?

Yes, although screening is probably only one factor in the drop. Between 1989 and 1998, the number of women dying from breast cancer fell by 14%. Britain still has a higher mortality rate than the rest of Western Europe.

Do other countries screen too?

Yes. Canada, Sweden, Holland and the United States are among the countries with screening programmes. US researchers say that it prevents 6 breast cancer deaths in every 10,000 women between 50 and 70.

So why does the Lancet medical journal think it a waste of time?

The study (which you can read online from the evening of 7 January) looked at eight existing screening trials in Sweden, Canada, Scotland and the US which are used to justify the programmes. It criticised the lack of reliable 'control groups' in six of them, and also found that while the mortality rate from breast cancer did fall, the screened women were more likely to have died from other causes.

They concluded that even if the trials were unbiased, no lives were saved by screening; and if they were not reliable, there was certainly no evidence that it cut mortality rates.

Professor Michel Baum of the Royal Free in London claims that it is new cancer treatments that have cut mortality rates, not screening programmes.

Who still supports screening?

The NHS Breast Cancer Screening Programme, of course, who expect to save around 1,250 lives each year 'at a conservative estimate'. The Lancet's interpretation and methodology is, they say, 'open to question'. The Cancer Research Campaign and Breakthrough Breast Cancer also endorsed the programme, pointing out that early detection very often meant that women could avoid mastectomies and aggressive treatments.

Dutch doctor Harry de Koning has commented that screening evaluations can only take place over a long period. He says breast cancers are certainly being detected earlier through the programmes.

What will happen to the screening programme now?

More research is certainly needed, and the NHS Screening Programme will release new figures later this year. However, it would be difficult for the government to deny women mammograms on the NHS.

It may be that women are put off screening. But while the recent scares over cervical smears were due to medical errors - lab staff overlooked malignant smears - the Lancet research questions the validity of the entire screening programme.

It may be that the focus will shift to better treatments. The drug tamoxifen has helped many women, and a breast cancer vaccine is currently in development.

fields.headline: Alan Parker
fields.standfirst: Angela's Ashes: The manuscript | The casting | The filming
fields.trailText: Angela's Ashes: The manuscript | The casting | The filming
fields.body:
BN: How, and why, did you get involved with Angela's Ashes in the first place?

AP: It was sent to me as a manuscript of a book before it was published, and I quite liked it and enquired about acquiring the rights but they'd gone to Scott Rudin - one of the producers - who buys every single book that's published in New York, so to get a book ahead of him is very difficult. It finally came back to me, and I was asked to do it by Scott and David Brown, the other producer.

BN: The book was a hugely successful and lots of people have read it and have their own image of what the film should be like. Is there a danger that those people going to see your film will be looking not for the film you've actually made but for the film you should have made? Were you conscious of that danger?

AP: I was, I think that's been the difficulty for film-makers throughout history really when you take a great literary work - and this is [a great work]. It's not just that it won the Pulitzer Prize, it's been a publishing phenomenon everywhere around the world. It had won the Pulitzer Prize by the time it came to me and it was a number one bestseller in the New York Times bestseller list. In Hollywood they always say, "Well, that's okay, that's people who read but there's not many of those are there?" .... To be honest this kind of film is the hardest to make, in that I needed to build sets but it's a very small story. It's based on someone's life, it's an Irish story and American studios are very reluctant to give to you money [for something], but because of the success of the book we were able to make the film.

I loved it when it was sent to me in manuscript form, and you can be intimidated by it - all of you here who've probably read the book before you saw the film have a different film in your head, and I can never ever do it as good as that.

My great mentor Fred Zinnemann did From Here to Eternity which had terrible, terrible reviews when it came out because it could never be as good as the book. But when it came down to it, his work was as important as the book because film is an organic process and maybe more people get to see the film, that's just by virtue of the different art forms. But you are nervous about anyone who has read the book - can I do justice to it? - I hope I have, and there are people who've read it and maybe thought I haven't.

BN: I would think that one of the great difficulties was that the book is told in the present tense by the young Frank at various ages. There was a script already in existence by Laura Jones, an Australian writer. Was it she who decided that instead of doing the young boy's voice going all the way through the film you should do it a little time afterwards, in retrospect, by the grown-up Frank, or was that your decision?

AP: Scott Rudin and David Brown developed the script with Laura Jones and she was able to take what was a very difficult and complex book and pare it down to the very bare minimum. I thought she'd probably been too strict with paring it down, and I tried to flesh it out. One of things I did was to go back to the book because there's always so much more in the book than you could possibly put in a film. A film of the entire book would have been 5 - 8 hours long and that's a bit long really! [Laura Jones] did a really good job, it was a blueprint for what the film became.

BN: You cast Robert Carlyle and Emily Watson, two non-Irish actors. Why did you choose those two?

AP: Most directors have little lists in their heads of people they really want to work with. I had seen Emily in Breaking the Waves and I'd seen her in The Boxer - I hadn't seen her in Hilary and Jackie at that point - and I met her and she's an Arsenal supporter which was...

BN: ...that's the worst thing you've said about Emily Watson!

AP: I know, but we are at the NFT so we have to give intellectual reasons for choosing actors. [Laughter] She grew up in Islington and is an Arsenal supporter so she got the job. [Laughter] Robert Carlyle, for some strange reason, supports a Scottish team. No, Emily Watson and Robert Carlyle were the first choices for the film.

BN: What about Irish actors though? You can't be too popular with the Irish acting fraternity?

AP: Well, there are 350 cast and crew who made that film who are Irish and it's their film.

BN: But the main characters weren't [Irish].

AP: I suppose so, but every other actor is Irish. If there was somebody else better there to do it I would have gone with it. The reason the film got made was because the American studios thought it was a good bet because it was a hugely successful book, simple as that, and they allocate X amount of money for me to make it. It wasn't necessary to have a movie star, it was my decision to go with the actors that I was comfortable with and so it's my fault. I chose them because I thought they were the best for it. I actually did think of all the Irish actors who were available to do it and decided on those two, and I can't blame anybody but me really.

BN: The more you look at the film the more you realise how difficult it was to make because your central character changes twice. That must have caused problems because the audience is involved in little Joe Breen [young Frank], then suddenly it's somebody else in his place. How did you overcome that?

AP: It's the hardest thing when you've got a young child growing up - when you read the book you can go day by day, week by week, month by month, year by year and you don't even notice it. On a film you have to be much more specific. But really the only way to do it is to break the whole film down into the classic three-act structure, and therefore I needed three boys. It's very difficult, I tried to make the transitions as smooth as possible. The problem is that there is the young Frank who is very sweet and loveable and in whom, as an audience, you invest so much, then suddenly you see the middle boy and the big worry was that the audience would then groan, "Oh, I'm not going to see that little boy anymore, he's gone."

Ciaran Owens - who plays the middle boy - is also very good and he has his amount of charm, and so Michael Legge - who plays the older Frank - has a very hard job because he's got to follow those [younger] boys who have so much natural charm, but there's no other way of doing it. I don't know how you can show such time difference really.

BN: I gather Joe Breen has been a huge hit in America. How old is he? 9?

AP: He was eight when he made the film. He's a farmer's son from Wexford before he came to the audition he had to milk the cows! He did the David Letterman show in New York and was a huge hit and he's been asked back. His parents have asked me if I could talk to him because you take a kid from nowhere and you are totally changing their lives and the reason he's so lovely is because he's unspoiled, and what we do is spoil him by putting him on American chat shows. For him to stay normal is very difficult, and it's very hard for him because I care more about him staying normal than him doing all the new chat shows. He's stayed pretty normal, mostly because he's got a really good Mum and Dad and because he's been brought up in a very nice way.

BN: Was Joe Breen overawed by David Letterman?

AP: No, Joe destroyed David Letterman! Letterman did not know how to deal with him because he totally and utterly told the truth. Apparently half-way through the questions Joe said to him, "You bite your nails". It takes a 9-year-old Irish kid to say that.

BN: What about the making of the film, because it looks cold and wet. Was that deliberate, or was it wet and cold while you were making it?

AP: Both, it was pretty cold and pretty wet, and in the book Frank talks about "The damp, the damp, the damp". It was a reason for a lot of the illnesses and the deaths of the children at the beginning of the film; there's not a page that goes by where it doesn't talk about the damp. But damp is quite a difficult thing to film because you feel it, you don't see it. Rain is also very difficult to film, particularly in Ireland because it's quite fine, so fine that the Irish don't even acknowledge that it exists. [Laughter]

So if you have rain machines like we did you have to have heavy rain in order to photograph it, and it has to be back lit, even heavy rain. So you get into the mechanics of that to give an impression of damp because I can't do that in film - you have to see it and experience it but you can't feel it, not yet you can't.

BN: The cold comes across in the colour of the film, the colours are sharp but they are cold - you're under no illusion that this is a warm place in which this film has been made.

AP: Period recreation is very difficult unless you make a black and white movie, which in a way would have been easier to do but I wouldn't have made it in black and white even if we'd been allowed to, which we were not. What you do is narrow the colour palette and so the costume designer, the production designer and the cinematographer are all working in the same colour palette, which is to get rid of all those primary colours, and then the moment you put the rain in it automatically mutes the colours even more. You get back to that monochromatic which gives you a period feel, but is still real because it's still in colour.

BN: Those dreadful alleys were recreated?

AP: The main lane, Roden Lane - the centrepiece of the film - was a big set actually in Dublin, the interiors were at the studios but the big lane was built in the middle of Dublin in a bit of waste ground that we found.

BN: How did the people of Limerick react? From what I've heard half the people of Limerick say, "Oh God, it was nothing like that at all", and the other half claim to have lived next door to the family. Was there opposition or support for you when you went to film there?

AP: There are a lot of people in Limerick who have opinions about Frank McCourt's book, it's made Limerick very famous now. When you have that kind of publishing phenomenon which is about a place called Limerick then suddenly Limerick becomes very famous. In the contemporary sense Limerick isn't really, no one ever cares about Limerick in Ireland, it's called 'Stab City'. The main church where [Frank McCourt] went when he was a kid, called St Joseph's, certainly wouldn't let us in, they wouldn't even let us paint the railings outside. Five minutes from there is the Redemptonist church which figures in the masturbation scene. They - for very obvious reasons - wouldn't let us in [Laughter], and then there is the Franciscan church which figures at the end where the priest is one of the very few people who is kind to him. It's such a wonderful moment in the fact that this kid never lost his faith and I thought it was very beautifully explained in the film and in the book, and so you think that the Franciscans and that church would have been a bit kinder to us and would have allowed us to film in it. They did say yes, but a bit later on they said no.

fields.bodyText: BN: How, and why, did you get involved with Angela's Ashes in the first place? AP: It was sent to me as a manuscript of a book before it was published, and I quite liked it and enquired about acquiring the rights but they'd gone to Scott Rudin - one of the producers - who buys every single book that's published in New York, so to get a book ahead of him is very difficult. It finally came back to me, and I was asked to do it by Scott and David Brown, the other producer. BN: The book was a hugely successful and lots of people have read it and have their own image of what the film should be like. Is there a danger that those people going to see your film will be looking not for the film you've actually made but for the film you should have made? Were you conscious of that danger? AP: I was, I think that's been the difficulty for film-makers throughout history really when you take a great literary work - and this is [a great work]. It's not just that it won the Pulitzer Prize, it's been a publishing phenomenon everywhere around the world. It had won the Pulitzer Prize by the time it came to me and it was a number one bestseller in the New York Times bestseller list. In Hollywood they always say, "Well, that's okay, that's people who read but there's not many of those are there?" .... To be honest this kind of film is the hardest to make, in that I needed to build sets but it's a very small story. It's based on someone's life, it's an Irish story and American studios are very reluctant to give to you money [for something], but because of the success of the book we were able to make the film. I loved it when it was sent to me in manuscript form, and you can be intimidated by it - all of you here who've probably read the book before you saw the film have a different film in your head, and I can never ever do it as good as that. My great mentor Fred Zinnemann did From Here to Eternity which had terrible, terrible reviews when it came out because it could never be as good as the book. But when it came down to it, his work was as important as the book because film is an organic process and maybe more people get to see the film, that's just by virtue of the different art forms. But you are nervous about anyone who has read the book - can I do justice to it? - I hope I have, and there are people who've read it and maybe thought I haven't. BN: I would think that one of the great difficulties was that the book is told in the present tense by the young Frank at various ages. There was a script already in existence by Laura Jones, an Australian writer. Was it she who decided that instead of doing the young boy's voice going all the way through the film you should do it a little time afterwards, in retrospect, by the grown-up Frank, or was that your decision? AP: Scott Rudin and David Brown developed the script with Laura Jones and she was able to take what was a very difficult and complex book and pare it down to the very bare minimum. I thought she'd probably been too strict with paring it down, and I tried to flesh it out. One of things I did was to go back to the book because there's always so much more in the book than you could possibly put in a film. A film of the entire book would have been 5 - 8 hours long and that's a bit long really! [Laura Jones] did a really good job, it was a blueprint for what the film became. BN: You cast Robert Carlyle and Emily Watson, two non-Irish actors. Why did you choose those two? AP: Most directors have little lists in their heads of people they really want to work with. I had seen Emily in Breaking the Waves and I'd seen her in The Boxer - I hadn't seen her in Hilary and Jackie at that point - and I met her and she's an Arsenal supporter which was... BN: ...that's the worst thing you've said about Emily Watson! AP: I know, but we are at the NFT so we have to give intellectual reasons for choosing actors. [Laughter] She grew up in Islington and is an Arsenal supporter so she got the job. [Laughter] Robert Carlyle, for some strange reason, supports a Scottish team. No, Emily Watson and Robert Carlyle were the first choices for the film. BN: What about Irish actors though? You can't be too popular with the Irish acting fraternity? AP: Well, there are 350 cast and crew who made that film who are Irish and it's their film. BN: But the main characters weren't [Irish]. AP: I suppose so, but every other actor is Irish. If there was somebody else better there to do it I would have gone with it. The reason the film got made was because the American studios thought it was a good bet because it was a hugely successful book, simple as that, and they allocate X amount of money for me to make it. It wasn't necessary to have a movie star, it was my decision to go with the actors that I was comfortable with and so it's my fault. I chose them because I thought they were the best for it. I actually did think of all the Irish actors who were available to do it and decided on those two, and I can't blame anybody but me really. BN: The more you look at the film the more you realise how difficult it was to make because your central character changes twice. That must have caused problems because the audience is involved in little Joe Breen [young Frank], then suddenly it's somebody else in his place. How did you overcome that? AP: It's the hardest thing when you've got a young child growing up - when you read the book you can go day by day, week by week, month by month, year by year and you don't even notice it. On a film you have to be much more specific. But really the only way to do it is to break the whole film down into the classic three-act structure, and therefore I needed three boys. It's very difficult, I tried to make the transitions as smooth as possible. The problem is that there is the young Frank who is very sweet and loveable and in whom, as an audience, you invest so much, then suddenly you see the middle boy and the big worry was that the audience would then groan, "Oh, I'm not going to see that little boy anymore, he's gone." Ciaran Owens - who plays the middle boy - is also very good and he has his amount of charm, and so Michael Legge - who plays the older Frank - has a very hard job because he's got to follow those [younger] boys who have so much natural charm, but there's no other way of doing it. For him to stay normal is very difficult, and it's very hard for him because I care more about him staying normal than him doing all the new chat shows. He's stayed pretty normal, mostly because he's got a really good Mum and Dad and because he's been brought up in a very nice way. BN: Was Joe Breen overawed by David Letterman? AP: No, Joe destroyed David Letterman! Letterman did not know how to deal with him because he totally and utterly told the truth. Was that deliberate, or was it wet and cold while you were making it? AP: Both, it was pretty cold and pretty wet, and in the book Frank talks about "The damp, the damp, the damp". It was a reason for a lot of the illnesses and the deaths of the children at the beginning of the film; there's not a page that goes by where it doesn't talk about the damp. But damp is quite a difficult thing to film because you feel it, you don't see it. Rain is also very difficult to film, particularly in Ireland because it's quite fine, so fine that the Irish don't even acknowledge that it exists. [Laughter] So if you have rain machines like we did you have to have heavy rain in order to photograph it, and it has to be back lit, even heavy rain. So you get into the mechanics of that to give an impression of damp because I can't do that in film - you have to see it and experience it but you can't feel it, not yet you can't. webTitle: Guardian readers: are you all whingers?

fields.headline: Guardian readers: are you all whingers?
fields.standfirst:
Guardian readers have been discussing in our letters pages whether they are big whingers. Here's some extracts from this week - do you agree with those who think the millennium celebrations were a disgrace or those who say Guardian readers should cheer up?

 Vote here
 Talk about it
 See what David Baddiel has to say about it
 Comment editor David Leigh defends Guardian readers' honour
fields.trailText:
Guardian readers a miserable bunch of whingers? Surely not; as Mark Twain reminds us: "irreverence is the champion of liberty and it's only sure defence".
Anne Kenny
Canterbury
fields.body:
Guardian readers a miserable bunch of whingers? Surely not; as Mark Twain reminds us: "irreverence is the champion of liberty and it's only sure defence".
Anne Kenny
Canterbury

If there's nothing to whinge about, what's the point of writing to papers?
Tony Black
Sevenoaks

The millennium party: a national disgrace?

The London millennium party was a national disgrace. Far from being a festive spirit, the scenes were reminiscent of refugees evacuating a war-time European capital.
Humphrey Hawksley
London Hwhawksley@cs.com

The real scandal was the lack of public loos. Reminiscences of the great night are dominated by tales of heroic bladder control as men and especially women sought in vain for a toilet... Is this further proof that without Ken running the show, London is incapable of organising a piss-up for the millennium ?
Davy Jones
London davyjones@cwcom.net

Stop moaning!

What a miserable bunch of whingers. Just how many lavs would you need to deal with 2m people? I am beginning to understand why the phrase 'Guardian reader' has taken on pejorative overtones.
Brian Blain
London

Ever since whoever it was suggested a sample of gifts for the millennium child, the letters page has been full of smug scoffers, cynics and moaners. Yesterday out of 27 letters, 19 were moans and complaints more suited to the columns of the Telegraph. Has liberal guilt changed to liberal bile?
Anne Hughes
Seaford, E Sussex.
AnneHughes2@compuserve. com

The magazine I edit is well-known for the bilious whingeing and moaning that fills its letters pages each month. Our most recent readership survey found that 35% of ours were also Guardian readers, streets (nay, broad leafy boulevards) ahead of any other daily. Your letters page gives a clear indication that things aren't going to change very much this century, are they?
Ian Anderson
Editor, Folk Roots magazine froots@froots.demon.co.u k

One of the oddest things those of us from overseas find about the British character is your attitude to any form of success or achievement. You stage the biggest millennium celebrations in the world, have the biggest and best party in the spectacularly unique Dome, and cover the event with 30 hours of superb television. And what is everyone talking about? A few queues of disgruntled people and a handful of fireworks that failed to ignite. You really should be so proud of your successes  I know that I was proud to be with you all on the big night.
Robert Petric
Zagreb, Croatia

The real reason?

I am amazed Guardian readers have failed to make the most obvious connection between the 19 whingers (Letters, January 3) and the gender imbalance of correspondents. All the whingers were men. Victor Meldrew is alive and well. Val Stevens Manchester

valstevens@transport.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Hollywood Beyond
fields.standfirst: These days, Mike Figgis is travelling down some wild and exotic routes. The week The Loss of Sexual Innocence opens in the UK, Xan Brooks went to the director
fields.trailText: These days, Mike Figgis is travelling down some wild and exotic routes. The week The Loss of Sexual Innocence opens in the UK, Xan Brooks went to meet the director
fields.body:
Mike Figgis's The Loss of Sexual Innocence intertwines a coming-of-age fable with a retelling of Adam and Eve's exile from Eden. His next project is a 93-minute sprint, shot in one take, on digital and projected simultaneously on four movie screens. "I wrote it like a string quartet," he explains helpfully. "On sheet-music paper".

Certainly, this is a far cry from the Figgis of old. This, after all, is the man whose 1987 Newcastle-set debut, Stormy Monday, paved a route to the Hollywood fast track, who resurrected Richard Gere's career with Internal Affairs and clashed spectacularly with big-shot producer Ray Stark over the final cut on 1993's Mr Jones.

Now based back in London and operating out of a skeleton-crewed office off Tottenham Court Road, Figgis looks back on that whole time as an aberration. "It was something I was excited to fall into," he admits, "because I was suddenly in a position of such power, and I was suddenly earning such money and meeting world-famous actors on a casual basis. And it feels terribly cool. You start regarding yourself as a very special individual. But then at a certain point you suddenly feel: 'I am so frustrated and bored by this', and you see the British people who have gone there and become so homogenised. And I guess I had a fear of that.

"Hollywood," he adds, "destroys people and ages people and throws them out on a weekly basis."

But clearly some fascination remains. Figgis has recently completed work on a book (published in the Projections series) of one-on-one interviews with a variety of Hollywood players, from Mel Gibson to Jodie Foster to Jerry Bruckheimer to Salma Hayek.

Some of the transcripts - most notably the interviews with an embittered Ally Sheedy and a tailspinning Robert Downey Jr - make for uncomfortable reading. "I was interested to talk to some of the road victims, and make them a little more honest about the structure they're involved in. I mean, the elements of prostitution are on a grand scale, either literal or metaphorical."

He admits that some subjects (Alicia Silverstone) refused to speak to him, and that others (Warren Beatty, Joe Eszterhas) proved impossible to get hold of. "It could have become a lifetime job," he says. "In fact I'm going back to do some more this month." Figgis filmed all 32 of his interviews on video; FilmFour are currently screening them every Thursday.

In the meantime, Figgis looks to be steeling himself for the response to The Loss of Sexual Innocence, which stars his current partner Saffron Burrows and is the sort of florid, ambitious art-movie guaranteed to polarise viewers.

But experience has taught him to learned to be sanguine over his hits and misses. He figured that his 1995 saga Leaving Las Vegas would be seen by no more than "friends and a few film nuts". It turned out to be a global hit that won an Oscar for its star, Nic Cage. So if Sexual Innocence plays to a smaller audience, Figgis isn't overly bothered.

"It's already been really beaten up by American critics," he says. "Certainly the mainstream critics really kicked the shit out of it. And I was a bit upset. But someone said to me: 'It's rather arrogant to be upset, because the fact that you even got this film made is a remarkable achievement. If you want your cream with it, if you want good reviews, you must be out of your tree'. It was a good reality check for me. You can't expect good mainstream reviews if you make a film like this."

But then Figgis does look to be pulling increasingly away from what is traditionally viewed as the movie mainstream. He claims to feel an affinity with the Dogme school of young directors (Lars von Trier, Thomas Vinterberg) and is excited by the possibilities suggested by the micro-budgeted Blair Witch Project.

Film he feels, is on the brink of becoming more democratic, more open to possibility. "After Blair Witch the floodgates have opened. I wouldn't like to be on the selection panel at Sundance for next year. You used to have to plough through scripts. Now you're going to have to plough through videos. There will be literally thousands of films being made, which is brilliant." He pauses to take a sip of water.

"I have a theory that film has replaced religion, because it's projected in temples, basically, and seems the ultimate corruption of a pure religious ideal in that it's about excessive sensuality on a cheap level. . . My hope is that these new developments will de-signify the temple and turn film into an amateur thing. The idea that anyone can make a movie is healthy. You don't have to have a mark from God."

fields.headline: Ashes and diamonds
fields.standfirst: Emily Watson faces poverty and hardship in her latest film Angela's Ashes but, as she tells Claire Armitstead, she finds a fragile beauty in the desolation
fields.trailText: Emily Watson faces poverty and hardship in her latest film Angela's Ashes but, as she tells Claire Armitstead, she finds a fragile beauty in the desolation
fields.body:
For those of us who have never reached such heights, the idea of stardom creates two great questions: what is the precise moment that you realised you were a star, and can you ever be the same again? Emily Watson thinks deeply about this, her forehead puckering up with concentration. "In other people's perception I might be, but I'm not really. And anyway, it's a very abstract thing. It's not like getting a sofa for your front room."

As an afterthought, she concedes that what first made her think she might be one was sitting on planes with Mike Leigh back in 1996. Watson had just made her debut in Breaking the Waves, Leigh had made Secrets and Lies, and they kept being booked on the same flights to the same awards ceremonies. "It was like, hey, isn't this exciting, the Brits are coming. It was a fairytale year for a lot of people."

Four years on, she has been hired - along with Robert Carlyle - to bring a bit of name recognition to a movie that is all about childhood. Alan Parker's film of Frank McCourt's bestselling memoir is a conflicted beast: in order to appeal to the American market that has kept Angela's Ashes in the bestseller lists for so long, it must have its adult stars. Yet the whole appeal of the book is its story of the child McCourt and his ability to save himself from the slough of despond inhabited by his alcoholic father and helpless mother.

As the eponymous Angela (McCourt's mother), Watson gives birth to seven children and loses three of them to the ravages of poverty and disease, before losing her useless husband Malachy (a surprisingly unraddled-looking Carlyle) to the drinking life in England.

For Watson, the film created several problems. First and foremost, how does a young, middle-class Londoner come to grips with the hardships of 1930s Limerick? "It was really hard to get your head around. We have such a modern sensibility: if someone now had lost three children it would be in the newspapers for a start, and we have an army of bereavement counsellors, drugs and God knows what else to help us, whereas Angela had nothing. She just had to get on with bringing up the rest of her children as best she could."

The imaginative problem is matched by a technical one: dramatically, Angela is a cipher. In the book, McCourt doesn't presume to understand her hopeless stoicism. In film terms, this means that she has no back story, no scenes of psychological revelation around which an actor can construct a three-dimensional movie character.

There is one moment - Malachy has landed his first job and he and Angela canoodle for an instant in their front parlour - when Parker allows them to show a spark of the sexual attraction that must have held them together. But the rest of the film is characterised by Watson, head down, cigarette jutting from her mouth, tramping the mean streets from one charitable organisation to another in search of a crust to put in her children's mouths.

"The material is so powerful it's bewildering," Watson says. "You get to the end of the day and Alan says, 'That was great work', but something's nagging in the back of your mind. Something awful happened. Then you think, 'Oh yeah, my baby died.' "

So how is it that the Islington-born, private-school educated daughter of an architect and a teacher has ended up playing such a no-hoper? Watson smiles. "I'd always been told that in film and television you get cast as you are - so, as a middle-class English girl, I'd be in Jane Austen territory. I had no idea I'd be cast as a Scot or an Irishwoman."

Yet it was as a Scot that she made her breakthrough, in Lars Von Trier's film of life at the edge of civilisation, Breaking the Waves. As the lonely islander besotted with a Danish rig-worker, Watson gave human shape to a particular sense of desolation. "Lars didn't say anything as obvious as 'Look, you can do it'. He just saw something I didn't know was there. He opened a door and helped me through it. I absolutely credit him with finding that for me."

I've got one of those faces that shows things. It's not doing, but being. The funny thing is that I didn't know how bizarre my face looked until somebody put a camera on it. You really only know what you look like when you start to see yourself on film."

One of the odd effects of her apparent fragility is that it comes as a surprise to see how tall she is - 5ft 8ins in bare feet - even though the evidence is there in the films. In The Boxer, she towers above her screen father, Brian Cox, and walks practically shoulder to shoulder with the stringy Day-Lewis.

In retrospect, you could almost say that her height becomes an emblem of the characters she is playing. In Hilary and Jackie, she coils it around her cello; proclaims it from the podium with such force that her earlier, straight-backed confidence fuels the tragedy of the juddering, neurotic wreck that Du Pré eventually becomes. In a film that sets out to demolish the myth of heroic personality - and which pushes the actress to almost gothic extremes of manipulativeness - Watson somehow hangs on to a credible sense of tragic stature.

We're back on the theme of where it all comes from. "I don't know. What I do know is that I love that sense of coming away from a scene where you feel you've really found something - not something you've planned or rehearsed, but something about the character that comes to you on camera out of the blue. It's not work that translates directly on to the screen but it feeds in at a subtle, perceptual level."

Can she think of any examples? "In Star Wars, when Princess Leia says 'I love you' and Harrison Ford replies, 'I know'. In the script I think he said 'I love you too'. It may be apocryphal, but I love that story. It's such a brilliant moment, so typical of the arrogance of that character."

Watson speaks quietly and thoughtfully, and it's not a surprise to learn that at school she was taught to meditate. It was also at school that she began to act. "But I don't think I showed any more promise than anyone else. In terms of talent, I was probably a late developer." She went on to read English at Bristol university, and only then decided that she would blow her savings on a drama training. After being rejected by two drama schools, she finally found one that would take her. "My parents never opposed me, though in private I think they were kind of circumspect."

For years she followed the jobbing actor's star - in and out of work, up and down the country. It's easy to forget how suddenly success struck, and from what an unlikely quarter. "I'd never heard of Lars Von Trier," she admits. "I was telling people I was going up for this really strange little Danish movie. I didn't know me arse from me elbow." Realisation only kicked in months later, after the film's gala screening at the Cannes film festival, when 2,500 rose to their feet in a spontaneous standing ovation. Are her parents proud of her? "Oh they're becoming more blasé, but they see the downside - they know I get lonely and they worry about me."

More trickily, her husband, Jack Waters, is also an actor, whom she met during a spell of work for the Royal Shakespeare Company. Does he find her success difficult? "I think there have been periods when it has been a bit weird for him, but we try to go through the experience of it together. He comes to Los Angeles with me, and he's very at ease with the whole round."

The downside to success, she admits, is that "things do change". "Meeting new people is strange. You can understand why people begin to revolve in film circles, because nobody's fazed by it. But, you know, my friends are still my friends. And there are certain advantages: when you start out as an actor you are just resigned to being penniless for the rest of your life. It goes with the territory. And suddenly I'm wealthy. I own my first home. I pinch myself about that."

She insists that, though she has never doubted she would get by, nor has she ever had a masterplan. "There are lots of things I want to do: I'd like to have children; I'd like to do more theatre; I've started writing some projects of my own and I'd like to finish them. And I'm looking forward to playing someone with a bit more life in them."

One story she tells reveals a lot about the distance that this 32-year-old actress has travelled. "I remember the moment my first film finished. I was devastated. It was such a big experience that I thought I'd never get over it. It's terribly sweet and innocent to be that devastated. But now I'm a little bit older and a little bit wiser I know that when the director says cut for the last time, it's cut. That's it. Something's gone." As she speaks, her face takes on something of Angela's impenetrable resignation.

 Angela's Ashes is released on January 14. The Guardian Interview with Alan Parker is tonight at the NFT, South Bank (0171-928 3232), following a screening of Angela's Ashes at 6.30pm.

fields.headline: Whingers - a formidable minority
fields.standfirst:
They make up in passion what they lack in numbers, writes David Leigh, the editor of the Guardian's comment pages
Guardian readers: are you all whingers?
Vote here
See what David Baddiel has to say about it
fields.trailText: Guardian letter-writers have been recently accused of whinging - about the dome, Tony Blair, the millennium - anything and everything. Our readers send in about 300 letters a day. How many of  them are from whingers? Actually, not such a lot.  Only about 20% of the contents of our large postbag could fairly be classified as whinging, with a grouse, a grievance, or a surly and joyless approach to life. The great majority of letter-writers are quite cheerful and often set out to be entertaining.  More typical  than the whingers is  the reverend who submitted this: My wife told me to write to you about the gender imbalance on the letters page. She says she has better things to do with her time.
fields.body:
Guardian letter-writers have been recently accused of whinging - about the dome, Tony Blair, the millennium - anything and everything. Our readers send in about 300 letters a day. How many of them are from whingers? Actually, not such a lot. Only about 20% of the contents of our large postbag could fairly be classified as whinging, with a grouse, a grievance, or a surly and joyless approach to life. The great majority of letter-writers are quite cheerful and often set out to be entertaining. More typical than the whingers is the reverend who submitted this: My wife told me to write to you about the gender imbalance on the letters page. She says she has better things to do with her time.

Nevertheless, the whingers are a minority which is formidable. They make up in passion for what they lack in numbers. I always imagine the composite Guardian writer of whinging letters to live in some grim northern town  Huddersfield, perhaps, or Barnsley  where the rain perpetually sluices down the cobbles and its always early closing at the shops. One woman cabinet minister recently told me that the Labour party of the past had seemed full of angry men. It reminded me of something  for the Guardians whingers too, are, I suspect, mainly male.

All the same, theres a value in whinging. It would be a bad thing if all our readers went around in a Pollyannish cloud of vacuous enthusiasm for this imperfect world. Getting cross is often a prelude to getting off the sofa and doing something to make a difference. As William Blake wrote: Damn braces, bless relaxes. And if youre going to whinge, its certainly a comfort to know that, at the Guardian, youre competing in the Premier division.

fields.headline: Alan Parker - part two
fields.standfirst: The BFI and the British film industry
fields.trailText: Part two of the Alan Parker interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
BN: Moving away from Angela's Ashes, one of your criticisms in the past concerned the British Film Institute and the establishment, and then all of a sudden here's Alan Parker, who slagged off Peter Greenaway and Derek Jarman, becoming the chairman of the board of the BFI, and from that you go on to an even loftier establishment post as the head of the Film Council. How did this all come about, and why?

AP: It sounds terribly cliched but I love film and I'll fight for anybody who wants to make any kind of film and have done and will do. But I think at the time of films like Greenaway's The Draughtsman's Contract there were a lot of us doing different kinds of films, and the people at the BFI were very articulate and very aggressive about their opinions, and there was an argument that that it was that kind of film that was acceptable and we were arguing for a different kind of cinema.

My view is that cinema is quite complicated. There are fancy phrases like pluralism, but in the end film changes from year to year, from decade to decade and people had got stuck in a certain groove, the French philosophy of the Cahiers du Cinema which is that there is only one kind of cinema. The truth is there had never been one kind of cinema ever since cinema began. And all I argued was that we were every bit as good as those other people who were being lauded and praised in regards to the art of cinema. Whether you lot here like what I do or not I don't give a tuppenny toss, but it's as much an art form as anything you would see at the NFT, and I will always argue for that. It's not important that you like it. The way I go about it is no different to Derek Jarman in the way that he went about it or Peter Greenaway goes about doing what he does or Tim Burton in what he does or Martin Scorsese ... we all do it the same way, actually, and the reason why this art form is so rich and so beautiful and so fantastically effective is because it's so very different and everybody has that opportunity. It's all changed now, but 20 years ago that's where the anger came from.

BN: In your time at the BFI what do you think you achieved?

AP: I was only there for a very brief time and I was only the chairman of the board of governors, and I think what was achieved by the BFI was achieved by the people who worked there.

BN: But what were you setting out to do?

AP: When I became chairman, the BFI was a much-unloved organisation and that was sad because they had done, and were doing, and continue to do, extraordinarily important and good work, so it was to get them to be loved again. They were trying to be all things to all people, they were speaking for the British film industry - which they are not. [I set out to] refocus it to its cultural remit and its educational responsibility.

Today I happen to believe that the NFT is suddenly the hippest cinema in the whole of London and that's great. I open my programme for February and I think there's all those things I can't do and I never ever did that before. This wonderful, fantastic notion is hugely important and the fact that we are in a building that is kind of shabby compared to what we do here still has to be fought for. You have the museum next door which has to be fought for to exist again in another form.

BN: You have quite a lot of influence over the funding of films at the Film Council, and you're not entirely happy with the state of the British film industry at the moment, are you? Do you think you can do anything about that at the Council?

AP: We're not really responsible for the film industry and I know that's a kind of drastic thing to say. We have very little amount of money. We're supposed to have £150m for three years. One year's has gone because they took so long to set up the Film Council. We have £50m per year basically, but the gigantic chunk of it is taken up with grant in aid, which is direct money from the government (which is actually responsible for running the most important things ie running the BFI), and that will not change, not while I'm chairman, so the cultural remit is safe.

We're also responsible for the Film Commission, which is inward investment into this country, and I think that that also won't change. The big area, the most contentious area, is that there is public money involved with regards to the lottery, and the lottery money is, in the main, where people like yourself are most critical because we have made a lot of films in the last four years which aren't good enough. That's got to change, and we will change that.

That's what people are looking to us to do but it's such a small part of what we do. In the end all the Film Council is is the means to create an environment where we can create a film industry. You can't create a film industry, an industry has to create itself, and we're only involved with the money that comes from the government and the public sector.

BN: What I respect very much about your film career is that every time there's an Alan Parker film it's a different kind of film. You were never tempted to follow a genre.

AP: It would have been a lot easier to have done that. My first film was Bugsy Malone, which was a pragmatic exercise because every script I had written up to that point came back with a stamp on it saying, 'Parochial, parochial' and nobody wanted to make it, so I thought I'd make an American film. I hadn't been even been to America at that point, it was 1974, so I made a film about American films - it was a gangster film and it was a musical. But having done that it was nothing to do with the films I wanted to make, or who I was, so I thought so I had to do a different film and so I did Midnight Express. That was so controversial that I thought "I don't want to do that anymore" so I was forced to do different things.

I've realised that that was quite important because from a creative point of view it's good to do different things. Sometimes you succeed, sometimes you fail, but you do stretch yourself.

fields.headline: Thuggery, Toxins and Ties
fields.trailText: RED IS THE COLOUR
fields.body:
RED IS THE COLOUR

It's the biggest scandal since Mrs Simpson told her husband she was off to England for a spot of tiffin. David Beckham got himself sent off for kicking Mexican midfielder Jose Milian in Brazil yesterday evening. Today he's been banned from playing in tomorrow's match with Vasco da Gama, fined 2000 Swiss francs (?!?), and the whole world's gone nuts about it. Well the Lord Justice Alex Ferguson has anyway.

"The reaction of the Mexican players got him sent off," Fergie fumed today, while chewing the head off a Martin Samuel replica action figure ('Watch him write! Watch him eat!'). "The referee reacted to the Mexican players and that's disappointing." Ferguson failed to specify which Mexicans the ref reacted to however, the ones standing around complaining or the one flying halfway across the Amazon with his groin in tatters.

Fortunately for Ferg, Ted Beckham's backing him to the hilt. David's grammatically-challenged dad (it's in the genes) insists his son shouldn't have been sent off because "you see a lot worse challenges than last night's". Mark Bosnich also got behind his angry teammate - which is surely the safest place to be. "He didn't do anything," said the fascist-saluting stopper. "All he did was motion to the guy to get up and it was pathetic all round." A comment which also extends to Bozzie's attempt at stopping Necaxa's goal last night.

But according to Max Clifford, PR supremo, all United need to do to calm this particular storm is a good bit of, er, PR. "What they should be doing is having a kickabout on the beach with kids, going to the local hospitals and taking loads of Manchester United posters and shirts. webTitle: Met faces fresh attack on race crime

fields.headline: Met faces fresh attack on race crime
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police will face stinging criticism on Monday in a comprehensive report which has looked at the force's approach to unsolved murder investigations and its performance on racial crime, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police will face stinging criticism on Monday in a comprehensive report which has looked at the force's approach to unsolved murder investigations and its performance on racial crime, the Guardian has learned.

The study by her majesty's inspector of constabulary (HMIC), which was called for by Sir William Macpherson in his report last February into the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry, will criticise Scotland Yard's resourcing inquiries of murders in recent years.

It is also expected to criticise the force over its use of stop and search powers, its race training for officers, and will raise concerns that the race crime initiatives put in place last year have been overhyped and cannot be maintained.

However, Scotland Yard sources said officers would be in "combative" mood when the findings were published. One officer admitted being "irked" by the attitude of HMIC. And there is frustration that the inspectors, David Blakey and Dan Compton, have not given enough credit to the force for the advances made, or the pressures of policing London, which has more murders in a week than some forces face in a year.

Sir Paul Condon, the Met commissioner, refused to talk about the report yesterday, insisting it was embargoed. But he made it clear that criticisms of the force focusing on resources and made with the benefit of hindsight were "not Met specific" and could apply to any force in the country.

He said senior investigating officers had "to be pretty gutsy". Officers not only had to tackle major crimes with dwindling resources, but they also had to deal with an infrastructure of scrutiny.

The report was ordered by the home secretary, Jack Straw, and is the most comprehensive ever undertaken. Its remit was huge and came under two broad headings. First, "a focused examination of unsolved murders and general competencies"; second to assess the force's "performance in the area of investigation of racist crime".

The HMIC report is likely to say that efforts to combat alleged racism have met resistance within the force, and that many rank and file officers have still not accepted the need for fundamental reform. The inspectors were concerned that the Met had exaggerated the progress of race initiatives, though there is praise for the Yard's appointment of race liaison groups and extra resources for the reporting of race-related crime.

In an interview with the Guardian yesterday Sir Paul suggested that the police should offer short term contracts to graduates to help solve recruitment problems.

webTitle: Everton fans top racist 'league of shame'

fields.headline: Everton fans top racist 'league of shame'
fields.standfirst:
Abuse still hurled at black players as clubs step up efforts to eradicate it

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Racial abuse aimed at black or foreign players at football grounds is still rife, according to university researchers who carried out a survey of 33,000 fans.
fields.body:
Racial abuse aimed at black or foreign players at football grounds is still rife, according to university researchers who carried out a survey of 33,000 fans.

Fans from Everton, Rangers and Celtic topped the league table for making the largest number of racist comments heard, the survey found.

Arsenal, Charlton Athletic and Wimbledon won praise for reducing racism through campaigns inside their grounds, but according to Sean Perkins, of the Sir Norman Chester centre for football research at Leicester university, racism overall has remained much the same since the last survey, in the 1996-97 season.

The research covered the four divisions of the English football league plus Rangers and Celtic, but only last year's Premier league teams and Scotland's two leading clubs were ranked in a "league table of shame".

Fans were asked: "Have you witnessed racism aimed at players this season (1998-99)." The percentages of fans who heard racist abuse were: at Everton 38%, at Rangers 36%, at Celtic 33%, at West Ham 32% and at Newcastle by 31%. Best in the ranking were Wimbledon on 11%, Charlton on 12%, Derby on 14%, and Southampton and Arsenal on 16%.

Everton fans became notorious in the 1980s for singling out the black footballer John Barnes, who played for Liverpool, during his first appearance in a Merseyside derby, when scores of bananas were thrown on to the pitch. The club was also one of the last in the country to have a black player in the team.

Other clubs such as Chelsea, Leeds and Rangers became fertile grounds for organised rightwing groups in the 1980s and vociferously abused black players and fans, with the football authorities and police turning a blind eye.

Dr Perkins said that although abuse overall did not appear to have diminished, it did seem to changing. More overt abuse, such as throwing bananas on to the pitch and groups chanting abuse, was rarer, and most examples were confined to individual bigots.

The abuse was not confined to black players: foreign players were also verbally abused.

"The fact that racist abuse in all its forms is being reported so readily could be an encouraging sign that the high profile campaigns make people aware it is going on," he said.

Since the 1980s, however, football has tackled racism. Many clubs have signed up to anti-racist initiatives and tried to attract non-white fans to their grounds. Figures continue to show that few black fans attend matches.

The campaign is led by Kick It Out, which has enlisted the help of leading footballers to highlight racism, organises anti-racist days at the clubs, had Kick It Out banners erected at clubs, and is launching an anti-racist campaign at the end of this month with the support of the England manager, Kevin Keegan.

The government has recently tightened legislation to stamp out racist chanting at grounds. Charlton Athletic said yesterday that leading clubs needed to do more to combat racism in and outside grounds.

Yasin Patel, of Charlton Athletic for Race Equality, set up by the club and the local authority, said: "It's good news for Charlton, but the survey shows that many clubs are merely paying lip service to the problem of racism."

Dr Perkins said the fears of football fans had also changed. "Before the Hillsborough disaster people were scared of being beaten up in grounds or crushed. Now it is more about lifestyle and sensibilities. Women and children, for example, who are now far more numerous in grounds, are offended by swearing, whereas men regard this as part and parcel of being a football fan."

Another new factor, caused by all-seater stadiums, was that fans could no longer move away if a fan next to them was offensive, as they had been able to on the terraces.

fields.headline: Our breasts, ourselves
fields.standfirst: The issues explained: breast cancer screening
fields.trailText: Breast screening using mammography is "unjustified", concludes an article published yesterday in the medical magazine The Lancet*. In an argument which would not have disgraced a bunch of clerics debating the number of angels who could stand on the head of a pin, two Danish medics have trashed a decade's worth of research and added yet more weight to the growing grumbling about the money being spent on early screening for breast cancer.

Peter Gotzche and Ole Olden are not alone in their belief that breast screening programmes are a waste of money. Michael Baum, professor of surgery at the Royal Free, has long been a critic of the programme he helped to set up ten years ago. If, on the basis of this article, more influential doctors climb onto this particular bandwagon, women could well see the screening programme dismantled and the funds diverted elsewhere.

The Danish researchers picked holes in the methodology of virtually every piece of research which shows that screening works. They were particularly scathing about both the research and the effects of screening in Sweden where death rates have barely dropped in the 15 years since screening was introduced. Sadly they didn't take that crucial step back and look at the bigger context.

In Sweden, the five year survival rate (which is how success is measured), currently stands at 80% - the best in Europe. Screening may not have improved the rates but, it could be argued, it has held the death rate steady and lengthened lives. Any future improvement will probably rely on better treatments.

Our own particular situation is very different. Five year survival rates in England and Wales are still only at 67%, but even that is a significant improvement since the introduction of screening, while death rates dropped by 14% over the first ten years of the programme. But these are just statistics - to be chewed over by accountants. The personal implications are even more compelling. Last year the programme detected 3,381 cancers smaller than 15mm. That means smaller than you could feel by examining your own breasts in the bath. Each one of those cancers discovered stood a higher chance of successful and less radical treatment than could have been possible by the time even the most conscientious amongst us might have made it to a doctor.

There are still some cancers which do not respond to treatment, however early we catch them, and treatment is rarely cure (many women die of their cancers years later) but screening gives us knowledge and knowledge gives us the power to make demands for better treatments and more targetted screening. Scientists might be more usefully employed looking for those.

 Angela Phillips is the coeditor of The New Our Bodies Ourselves (British Edition), Penguin.

webTitle: Russia's new boss has an extremely strange history

fields.headline: Russia's new boss has an extremely strange history
fields.trailText: Who would have dreamed only a few months ago that the first new national leader to emerge in the 21st century would be a 47-year-old ex-spy who virtually nobody had heard of before last August? The name of Vladimir Putin does not appear in Leon Aron's just published biography of Boris Yeltsin, because Putin was not even a spear carrier on the Russian political stage when Aron was finishing his book. Yet everything now suggests that Putin is the man who is going to rule Russia for the next decade or even longer.
fields.body:
Who would have dreamed only a few months ago that the first new national leader to emerge in the 21st century would be a 47-year-old ex-spy who virtually nobody had heard of before last August? The name of Vladimir Putin does not appear in Leon Aron's just published biography of Boris Yeltsin, because Putin was not even a spear carrier on the Russian political stage when Aron was finishing his book. Yet everything now suggests that Putin is the man who is going to rule Russia for the next decade or even longer.

Some might argue that it is equally surprising that a superannuated actor should have served two terms as US president, or even that a boy from a Scottish public school should be Britain's Labour prime minister. It is true that there is a sense in which everything in life is surprising. These men, however, like those now contending for presidential office in America, served an apprenticeship within the political class, as did Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev before him. Yeltsin was a politician experienced and especially gifted in seeking and, until recently, in holding popular support, and he was a nationally known Soviet figure long before he became president of Russia.

Putin is a man whose adult years are shadowy. There is no documentation on his time in Germany as an agent, except that his job was probably commercial espionage. His later career, slightly more public, carried on the economic theme for a while, and he has associations with a number of the country's economic reformers. He then became one of the presidential fixers, before returning to the intelligence service as head of the FSB, successor to the KGB.

Putin recently praised not only the FSB and the KGB but, by implication, their predecessors the Cheka, the OGPU and the NKVD, in a speech on the anniversary of the foundation of the Cheka. As the Russian expert Richard Pipes has pointed out, this tribute to the Soviet state's instruments of repression must give pause. It was almost as if Putin was implying that these agencies were the keepers of the flame - organisations that placed the maintenance of Russian power and Russia's defence against its enemies above other considerations. Even given the novel nature of Russia's democracy, Putin's profile as agent-politician is a strange one, which he shares with Yevgeni Primakov, who most seem to think is the only man who could best him in the March elections.

Primakov has much more of a proper public record than Putin, but after defections from his camp this week his chances in March are much diminished. It is truly odd that if there is to be a real contest it will be between two spies, and that other politicians of the new Russia are likely to be either out of it or struggling to rack up a respectable losing vote.

Is it only that Putin, who could have been just one of the many revolving-door figures that Yeltsin popped in and out of the cabinet, happened to be there when a popular war was being waged?

Between the first Chechen war and the second there was a change in the Russian mood. There was a shift from popular hostility toward a shambolic imperial operation to keep the Chechens in a federation to which they did not wish to belong, to popular support for a necessary and more efficient operation to defend Russia against extremists. Chechen banditry played its part in the transition, but so did a broader yearning for strong government in every sphere, not just the military.

It was this sea change which gave Putin his opportunity, and which produced the huge vote at last month's elections for a new political grouping which had no other platform but the war. The success of the Unity party and other factions supporting Putin is what allowed Yeltsin to make his exit. He could do so with reasonable certainty that President Putin would be a sufficiently strong and long-lasting leader to ensure that Yeltsin's allies would have immunity against investigation and prosecution and a continued share in power.

That the Russian intelligence services, in spite of reforms, have continued in some ways unchanged is widely acknowledged. It is a long jump from that to the view that Putin's ascension is the result of a conspiracy that may have involved the deliberate planting of bombs in Russian cities. For this there is no evidence, and the likelihood remains that it was Chechen extremists who were responsible.

Still, Putin's elevation strengthens the security state in Russia. His belief in the important role of the secret agencies, and his support for a large increase in military spending could, if more than rhetorical, partially reverse Yeltsin's policies of reducing the size, costs, and institutional prominence of the armed forces and intelligence services. A full reversal, of course, is beyond the means of the Russian state, but even a limited swing of the pendulum would be a damaging development.

Belief in a strong Russia in a more general sense is hardly to be condemned. Putin's recent comments about economic health, competitiveness, and the need to deal with western countries on more equal economic terms could have come out of the mouth of a Russian reformer of a century ago. Nor are his views on the role of the state necessarily ominous. The shrinkage of the central government's real capacity to influence events, while its theoretical capacity to do so was supposedly enhanced by new laws and decrees, was a marked feature of both Gorbachev's and Yeltsin's rule.

A president who had a substantial body of support in the Duma, as Putin would have, if successful in March, could make serious inroads into the problems of overmighty corporations, unresponsive provincial governments, and obstinate bureaucracies. That same president, having secured office, could also make unpopular decisions about Chechnya, building on military victory to open the road to transitional autonomy and then independence as long as there were proper guarantees of Russian security.

"Could" is the word. The leadership of Russia has been placed within Putin's grasp before Russians, or anybody else, have had a chance to measure his real capacity as a politician or to judge his programme - if, beyond the war, he has one. "The attributes of the traditional Russian state - authoritarianism, imperialism, militarism, xenophobia - are far from extinguished," Aron writes in his book. "Yet more and higher hedges have been erected against their recurrence under Yeltsin... than at any other time in Russian history."

It would be irony indeed if Boris Yeltsin were to prove to have undermined that achievement by the manner of his going. Whether he has done so is a question to which only Vladimir Putin may have the answer.

 Boris Yeltsin by Leon Aron is published by HarperCollins.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Chloe lunettes
fields.trailText: Last summer, the fashion police (sunglasses division) decreed that you weren't anyone unless you owned a pair of Chloe Aviators - bad luck for most of us, as they were so hard to come by that even Posh couldn't get her hands on a pair. This year, Ms McCartney has decided to tempt us once again by creating sunglasses that will have even the biggest Ray-Ban stalwart purring at the thought of them:sultry little numbers with a tiger on each lens. Made by Marcolin, the wraparound shades cost £115 and come in gold or silver. We know it's January but we're telling you now so you can get your name down on the list in time for summer. These are desperate times and desperate measures are called for.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  UDIs
fields.trailText: Oh dear. One week after the event and I'm still sporting a scratched neck (drunken friend with long nails grabbing me), a bruised arm (drunken stranger with full pint nudging me) and a swollen knee (nobody's fault but my own: I fell over). UDIs or Unidentified Drinking Injuries - acquired on that fateful New Year's Eve after drinking more than was seemly and acquiring all the hand-to-eye co-ordination of an ox in a hemp field - have hit record highs this week. Got a touch of the January blues? Meet your friends in the pub to compare war wounds: you'll soon be laughing at how hilarious it was when X bumped into a wall in pursuit of his girlfriend, who had just snogged a man she was convinced was Brad Pitt. Legend has it we're supposed to bounce back into the office looking healthy and rested after the festive break, but the sad truth is The Biggest Night Out Ever In The History Of The World has left most of us looking more bashed-up than ever. The most puzzling UDI we've heard of is a huge purple lovebite that appeared on one friend's neck the morning after, even though she swears she remained chaste the night before. This year, keep it tidy - and wear a polo-neck until your "injuries" fade.
