fields.headline: Always and forever
fields.standfirst: New year, new wardrobe. But what to buy?  Susannah Barron explains why classics are a girl's best friend
fields.trailText: It's the most overused word in the fashion vocabulary and never more so than at this time of year. Come the January sales, what are we told to look out for? Classics. Ignore the high-fashion left-overs, such as last season's silver mules, say the experts, and concentrate on classics. You can't go wrong.
fields.body:
It's the most overused word in the fashion vocabulary and never more so than at this time of year. Come the January sales, what are we told to look out for? Classics. Ignore the high-fashion left-overs, such as last season's silver mules, say the experts, and concentrate on classics. You can't go wrong.

Except you can. What exactly constitutes a classic these days? The term is used to describe everything from the Hermès Kelly bag (launched in 1935) to the Fendi baguette (launched, um, a couple of years ago, but that's OK because it's an instant classic). It is used as a euphemism for not-very-fashionable; it is also, paradoxically, the height of fashion. Prada's enthusiastically received spring collection has the kind of smart shoes, pencil skirts and co-ordinating scarves beloved of bourgeois ladies that positively scream classic.

Are these the safe option, then? Well, no. There is a very fine line between classic and dowdy. Nothing, for example, is as classic as a smart navy blazer, but in 1999, the year of the embroidered cardigan, nothing could have been less fashionable. Invest in a Burberry mac, on the other hand, and you will be the epitome of style this spring.

Our concept of what is classic alters over time and even something very basic, such as a plain white shirt, has to metamorphose. British designer Margaret Howell, who has been making quietly quirky classics since 1976, includes a white shirt in every womenswear collection, but it's never the same shirt. She now has an archive of over 40 different designs. "I love classic pieces," she says, "but you have to alter them to keep them interesting."

Plain cashmere sweaters are also cited as can't-go-wrong classics but these, too, have evolved. "You do have to adjust them for shape and tiny details," says Doreen Keen, head of design for Scottish knitwear company Pringle. Only a few years ago, the classic Pringle sweater was a bloused affair that now looks frumpy; these days, it's fitted closer to the body and finer in texture, thanks to new yarns.

What, then, should we be looking for when we trawl the sales? "Something comfortable that fits into your wardrobe and you know you'll wear constantly," Keen says. Clued-up shoppers have always known where to get such pieces: cardigans from Agnès b, slip dresses from Ghost, trousers from Joseph, scarves from Burberry, sweaters from John Smedley, coats (if you can afford them) from MaxMara. Increasingly, however, designers are making it simple for us to recognise these pieces, by branding them differently from their more trend-led, seasonal lines. There is Joseph Essentials, the look-no-further range based around his famously well-fitting trousers and simple Ts. Autumn/winter saw the debut of Emporio Armani Easy Pieces and 'S MaxMara, offering the kind of basic, sporty pieces - quilted nylon coats, machine-washable wool sweaters - the company no doubt hopes you can't live without.

Marketed as "essentials", "basics" or "staples", these ranges will do everything you'd want a classic to do: they transcend the seasons and look smart and modern without being too high-fashion. They won't give you a top-to-toe look but are designed to be worn with more trendy or quirky pieces. "It's something you can keep wearing," says Giorgio Giudotti, MaxMara's art director, about 'S MaxMara. "These are very simple but luxurious pieces that have no season." Would he like to see a woman still wearing them in, say, five years' time? "Maybe with a new pair of shoes or a new bag."

While sniffier souls might find such ranges faintly patronising, there is certainly a demand for them. Pollyanna, the designer emporium that brought to Yorkshire the likes of Issey Miyake and Comme des Garçons, has been producing its own range of basics, such as utterly simple Lycra dresses, for the past four years. "It's one of our bestselling ranges," says Pollyanna's Rita Britton, who developed the line to fill a gap in her own wardrobe. "There's hardly a thing that goes into the sale."

For something to be defined as truly classic, of course, it has to prove its staying power. As Margaret Howell says: "Some things come back and have an appeal in a new era. They are the real classics."

But while we don't know whether Emporio Armani's Easy Pieces or 'S MaxMara's hooded jackets will still be with us in 20 years' time, maybe that doesn't matter. They're simple, modern and, as Giorgio Giudotti puts it, "slick": you can sling them on in the morning without worrying too much about how they look and they are simple enough to be worn for several seasons without becoming dated. That's classic enough for most of us.

They are the real classics." But while we don't know whether Emporio Armani's Easy Pieces or 'S MaxMara's hooded jackets will still be with us in 20 years' time, maybe that doesn't matter. They're simple, modern and, as Giorgio Giudotti puts it, "slick": you can sling them on in the morning without worrying too much about how they look and they are simple enough to be worn for several seasons without becoming dated. That's classic enough for most of us.

webTitle: Return of the cane 'completely off the agenda'

fields.headline: Return of the cane 'completely off the agenda'
fields.standfirst: Should we spare the rod? Tell us what you think on the Education Unlimited talkboards. Registering to post a message is quick and simple.
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders today dismissed a call for the return of the cane to schools and said parents who wanted it must share the blame for a decline in discipline.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders today dismissed a call for the return of the cane to schools and said parents who wanted it must share the blame for a decline in discipline.

Fifty-one percent of parents back the re-introduction of corporal punishment in a new poll, and two-thirds of those questioned believed school discipline had worsened over the past 10 years.

The findings follow a warning by teachers' leaders that government moves to reduce exclusions from schools were compromising their ability to maintain good order. Corporal punishment was outlawed 14 years ago in state schools and last year in the private sector.

Today's survey of 1,000 parents by pollsters FDS International for The Times Educational Supplement showed that parents held definite views on corporal punishment. Only 2% had no opinion and 47% favoured a continued ban.

Teachers' leaders said there was no realistic chance of its re-introduction. David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "Parents might want a return to the cane but it won't happen. It would be quite contrary to the wishes of every head and teacher in the country and it would breach the European Convention on Human Rights. It would put us in jeopardy in European law.

"I'm not surprised parents identify bad behaviour in schools as a problem. But schools can only operate within the communities they serve. Indiscipline often results from factors outside the school. A lot of the blame lies not with teachers but with parents."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said corporal punishment was "completely off the agenda".

"It didn't work when we had it," he said. "When I started work as a head teacher, I looked at the punishment book in the school and the same pupils' names cropped up again and again. That's proof that caning them didn't change their behaviour."

"The discipline problem is a comment on society... Children have become less biddable and keeping good discipline in schools has become much harder for teachers."

Part of the reason was a shift in the balance of rights and responsibilities, he said.

"For many years, the emphasis has been on the responsibilities of schools and the rights of parents and children. We look to the government to redress that balance."

Elsewhere in the poll, parents identify education funding as another key concern, with 83% saying they do not think the government is spending enough - despite its much-vaunted £19 billion investment.

Seven out of 10 parents say they would be prepared to see income tax increased to fund improvements in schools. Nearly half say they think education standards have improved over the past 10 years, but the present government takes little credit. Only two out of 10 said they thought standards had improved since the general election, with 62% believing they had stayed the same.

Asked what they thought were the biggest problems facing schools at the start of the new millennium, 30% said lack of resources and 24% disruptive pupils.

Just under one in 10 cited teacher shortages, 7% poor teaching, 7% overcrowding in schools and 2% lack of parental support. More than half thought standards were "fairly good" and 25% "very good".

By contrast, almost half of parents thought standards at their own children's school were "very good".

fields.standfirst: Sleepy Hollow | Angela's Ashes | Time Regained | The End of the Affair
fields.trailText: The next month sees a slew of literary adaptations, the first and weirdest being Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, which plays with the original plot but perfectly catches the otherworldly spirit of what Burton calls "one of the few American horror stories", Washington Irving's The Legend of Sleepy Hollow (read the full text).
fields.body:
The next month sees a slew of literary adaptations, the first and weirdest being Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, which plays with the original plot but perfectly catches the otherworldly spirit of what Burton calls "one of the few American horror stories", Washington Irving's The Legend of Sleepy Hollow (read the full text).

Angela's Ashes is a rich adaptation of Frank McCourt's stirring memoir of childhood poverty in Ireland. Take a tour of McCourt's Limerick, watch a clip of Frank McCourt talking about the adaptation at Film Unlimited, or read a digest of his sequel, 'Tis, in 400 words.

Presumptions of Proust's unfilmability are proved wrong by Raul Ruiz's inventive Time Regained, based on the final volume Remembrance of Things Past, out now; while Neil Jordan's finely balanced adaptation of Graham Greene's The End of the Affair is released on February 4.

fields.headline: Blunkett outlines vision for over 11s
fields.standfirst:
Pupils to get education plans suited to their skills and interests
David Blunkett's Speech at the North of England Education Conference
fields.trailText: The government yesterday published a blueprint for a hi-tech revolution in secondary schools over the next 10 years to provide every pupil with a customised learning plan and keep all young people in education or training until the age of 19.
fields.body:
The government yesterday published a blueprint for a hi-tech revolution in secondary schools over the next 10 years to provide every pupil with a customised learning plan and keep all young people in education or training until the age of 19.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, unveiled promises in Labour's next election manifesto that will extend the campaign to raise education standards from primary schools to new local networks of comprehensives.

He said the government was preparing to move on "from mere improvement of the existing system to genuine transformation".

Opportunities for every child would no longer depend solely on the school that they happened to attend.

The comprehensive system "has not delivered what its advocates hoped for, never mind what we require for the 21st century". But the government's plans for a network of non-selective community schools would show "there are no limits to what can be achieved in the state sector".

Each pupil would get an "individual education plan" to suit their abilities and interests. They would get the opportunity to study at more than one school, using specialist facilities at neighbouring comprehensives.

The deployment of information technology, harnessed at city learning centres, would mean pupils would not have to be bussed between lessons.

"This is a new approach which defines the education service as a resource to be drawn on wherever and whenever a young person needs to do so," he said in a pamphlet published to coincide with his address to the north of England education conference in Wigan.

The first stages of the plan are being tested in networks of comprehensives in six conurbations in the government's Excellence in Cities programme. Mr Blunkett said he wanted to spread that throughout England.

In the secondary school of the future, pupils would get the opportunity to follow their enthusiasms.

Reform would start with better transfer of information about every child's capabilities as they moved from primary to secondary education. Those struggling with reading, writing and arithmetic would get extra help at summer schools. The government's strategy for improving teaching of literacy and numeracy in primaries would be extended into the first year of secondary school. A new national test at 12 would establish how well this was working.

Every secondary would be set targets for improving performance in national tests at 14 in English, maths and science. Some would opt for workplace learning. Others could choose from a wide variety of languages, ancient and modern; the full range of the arts and sciences; and early access to university courses.

There would be mentoring schemes to raise the aspirations of young people, summer schools, more international exchanges and information technology to provide tailor-made programmes of study for each individual.

At a press conference, Mr Blunkett forecast that the work of secondary teachers would change radically. "They are going to take on the role of learning managers with many more people assisting them, using technology to tailor the work to pupils and using out of school and home-based learning as well as school."

He admitted to the conference that his department was "a little centralist and occasionally a bit dictatorial" in its imposition of literacy and numeracy strategies on primary schools, now being extended to secondaries.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said Mr Blunkett's plans were "a complete revolution in how we deliver education in the 21st century. In 10 years every secondary will be a community school opening for an extended day from 8am to 10pm. They will be working for the community as a whole and not just for their own students."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "Mr Blunkett's vision will require radical change in the exam system at 16 and 18. GCSEs as they exist at the moment will disappear and students will build a portfolio of qualifications from modular courses across a wide range of learning situations.

"Mr Blunkett's speech is a significant turning point. He will need courage not to back away from inevitable criticism from traditionalists who think the only legitimate exams are the ones they did at school."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said Mr Blunkett failed to ask secondary teachers to become partners in his revolution or show that he thought they had views worth considering.

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said it was a courageous speech, but the proposals were not thought out. "He had more vision than focus," he added.

Main points

 Summer schools for 11-year-olds to get slow learners ready for secondary school and develop the most talented.

 A new national test of 12-year-olds in English and maths to gauge success of teaching strategy.

 All secondaries to have challenging targets in tests at 14 in English, maths and science.

 Individual learning plans to match abilities and interests of all secondary pupils.

 Lessons at neighbouring schools specialising in pupils' chosen subjects.

 All young people to have obligation to stay in education or training until 19.

 Teachers to become "learning managers" supported by assistants and information technology.

webTitle: Embattled Dobson attacks 'play now, pay later' Livingstone

fields.headline: Embattled Dobson attacks 'play now, pay later' Livingstone
fields.standfirst: With Labour's bitter mayoral contest to be decided within weeks, Dobson ups  his campaign tempo
fields.trailText: With Labour's bitter mayoral contest to be decided within weeks, Dobson ups  his campaign tempo
fields.body:
The Labour leadership's favoured candidate for mayor of London, Frank Dobson, relaunched his mayoral campaign today, announcing a raft of new policies and attacking "play now, pay later" Ken Livingstone.

The embattled former health secretary's new offensive comes in the wake of a massive boost for Mr Livingstone's campaign after he secured 85.8% of the vote in a Transport and General Workers Union ballot - compared to Mr Dobson's 6.9%.

He insisted he would do better in other union contests and said it was time for all the candidates to set aside issues about personalities and "get down to brass tacks".

With his deputy, former journalist Trevor Phillips, Mr Dobson set out five key pledges which they said would improve Londoners' lives.

 A named police officer would be assigned to every Londoner to help tackle crime;

 A medical officer of health would be appointed for the city to reduce health inequalities;

 Low-cost homes would be developed for key workers, such as nurses and teachers;

 Free bus passes would be given to every young person under the age of 18;

 And in order to improve education and leisure private sector partnerships would help ensure that four in five London households get internet access.

Mr Dobson said: "Ken [Livingstone] has nothing to say on these issues.

"He prefers to argue about process and doesn't want anyone to look closely at what he stands for."

The MP for Holborn and St Pancras attacked Mr Livingstone's plans to revitalise London's creaking transport system, claiming his proposals for the tube would cost up to £3 billion more than current plans.

He also criticised Mr Livingstone's plans for a flat rate £100 tax on car owners in central London, saying it amounted to a "poll tax on wheels".

"In total, if Ken had his way, he would cost Londoners an extra £18 billion - that is £6,100 for every London household in his first term as mayor.

"The truth is that with Ken Livingstone you play now, but pay later."

But Mr Dobson ran in trouble when he remarked he found it funny to watch "toffee-nosed" people queuing for the Millennium Dome.

Expressing his amusement at the chaotic scenes of visitors clamouring to get into the Greenwich attraction during an interview about how he spent New Year's Eve, Mr Dobson told News Direct: "It was a bit of a laugh really, some of those toffee-nosed people having to queue."

Shadow minister for London Bernard Jenkin called for Mr Dobson to make "an immediate apology" for his "crass comments" which were "a massive insult to ordinary people visiting the Dome."

"Many of those having to queue were not VIPs but had been invited because of their dedication to voluntary or charity work," Mr Jenkin said.

 After his good result in the TGWU ballot, Ken Livingstone has been made 2/5 favourite by William Hill to win the race for Mayor of London.

It has lengthened Frank Dobson's odds from 2/1 to 11/4 second favourite and also offers 7/1 Steve Norris, 16/1 Glenda Jackson, 100/1 Andrew Boff and Susan Kramer.

fields.headline: Doom and the Dome
fields.standfirst: The millennium has given the British a much-appreciated opportunity to moan
fields.trailText: A most entertaining national divide is opening up over the Millennium Dome.   There are those who whinge about it, and there are others who whinge about   the whingers. (There is a third large category of folk who don't give a   tinker's toss either way, but let's not cloud the issue).
fields.body:
A most entertaining national divide is opening up over the Millennium Dome. There are those who whinge about it, and there are others who whinge about the whingers. (There is a third large category of folk who don't give a tinker's toss either way, but let's not cloud the issue).

The first set of whingers, the negative ones, are a varied bunch. Some don't like the Dome because it is naff, and others don't like it because it isn't naff enough. They say, on the one hand, that it is shallow and tawdry and lacks the intellectual stimulus you would expect from, say, reading a copy of Hello! Another camp, firmly based in the design and street-cred industries, says it is all too predictable and middle-class. Specific complaints range from long queues - unlikely to be a lasting problem according to reports of ticket sales - to crappy food.

Now queuing and eating crud are both venerable features of the British Way of Life, and it might be argued that they deserve to be honoured in our millennium celebrations. But the anti-whingeing tendency, the ones who whinge about the whingers, are taking a more positive tack. They point out that most people who go to the Dome - at least 70% according to straw polls - are actually thrilled with it. They love the giant space, the whirling acrobats, the flashing lights, and no doubt the Yookay Yukkiburgers too.

What unites both camps is their quintessentially British love of a good grizzle. It is, in many ways, what we are best at, and the Dome, bless it, has given us a splendid opportunity to hone our moaning abilities. It's been going on since plans were first unveiled, to a grumbling chorus of complaint. Waste of money. It'll never be finished on time. Why should bleedin' London get everything? They'll be talking about a giant ferris wheel next, you mark my words.

Now we have found a new target for our moaning self-pity: the moaners themselves. Why do we always knock ourselves so? Why can't we celebrate for once? Why do we have to accentuate the negative? Why do we insist on giving foreigners such a miserable impression?

This last line of argument, threading its way through scores of chat-shows and phone-ins, is the most revealing. It is a truism that Britain - or more correctly, England - lacks national confidence and self-esteem. We long to be loved, or at least praised, but we don't care to be thought pushy or boastful. Also, we have an ingrained, entirely healthy contempt for those who govern us, and who attempt to amuse us from time to time with projects like the Dome. We consider it our solemn duty to knock and nit-pick anything handed down by authority, and the Greenwich marquee is in every sense too big a target to miss.

Are you really all whingers?
Read a selection from the Guardian's postbag on this subject.

Gone aloft

The death of Patrick O'Brian in Dublin has taken from the world a great storyteller, and a considerable enigma. In his 85 years he produced 33 books, including distinguished biographies of Pablo Picasso and his own great hero, the 18th century naturalist Joseph Banks. But he will be forever remembered, wherever good reads are appreciated, for his 20-volume sequence of Napoleonic maritime novels featuring Captain Jack Aubrey and his dear friend, surgeon and spy Stephen Maturin.

The latter is one of the most complex characters in popular fiction, and O'Brian was one of the most complex authors. His real name was Richard Patrick Russ, and he was born in Buckinghamshire. Of German extraction, he lived much of his life in the south of France, but preferred to project himself as an Irishman - like Maturin. He never denied, or confirmed, speculation that he was deeply involved in intelligence operations during the second world war.

Those who have not read any of the Aubrey-Maturin series are deeply to be envied, for they have a marvellous treat in store. For the rest of us, the passing of O'Brian is a good excuse to honour his memory by starting all over again, with Master and Commander, and work through to last year's Blue at the Mizzen. And all the while we will be willing ourselves to read slowly, to prolong the sheer pleasure of it.

fields.headline: What is the north-south divide?
fields.standfirst: Guardian regional affairs correspondent Peter Hetherington explains the background to the debate
fields.trailText: Guardian regional affairs correspondent Peter Hetherington (left) explains the background to the debate
fields.body:
Regional sensitivities in Britain were further inflamed this week when Bank of England governor Eddie George stepped into the row over the north-south divide by signalling that fresh interest rate rises are on the way.

This has become familiar territory for the bluff governor, who implied last year that job losses in the north were an acceptable price to pay in the battle against inflation.

But to most people outside London and the overheating south east - manufacturers and home owners alike - the Bank's policy, determined by its independent monetary policy committee, is so narrowly focused that it has only one clear objective. This is geared to curbing house price inflation, in a region dominated by service industries, with little or no unemployment and a labour shortage, at the expense of the north dependent on manufacturing - and hence vulnerable to higher interest rates - where there is a jobs shortage.

Under Labour, voters in the northern regions (north east, Yorkshire and Humberside, north west) expected a Blair government to create more of a level economic playing field - particularly since those regions, heartland of old Labour, sustained the party during the bad times.

But for New Labour, the south is equally important because its huge majority is dependent on votes in 'middle England'. Indeed, its aspirations - lowish taxes, combined with reasonable public services - form the credo of Blairism.

The north, sure, has many islands of prosperity and vibrant cities. But, on any regional wealth indicator, it is well below the European average as measured by GDP per head - while the south is well above it.

Consequently, Labour MPs, councillors and activists are restless. Some want more regional autonomy so that political decisions can be taken closer to home. Others certainly want more Government money pumped into the north to compensate for unrelenting growth in the south. This has fuelled a debate, almost as old as the political process itself, called the north-south divide.

Until recently, it was dismissed by ministers as an irrelevance. After the election they had created eight regional development agencies (RDAs), apparently with the aim of ironing out regional divisions, so why bother? But the RDAs are mere shadows of the grand regional design presented by John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, before the last election. They are poorly funded.

So recently, Mr Blair was forced to acknowledge the great divide. He set up an inquiry to discover if it was an over-simplification. It came as no surprise when it gave the prime minister what he wanted. This allowed the PM to argue that while the north had its problems, the south also had them by the bucketload - from sink estates to poverty and (in parts of London, at least) heavy unemployment. But the debate will not go away. Backbenchers remain restless.

fields.headline: Aitken released from jail
fields.standfirst: Former cabinet minister to be electronically tagged at home
fields.trailText: Former cabinet minister Jonathan Aitken was released from prison today after serving seven months of his 18-month sentence for perjury and perverting the course of justice.
fields.body:
Former cabinet minister Jonathan Aitken was released from prison today after serving seven months of his 18-month sentence for perjury and perverting the course of justice.

Aitken, 57, who was once one of the most powerful men in Britain as chief secretary to the treasury, was carrying his belongings in a black plastic bag as he emerged from Elmley prison on the Isle of Sheppey, Kent, shortly after 8am.

Wearing a dark blue sweatshirt and jeans, Aitken, who will have to wear an electronic tag on his ankle for two months, shook hands with the driver of a waiting saloon before climbing in and being driven away.

Aitken was the only inmate to emerge from the category C prison when the jail's large brown gate rolled open.

As he walked to the waiting Renault Laguna, Aitken ignored questions from reporters and requests to pose for photographs. Many journalists had been camped outside the jail all night.

Aitken did not glance backwards as he got into the car. Minutes after his release, his mother Lady Aitken called for the media to leave her son alone now he has served his sentence.

"It is crazy. I have been listening to my radio this morning and there is important international news yet every few minutes there is something about Jonathan. I think you have all gone mad," she said. "He is out of jail now. For goodness' sake leave him alone."

The former Tory MP will spend a further two months on a 7pm to 7am curfew, monitored by electronic tagging equipment. He will be met later today at his home by officials from the tagging company, who will fit the equipment, which is linked to the phone line and will alert security staff if Aitken leaves his house during curfew hours.

His release comes after he was allowed home at Christmas for a six-day break.

Aitken was sentenced last June at the Old Bailey in London after evidence of his perjury caused a libel action against the Guardian newspaper to collapse.

He was told by Mr Justice Scott Baker he could expect to serve nine months of his 18 month sentence. He began his sentence in Standford Hill open prison, also on the Isle of Sheppey, but was moved after his return from the Christmas break after prison wardens uncovered a plot by other inmates to drug, strip and take compromising pictures of Aitken.

Three prisoners at Standford Hill jail are thought to have hatched a plan to drug him with the date-rape drug Rohypnol and photograph him with another nude male inmate.

fields.headline: Gone aloft
fields.trailText: The death of Patrick O'Brian in Dublin has taken from the world a great storyteller, and a considerable enigma. In his 85 years he produced 33 books, including distinguished biographies of Pablo Picasso and his own great hero, the 18th-century naturalist Joseph Banks. But he will be forever remembered, wherever goood reads are appreciated, for his 20-volume sequence of Napoleonic maritime novels featuring Captain Jack Aubrey and his dear friend, surgeon and spy Stephen Maturin.

fields.headline: Close encounters
fields.standfirst:
Only one man stands between the last survivors of one of the Amazon's Stone Age tribes and extinction at the hands of settlers - the same man who first 'discovered' them four years ago. Alex Bellos travels upriver with Brazil's most famous Indian tracker, Sydney Possuelo

Survival International
fields.trailText: Only one man stands between the last survivors of one of the Amazon's Stone Age tribes and extinction at the hands of settlers - the same man who first 'discovered' them four years ago.  Alex Bellos  travels upriver with Brazil's most famous Indian tracker, Sydney Possuelo.
fields.body:
For the loggers and rubber-tappers of the Javari Valley, the Korubo were a constant, hidden threat. Since records began, in 1928, at least 50 people had met their deaths - some by arrows, some clubbed, many with the flesh ripped from their bones - at the hands of the "undiscovered" Stone Age tribe. But the Brazilian settlers were not the only victims. If anything, they provoked the slaughter. In the same period, more than 150 Korubos were gunned down as "civilised" man plundered the rainforest for its natural riches.

It was, essentially, a state of war between the new and the old inhabitants of the jungle, a violent struggle that has continued sporadically all over the Amazon basin since the first Europeans arrived in South America five centuries ago. Many tribes have been wiped out. The indigenous population has collapsed from between 3m and 5m to 300,000.

The Korubo owe their survival to their awe-inspiring violence and their inaccessible home in the thick rainforest frontier between Brazil and Peru. And possibly to Sydney Possuelo. Whenever there are reports of lost or uncontacted tribes - often sparked by the discovery of the dismembered corpse of a pioneer - Possuelo gets a call. He is Brazil's most famous Indian tracker. But unlike the majority of the white men who have stalked tribes, he hunts them down to save them.

Aged 59, Possuelo has spent four decades working in the Amazon to protect its indigenous people. He is one of the few remaining sertanistas, the swashbuckling Brazilian term for those who immerse themselves in the backlands' natural heritage. With his untamed black beard, piercing eyes and ripped khakis, he looks every inch the jungle explorer.

In 1996, Possuelo decided to try to contact the Korubo. With a team that included Indians from nearby tribes, he made several expeditions, through the virgin rainforest, looking for the footprints and broken branches that would indicate the presence of human life. On the third trip he found a clearing and a hut of sticks and leaves. "The tension was enormous. No one knew what was going to happen. All previous attempts at getting close had always resulted in death," says Possuelo. "The big problem was that we didn't know how many of them there were. They could have circled us and killed us all."

The Indians didn't appear. Possuelo left presents - knives, pans, an axe - and then left. First contact was only made on a following sortie, after his team had been camped by the Indians' clearing for a week.

The Korubo were inevitably suspicious; their knowledge of the white settler was as a gun-toting aggressor. However, they seemed intrigued by the uncharacteristic behaviour of their visitors. Possuelo's group were leaving presents and singing Brazilian folk songs loudly, so as to "announce their arrival with good intentions".

The Indians gradually appeared from behind the trees. First came a man, later identified as Shamabo, naked but for a piece of string tied round his waist to hold up his penis, covered in the red paint derived from urucu fruit, and holding a club. A second man arrived, then a woman. One Korubo took someone's hat and put it on. Another tugged at someone's necklace. Then they moved to the base camp, rifled through the food and took the packets of cheese crackers. Indians from the Matis tribe brought along by Possuelo managed to communicate; the languages turned out to be similar. The tribe was primitive, that was obvious. There were just 16 members left.

In Possuelo's career at the National Indian Foundation (Funai) - the governmental branch responsible for Brazil's native population - Possuelo has tracked down seven new tribes, most recently the Korubo. Academics believe the Amazon holds the largest number of "lost" tribes of any equatorial area, sheltering more than 20.

Possuelo runs Funai's Department for Isolated Indians, which he founded a decade ago. "We started to collate information. There were 113 possible places," he says. Since then his team has proved the existence of "lost tribes" in 22 places and eliminated the possibility in 63 cases leaving 28 sites under investigation.

These tribes live as they have for tens of thousands of years. They make fire by rubbing sticks together. They hunt with spear, arrow and blowpipe. They have no written language or system of counting beyond the first few digits. But something has happened to them in the past few centuries. According to Possuelo, each tribe has either seen or heard of confrontation due to the white invasion. They are all aware of an outside threat. We may not yet have discovered them, but they have discovered us.

The first coherent Brazilian policy towards Indians emerged at the beginning of the century through the work of Candido Rondon, an army marshal who felt he should contact Indians for their own good. But the Indians died, and not just through murder, enslavement and poverty. "What really killed them were the viruses we carry," says Possuelo. "You could turn up one day and meet 200 Indians, and when you went back a week later only four were still alive."

A pugnacious idealist, Possuelo has turned Indian policy on its head. His idea was to stop contact. Now, when a group of isolated Indians is located, they are left alone. Possuelo's job is to demarcate the land around them to stop anyone entering. He is both the only hope of finding out about the last tribes in the wild and the biggest obstacle to finding out more about them.

The Korubo needed to be contacted for their survival. In the mid-90s, two whites were killed and there were reports of a massacre of 10 Indians. "I think that if we didn't make contact, all the Indians would have died because of the settlers," says Possuelo. "Now you see the Korubo playing by the banks of the river in peace."

A hundred miles up a tributary of the Amazon from the triple frontier of Brazil, Peru and Colombia, where the river bobs with pink freshwater dolphins, a floating house marks the entrance to the Javari Valley. The valley is the size of Portugal and home to five contacted and about five isolated groups of Indians, including the Korubo. The house is also Possuelo's "contact front", the base he uses to protect the land from outsiders and to launch expeditions. It is has medical supplies and a 10-metre radio antenna (paid for by the European Union).

From the house, it is an hour by motor boat to the village. The Korubo are waiting at the side of the river, smiling and shouting in high-pitched, syncopated sentences. The adults are no more than five feet tall, stocky, and with a crescent of hair shaved from the crown. We disembark and they lead us to a clearing where there is a large straw hut and planted corn.

Possuelo, hyperactive and quick-tempered in his own environment, becomes a model of patience and calm. The Indians sit next to him, laughing with him. The chief, Shishu, puts his arm around him for about half an hour. Shishu makes us tea by grating a vine over a club encrusted with monkey-teeth, and then wetting and squeezing the result. A woman pulls down a stalk of maize, removes two corncobs, retires to the hut and emerges with them cooked. We are also offered the remains of a sloth. One man pulls up my shirt to see if I have breasts and looks down the trousers of Possuelo's long-haired teenage son. Several Indians show us lead shot embedded in their skin from the years of strife.

The tribe appears happy and playful. They show no aggression. But some of the Indians are coughing, an indication that they are susceptible to germs visitors bring. Also, they are using the pans, axe and knives they were given, alien technology which undermines traditional means of cutting and cooking. I feel uneasy that our appearance, even in good faith, is somehow helping to destroy a fragile culture. How can they reconcile, for example, seeing themselves on my video camera, when the only time they have ever seen their own faces before is a dim reflection in the murky brown water of the Amazon?

Using the Matis as interpreters, Possuelo's team has tried to discover some Korubo history. It appears that they were part of a larger group of as many as 100, but they splintered off a few years ago. "There was an argument over a woman," says Possuelo.

He is also a type threatened with extinction. He is fighting on all fronts - against the elements (he has had malaria 36 times), against the local white population ("People here want to kill us. Before we got here they used the area like their own back yard. It was full of loggers, rubber tappers and hunters. Now all that has stopped.") and against dwindling funds (he has a team of 16, poorly paid, spread out in an area the size of western Europe). Some of his "contact fronts" are unmanned, meaning that loggers are able to get to the indigenous areas unchecked.

Possuelo is also in danger of being killed by the very people he is trying to protect. In 1997, the Korubo unexpectedly clubbed one of his colleagues to death. Last year a team of his men was besieged and terrorised deep in the jungle area of Acre by the tribe whose habits they were trying to research. "Sydney has taken on one of the most difficult areas of work with Indians," says Orlando Villas-Boas, 86, Brazil's most famous sertanista . "These Indians are in violent conflict with white man. They are very aggressive. Sydney has without question made great progress."

Possuelo is working for what he believes is best for the isolated Indian population. But through contact, Indian priorities change. Often, they begin to want more contact with the white man. In one case, a whole tribe hailed a bus on a nearby road, and demanded to be taken to the nearest town. "They might want to go to the towns, but what opportunities would they have there? When I say keep them isolated, I say this to win time. Time for us. Time doesn't change them. Time changes us. I hope our society will become a little bit more humane. If we continue to be imperialist, predatory then it is possible that in 30 years there won't be any isolated Indians left. I am not worried about morality. My work is about human rights. They have a right to be Indians. We should respect that."

In one case, a whole tribe hailed a bus on a nearby road, and demanded to be taken to the nearest town. "They might want to go to the towns, but what opportunities would they have there? When I say keep them isolated, I say this to win time. Time for us. Time doesn't change them. Time changes us. I hope our society will become a little bit more humane. If we continue to be imperialist, predatory then it is possible that in 30 years there won't be any isolated Indians left. I am not worried about morality. My work is about human rights. They have a right to be Indians. We should respect that."

fields.headline: Alan Parker - part three
fields.standfirst: Questions from the audience: The issue of poverty today | The British film industry | Working with young actors | The British screenwriting industry | The most memorable moment filming Angela's Ashes
fields.trailText: Part three of the Alan Parker interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
Question 1: Angela's Ashes deals with the subject of poverty. How important is the issue of poverty today for you?

AP: Apparently there are 15m people in this country whose families are living below the minimum wage. One in four kids in California live in poverty. It's absolutely a problem of today, the thing is if you make a film that is relevant right now we find it hard to take, but when you set it in a period that's gone by people find that a little more acceptable. I remember that when I did Mississippi Burning that opened up a controversy, and suddenly I wasn't answering questions relevant to Mississippi Burning and the black civil rights movement in the 60s, I was talking about racism in the US now. Every film you do, even if it is set in the past, still has to have its echoes and resonances for now, and maybe that's its value.

Question 2: Where do you think the British film industry is at now?

AP: We need a lot of help: without government support the film industry could collapse. We're very small fry compared to the cinema of the US. There is a colossal amount of talent in this country with regard to directors, actors, writers, producers and the technical infrastructure is fantastic - as good as anywhere in the world - what we don't have is any kind of corporate structures or business acumen, and that makes us very, very vulnerable.

We've always been this weird cottage industry and nothing has changed in 20 years. This government is [helping] and we're grateful for that, however film is a sexy business, it's an easy political thing, that's why they like us. Every time the Oscars come around we'll have one or two successes that will be lauded - it becomes a matter of national pride to do that. World cinema is totally and utterly dominated by American cinema, and for us to make inroads into it is very, very difficult, but we are able to do that more than any other country and we're doing that. We're strong because we're strong creatively, we're fiscally weak - that's why we need government support, but I'm optimistic, every day there's another director, another writer, another actor who comes along.

BN: We're not so strong on the writing line are we? We make too many films which go into production before the script is right, either because the money will be withdrawn unless they start production now, or because we haven't got the screenwriters. We don't respect screenwriters as much as the Americans do, do we? We're still into playwrights and novelists much more than screenwriters.

AP: It's very interesting - in America they're starting to respect them far too much. Next year the possessive credit is going to be the biggest single, solitary battleground in that American film directors will possibly go on strike yet again to retain the possessive credit. Writers totally and utterly disagree with it in the US. But although we're a literary nation we're very poor at screenwriting. It's the weakest area with regards to infrastructure: our scripts are bad. And a lot of it is to do with philosophy in so much as we have very strong theatre, and if someone writes for the theatre they can succeed because of the auteur theory - which has also rubbed off on people who write screenplays in this country, which is that it's not allowed to be interfered with when it's actually at its most formative time. There's not a screenplay ever written in history that wasn't actually made better than its first draft, but with so many films here somebody writes something and they get it made. And no one's allowed to comment on it, and that's a lot of the reason why a lot of bad films have been made in this country.

Question 3: Do you need any special skills to work with young actors? How do you achieve such great results?

AP: The secret is in the casting. If you don't cast it correctly you can't get the performances from them, and I put more effort into the casting than anything. For [Angela's Ashes] we went all over Ireland looking for the kids, and all you can do is to create an environment where they can be at their best. If it's an unpleasant atmosphere they won't perform, so you end up sometimes being very strict with them but most of the time I think I was a friend to them. Joe [Breen] did a press conference where they said to him, "What was it like working with Alan Parker?" and he said, "Oh it was fine, he doesn't mean to lose his temper." So however kind I think I am, I'm probably not sometimes.

BN: Rumour has it that 15,000 kids were looked at for the film. Is that true?

AP: Yes, on tape - it's not that difficult to do on fast forward actually.

Question 4: Do you agree that one of the problems for British screenwriters is the lack of means of getting their scripts read?

AP: If you haven't got production companies who are healthy and can invest in treatments, in rough scripts even, that makes it much harder for the writers to know where they're going to go. With theatre there is a structure so that you can go to theatre in Liverpool or wherever and somebody might give you a chance to do a play by reading what you've written. Film is very different because although it ought not to be expensive to write a screenplay, it's actually very expensive to make a film and we don't have that infrastructure outside our television companies where you have a script editor who can take a young writer with a good idea and develop it.

The television companies who have those resources have not been particularly interested in cinema, outside Channel 4; the BBC have just got back into doing it, but very belatedly considering the power they have. Sky don't need to do it because they are owned by Fox which is Murdoch so that's already covered, but Granada - the biggest company in this country - don't have this. And that's the greatest sadness because Granada is actually the healthiest and richest and most responsible company in many ways, and from an industry point of view they're not interested in us.

Question 5: What was your most memorable moment making Angela's Ashes?

AP: I just remember being wet most of the time! And for three months I didn't talk to anybody without them blowing their nose. I love little Joe, I have four kids of my own but if I could have adopted him I would have done so immediately. Unfortunately he has a really nice Mum and Dad so it's very difficult. There's a scene very early on in the film where he goes to Aunt Aggie's where he's eating porridge and he could not eat it. On take eight he refused to eat it and I had words with him, and if you look very closely he's actually cried quite a lot because it took about an hour and a half for us to get him back to the set. I remember him saying to me, "I don't care if you're a famous film director, I'm not eating any more porridge!"

webTitle: Mars Lander may have hit crater

fields.headline: Mars Lander may have hit crater
fields.trailText: The ill-fated Mars Polar Lander, last heard from on December 3, 1999 as it started a descent to the surface of the Red Planet, may be lying crippled in a huge crater, the chief mission scientist said on Thursday.
fields.body:
The ill-fated Mars Polar Lander, last heard from on December 3, 1999 as it started a descent to the surface of the Red Planet, may be lying crippled in a huge crater, the chief mission scientist said on Thursday.

But Richard Zurek, the Mars Polar Lander Project Scientist, said the crater theory was just one of several scenarios being considered by scientists at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena. He said the three-legged craft was heading in the direction of the crater when it hit the Martian atmosphere.

"There is a large crater in the western portion of the landing zone which contains rougher terrain than what we've seen elsewhere," Zurek told reporters.

He described the crater, close to the Martian south pole, as being about two thirds of a mile deep and covering an area the equivalent of California's vast Central Valley, which measures several thousand square miles.

The sides of the crater slope at 20 degrees, which would send the lander tumbling to the bottom of the crater. It was designed to land on slopes no greater than 10 degrees.

Zurek said that after flight controllers at Martin Lockheed in Golden, Colorado, had performed a fourth flight correction manoeuvre a few days before the lander reached Mars, scientists realised they were drifting west and toward the huge crater.

"We had planned a fifth and final correction for a few hours before the landing to push the lander more to the east, but we realised that manoeuvre would also push us too far to the south, so we chose to control the... landing path. We expected we would have landed a bit north of the crater," he said.

But he said there were so many variables that the final resting place of the $165 million lander might never be known, unless the Mars Global Surveyor satellite, which has been mapping the Red Planet since 1997 and is photographing the landing site, can find its long white parachute - the largest single object with the tiny craft.

One of those variables is the Martian wind, which can howl through the atmosphere at nearly 70 mph, kicking up huge dust storms. Zurek said that if the winds were coming from the east they could possibly have blown the craft over to the crater.

Zurek said the Global Surveyor, which started looking for the lander two weeks ago, will continue its search for another two weeks. The best hope is the satellite will be able to take pictures of the craft's 65-foot long parachute draped across the surface, because the tiny lander is too small for the satellite's cameras to pick up.

"If we find the parachute we will know that the lander is no more two thirds of a mile away because if everything went right the two would have separated one kilometre above the surface and there wouldn't be much distance between them when they came down," he said.

Zurek said the investigation into what happened is far from over and the crater theory is just one possibility.

"We have not ruled out anything. We have not yet found any piece of information that tells us it's the landing site, the flight system, the radar system - a whole host of things could have caused us to lose the lander," he said.

And he described a story in Thursday's Denver Post in which unnamed engineers at Lockheed Martin were quoted as saying the crater was probably the most likely theory as "premature."

Zurek also disputed the claim that Lockheed Martin was not told of the crater until two weeks after the lander disappeared.

"No one on our side knew that canyon was there. All of a sudden, two weeks later, we got this... data" - essentially Martian topographical maps and images - "and it was like, 'Look at that hole!' Everybody was fairly surprised to see that data," the unnamed source told the Denver Post.

Zurek said, "Data was showing the canyon when we picked the landing site. This was exposed to the team at Lockheed Martin."

Dr. Noel Hinners, Vice President of Astronautics Flight Systems at Lockheed Martin, said that while the crater landing was one scenario, "We have no knowledge, zip, zero, of what went wrong. We don't know anything for sure. The door is still wide open. The (Denver Post) article is totally false."

He agreed that finding the craft's parachute was paramount in the investigation. "If we see the parachute it tells us we had good separation from the cruise stage, we really know where we landed. The hunt for parachute is very important," he said.

The failure of the Mars lander was Nasa's second major loss at the Red Planet in three months. In September 1999 the Mars Climate Observer satellite was lost due to human error as it approached the planet, bringing the total loss to $265 million.

fields.headline: Have you seen these men?
fields.standfirst:
As Konrad Kalejs, an 86-year-old accused of Nazi war crimes, flees to Australia, Nick Hopkins looks at the fugitives topping the world's most-wanted lists

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: As Konrad Kalejs, an 86-year-old accused of Nazi war crimes, flees to Australia, Nick Hopkins looks at the fugitives topping the world's most-wanted lists.
fields.body:
Konrad Kalejs will probably be fetching his bags from one of the carousels at Melbourne airport this morning while the home secretary, Jack Straw, tucks into breakfast. The 86-year-old accused of Nazi war crimes will be chased by the media as he returns to his suburban house but, before long, he will probably sink back into relative obscurity.

The decision to chase Kalejs out of the UK with empty threats of deportation (he was never likely to hang around) is another blow to investigators at the Simon Wiesenthal Centre. They have uncovered the whereabouts of numerous alleged war criminals, and watched goverments, with notable exceptions, proscratinate over what to do with them.

Kalejs was not the first to be let off the hook; he will not be the last. If truth be told, Kalejs was not even on their most wanted list, and he certainly does not feature on the books of either Interpol or the FBI, which compile their own. But many alleged war criminals are - both from the second world war and from recent conflicts in the Balkans.

The FBI top 10 has been biased in the past towards terrorists who have targeted US citizens, drug traffickers and murderers while Interpol's is necessarily biased towards criminals in Europe. Some detectives doubt their worth, saying they are a PR exercise.

Most terrorists are out of police jurisdiction, holed up in countries friendly to them, which would never consider handing them over. But agencies increasingly believe they can be a useful tool. Although they run the risk of being called by hoaxers, there is always the possibility that a criminal will be recognised and a vital lead provided. Investigators who support the use of lists remember the occasion in 1985 when Abu Nidal visited the police station at Paddington Green to report that his briefcase had been stolen. If his picture and details were as widely known then as they are now, he may have been caught.

No definitive list of the world's most wanted men is ever likely to be agreed. Here, we have 10 men currently wanted for heinous crimes. The names and details of the accused have come from different organisations and there is no attempt to put them in any order. The only strand connecting them is that the men are all accused of horrific crimes - and they are all at large...

Antanas Gudelis
Antanas Gudelis, 88, a Lithuanian living in Adelaide, Australia, is a prime target for Nazi hunters. He has been charged with genocide by the prosecutor general's office in Lithuania, but there is little likelihood he will ever be deported, let alone stand trial.

Gudelis was a lieutenant in Lithuania's Third Auxilliary Police Batallion during the second world war. The force, controlled by the Nazis, was instrumental in the persecution of Jews in the Kovno ghetto, and was responsible for the slaughter of 9,200 men, women and children on a single day in October, 1941: the worst mass murder in Lithuanian history.

Gudelis was investigated by the Australian war crimes tribunal but he was not brought to trial. However, the Simon Wiesenthal Centre uncovered additional evidence which, three years ago, led to him being charged by the Lithuanians over the deaths of more than 10,000 Jews. The extra evidence was presented to the Australian authorities but seems to have been ignored. Gudelis's son, Edward, said recently that the Australian police investigated his father seven years ago and "did not find damaging evidence". Gudelis has denied any involvement in war atrocities.

Aleksandras Leleikis
Aleksandras Leleikis, 92, is another Lithuanian who has evaded prosecution, even though he was stripped of US citizenship, forced to return to Vilnius, and charged with genocide. Leleikis, a law graduate, lived in the US for 41 years. Suspicions that he was involved in war crimes were confirmed in 1990 when Lithuania declared its independence and opened its state archives.

The special investigations office of the US justice department has alleged Leleikis was district security chief of the Lithuanian police in Vilnius. The force, which was subordinate to the Gestapo, was responsible for the murder of 50,000 Jews between June 1941 and July 1944. Mike Macqueen, from the OSI, discovered documents for the arrest, detention and transfer for execution of hundreds of Jews signed by Leleikis.

In hearings to strip him of his American citizenship, Leleikis said he was only carrying out orders. In June 1996, he boarded a plane to Vilnius and two years later was charged over the deaths of 74 Jews by the Lithuanian authorities. The trial was halted because of his alleged poor health. America and Israel believe he is faking. "This is the latest episode in the tragic story of the Lithuanian government's consistent failure to achieve justice in cases of Nazi crimes against humanity," said Eli Rosenbaum, head of the OSI.

Alois Brunner
The arrest and conviction of Alois Brunner remains the top priority of war investigators. He was private secretary to Adolph Eichmann, who oversaw Hitler's "final solution". Brunner has been blamed for the murder of 128,500 Jews from Austria, Greece, France, Romania and Hungary. Several countries have issued arrest warrants for him and there is evidence he is currently living in Syria under the name Georg Fisher, though this has never been properly verified.

He joined the Austrian Nazi Party in 1931, aged 19, and the SS in 1932, where he was promoted because of his rabid anti-semitism. He was responsible for deporting 44,000 Jews in sealed wagons from Salonika, Greece, to concentration camps in six weeks. As head of the Drancy concentration camp, near Paris, he sent more than 23,500 Jews to their deaths. Claiming Jewish children were "future terrorists", he ordered 250 children onto a cattle wagon bound for Auschwitz in July 1944. More than 200 were murdered, mostly by gas, some from medical experimentation. Camp survivors referred to him as "the dark nightmare" and a "mad sadist". At the end of the war, he escaped from Europe with false papers and helped set up Syria's intelligence services.

Abu Nidal
Abu Nidal, which means "father of the struggle", has been one of the world's most wanted terrorists for the past 20 years. He is wanted by Italy, the US and the UK for attacks which have killed 250 people. Nidal, a Palestinian whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, is currently thought to be living in Libya.

In 1973, he formed the Fatah Revolutionary Council, described by the US as the "world's most dangerous terrorist group". At the time, Nidal was ambassador for the PLO in Sudan and Iraq, but he defected because he did not agree with Yasser Arafat's conciliatory attitude. Nidal was responsible for the attacks on Rome and Vienna airports in 1985, which killed 17, and the 1986 synagogue bombing in Istanbul, in which 21 people perished. He was also behind the attempted assassination in London 18 years ago of Shlomo Argov, the Israeli ambassador. In 1987, he shot 150 of his own agents to ward off traitors within his 800-strong organisation.

Osama Bin Laden
Osama Bin Laden is currently the FBI's most wanted man. It has offered a $5m reward for information leading to his capture. Investigators believe he is in Afghanistan, protected by 300 bodyguards, and do not believe he will ever be brought to justice. Bin Laden, also known as "the prince" and "the director", is head of the terrorist organisation, Al-Qaeda, which was responsible for the bombings of the US embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya, in August 1998. More than 200 people were killed in the blasts.

Bin Laden is the mastermind of most Islamic terrorism, and has an estimated fortune of $200m. He is thought to have been responsible for the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Centre in New York, and attacks on US soldiers in his native Saudi Arabia.

Eric Robert Rudolph
Also on the FBI top 10 list, Rudolph was charged two years ago with bombing the Centennial Olympic Park during the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. The blast killed one woman and injured hundreds of others. He is also thought to have bombed two abortion clinics and a lesbian nightclub in 1997 and 1998.

The FBI first heard about him the day after the explosion at the clinic in Birmingham, Alabama, on January 30, 1998. A witness noticed the registration number of his pick-up truck and when officers searched his house they found bomb-making material.

Rudolph, 34, has been on the run ever since. An army veteran and specialist in survival techniques, he is thought to be hiding somewhere in the Great Smoky Mountains Range, which divides North Carolina and Tennessee. The FBI has offered $1m for information leading to his arrest.

Antonio Angeles Martins
One of Interpol's most wanted men, the poster with his name and details describes him as "dangerous, violent, infectious and addicted to drugs". Born in Brazil, Martins, 34, has been charged in Spain with the kidnap, rape, torture and murder of three teenage girls in November 1992. The girls, who came from a village near Valencia, were hitchhiking to a disco when Martins and an accomplice abducted them. Their bodies were found 65 days later, buried in shrubland near Tous. Post mortems confirmed the girls had been shot and subjected to horrific torture. Martins, who has Spanish citizenship, has been on the run ever since. There have been unconfirmed sightings of him in Lisbon and Brazil.

Ramon Eduardo Arellano-Felix
Leader of the notorious Mexican drug syndicate, the Tijuana Cartel. The FBI believes the 34-year-old, a former policeman, is one of the world's biggest cocaine smugglers. Thomas Constantine, former head of the US drug enforcement administration, said the Tijuana Cartel, and its rival the Juarez Cartel, are more powerful than the Mexican government. He described Arellano-Felix as one of the new breed of "narco-juniors" who are better educated, more sophisticated and more entrepreneurial than their predecessors. He is on the FBI's current top 10 wanted list.

Radovan Karadzic

fields.bodyText: Konrad Kalejs will probably be fetching his bags from one of the carousels at Melbourne airport this morning while the home secretary, Jack Straw, tucks into breakfast. The 86-year-old accused of Nazi war crimes will be chased by the media as he returns to his suburban house but, before long, he will probably sink back into relative obscurity. The decision to chase Kalejs out of the UK with empty threats of deportation (he was never likely to hang around) is another blow to investigators at the Simon Wiesenthal Centre. They have uncovered the whereabouts of numerous alleged war criminals, and watched goverments, with notable exceptions, proscratinate over what to do with them. Kalejs was not the first to be let off the hook; he will not be the last. If truth be told, Kalejs was not even on their most wanted list, and he certainly does not feature on the books of either Interpol or the FBI, which compile their own. But many alleged war criminals are - both from the second world war and from recent conflicts in the Balkans. The FBI top 10 has been biased in the past towards terrorists who have targeted US citizens, drug traffickers and murderers while Interpol's is necessarily biased towards criminals in Europe. Some detectives doubt their worth, saying they are a PR exercise. Most terrorists are out of police jurisdiction, holed up in countries friendly to them, which would never consider handing them over. But agencies increasingly believe they can be a useful tool. Although they run the risk of being called by hoaxers, there is always the possibility that a criminal will be recognised and a vital lead provided. Investigators who support the use of lists remember the occasion in 1985 when Abu Nidal visited the police station at Paddington Green to report that his briefcase had been stolen. If his picture and details were as widely known then as they are now, he may have been caught. No definitive list of the world's most wanted men is ever likely to be agreed. Here, we have 10 men currently wanted for heinous crimes. The names and details of the accused have come from different organisations and there is no attempt to put them in any order. The only strand connecting them is that the men are all accused of horrific crimes - and they are all at large... Antanas Gudelis Antanas Gudelis, 88, a Lithuanian living in Adelaide, Australia, is a prime target for Nazi hunters. He has been charged with genocide by the prosecutor general's office in Lithuania, but there is little likelihood he will ever be deported, let alone stand trial. Gudelis was a lieutenant in Lithuania's Third Auxilliary Police Batallion during the second world war. The force, controlled by the Nazis, was instrumental in the persecution of Jews in the Kovno ghetto, and was responsible for the slaughter of 9,200 men, women and children on a single day in October, 1941: the worst mass murder in Lithuanian history. Gudelis was investigated by the Australian war crimes tribunal but he was not brought to trial. However, the Simon Wiesenthal Centre uncovered additional evidence which, three years ago, led to him being charged by the Lithuanians over the deaths of more than 10,000 Jews. The extra evidence was presented to the Australian authorities but seems to have been ignored. Gudelis's son, Edward, said recently that the Australian police investigated his father seven years ago and "did not find damaging evidence". Gudelis has denied any involvement in war atrocities. Aleksandras Leleikis Aleksandras Leleikis, 92, is another Lithuanian who has evaded prosecution, even though he was stripped of US citizenship, forced to return to Vilnius, and charged with genocide. Leleikis, a law graduate, lived in the US for 41 years. Suspicions that he was involved in war crimes were confirmed in 1990 when Lithuania declared its independence and opened its state archives. The special investigations office of the US justice department has alleged Leleikis was district security chief of the Lithuanian police in Vilnius. The force, which was subordinate to the Gestapo, was responsible for the murder of 50,000 Jews between June 1941 and July 1944. Mike Macqueen, from the OSI, discovered documents for the arrest, detention and transfer for execution of hundreds of Jews signed by Leleikis. In hearings to strip him of his American citizenship, Leleikis said he was only carrying out orders. In June 1996, he boarded a plane to Vilnius and two years later was charged over the deaths of 74 Jews by the Lithuanian authorities. The trial was halted because of his alleged poor health. America and Israel believe he is faking. "This is the latest episode in the tragic story of the Lithuanian government's consistent failure to achieve justice in cases of Nazi crimes against humanity," said Eli Rosenbaum, head of the OSI. Alois Brunner The arrest and conviction of Alois Brunner remains the top priority of war investigators. He was private secretary to Adolph Eichmann, who oversaw Hitler's "final solution". Brunner has been blamed for the murder of 128,500 Jews from Austria, Greece, France, Romania and Hungary. Several countries have issued arrest warrants for him and there is evidence he is currently living in Syria under the name Georg Fisher, though this has never been properly verified. He joined the Austrian Nazi Party in 1931, aged 19, and the SS in 1932, where he was promoted because of his rabid anti-semitism. He was responsible for deporting 44,000 Jews in sealed wagons from Salonika, Greece, to concentration camps in six weeks. As head of the Drancy concentration camp, near Paris, he sent more than 23,500 Jews to their deaths. Claiming Jewish children were "future terrorists", he ordered 250 children onto a cattle wagon bound for Auschwitz in July 1944. More than 200 were murdered, mostly by gas, some from medical experimentation. Camp survivors referred to him as "the dark nightmare" and a "mad sadist". At the end of the war, he escaped from Europe with false papers and helped set up Syria's intelligence services. Abu Nidal Abu Nidal, which means "father of the struggle", has been one of the world's most wanted terrorists for the past 20 years. He is wanted by Italy, the US and the UK for attacks which have killed 250 people. Nidal, a Palestinian whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, is currently thought to be living in Libya. In 1973, he formed the Fatah Revolutionary Council, described by the US as the "world's most dangerous terrorist group". At the time, Nidal was ambassador for the PLO in Sudan and Iraq, but he defected because he did not agree with Yasser Arafat's conciliatory attitude. Nidal was responsible for the attacks on Rome and Vienna airports in 1985, which killed 17, and the 1986 synagogue bombing in Istanbul, in which 21 people perished. He was also behind the attempted assassination in London 18 years ago of Shlomo Argov, the Israeli ambassador. In 1987, he shot 150 of his own agents to ward off traitors within his 800-strong organisation. Osama Bin Laden Osama Bin Laden is currently the FBI's most wanted man. It has offered a $5m reward for information leading to his capture. Investigators believe he is in Afghanistan, protected by 300 bodyguards, and do not believe he will ever be brought to justice. Bin Laden, also known as "the prince" and "the director", is head of the terrorist organisation, Al-Qaeda, which was responsible for the bombings of the US embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya, in August 1998. More than 200 people were killed in the blasts. Bin Laden is the mastermind of most Islamic terrorism, and has an estimated fortune of $200m. He is thought to have been responsible for the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Centre in New York, and attacks on US soldiers in his native Saudi Arabia. Eric Robert Rudolph Also on the FBI top 10 list, Rudolph was charged two years ago with bombing the Centennial Olympic Park during the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. The blast killed one woman and injured hundreds of others. He is also thought to have bombed two abortion clinics and a lesbian nightclub in 1997 and 1998. The FBI first heard about him the day after the explosion at the clinic in Birmingham, Alabama, on January 30, 1998. A witness noticed the registration number of his pick-up truck and when officers searched his house they found bomb-making material. Rudolph, 34, has been on the run ever since. An army veteran and specialist in survival techniques, he is thought to be hiding somewhere in the Great Smoky Mountains Range, which divides North Carolina and Tennessee. The FBI has offered $1m for information leading to his arrest. Born in Brazil, Martins, 34, has been charged in Spain with the kidnap, rape, torture and murder of three teenage girls in November 1992. The girls, who came from a village near Valencia, were hitchhiking to a disco when Martins and an accomplice abducted them. Their bodies were found 65 days later, buried in shrubland near Tous. webTitle: War crime suspect flies to Australia

fields.headline: War crime suspect flies to Australia
fields.standfirst:
Straw admits Kalejs should have been on suspects' index barring entry

Simon Wiesenthal Center
The holocaust history project
The Home Office: Immigration information
Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw branded Konrad Kalejs a war criminal yesterday as the alleged death squad lieutenant left Britain and dashed hopes that he would be prosecuted here.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw branded Konrad Kalejs a war criminal yesterday as the alleged death squad lieutenant left Britain and dashed hopes that he would be prosecuted here.

Kalejs, 86, made a pre-dawn escape from the Leicestershire residential home where he had been staying. He left Britain voluntarily after the home secretary issued a notice that he intended to deport him.

Kalejs was accompanied to Heathrow by police and immigration officials. Just after 10.30am he left British soil en route to Australia aboard a Singapore airlines jet.

It is believed he will be greeted by protests in Melbourne today, which will renew pressure on the Australian government to prosecute him. Latvia stressed last night that it was investigating him.

Nazi-hunters wanted Kalejs, an Australian citizen, charged in Britain for involvement in the murder of 30,000 people, mainly Jews, while joint second in command of a Latvian mobile killing squad, the Arajs Kommando, that collaborated with the Nazi occupiers of Latvia during the second world war.

In London, the home secretary intensified his offensive against critics of Britain's decision that there was insufficient evidence to prosecute Kalejs which let him leave the country as a free man.

The US and Canada had both considered the evidence of Kalejs's involvement in war crimes strong enough to deport him.

Mr Straw admitted that "with hindsight" Kalejs should have been on the suspects' index, which would have led to him being denied entry into Britain.

His name has now been added to the list of 500,000 to be refused entry.

The home secretary also hinted that even if there had been strong evidence, the war crimes act may not have covered Kalejs. He said Scotland Yard "considered it legally questionable whether Kalejs could be regarded as resident in the United Kingdom as would be required if he were to be tried under the war crimes act 1991".

He stressed that his decision that Kalejs should be deported required a lower standard of proof than a criminal prosecution: "My decision that reasonable grounds existed to believe that Kalejs was complicit in war crimes was, of course, reached where necessary on the balance of probabilities."

Mr Straw said nothing more could have been done, but sidestepped questions about the rigour of the police investigation into Kalejs, who was never questioned by officers about any of the war crimes allegations against him.

Kalejs entered Britain at Birmingham airport on September 27 1997, from Frankfurt and as an Australian national had permission to stay for six months.

He had a passport which had been renewed in February 1999 which did not contain stamps which could have alerted immigration officers to the fact that he had been deported from the US in 1994 and Canada in 1997.

Britain's refusal to prosecute Kalejs was condemned by one of his alleged victims Alfred Winter, 81, who lives in the US. Mr Winter told the Guardian he was guarded by Kalejs's unit at the Salaspils camp where he was held from December 1941 to July 1942 and saw executions, beatings and death from starvation: "It's a very bad feeling that he has escaped justice again."

Lord Janner, who campaigns for war criminals to be brought to justice, said: "I am deeply disappointed, frustrated and sad that this evil man was allowed to leave Britain before he was sent to jail for the rest of his days. It is now up to the Australian authorities. We are going to try to get them to investigate fully."

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe expressed dismay that Kalejs had departed without facing criminal action in the UK.

In Australia, ministers have also promised to reinvestigate Kalejs if new evidence comes to light, having dropped a prosecution for lack of evidence.

The Latvian government said yesterday that criminal proceedings had been started against Kalejs in that country and called for international help gathering information which might provide evidence against him.
