fields.headline: Mr Kalejs says goodbye
fields.standfirst:
A bungle, but mainly Australia's bungle

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: The intense fury of campaigners over Konrad Kalejs' departure yesterday is understandable. They argue that we have allowed to slip between our fingers a man whom they alleged to be one of the last big Nazi war criminals yet to be prosecuted.
fields.body:
The intense fury of campaigners over Konrad Kalejs' departure yesterday is understandable. They argue that we have allowed to slip between our fingers a man whom they alleged to be one of the last big Nazi war criminals yet to be prosecuted.

Mr Kalejs, it is claimed, was that rare prize, a commander who organised and gave orders in a Latvian unit which killed thousands of Jews. What adds bitterness to their exasperation is that this case is very likely to be the last reckoning in this country of the last century's great horror, the Holocaust. After the conviction of Anthony Savoniuk last year, there are no more war crime cases pending, the Scotland Yard War Crimes Unit has closed: it is the end of this story of frustrated justice.

That is the emotionally charged context for the fierce criticism of Jack Straw's decision not to detain Mr Kalejs, not to attempt to prosecute him in Britain, but to deport him. But it is hard to see what else Mr Straw could have done.

Firstly, even his fiercest critics admit it would have meant "stretching" the law to detain the 86-year-old long enough to decide whether a prosecution was possible. Comparisons with General Pinochet are completely spurious (and opportunistic on the part of his allies), since no one has requested Mr Kalejs' extradition. Secondly, the 1991 war crimes act applies to British citizens, while Mr Kalejs became an Australian in 1957.

Mr Kalejs' case exposes the inadequacy of the whole international effort over the last two decades to close the loop on Nazi war criminals who fled eastern Europe. Australia, the US and Canada have played an elaborate game of pass the parcel and now Mr Straw has joined in. But in the order of shame, Australia comes top. He has been deported back there twice, yet no prosecution was initiated. The political will in Canberra to pursue war criminals has sadly long since run out.

The disappointing irony is that this was the country which was held out as a model of second world war crime investigations. While this has led to an unrivalled archive on the killing teams of Nazi-occupied Europe and investigation skills which have been copied in Bosnia, it has been singularly unsuccessful in achieving convictions. The ball is now back in Australia's court. Its only way out is if Latvia decides putting Mr Kalejs on trial in Riga might earn it a few brownie points for its application for European community membership.

webTitle: Pretend you know all about: Escorial

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about: Escorial
fields.trailText: Now that pashminas are sold in Kwik Save (probably) and shahtooshes can land you in jail, how does one keep warm and establish one's superiority to hoi polloi at the same time? This pressing problem has been solved with the arrival of Escorial, the new posh kid on the luxury fabric block. Escorial is made from the soft, springy coat of the rare Mahgreb sheep, North African in origin but now bred in New Zealand. The appeal of the fibre lies in its natural spiral shape which traps air, giving the yarn an elastic, crease-free nature and making it appear full while feeling feather-light.
fields.body:
Now that pashminas are sold in Kwik Save (probably) and shahtooshes can land you in jail, how does one keep warm and establish one's superiority to hoi polloi at the same time? This pressing problem has been solved with the arrival of Escorial, the new posh kid on the luxury fabric block. Escorial is made from the soft, springy coat of the rare Mahgreb sheep, North African in origin but now bred in New Zealand. The appeal of the fibre lies in its natural spiral shape which traps air, giving the yarn an elastic, crease-free nature and making it appear full while feeling feather-light.

The name Escorial dates from 16th-century Spain, when the Spanish king housed at his monastery, El Escorial, the sheep the Moorish invaders had brought from Africa. The fabrics woven from the yarn were top of every princess's wish list. The Spanish flocks died during the Napoleonic wars; however, some sheep had been given by Spain's Charles III as a gift to his cousin Xavier, the Elector of Saxon, and the pure breed survived in Germany until the 19th century when Scotswoman Eliza Furlonge took a hundred of the best animals to Australia, from where the breed spread to New Zealand. Quite an impressive pedigree for a scarf, I think you'll agree.

As well as the sheep, there are two humans hard at work in the production of Escorial: New Zealand farmer Peter Radford and London-based creative director Ben Frankel. Gucci, Chanel, Comme des Garçons and Whistles are all working with the fabric. Whistles already stock a Cloak of Stars scarf, made from the purest part of the sheep, with a lighter version in 20 colours in the pipeline for spring/summer and a clothing range planned. As you might have guessed, these scarves aren't cheap - £495 for Whistle's Cloak of Stars, £245 for the summer scarf. Buy now while they're really expensive: once you can buy them for a reasonable price, no one will want them any more. That's fashion for you.

fields.headline: The best hospital scene
fields.standfirst: Bringing Out the Dead
fields.trailText: New York, Our Lady of Misery Medical Center. Attempting to wheel their patient, a heart attack victim, into reception, paramedics Frank (Nicolas Cage) and Larry (John Goodman) find themselves confronted with the hospital security guard.
fields.body:
New York, Our Lady of Misery Medical Center. Attempting to wheel their patient, a heart attack victim, into reception, paramedics Frank (Nicolas Cage) and Larry (John Goodman) find themselves confronted with the hospital security guard.

"You're going nowhere. They're all backed up."

Frank stares at the guard.

"Just let us in."

The guard is incredulous.

"Just let us in?"

Frank and Larry push past, into the hospital. As they wheel the patient down a corridor, we cut to an anteroom, where a doctor is talking to a pale man in his thirties. The man shakes.

"So," the doctor begins, "you've been taking cocaine for three days, and now you feel as if your heart is beating too fast. And you want us to help you. Well, to tell you the truth, I don't see why we should."

The man leans forward in a state of some agitation.

"Aw, come on ."

"I mean, correct me if I'm wrong, but while we've been here saving lives, you've been at home putting shit up your nose..."

Cut back to Frank, standing over his patient as Larry searches for assistance. Another man, dreadlocked and wide-eyed, is bound to a stretcher outside an office. He screams. "LET ME PLEASE GET A GLASS OF WATER! CAN I PLEASE GET A GLASS OF WATER?"

See also: The Kingdom, Re-Animator, King of New York, Carry On Nurse

Don't see also: Extreme Measures

Pointless trivia: Nicolas Cage is identified in the closing credits of the 1982 movie Fast Times At Ridgemont High as Nicolas Coppola

fields.headline: Gwyneth 'fesses up about breaking down
fields.standfirst: Also today, Universal in a flap over Hannibal, Johnny Depp steps out in London, the world is not enough for Zeta-Jones, and Shakespeare in Love director to lead Captain Corelli adaptation
fields.trailText: Gwyneth Paltrow has lablled herself a wimp for breaking down in tears during her acceptance speech at last year's Oscars' ceremony.
fields.body:
Gwyneth Paltrow has lablled herself a wimp for breaking down in tears during her acceptance speech at last year's Oscars' ceremony.

The star seriously dented her ice-cool image when she blubbed on stage after receiving the best actress Academy Award for Shakespeare in Love.

In the speech, she thanked her family, fellow nominees, co-star Joseph Fiennes and then boyfriend Ben Affleck, before dedicating the award to her cousin Keith Paltrow and her dead ex-lover Harrison Kravis.

In an interview with Now magazine the star says she spent days in bed after the ceremony because she was so embarrassed. "I can't believe I was such a wimp. I honestly had no expectation of winning. I had nothing prepared and I just started crying".

She adds that she is still scared to talk about the awards night even now.

Remind yourself of the full horror: listen to her acceptance speech here.

Universal in a flap over Hannibal

Jodie Foster's decision to take the veggie option and drop out of Hannibal has put Universal, the studio behind the The Silence of the Lambs sequel in a flap.

Foster's bombshell, dropped just after Christmas caught most executives off guard, and the studio has less than three weeks to decide what to do next.

A spokeswoman admitted: "there is no cohesive plan right now". It is rumoured that executives are still desperate to get Foster on board, and are attempting to work out a schedule to accommodate both her participation in the film and her decision to direct Flora Plum (see last week's news story).

Another option would be to scrap Hannibal altogether, but it is unlikely Universal would countenance this - the studio has already sunk $10m into the film simply for story rights and script fees.

Meanwhile the names of possible alternatives to play Clarice Starling are racking up. Cate Blanchett, Angelina Jolie, Hilary (Boys Don't Cry) Swank, Gillian Anderson, Helen Hunt, and even Calista Flockhart.

But there is no word from the Hollywood's most wanted woman. Foster is away on a skiing trip and could not be reached for comment.

Depp steps out

Johnny Depp was in town last night to celebrate the UK release of his latest film, Sleepy Hollow.

The star of Tim Burton's gothic horror fantasy which opens in the UK today, turned up for dinner at an exclusive West End venue in a silver Mercedes but dressed in a woolly black hat, battered leather jacket and grubby jeans. He signed one autograph but made no comment to waiting fans or the press.

Earlier yesterday evening, Tim Burton talked to Mark Kermode at the NFT in a new season of Guardian Interviews. The genial, slightly diffident director discussed the making of Sleepy Hollow, working in the UK, and how he seems to have a psychotic twin who spreads rumours about him on the internet. You heard it here first.

 You can read the full transcript and listen to soundclips from the Tim Burton interview on Film Unlimited next week

The world is not enough for Zeta-Jones

Yesterday Catherine Zeta-Jones announced her engagement to Michael Douglas. Today she unveils her plans to become a studio producer.

The star of Entrapment, has joined forces with her two brothers and set up a production company called Zeta Films.

The company, financed by International Entertainment Group, an independent production and distribution company based in Beverly Hills, aims to produce between two and six movies a year, with budgets ranging from $5m to $50m.

Her older brother is an executive at IEG and helped clinch the deal.

"IEG has assembled a great work force and I respect them, both on a business level and a creative level,'' Zeta-Jones said. "I look forward to being part of the team".

Casting couch

 Shakespeare in Love director John Madden will direct Captain Corelli's Mandolin, the Louis de Bernieres world war two novel about an Italian officer who is torn between his military duties and the love of a woman. Nic Cage is tentatively attached to star as the eponymous hero; filming starts in Corfu in May.

 Friends star Lisa Kudrow, last seen in Analyse This is to star in a film version of the ever-popular TV series, I Dream of Jeannie, playing the dizzy housewife genie.

 Moby will provide some of the music for Cecil B. Demented, John Waters's new film about a group of renegade film-makers who kidnap a Hollywood actress and force her to star in their low-budget movie.

fields.headline: 'Sad-eyed chronicler of sex and sin'
fields.standfirst: 'My books don't make good films,' said Graham Greene. As Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair hopes to change all that, Giles Foden looks back at the novelist's unrequited love affair with the cinema
fields.trailText: 'My books don't make good films,' said Graham Greene. As Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair hopes to change all that, Giles Foden looks back at the novelist's unrequited love affair with the cinema
fields.body:
At the start of his memoir, A Sort of Life, Graham Greene makes pointed mention of the cinema in the high street of his childhood Berkhamsted. With its voluptuous Moorish dome, the picture palace was forbidden territory to Greene and his schoolboy friends. The author's father, at that time headmaster of Berkhamsted School, was chary of the place in any case. He had once "allowed his senior boys to go there for a special performance of the first Tarzan movie, under the false impression that it was an educational film of anthropological interest".

Greene relates how, ever after, his father "regarded the cinema with a sense of disillusion and suspicion". Those two words, carefully chosen, are a perfect description of the landscape that has, for better or worse, become known as "Greeneland". Greene himself, who hated the term, reluctantly described it as: "White men going to seed in outlandish places. Unshaven, guilt-ridden, on the bottle."

You can understand an author's reaction to critical shorthand, but there is more to Greeneland than Greene's terse definition. Even a book like The End of the Affair - set in upper-middle-class London and newly brought to the screen by Neil Jordan - is well within its ambit.

Sometimes noirish (The Third Man), sometimes tropical (The Comedians), sometimes criminal (Brighton Rock), nearly always, even if at a submerged level, religious - insofar as it involves a journey through personal crisis - Greeneland is a mixed vernacular. It is one that has informed cinematic as well as literary narrative. Directors of the quality of John Ford, Fritz Lang and Carol Reed are among those who have turned their attentions to the books of an author whose work has been translated to film more than that of any other 20th-century writer.

Disillusion and suspicion also describe, however, Greene's own feelings about the film industry at the end of his 50-year association with it as optioned novelist, adapter of his own works and those of others (Evelyn Waugh tried to persuade him to do Brideshead Revisited), original screen-writer and prolific film critic.

Although Greene was always at pains to emphasise that it was money that drew him to films, it wasn't just a journeyman attachment; it went right to the heart of his own aesthetic matter. As David Parkinson puts it in the introduction to his invaluable Graham Greene film reader, Mornings in the Dark, "Greene's fictional style was undeniably filmic."

By the time of his death, his oeuvre had given rise to some 40 feature films, not to mention numerous short films for television, a host of unmade projects, and his own evanescent scenario work for Korda, the GPO film unit and others. Some of the films of his books are unmitigated disasters; others - notably The Third Man, originally written as a screen treatment - are acknowledged classics of cinema.

Yet in general, with only a few exceptions, Greene believed that "my books don't make good films". One of those exceptions was the 1955 adaptation of The End of the Affair, his 1951 novel about a love-triangle in the Blitz. From multiple perspectives, entangling religious and sexual themes, the book tells the tale of a egoistic writer's affair with the wife of a pitiful civil servant. Jordan's new film of the novel - which was based very loosely on one of Greene's own affairs - has Ralph Fiennes, Julianne Moore and Stephen Rea playing writer, wife and civil servant respectively.

Starring Deborah Kerr and directed by Edward Dmytryk, the original was adapted by one Lenore Coffee. In a 1984 Guardian Film Lecture, Greene described it as the "least unsatisfactory" of the adaptations of his religious novels, his particular bête noir being The Heart of the Matter, in which the suicide of Catholic policeman Scobie was obscured for reasons of populism, censorship and fear of offending Catholic sensibility.

In The End of the Affair, the religious theme hangs on a sort of inverted Pascal's Wager. After making love to the writer, Bendrix, the adultress (an outmoded term now, but potent as hemlock in the 1940s time frame) Sarah witnesses what she believes to be his death when a bomb falls nearby. A devout, if straying Catholic, she prays with all her heart that if God brings Bendrix back to life, she will give him up forever. When he wakes up - or is he woken up? - she breaks off the affair, without saying why.

The subtle unfolding of the story, two years later, follows Bendrix's slow grasping of what has taken place and, briefly and tragically, the lovers' reunion. One of the strengths of this very powerful, not to say harrowing, tale is that its mystical drama never loses sight of the everyday. This is true even of the final "miracle", involving the disappearance of a facial blemish touched by Sarah.

The atheist Bendrix's own story concerns the acceptance or otherwise of faith, as provoked by these events. In Jordan's version, Bendrix is made the main focus, with the stealing of Sarah's journal giving access to her point of view. Like the novel, Jordan uses a deal of flashback - something that was dropped by Columbia in the earlier film (they also distribute the new one), much to Greene's disappointment.

Despite bridling at lack of control, he definitively did not want to do the original adaptation himself. But he did show up on the set. In August 1954, the Daily Sketch had Greene, "that sad-faced chronicler of sex and sin", turning up at Shepperton. He told the reporter that "scripting your own stories can be unwelcome and fatiguing". It appears to have been a gruelling visit anyway. Thirty years later, in his Guardian interview with Quentin Falk, he related with some distaste how the actor playing Bendrix (Van Johnson) put his stored chewing gum back in his mouth whenever he was off-camera.

Who is to say whether Jordan's adaptation would have met with the approval of a writer who was the first to admit his own failings, with those of others following a very close second? What we can say is that, keeping agnosticism and the miraculous in the balance, it will find a ready audience thirsting for religious guidance.

It will also find an audience hungry for the erotic. For Greene, who became a regular at Oxford film theatres in pre-talkie days, the ritual of cinema-going always had something of the illicit about it: "There is the secrecy of sneaking into a cinema in the dark, perhaps with a girlfriend: no one need know."

As master chronicler of the Absconded God's flight from his sinful creatures, Greene also saw how religious ecstasy could no longer make magnificent declaration of its sensual qualities: far from being public art, like Bernini's statue of St Theresa, 20th-century sensual religious experience would, in his hands, be a secret, half-lit thing. The preserve of a cinema-goer. An adulterer. A novelist in his garret.

Or all of the last three: a knowing scene in Jordan's film shows the lovers in a picture-house watching an adaptation of one of Bendrix's novels. "I didn't write it that way," he says, in a moment heavy with an ironical sense that the divine author's scenario for the outcome of the affair might not accord with his present plans either. Greene himself was more direct, talking of the flaky adaptations of books (and, just as often, the acting or camera technique) as if they were outright mortal sins, things to be ashamed of, even - especially - when he was directly involved.

It was almost as if traffic with the film industry itself had a sinful dimension. And the industry seemed to sense this conflict. Guy Elmes, who adapted two of Greene's novels, said that it was "the theology that gives the tone that attracts people to buy the stuff to film in the first place... then they actually have to script it and it becomes rather frightening and a concern whether mass audiences will be able to take this internal agony thing he's trying to externalise all the time."

At first, though - at the start of Greene's affair with cinema - it was love. In Mornings in the Dark, Parkinson reveals the pitch of the young novelist's excitement about the medium. In 1936, with one novel adapted and the rights to another sold, he wrote to his brother: "I'm getting deep into films, so deep that Grierson sounded me the other day on whether I should be interested in a producing job..." By the end of the year, he is "thick in scenario, Medium Shots and Insert Shots and Flash Backs and the rest of the racket".

It was a bit of an exaggeration. With neither film nor book money coming in quickly enough, he was already back in journalism. Ten years earlier, Greene had taken a job as a sub-editor on the court pages of the Times. Later came (anonymous) film reviews for that paper's entertainment section. His first novel, The Man Within, was published in 1929, while he was still on the Times. Five more came, with limited success, between then and 1935, when he rather casually took up the job which would see him become a regular face at preview screenings.

By then a book reviewer for the Spectator, he suggested - at a drinks party, after that "dangerous third martini" - that he become their film critic. They accepted, and one of the most incisive writers on film (Philip French: "the most ferocious I've ever come across") was launched.

That was June 1935. Within just three years, his reputation went far and wide, with one aggrieved film-maker sending him a piece of shit enclosed in a letter. By 1938, he was also contributing to Night and Day magazine, and found himself accused of writing, in a review of Wee Willie Winkie, that 20th-Century Fox had procured Shirley Temple for immoral purposes. The nine-year-old Miss Temple ("infancy is her disguise, her appeal is more secret and adult") won her case, and Greene had to pay £500 of the £3,500 costs.

Other stars fared little better, but Greene wasn't into bitchiness alone. He also tried to put across an idea of the cinema that would return it to the true populism of the Elizabethan stage, to vibrancy in place of gentility.

But in spite of renown, those "four and a half years of watching films several times a week", those "mornings in the dark", were really a means of escape from novel writing - "escape from the hellish problems of construction in Chapter Six, from the secondary character who obstinately refuses to come alive, escape for an hour and a half from the melancholy which falls inexorably round the novelist when he has lived for too many months on end in his own private world".

With the coming of the second world war, Greene's reviewing activity began to tail off. It was partly the welcome excitement of the war, but he seems to have felt tarnished, as if he were a patent examiner who'd seen too many inventions that failed.

Post war, for Greene as novelist and screenwriter supplying the film industry, there was still much invention to come, but the appeal of this would tire too: "I've made films in the forties, fifties and sixties. But the time comes when one's enthusiasm begins to slacken. One's left with only enough enthusiasm for one's own work, which is writing novels..."

Film, however, was also at the centre of that "own work", in Greene's consolidation of the use of cinematic style in fiction: the "new habit of narrative" as Evelyn Waugh called it in a review of The Heart of the Matter. Greene himself, in words that no contemporary novelist can afford to ignore, put it like this:

"When I describe a scene, I capture it with the moving eye of the cine-camera rather than the photographer's eye - which leaves it frozen. In this precise domain I think the cinema has influenced me. Authors like Walter Scott or the Victorians were influenced by paintings and constructed their backgrounds as though they were static and came from the hands of a Constable. I work with a camera, following my characters and their movements."

 The End of the Affair will be released on February 4. The Guardian Interview with Neil Jordan, Ralph Fiennes and Stephen Woolley will take place on February 1 at the NFT. Giles Foden's novels, The Last King of Scotland and Ladysmith, are in development as films.

Greene on Hollywood women

Mae West: "Big-busted carnivorous creature in tight white sequins."

Shirley Temple: "An oddly precocious body as voluptuous in grey flannel trousers as Miss Dietrich's."

Jean Harlow: "Her technique was the gangster's technique - she toted breast like a man totes a gun."

Irene Dunne (singing to a horse): "The one without the white patch on her forehead."

Greta Garbo: "The finest filly of them all."

Shirley Temple: "An oddly precocious body as voluptuous in grey flannel trousers as Miss Dietrich's." Greta Garbo: "The finest filly of them all."

webTitle: Naval novelist Patrick O'Brian dies, aged 85

fields.headline: Naval novelist Patrick O'Brian dies, aged 85
fields.trailText: Patrick O'Brian, the novelist whose naval tales captivated millions of readers despite the scorn of critics, has died aged 85. A near recluse who found fame with his maritime tales of the Napoleonic wars, he died suddenly on Sunday evening in a Dublin hotel.
fields.body:
Patrick O'Brian, the novelist whose naval tales captivated millions of readers despite the scorn of critics, has died aged 85. A near recluse who found fame with his maritime tales of the Napoleonic wars, he died suddenly on Sunday evening in a Dublin hotel.

Though he had lived in seclusion with his second wife in the coastal village of Collioure, near Perpignan, France, since 1949, he had been wintering at Trinity College, Dublin. His body will be flown this morning to France where he will be buried.

Most famous for his 20 novels featuring Captain Jack Aubrey and Dr Stephen Maturin, O'Brian was renowned for the historical accuracy of his books, and attracted a huge following of readers who revelled in the detail of life aboard ship. Dozens of websites are devoted to decoding the period terminology in his books, and a cooking club was founded in to recreate the sumptuous meals described in his work.

His fame came late in life and despite his work being dismissed in some quarters as mere "historical fiction".

His early work was coolly received and O'Brian resorted to working as a translator to survive. In 1969 he began work on the first of his Aubrey-Maturin novels, the series that was to transform him from impecunious author to global bestseller. Sales were slow, although the books attracted the support of AS Byatt and Iris Murdoch, but through the next two decades his following grew steadily.

His work was revealed to a far wider audience in the 1990s after the New York Times referred to him as "the best novelist you've never heard of", while the New Yorker compared his delicate observations of 19th-century political, social and military life with the work of Jane Austen.

While his fiction was painstaking in its detail, the author was less forthcoming about his private life, which provided perhaps the best story of all.

It had always been assumed that O'Brian was an Irish Catholic, while his writings suggested that he had worked for military intelligence during the second world war. But in 1998 it emerged that none of this was true, and that Patrick O'Brian was a nom de plume.

After an investigation by a newspaper he was named as Richard Patrick Russ, eighth son of an English doctor, born in Chalfont-St-Peter, Buckinghamshire and educated in Torrington, Devon. After the death of his mother in 1920, an event he said "caused the family to fall apart", his work was first published under his real name in 1930, aged 15.

In 1936 O'Brian married and a year later had a son, Richard, who survives him. In 1939 his wife, Sarah, had a daughter, Jane, who had spina bifida and died at the age of three. Shortly afterwards O'Brian and his wife separated.

O'Brian spent the war honing his literary skills at the special operations executive, where he worked in the political warfare executive, a desk-bound department specialising in propaganda, and was married again in 1945, to Mary Tolstoy-Miroslavska, with whom he had worked in military intelligence.

O'Brian reacted phlegmatically to his sudden fame and the emergence of a fan club that counts Charlton Heston, Mark Knopfler, William Waldegrave and Michael Grade among its number.

He is survived by his son, Richard Russ, his second wife, Mary, and his stepson, Nikolai Tolstoy-Miroslavsky.

webTitle: A circus, Noah's Ark and two economists

fields.headline: A circus, Noah's Ark and two economists
fields.trailText:
• How do you kill a circus?
Go for the juggler.
fields.body:
 How do you kill a circus?
Go for the juggler.

 One day God calls down to Noah and says: "Noah me old china, I wants you to make me a new Ark"

"No probs God, anything you want after all you're the boss!" replies Noah

But God interrupts: "Ah but there's a catch this time Noah. I want not just a couple of decks I want 20 decks one on top of the other."

"20 DECKS!" screams Noah. "Well, OK big man, what ever you say, should I fill it up with all the animals just like last time?"

"Yep, that's right, well sort of right This time I just want you to fill it up with fish," God answers.

"Fish?" Queries Noah.

"Yep, fish... Well, make it more specific Noah, I want Carp, wall to wall, floor to ceiling Carp!"

Noah looks to the skies: "Let me get this right, you want a new Ark?"

"Yessiree"

"With 20 decks, one on top of the other?"

"Yup"

"And you want it full of Carp?"

"Surely"

"Why?" asks the perplexed Noah, who was slowly but surely getting to the end of his tether!

"Well" says God, "I just always fancied a Multi-Story Carp Ark"

 Two economists were walking down the street when they noticed two women yelling across the street at each other from their apartment windows. Of course they will never come to agreement, stated the first economist. And why is that? inquired his companion. Because, the other intoned, they are arguing from different premises.

Thanks to: Roy Findus

webTitle: Losses cut as Freeserve fends off US rivals

fields.headline: Losses cut as Freeserve fends off US rivals
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Freeserve
fields.trailText: Freeserve produced the strongest set of figures in its short history yesterday to claw back some of the ground its shares lost in the new year sell-off of internet stocks.
fields.body:
Freeserve produced the strongest set of figures in its short history yesterday to claw back some of the ground its shares lost in the new year sell-off of internet stocks.

John Pluthero, chief executive of the UK's largest internet service provider, said quarterly figures showing a reduced pre-tax loss of £3.6m on a turnover of £3.8m, and 1.575m registered users were "very strong".

The figures, for the 12 weeks to November 13, 1999, compare with a pre-tax loss of £5m and a turnover of £3.4m in the previous 16-week quarter.

Mr Pluthero pointed to the 14,000 new customers joining the service each week and the increased amount of time they are using the service as evidence that Freeserve has been holding firm against rival offerings from big American providers.

Shares in Freeserve edged up 2p to 491p in a market still nervous about the prospects of internet companies. Last month Freeserve shares were trading at 590p.

"This has been a good quarter for us," Mr Pluthero said. "Independent figures show we now have the most recognised internet brand in the country and we reach 85% of the internet population.

"Our e-commerce is improving and we are positioning ourselves to be at the front of the wave when internet access goes mobile later this year."

Analysts broadly welcomed the results, describing them as "solid" and saying losses were less than had been expected. However, some remained cautious.

"Freeserve has certainly not been as volatile as such fireworks as QXL [the online auction house] but the current results do nothing to alter its exposure to current anxieties over tech stocks," said Miles Saltiel, head of technology research at West LB Panmure.

Mr Pluthero said he was unconcerned by analysts' forecasts that Freeserve, which is valued at more than British Airways, will not make a profit until the third year of its operation.

"We are in an investment stage which is about growing our brand and our user base," he said.

"Our losses are in line with analyst expectations of around £10m-£15m a year over three years. I think most people would spend £30m-£40m to build the biggest internet company in the UK."

The figures showed that advertising now provides £4.50 for every 1,000 page impressions, more than double Freeserve's target.

The company has also doubled the number of e-commerce partners it had last quarter to 80 and expects to add another 30 over the next few months.

Increased advertising and e-commerce revenues, plus a share of telephone call charges, helped the company offset an expensive pre-Christmas advertising and marketing campaign.

Freeserve remains on the lookout to buy smaller internet service providers.

"We're talking to various people about what to do with their subscriber bases," Mr Pluthero said. Deals are likely to be structured either as alliances or paper acquisitions.

Freeserve was floated in July at 150p per share and is still 80% owned by the electrical retailer Dixons. It recently signed a deal with BT Cellnet to provide mobile internet services to the next generation of wireless application protocol (WAP) mobile phones, due out in the spring.

However, Mr Pluthero said yesterday: "It will be a slow-burn story this year with only 10% of the UK population owning next generation phones by the end of the year - 2001 is going to be the year of WAP."

webTitle: Gates hopes to break print habit

fields.headline: Gates hopes to break print habit
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Microsost
barnesandnoble.com
fields.trailText: Microsoft yesterday challenged the last bastion of the print medium when it announced a deal to develop and market electronic books with Barnes & Noble, one of the world's largest book retailers.
fields.body:
Microsoft yesterday challenged the last bastion of the print medium when it announced a deal to develop and market electronic books with Barnes & Noble, one of the world's largest book retailers.

Barnes & Noble's 960 bookstores, along with its website - barnesandnoble.com - aim to begin offering e-books from the middle of next year.

Microsoft hopes that its Reader software, demonstrated for the first time yesterday, will overturn one of the most ingrained views of ink and paper fans, that readers are unwilling to read more than small sections of text from a screen.

Apple also announced its intent to branch out from its traditional markets with a $200m investment in Earthlink Network, the second-largest internet service provider in the United States, behind America Online.

Steve Jobs, who founded Apple 25 years ago and returned to rescue it in 1997, has dropped the "interim" as a prefix to his chief executive title, marking his ambition to stay with the business indefinitely.

Microsoft claims its Reader software delivers an on-screen reading experience similar to print. It includes comparable spacing, margins, kerning and leading as well as tools for book marking and annotation.

Reader uses ClearType technology which improves character resolution on LCD screens.

"This collaboration is a concrete declaration of support by two industry leaders for the future of e-books," said Steve Riggio, vice-chairman of Barnes & Noble. "We envisage a time in the not too distant future when there will be electronic versions of virtually every book in print."

The products are part of a new wave of handheld devices which are due to come on to the market in the first half of this year.

Microsoft was unveiling its latest palm-sized Windows CE-based software at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, and coined the phrase "pocket PCs".

Products from companies such as Casio, Compaq and Hewlett Packard will bring colour and stereo-quality sound to handheld devices.

The CE launch is part of Microsoft's revised mission statement to "empower people through great software - any time, any place and on any device", which recently replaced the more modest aim to put a PC on every desk.

Microsoft's founder, Bill Gates, also demonstrated new software to download music and maintain personalised music libraries.

 Microsoft has run into more bad publicity in China, with a newspaper reporting that government departments are being barred from using its Windows 2000 operating system, even before its formal launch in March. Microsoft and Chinese officials yesterday denied the report, which appeared in the Yangcheng Evening News. But a ministry of information official said the government advocated that users buy domestically produced software.

fields.headline: FT site targets European investors
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
MarketWatch.com
FT.com
fields.trailText: A European internet news service aimed at private investors will be launched within the next six months following the announcement yesterday that the Financial Times Group has signed a joint venture with MarketWatch.com, operator of one of America's leading financial news websites.
fields.body:
A European internet news service aimed at private investors will be launched within the next six months following the announcement yesterday that the Financial Times Group has signed a joint venture with MarketWatch.com, operator of one of America's leading financial news websites.

The service will be modelled on CBS.MarketWatch.com, a financial news site in the United States. Its creation is a further indication of the growing demand for online financial news from investors keen to exploit the long-term rise in share prices in technology and internet companies.

Under the terms of the deal, the Financial Times Group will advertise and market the service through its network of European business papers and websites. MarketWatch.com will supply the technology and infrastructure for the deal, the financial terms for which were not disclosed.

The service, funded by advertising revenue, will supply a free news service to investors. It will include internet links to the US service and the FT's portal, FT.com, and its personal finance website, FTYourMoney.com.

The editor, Thom Calandra, will recruit European journalists to staff the service. Although based in London, the service will be pan-European with bureaux in Paris, Amsterdam and Frankfurt. Dedicated services in each major European market will be launched eventually.

Larry Kramer, chairman and chief executive officer of CBS.MarketWatch.com, said the service aimed to give the private investor access to the same information that was already available to City professionals. "There is a revolution occurring in how people manage their money and investments, and the tidal wave that started in the US is coming to Europe," he said.

CBS.MarketWatch.com supplied news to the "exploding market of individual investors" in the US and, with the FT, hoped to capture the same market in Europe.

MarketWatch.com is a joint venture part-owned by the Financial Times, US broadcaster CBS and Data Broadcasting Corporation, a provider of financial market data.

fields.headline: BBC's flu-hit castaways flee isle
fields.standfirst:
Days after start of televised experiment, volunteers quit to nurse illness

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: After the SAS-style survival training, it should have been a mere trifle. But, though they coped with the gusting 140mph winds and driving rain, castaway volunteers of the BBC's latest series have been forced off their deserted island by a bout of flu.
fields.body:
After the SAS-style survival training, it should have been a mere trifle. But, though they coped with the gusting 140mph winds and driving rain, castaway volunteers of the BBC's latest series have been forced off their deserted island by a bout of flu.

Only days after arriving on the Outer Hebridean island of Taransay, some of the flu-struck volunteers, who will become the stars of the Castaway 2000 series, have abandoned their primitive homes in favour of centrally heated flats.

The BBC billed it is as a unique social experiment, building a community in one of the harshest environments in Britain.

The series producers said only those who wished to escape the new millennium and its comforts in order to reflect on life need apply.

Yet, as the flu bites, some of the 35 volunteers have been spotted living it up - in comparison - on a nearby island.

News of their premature departure from Taransay came to light when locals on Harris noticed "well-dressed English people" shopping on the high street at Tarbert, the main town.

"They came in and bought some bread and soup and then went on their way. They were quite young, probably in their twenties," said a shop worker.

Yesterday Jeremy Mills, the executive producer of the series, admitted that some of the worst affected volunteers, including children, had been allowed to leave the island.

They will stay on Harris until their illness wanes, while, five miles away, their colleagues have to put up with the Hebridean storms, which have destroyed a pig sty and blown off a roof.

"This was never intended to be a programme about survival," said Mr Mills. "It was felt that, because the project was at such an early stage and things just weren't up and running yet, it would be best for some of those with flu to go to Harris."

Before arriving on Taransay on December 31, the volunteers underwent training with the SAS survival expert Lofty Wiseman.

It is understood that some volunteers were unhappy at the others leaving so quickly - and this reaction will be broadcast in the series.

For the next year, the 35 men women and children - who include a doctor, teacher and butcher - will be deprived of any 20th or 21st century comforts. Mr Mills claimed the decision to let the flu-struck leave the island for Harris would perhaps not have been taken had the project been running longer.

 The UK looks likely to escape a flu epidemic this year, experts said, as figures published yesterday showed another rise in cases in England and Wales, but still well within the range for the time of year.

In the week ending January 2, 144 people per 100,000 saw their GP because of the flu, according to the Public Health Laboratory Service (PHLS). The normal winter range is between 50 and 200 per 100,000. The north is worst hit, where 171 per 100,000 have flu, with central England on 141 and the south on 134.

Wales and Scotland collate their figures differently, but similar patterns have been appearing. Numbers have doubled in Wales from 52.5 per 100,000 to 128. Scottish figures, which are collated differently, are also rising but within normal boundaries, at 539 per 100,000.

The figures are well short of an epidemic, which the PHLS for England and Wales defines as 400 with flu out of every 100,000, writes Sarah Boseley.

fields.trailText: The incomplete sentence at the end of our front page report, Four in 10 now own mobile phone, final edition yesterday, should have read as follows: "The sheer size of the US and Canada has also meant national networks have been [slow to develop]."
fields.body:
The incomplete sentence at the end of our front page report, Four in 10 now own mobile phone, final edition yesterday, should have read as follows: "The sheer size of the US and Canada has also meant national networks have been [slow to develop]."

In an article about electoral reform, page 2, yesterday, we referred to the pro-PR campaign, Make Votes Count, as being in receipt of £100,000 a year from the Rowntree Foundation. That should have read the Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust, which gives grants to non-charitable causes, unlike the Foundation which confines its activities to charitable trusts.

On page 11 yesterday we were reporting the proceedings of the British Psychological Society's conference in Brighton, and not those of the British Psychological Association as it was wrongly called in a heading and two accompanying reports. Hackney is not a Labour-controlled council, contrary to what we said in a report headed MPs name and shame town halls (etc), page 7, yesterday. There is no party in overall control.

The composition Mystagogia, referred to in our interview with John Tavener, was commissioned by the London Schools Symphony Orchestra for its 50th anniversary season in 2001 (not by the London Symphony Orchestra).

We were wrong to say that Humphrey Jennings's film Fires Were Started was the only documentary in the BFI's list of 360 classic films, page 6, Review, January 1. In fact, there are eight documentaries in all. It would have been correct to say that Fires Were Started was the only British documentary.

The first (near) homophone of the new year, from page 18, Media, January 3: "Stelzer ... is a super-lobbyist on behalf of the media magnet." [Rupert Murdoch].

fields.headline: Labour launches battle for EU
fields.standfirst:
Cook pledges campaign to convert public opinion as Byers hints at early poll on single currency

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday launched a six-month government campaign to swing British public opinion behind the European Union.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill in Lisbon and  Nicholas Watt
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday launched a six-month government campaign to swing British public opinion behind the European Union.

After two and a half years of dithering, the government is finally to take on the euro-sceptic press by aggressively making a positive case for the European Union.

"This is the fightback," a senior foreign office source said of the six-month campaign, stressing that it had the backing of Tony Blair and other ministers.

While Mr Cook was making his pledge to diplomats in Portugal, which took over the EU presidency this month, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, gave the strongest hint to date that Britain could face a referendum on the European single currency within two years.

"Recently, for the first time, big inward investors are telling me that we need to make a decision on the euro early in the next parliament," he told the New Statesman.

Last month Mr Blair and Mr Cook, reading press cuttings while attending the European summit at Helsinki, became increasingly enraged by the negativity of the British press towards Europe and decided urgent action had to be taken. The summit, dominated by rows over beef and the withholding tax, was a public relations disaster for the pro-Europeans.

In a sign of how much the government has come to regret its failure to turn round opinion, Mr Cook said: "Before an audience in Portugal, it is necessary for the representatives of the British government to show some humility on this question.

"In Britain, we have not been as successful as you in establishing the same political and public consensus in support of our role in the European Union". He promised "it will be a priority for the government of Britain throughout the Portuguese presidency".

The speech was cleared by both Downing Street and the treasury.

The Blairite Mr Byers' comments were immediately seized on by the Tories. Asked whether investors wanted a vote in favour of entry, he added: "Yes. They're saying the productivity gains are not always finding their way through because of the strength of the pound."

Francis Maude, the shadow chancellor, said: "Labour's recent attempt to play down their commitment to scrap the pound have been shown to be completely disingenuous."

Mr Byers insisted he was not departing from the official government line that Britain should only join the euro once economic criteria have been met. However, his decision to associate himself so closely with the views of pro-European business leaders indicates that Blairites in the cabinet are warming to the euro.

Mr Cook, formerly one of the most sceptical members of cabinet about the single currency, now shows all the zeal of the convert.

The prevailing view in the foreign office is for early entry, fearing Britain will in the long term lose foreign investment and become less influential by being excluded from key meetings.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, was initially one of the champions of the single currency, but the mood in the treasury has become more cautious.

In Lisbon, Mr Cook stuck to the formula that a referendum on the euro will be held when the government decides the economic conditions for entry are right. "Some in Britain have depicted the Euro as a do-or-die question of political sovereignty. As I hardly need tell this audience, it is not. That is why, in principle, we support British membership of a successful euro."

Mr Cook said the advantages of the EU were obvious to a Portuguese audience, but in Britain they had to be restated over and over again, and that was what he intended to do.

In his first two years as foreign secretary, he made relatively few speeches on Europe, but he is now intent on becoming a leading player, with further speeches planned in London this month.

"It is a case that this government intends to go on making, to win the battle for public opinion on this crucial issue for the British people," he said.

Disputes such as those over beef and tax were inevitable, he said. In a dig at the British press, he added: "It is time to get those disagreements in perspective and stop reacting as if every step towards closer co-operation between members states of the European Union is the same as a step towards a superstate."

fields.headline: 'Definitive' euro poll suffers rapid devaluation
fields.trailText: It is being billed as the definitive survey of business opinion on the controversial question of Britain's membership of the euro, the one that will settle once and for all the disputes about where UK plc stands.
fields.body:
It is being billed as the definitive survey of business opinion on the controversial question of Britain's membership of the euro, the one that will settle once and for all the disputes about where UK plc stands.

In reality it looks like becoming yet another arcane row over methodology.

With the results of previous business surveys clouded by arguments about the representativeness of their samples and loaded questions, the British Chambers of Commerce decided to attempt to pre-empt quibbling about the outcome of its new poll by involving both Business for Sterling and Britain in Europe to help frame the questions.

Announcing the poll yesterday, BCC deputy director general Ian Peters said: "With the support of Britain in Europe and Business for Sterling, the BCC will provide the definitive survey of business opinion on Emu."

Each organisation has agreed to supply a one-page summary of its arguments for or against ditching the pound.

However, the signs were not good last night that the BCC will succeed in its aim of raising the quality of the debate, with Britain in Europe and Business for Sterling backing away from whole-hearted endorsement in case the results go against them.

Anxious not to do down a project on which he collaborated, Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, said he was grateful to the BCC for having the opportunity to shape the questionnaire, covering seven options, ranging from "Britain should join immediately" to "Britain should never join the single currency".

But he added: "It will not be a definitive survey of business opinion because it will only question BCC members, who are not necessarily representative of British business. To some extent the replies will be self-selecting."

Britain in Europe was equally cautious. A spokesman welcomed the survey but echoed Business for Sterling's reservations about the BCC describing it as definitive.

Surveys by the CBI showing a clear majority of firms in favour of the principle of joining the euro have been criticised by Business for Sterling for giving undue weight to the opinion of big businesses. The BCC's membership is more weighted towards small and medium-sized businesses and is claimed to be representative of the national structure.

webTitle: Battle of wills Protesters rally over Cuban boy

fields.headline: Battle of wills Protesters rally over Cuban boy
fields.trailText: Hundreds of protesters returned to the streets of Miami last night - but their chances of preventing the return to Cuba of the six-year-old boy who has become an international cause celebre looked increasingly remote.
fields.body:
Hundreds of protesters returned to the streets of Miami last night - but their chances of preventing the return to Cuba of the six-year-old boy who has become an international cause celebre looked increasingly remote.

About 35 demonstrators were arrested for obstruction as the members of the Cuban exile community marched and tried to seal off the federal court building in Miami.

A few miles away in a safe house, Elian Gonzalez spent another day as a symbol of ideological struggle. He has already endured the breakup of his parents, left his father behind in Cuba, witnessed his mother drown and been rescued after clinging to an inner tube at sea for two days.

Lawyers for Elian's relatives in Florida said they would ask the courts to stop him being sent back within the next eight days. But appeals to President Bill Clinton and the attorney general, Janet Reno, to overrule the decision by the immigration and naturalisation service (INS) were rejected.

Mr Clinton backed the INS but said he had played no part in its judgment.

Ms Reno said: "He has a father, and there's a bond between father and son that the law recognises. We see no reason why that bond should not be honoured."

Ira Kurzban, an immigration lawyer, said: "This is not a tough legal issue. It's only an issue because it's Cuba. There are thousands of kids who come from Mexico every year: are you going to give them all a due process hearing?"

Fishermen picked up the boy six weeks ago off Fort Lauderdale after his mother, stepfather and eight others drowned when their boat capsized.

Normally, Cuban asylum-seekers are allowed to stay if they reach US shores but are sent back if intercepted at sea. But Elian was handed over to relatives in Miami who said they could give him a better life than he would have in Cuba.

The Republican presidential hopefuls George W Bush and John McCain have said they oppose Elian's return.

fields.headline: Vasco put pressure on United
fields.trailText: Vasco da Gama went top of Group B after their 2-0 victory over South Melbourne in Rio last night.
fields.body:
Vasco da Gama went top of Group B after their 2-0 victory over South Melbourne in Rio last night.

The 1998 Libertadores Cup winners were expected win more convincingly against the tournament outsiders, but the result will increase the pressure on Manchester United ahead of their fixture on Saturday.

Vasco secured the points thanks to two quality goals. Highly-rated young midfielder Felipe put the Brazilian side in front after 53 minutes with a spectacular 30-yard strike which flew over Melbourne 'keeper Chris Jones into the top corner of the net.

Edmundo settled the issue in the 85th minute with a tight-angled shot after chesting down a beautifully flighted ball from Juninho.

Romario should have got on the scoresheet when he was set up by a neat back-heel from Edmundo, but the former Barcelona star could only blast his shot high over the bar from eight yards out.

Alex Oliveira wasted a further glorious chance when chipping against the bar after being left one-on-one with the keeper.

fields.headline: Swindon sack 14 backroom staff
fields.trailText: Swindon Town yesterday dismissed their assistant manager Mike Walsh and 14 other members of the backroom staff as part of a drastic economy drive to keep the First Division's bottom club in business.
fields.body:
Swindon Town yesterday dismissed their assistant manager Mike Walsh and 14 other members of the backroom staff as part of a drastic economy drive to keep the First Division's bottom club in business.

Dave Moore, the first-team physiotherapist, was included in the cull, which is expected to trim some £300,000 off the wage bill. Swindon, four points adrift, are losing about £25,000 a week and expect to be £1m in the red by the end of the financial year.

The manager Jimmy Quinn, who sold Ty Gooden and Iffy Onuora to Gillingham for a combined £200,000 this week, said he was given the choice of losing Walsh, a former Bolton defender, or the reserve-team manager Alan McDonald. "It was an impossible choice but I had to do it. I felt Alan has only just moved to the area and it wouldn't be right to let him down, but Mike Walsh has been a great friend to me and has helped me tremendously."

Cliff Puffett, the chairman, said: "We have tried in vain to live with the action plan initiated two years ago, to achieve a play-off position and Premiership status. Now it seems like a foolish gamble."

Peter Davenport, 38, has stepped up from coach to succeed the new Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy as Macclesfield's manager, initially for the rest of the season. His only previous experience as a manager was a month as caretaker at Southport.

"Success would be to get into the play-offs and hopefully make a lot of money from a Wembley final," he said. "Sammy is a hard act to follow but I believe I have picked up plenty from the managers I have played under. Brian Clough gave me my chance [at Forest]; the way he motivated players was outstanding.

"Big Ron [Atkinson] signed me for United and he too could give you a great belief. Sir Alex took over and I had two seasons with him. I learned determination and desire from him."

Dion Dublin will be out for the rest of this season with his broken neck, a setback for Aston Villa after it was thought he would be absent only until March.

 Borussia Dortmund shirts, made by Nike, have been removed from German shops after traces of the highly toxic chemical tributyltin, which can disrupt the hormone system, were discovered in them. Nike was investigating yesterday.

fields.headline: e is for exaggeration
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It was billed as Britain's first e-Christmas, but it looks likely to have been the last for many hopeful cyber-retailers. For, although the volume of retail sales in December hit the highest levels since April 1997 and the most popular internet shopping sites captured their first significant slice of that trade, many wannabe e-tailers simply failed to make the grade.
fields.body:
It was billed as Britain's first e-Christmas, but it looks likely to have been the last for many hopeful cyber-retailers. For, although the volume of retail sales in December hit the highest levels since April 1997 and the most popular internet shopping sites captured their first significant slice of that trade, many wannabe e-tailers simply failed to make the grade.

Figures suggesting that only 1% of credit card sales were conducted over the internet in the run-up to Christmas have fuelled the notion that the widely predicted e-shopping bonanza was little more than hype. The recent sharp fall in the share prices of some of the internet's most prominent names, such as QXL, eToys and Amazon.com, has added to the sense that e-commerce is little more than a speculative bubble, with market valuation of internet stocks bearing little relation to the volume of transactions.

Internet trade is increasing, but not yet at a rate to justify e-tailers' market values. Verdict Research, the retail consultancy group, reckons internet shopping will have accounted for nearly 3% of all UK retail sales in 1999 - worth £581m - and expects this to rise more than twelvefold in the next four years to hit £7.4bn by 2004.

Daniel Gestetner, the managing director of ShopSmart.com - which runs an online shopping portal of more than 1,000 independent outlets - estimates that orders and sales last month for UK e-tailers were 100 times greater than during the previous Christmas and were 50% higher than in November.

What has confused the Christmas picture is that so much of the discussion about e-commerce relates to its potential rather than its performance. That is why a company such as Amazon.com - which started as an online book retailer but has branched out into groceries and pharmaceuticals - can be valued at $20bn on the stock market even though it has yet to turn a profit.

It also explains why "bricks and mortar" retailers such as Dixons see their share value soar once they reveal their credentials in the "clicks and mortar" world.

The success of the top web operators remains patchy, with the most prominent players clustered around a very small field of goods - books, music, videos, computer products and fashion clothing. "The products which are picking up on the net are those which have traditionally been bought by mail order," says Mike Godliman of Verdict, "so we have had the big sites all competing for the same pool of goods." Verdict already describes some sectors of the internet market as overcrowded.

It now looks likely that many internet hopefuls will fail, or will seek protective mergers. Christmas has only served to highlight the deficiencies of some businesses - great website, shame about the delivery. The secret of success in the virtual high street is a pedestrian ability to respond to customer orders and deliver them on time. The On-line Shopping Report, commissioned recently by the web design and marketing consultancy Dial Intern, revealed that in a test sample four of the 20 most popular UK websites failed to respond to customer enquiries, let alone get around to processing orders and delivering them. These shortfalls were notched up by big names such as Waterstones, Toys'R'Us, Virgin-mega and the music retailer CDzone.

The realisation that some of the most promising internet operators failed to deliver in the Christmas period has triggered a wave of selling in the shares of internet companies. In the US, disenchantment set in despite research which suggested that the number of visitors to US retail websites rose by nearly 40% in the run-up to Christmas.

The problems for US internet companies began before the end of 1999, when Value America, which sells electronic and office products, said it was sacking nearly half its staff and seeking a "strategic" merger. According to ShopSmart.com's Gestetner, a wave of defensive mergers is now almost certain in the UK, which is lagging some 12 to 18 months behind the US in terms of the development of internet sales.

"There is going to be a lot of consolidation in the next few months," he says. "A lot of people have been converted during Christmas to shopping on the web, but there have been delivery horror stories because some companies still fail to realise that e-commerce relies on its back-up distribution systems."

Everyone knows it is imperative to post early for Christmas but the same message failed to get through to net shoppers, many of whom were trying to place orders which were impossible for e-Santa to achieve, even though operations such as WH Smith and Amazon routinely operate a 48-hour turnround.

Chris Mole, a partner at PriceWaterhouseCoopers, says the lesson of the cyber retail world is that there are no second chances. It is a dire warning for internet companies as the industry enters a critical period which will separate the successful cyber-players from the web's also-rans.

 Lisa Buckingham is the Guardian's City editor

Daniel Gestetner, the managing director of ShopSmart.com - which runs an online shopping portal of more than 1,000 independent outlets - estimates that orders and sales last month for UK e-tailers were 100 times greater than during the previous Christmas and were 50% higher than in November. What has confused the Christmas picture is that so much of the discussion about e-commerce relates to its potential rather than its performance. That is why a company such as Amazon.com - which started as an online book retailer but has branched out into groceries and pharmaceuticals - can be valued at $20bn on the stock market even though it has yet to turn a profit. It also explains why "bricks and mortar" retailers such as Dixons see their share value soar once they reveal their credentials in the "clicks and mortar" world. The success of the top web operators remains patchy, with the most prominent players clustered around a very small field of goods - books, music, videos, computer products and fashion clothing. "The products which are picking up on the net are those which have traditionally been bought by mail order," says Mike Godliman of Verdict, "so we have had the big sites all competing for the same pool of goods." Verdict already describes some sectors of the internet market as overcrowded. It now looks likely that many internet hopefuls will fail, or will seek protective mergers. Christmas has only served to highlight the deficiencies of some businesses - great website, shame about the delivery. The secret of success in the virtual high street is a pedestrian ability to respond to customer orders and deliver them on time. The On-line Shopping Report, commissioned recently by the web design and marketing consultancy Dial Intern, revealed that in a test sample four of the 20 most popular UK websites failed to respond to customer enquiries, let alone get around to processing orders and delivering them. These shortfalls were notched up by big names such as Waterstones, Toys'R'Us, Virgin-mega and the music retailer CDzone. The realisation that some of the most promising internet operators failed to deliver in the Christmas period has triggered a wave of selling in the shares of internet companies. In the US, disenchantment set in despite research which suggested that the number of visitors to US retail websites rose by nearly 40% in the run-up to Christmas. The problems for US internet companies began before the end of 1999, when Value America, which sells electronic and office products, said it was sacking nearly half its staff and seeking a "strategic" merger. According to ShopSmart.com's Gestetner, a wave of defensive mergers is now almost certain in the UK, which is lagging some 12 to 18 months behind the US in terms of the development of internet sales. "There is going to be a lot of consolidation in the next few months," he says. "A lot of people have been converted during Christmas to shopping on the web, but there have been delivery horror stories because some companies still fail to realise that e-commerce relies on its back-up distribution systems." Everyone knows it is imperative to post early for Christmas but the same message failed to get through to net shoppers, many of whom were trying to place orders which were impossible for e-Santa to achieve, even though operations such as WH Smith and Amazon routinely operate a 48-hour turnround. It is a dire warning for internet companies as the industry enters a critical period which will separate the successful cyber-players from the web's also-rans.  Lisa Buckingham is the Guardian's City editor

fields.headline: Russian roulette
fields.standfirst: The argument about whether Dmitri Shostakovich was really a secret musical dissident has been raging for over 20 years, and now a new book is restoking the flames of controversy
fields.trailText: The argument about whether Dmitri Shostakovich was really a secret musical dissident has been raging for over 20 years, and now a new book is restoking the flames of controversy
fields.body:
Amid all the thousands of millennial hit lists which currently lie ready for recycling from the world's dustbins, the category of Most Influential Music Book of the 20th Century seems somehow to have been overlooked. Maybe the omission is not all that surprising, since there can be very little argument that Solomon Volkov's 1979 book Testimony would have been the runaway winner of the contest.

The writer Allen Ho calls Testimony "probably the most controversial book in the history of music." Few would disagree, even if they would then go on to disagree about almost everything else that the book contains. More than 20 years after its first publication, Testimony - or, to give it its more nuanced full title, Testimony: The Memoirs of Dmitri Shostakovich as related to and edited by Solomon Volkov - remains an astonishingly divisive book. And the imminent publication of a new study of Shostakovich by one of Volkov's principal critics seems certain to deepen the festering divisions still further.

The protagonists for and against Testimony are as intransigent and irreconcilable today as they were way back in 1979. In learned and sometimes not-so-learned articles, in increasingly long and heavy books, and on some of the hottest non-pornographic websites on the internet, the armies continue to fight a sleepless conflict for the soul of the great Russian composer. The venom with which the two sides routinely abuse one another has to be read to be believed.

The cold war may be 10 years dead in the political world, but it thrives undiminished in the argument over Shostakovich. Terms such as Stalinist, McCarthyite, revisionist and anti-revisionist fly regularly back and forth between the battle-lines. Charges of bias, incompetence, fraud, and intellectual dishonesty make up the everyday stuff of the unending hostilities. Even a brief exposure to the Shostakovich controversy makes one yearn for the peace, civility and aesthetic refinement of the Wagner-and-the-Jews debate.

When he died in August 1975, Shostakovich was recognised, though somewhat grudgingly in some western circles, as a hugely talented composer of uneven output, including 15 symphonies and as many string quartets. But he was still widely seen as the Soviet Union's man. Though he had been out of official favour at various times - notably during Stalin's "anti-formalist" clampdowns in the 1930s and again in the late 1940s - the presence in his 147-strong list of works of such compositions as Glory to Our Soviet Homeland, to say nothing of symphonies commemorating the 1905 and 1917 revolutions, tended to cast him in many eyes as an irreversibly implicated artist.

The publication of Volkov's book in the west - to this day it has never been published in Russia - turned that view on its head. Based on a series of conversations with the composer, Testimony depicted an altogether different Shostakovich. This Shostakovich was a troubled, angry, mordant, deeply ambivalent inner rebel against the Soviet system.

On the best of all possible authorities - the composer himself - Testimony asserted that several of Shostakovich's best-known works - including such major pieces as the fifth and 10th symphonies - were little more than works of sarcastic private dissidence against the Soviet system. Volkov's account triggered an enormous response among the general music public and among professional specialists, to say nothing of substantial book sales. It also set off two related arguments which, 20 years on, are still raging almost unchecked.

The first concerned the authenticity of the document published by Volkov under Shostakovich's name. Was it, in short, genuine? The second focused on the truthfulness of the Volkov/Shostakovich account. Was the book, in other words, a reliable source about the composer's life and music?

Two years ago, the musicologists Dmitry Feofanev and Allan Ho mounted the most extended defence yet - their supporters would say the most comprehensive vindication - of Volkov. The centrepiece of their book, Shostakovich Reconsidered, was a 300-page rebuttal of the repeated charges that Volkov's book is not genuine. The critics, says Ho, "have no facts with which to respond to our book". The pianist/conductor Vladimir Ashkenazy, who wrote an introduction to Shostakovich Reconsidered, said last year that Volkov was "an absolutely genuine presentation of Shostakovich's mind".

This year it is the turn of Volkov's critics to produce a heavyweight response. The latest episode in music's very own Twenty Years War is the publication of Laurel Fay's book, Shostakovich: A Life, which came out in the United States last year and is published later this month by Oxford University Press (£25). Fay's book has been coolly reviewed in the New York Times, mauled in the Washington Post, and monumentally attacked by the British writer Ian MacDonald, in an online denunciation on his Shostakovichiana website. Try though they may to move on, the two sides remain locked in battle just as they have been for decades.

No one has done more to challenge the cases for Volkov than Fay. As early as 1980, when she was a relatively unknown recent graduate student, Fay charged in a review article that Volkov had lifted large parts of his supposedly interview-based volume from already published articles by Shostakovich. Ever since then, Volkov's defenders - though only rarely Volkov himself - have fought to exonerate the book from Fay's charges and, even more significantly, from the implication that Testimony was in some important sense an unbelievable account, perhaps published more for political than musicological reasons.

In her book, Fay claims to stand above the argument over whether Testimony is genuine. "Even were its claim to authenticity not in doubt," she writes, "Testimony would still furnish a poor source for the serious biographer." Yet when I met her in New York last month, Fay told me that she is far from done with the issue. "I am going to revisit the authenticity issue again in print next year," she said. "Was it a document with which Shostakovich willingly collaborated and which he wanted published? I don't think it was."

Her riposte to Ho and Feofanov will be published in St Petersburg, in Russian, in a volume on Shostakovich edited by Lyudmila Kovnatskaya. "Testimony is identical in every respect, word for word, even down to the punctuation, with those parts which Shostakovich published during his lifetime," Fay continues to assert. "The basic point is the same now as it was in 1980. We haven't been given adequate evidence that this is authentic. I can counter all the arguments in Shostakovich Reconsidered."

One of the mysteries in the whole argument is Volkov's continuing reluctance to defend his book against the remaining critics. When he appeared at a New York conference last February, Volkov said it was his "first and very probably last" public statement about Testimony, which he insisted was "an absolutely honest book".

Attacking Fay as "out to get me", he claimed that he had not even read her 1980 review. "I don't have a view of Volkov as a person," Fay told me last month. "I am a scholar and I am interested in posterity. I know Volkov had conversations with Shostakovich. I think there are parts of the book that reflect those conversations. But a lot of it is the musical gossip that was current at the time. Testimony does reflect the kinds of stories and anecdotes that were floating around the musical community in Russia. In the end, though, people must check what was correct and what was incorrect."

In truth, the argument about Volkov's book was never exclusively about authenticity. Even without reading between the lines of much of the written material on Shostakovich, it has long been clear that the argument is still just as much about the wider reliability of Volkov's account. "Writing about Shostakovich remains laced with political and moral subtexts," says Fay in the introduction to her biography. "At its most extreme, it simply replaces one orthodoxy with another, reversing the polarities of the old, shopworn Soviet cliches; the true-believing communist citizen-composer is inverted into an equally unconvincing caricature of a lifelong closet dissident."

Fay was more forthright in her criticisms when we talked. "They want to read his music as encoded dissidence," she charges. "I don't. They start from the position of knowing the answers. I start from the position of asking the questions. I don't automatically assume that his 'Soviet' music is ironic. I allow that he might have been serious. The basic thing is that he was a great composer."

Shostakovich's life and work, Fay insists, is "not a black-and-white subject". While many former Soviet musicians, including Ashkenazy, have endorsed the Volkov portrait, she acknowledges, others in a position to know have not done so. The soprano Galina Vizhnevskaya, for example, said that the Shostakovich in the book was not the Shostakovich she knew. Even Maxim Shostakovich, the composer's son, remains equivocal.

Equivocation, though, remains a luxury in this intensely charged argument. During our conversation, I asked Fay why on earth she and her fellow sceptics never seem to have met any of their accusers. Her embattled reply epitomises a continuing cold war-era gulf. "I don't have any reason not to," said Fay, "but not while they're defaming me, not while they're throwing mud at me. I'm not going to be told I'm a liar and unethical just because I think they are wrong. These people aren't really interested in Shostakovich at all."
