fields.headline: Sights unseen
fields.standfirst: They have the stars and the cash... but no release date. Brian Pendreigh on the Brit films that went missing in action
fields.trailText: They have the stars and the cash... but no release date. Brian Pendreigh on the Brit films that went missing in action
fields.body:
Trainspotting had just been acclaimed as the best British film of the decade when Ewan McGregor joined Pete Postlethwaite, fresh from The Usual Suspects, in a cerebral period thriller called The Serpent's Kiss.

B Monkey is another thriller, set largely in contemporary London, from one of the hottest scripts around. It had behind it Oscar specialists Miramax, The Crying Game's producer Stephen Woolley, Il Postino director Michael Radford and a cast headed by Rupert Everett, Asia Argento, Jared Harris and Jonathan Rhys-Meyers.

And then there is World of Moss, a charmingly offbeat story about a boy growing up between the wars. It returned director Hugh Hudson and producer David Puttnam to the Scottish locations that had proved so propitious for them on Chariots of Fire and Local Hero respectively. The cast included Colin Firth and McGregor's Trainspotting co-star Kelly Macdonald. And again, most of the money came from Miramax.

It just seemed a matter of sitting back and thinking about Oscar speeches. But, more than two and a half years after they wrapped, none of these films has opened in British cinemas.

New British Film Institute figures show that, out of 116 British films made in 1997, 33 are still without a cinema, video or TV deal. The total number of British films has risen by half since 1994, but the proportion of unreleased films has almost doubled.

Some of the unreleased films are every bit as bad as you might fear, but not all. The Serpent's Kiss (pictured) is no masterpiece, but it is an unusual and intriguing film that shares the sexual deceits and artistic conceits of Peter Greenaway's The Draughtsman's Contract. It's set in the 17th century, with a budget of more than £10m; and was directed by cinematographer Philippe Rousselot. McGregor plays Meneer Chrome, a fashionable Dutch gardener, in flowing wig, bright yellow coat and huge white stetson.

An elaborate Dutch parterre garden was laid out on boards but they were warped by torrential rain, and there is at least one scene in the finished film in which the ground is seen to bounce up and down. When the film received a one-off screening in Glasgow, there was sniggering from an audience that found it difficult to accept their local hero as a Dutchman. McGregor felt the script lost a lot of its complexity in translation to the screen. "The director just missed the point really," he said after the Glasgow screening. "That was to do with him being very... difficult and arrogant."

The Serpent's Kiss premiered at the Cannes film festival in May 1997 and subsequently opened in France and several other countries, from Brazil to Japan. Hopes of even a limited release in the UK all but disappeared beneath the poor figures from overseas. "No one is likely to spend 200,000 quid on P&A [prints and advertising]," says Archie Colquhoun of sales agents J&M Entertainment. He hoped McGregor's appearance in The Phantom Menace might stimulate new interest in the UK, but it did not happen. The only British deal the film has is with Carlton's digital TV channel, which is unlikely to broadcast it before 2001.

B Monkey shot just after The Serpent's Kiss, though it already had a colourful history by then. Director Michael Caton-Jones left over casting differences with Miramax, who, he says, wanted to cast Drew Barrymore as a cockney. He was replaced by Michael Radford, a fellow Scot who, as director of Il Postino, the (then) highest grossing foreign-language film in history, was in demand.

He recruited Asia Argento, daughter of the famous Italian horror director, Dario Argento; he reworked the script and the female character became Italian. Argento plays Beatrice, a thief with a monkey tattooed on her shoulder; Jared Harris is a teacher and Everett and Rhys Meyers the partners-in-crime she cannot shake off.

Everett describes filming as "a lively experience". It was a shock compared with what he was used to in America. "We went to live in this little, tiny hotel in Cumbria and you could hear everything everyone else said in their bedrooms... There were endless fireworks and arguments and gangs." He responded by retiring to the bar and drinking copious amounts of bitter.

Everett's suggestions of a lack of control are borne out by others who worked on B Monkey. "There were different ideas of what the movie should be," says music supervisor Bob Last, who found his brief continually changing. The film was tested in New York, Miramax's base, with re-editing between screenings. When it surfaced at the London film festival in 1998, Radford described the post-production process as highly "collaborative".

B Monkey opened last September in a handful of US cinemas, then disappeared. It was on the 1999 UK release slate of Buena Vista, which, like Miramax, is part of the Disney empire. But its status is now "floating" and its seems unlikely to get a British cinema release.

Woolley says: "I think it was problematic in terms of the expectations of both the audience and the financiers... It was more disappointing than if it had just been an unknown producer, an unknown director, and four actors who had done a TV mini-series." Nevertheless, Woolley maintains the film is very good and it got some encouraging reviews. He says that, if he had still had his distribution company (Palace), he would have released it. He has lost touch with Radford. "Somebody said he had made a small-budget film in Los Angeles in a bar somewhere, but I don't have the number of the bar."

In late 1996 the Scottish Arts Council approved a £1m lottery grant for World of Moss. The story of a boy growing up on a Scottish estate between the wars, it was based on the memoirs of Sir Denis Forman, the Granada TV executive whose eccentric inventor father developed moss as a dressing for wounded soldiers.

The film seemed a natural candidate for Scottish lottery support. But the Scottish Arts Council was merely rubber-stamping a recommendation from the Scottish Film Production Fund, of which Forman had been chairman just a few years earlier. Bill Forsyth alleged the system was open to charges of "cronyism" and it went through a major overhaul.

Miramax put up the remainder of the £5m budget and World of Moss was shot in Scotland in 1997. The intention was to premiere it at Cannes in May 1998, but the film got caught up in what Steve Norris, head of the British Film Commission and one of the producers, describes as a "long and complicated post-production period".

Again Miramax tried it out on audiences in New York and decided it was not quite right. The first thing to go was the title: the aim had been something slightly mysterious and downbeat, like Dead Poets Society, but it did not work. Miramax opted for My Life So Far. The cast was recalled for extra shooting and testing went on for a year.

Miramax is famous for the time it spends fine-tuning films and Norris is not alone in seeing this as a positive process. Hugh Hudson believes some films are rushed too quickly through post-production: "Chariots of Fire came out two full years after it was made," he says.

My Life So Far was finally ready for last year's Cannes film festival, only to be turned down. Undaunted, Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein staged a charity screening outside the official programme. It came out last July in the US, where it secured some strong reviews and grossed over $600,000. Buena Vista had intended to release it in Britain last autumn, but put it back to May 2000 to secure a slot in the Curzon in London and avoid competing with some major arthouse titles.

It may seem strange that a film with £1m of British taxpayers' money in it should be tested in the US and released there almost a year before the UK. But at least British audiences will see this one... assuming the distributors do not change their minds.

Director Michael Caton-Jones left over casting differences with Miramax, who, he says, wanted to cast Drew Barrymore as a cockney. He was replaced by Michael Radford, a fellow Scot who, as director of Il Postino, the (then) highest grossing foreign-language film in history, was in demand. He recruited Asia Argento, daughter of the famous Italian horror director, Dario Argento; he reworked the script and the female character became Italian. Argento plays Beatrice, a thief with a monkey tattooed on her shoulder; Jared Harris is a teacher and Everett and Rhys Meyers the partners-in-crime she cannot shake off. Everett describes filming as "a lively experience". It was a shock compared with what he was used to in America. "We went to live in this little, tiny hotel in Cumbria and you could hear everything everyone else said in their bedrooms... There were endless fireworks and arguments and gangs." He responded by retiring to the bar and drinking copious amounts of bitter. Everett's suggestions of a lack of control are borne out by others who worked on B Monkey. "There were different ideas of what the movie should be," says music supervisor Bob Last, who found his brief continually changing. The film was tested in New York, Miramax's base, with re-editing between screenings. When it surfaced at the London film festival in 1998, Radford described the post-production process as highly "collaborative". B Monkey opened last September in a handful of US cinemas, then disappeared. It was on the 1999 UK release slate of Buena Vista, which, like Miramax, is part of the Disney empire. But its status is now "floating" and its seems unlikely to get a British cinema release. Woolley says: "I think it was problematic in terms of the expectations of both the audience and the financiers... It was more disappointing than if it had just been an unknown producer, an unknown director, and four actors who had done a TV mini-series." Nevertheless, Woolley maintains the film is very good and it got some encouraging reviews. He says that, if he had still had his distribution company (Palace), he would have released it. He has lost touch with Radford. "Somebody said he had made a small-budget film in Los Angeles in a bar somewhere, but I don't have the number of the bar." In late 1996 the Scottish Arts Council approved a £1m lottery grant for World of Moss. The story of a boy growing up on a Scottish estate between the wars, it was based on the memoirs of Sir Denis Forman, the Granada TV executive whose eccentric inventor father developed moss as a dressing for wounded soldiers. The film seemed a natural candidate for Scottish lottery support. But the Scottish Arts Council was merely rubber-stamping a recommendation from the Scottish Film Production Fund, of which Forman had been chairman just a few years earlier. Bill Forsyth alleged the system was open to charges of "cronyism" and it went through a major overhaul. Miramax put up the remainder of the £5m budget and World of Moss was shot in Scotland in 1997. The intention was to premiere it at Cannes in May 1998, but the film got caught up in what Steve Norris, head of the British Film Commission and one of the producers, describes as a "long and complicated post-production period". Again Miramax tried it out on audiences in New York and decided it was not quite right. The first thing to go was the title: the aim had been something slightly mysterious and downbeat, like Dead Poets Society, but it did not work. Miramax opted for My Life So Far. The cast was recalled for extra shooting and testing went on for a year. Miramax is famous for the time it spends fine-tuning films and Norris is not alone in seeing this as a positive process. Hugh Hudson believes some films are rushed too quickly through post-production: "Chariots of Fire came out two full years after it was made," he says. My Life So Far was finally ready for last year's Cannes film festival, only to be turned down. Undaunted, Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein staged a charity screening outside the official programme. It came out last July in the US, where it secured some strong reviews and grossed over $600,000. Buena Vista had intended to release it in Britain last autumn, but put it back to May 2000 to secure a slot in the Curzon in London and avoid competing with some major arthouse titles. It may seem strange that a film with £1m of British taxpayers' money in it should be tested in the US and released there almost a year before the UK. But at least British audiences will see this one... assuming the distributors do not change their minds.

fields.headline: Time Regained
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw This spacious, beautifully acted, lovingly considered film is a must-see
fields.body:
On first seeing Raul Ruiz's Time Regained at Cannes earlier this year, I was not entirely won over. His monumental rendering of the final volume of Proust's Remembrance of Things Past seemed to me, as a non-Proustian (I confess it humbly) over-determined, fussy, stagey and with a batsqueak of the absurd. But on a second viewing, its qualities flower, and it emerges as a richly suggestive, accomplished, indeed a remarkable piece of cinema. Its formal sense of composition and place is realised with such elegance and flair, and Ruiz has a musician's sense of phrasing and movement, making for a marvellous intelligibility in its structure, and the balancing of past and present.

The performers populating his belle époque include Catherine Deneuve as Odette, Emmanuelle Béart as Marcel's great love Gilberte, and a splendidly florid John Malkovich as the wicked and decadent Baron de Charlus - Ruiz assembles them like a dance company enacting the exquisitely sad balletic retreat from the certainties of privileged society at the end of the 19th century, through France's agony in the first world war, and into the irreversible loss of innocence in our 20th century, this terrible decline gaining in piquancy as we prepare to bid adieu to this last epoch.

All the things often supposed to be "unfilmable" in Proust - the stasis, the interiority of narrative voice and its obscure boundary with external "reality", the seamless interchange of past and present - seem here to be triumphantly brought to the screen in Ruiz's happy inventions of style. Moreover, his final delivery of Marcel's epiphanic "extra-temporal" sense of self is a revelation. This spacious, beautifully acted, lovingly considered film is a must-see.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: It All Starts Today... | Darkness Falls | Vendetta
fields.trailText: It All Starts Today... | Darkness Falls | Vendetta
fields.body:
It All Starts Today...
Retail £15.99
Artificial Eye, Cert 12
****

It starts like this: a desperate mother with no electricity and broken windows dumps her kids on the conscientious kindergarten teacher who has enough problems of his own with burglary, vandalism, obdurate child welfare people and parents too poor to pay for their school meals. It sounds like Ken Loach and hits you with the same worn-out end-of-the-tether raging realism, but the unemployment black spot here is in northern France and the director is Bertrand Tavernier, another expert on social realism.

The genesis of the film came from discussions with Tavernier's new son-in-law, a primary school head; the script shares the credit between the director and the younger couple, and provides the film with immediacy and anger shared with the fictional head teacher, played by Philippe Torreton, a Tavernier regular keeping it in the family.

The film hurtles along, throwing insoluble problems at its teachers and leaving the viewer almost as breathless as its protagonists. Like Loach, it has unfussy documentary-style direction and a mixture of professional and non-professional acting. But there's nothing amateurish about it and for all its hardships and the characters' failures, it doesn't share Loach's sense of helplessness.

There's a sense of joy at the achievements too, and the children involved look as if they were having a whale of a time. If there's a criticism, giving the teacher in a mining area of high unemployment an ex-miner father with bad lungs and a girlfriend with a delinquent son may have been overegging the pudding a bit dramatically. But the film, which won two prizes at the Berlin film festival, should be of wider interest than teachers and social workers and it looks fine in widescreen. Artificial Eye's clear subtitling is a bonus too in a talky film that crackles with exasperation and determination to improve things.

Darkness Falls
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 15
*

In a busy year for Ray Winstone, this was the role that got away in a film that crept briefly and hesitantly into the cinema and feels more like straight-to-video fare. Winstone appears uninvited in a swish pad inhabited by Sherilyn Fenn, once in Twin Peaks as TV's most improbable schoolgirl since Please Sir and here playing the bored wife of a dodgy financier with a £10m debt (Tim Dutton).

Adapted from NJ Crisp's play Dangerous Obsession, Gerry Lively's film struggles to avoid staginess. An interesting premise soon becomes a ponderous exposition in which you tend to guess the plot twists in advance (though not the ludicrous ending). Winstone looks ill at ease here: he's given shocking facial hair and isn't allowed to wear a West Ham shirt even once. Surprisingly, he opts to play a menacing character very quietly when a bit more threat might have livened things up.

Vendetta
Rental
Mosaic Movies, Cert 15
**

Very decent drama from HBO based on a shocking true story. It's set in turn-of-the-century New Orleans where workers fleeing famine in Sicily run fruit and vegetable stalls on the waterfront. When the local police chief gets murdered, they provide convenient suspects and the word Mafia (pronounced Mar-Feea in this locality) is bandied about for the first time in the deep south.

As a result, the video box labels Vendetta a "Mafia thriller" but the film is a thoughtful piece about prejudice, corruption and racism. There's a clumsily tacked-on romance but as a courtroom drama, it does a good job. The resultant travesty of justice was apparently condoned by Theodore Roosevelt, history's great proponent of fair trade. Christopher Walken, the cast's only star name, appears in a supporting role as a behind-the-scenes fixer. Nick Pileggi, co-writer of GoodFellas, is credited as an executive producer, and the director is Nicholas Meyer.

fields.headline: Sleepy Hollow
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: If anything in this camp goth extravaganza scares you, you must be a real wuss
fields.body:
The beautiful boy Johnny Depp returns to the embrace of director Tim Burton in Sleepy Hollow, Washington Irving's American gothic romance, and it is only with the faintly unwholesome, cadaverous look that Mr Burton is able to conjure up for his leading man that we can appreciate his cheekbones to the fullest. Depp is Ichabod Crane, the constable sent by the New York authorities in the late 18th century to investigate a creepy wave of decapitations in an obscure upstate village surrounded by woods called Sleepy Hollow. Here it is that Crane, a sort of prototypical FBI man, meets a range of glowering locals with creepy tales of the headless horseman who gallops around divorcing people's heads from their shoulders.

These Sleepy Hollow worthies are led by the wealthy farmer Baltus Van Tassel (Michael Gambon) and his hot babe of a daughter Katrina (Christina Ricci). Ichabod instantly forms a tendresse for her, but as there is only room for one black goth in this picture, Christina has to be blonde, with hardly any make-up, and looks like something by Millais. Depp plays Ichabod very amusingly: fastidious, scientific, insisting on reason and rationality, but investigating the headless corpses with a bizarre range of dissection implements that look like the weird gyno-instruments in David Cronenberg's Dead Ringers. He is panicky, anxious, and a refreshingly devout coward, often running away from danger, and doing everything short of wearing a woolly hat and apologising for everything straight into a video camera. Depp also does a very funny range of face-pulling winces at each ill omen and bad augury, in which he reminded me strongly of our own Jim Dale, in Carry On Don't Lose Your Head.

Tim Burton's direction and Ken Court's art direction give us a gloomy, hyper-real landscape, the lighting set always at a kind of Hammer-horror dusk, and we are certainly never allowed to forget that this is a film about people getting their heads chopped off. There is a cumulative yuk effect here: oh no, here's the headless horseman again, gallop, gallop, chop, spurt, yuk. Eventually it gets tiring, and if anything in this camp goth extravaganza scares you, you must be a real wuss. But it's worth it for Johnny Depp's feathery, nervy performance as Crane.

fields.headline: Lovers of the Arctic Circle
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw The narrative certainly has got an intense sense of eroticism and sadness, but the convolutions in the end are just a little too baroque
fields.body:
The new film by Julio Medem is an intriguing curiosity. It is a tale of destiny and passion between Otto and Ana, two young lovers who have known each other as children, brought up together as brother and sister, yet who have known the most ecstatic desire and terrible despair as they are parted, ultimately to find their fates intertwined in ways more extraordinary and improbable than they could have guessed.

Medem's film has an arresting story: like the Ancient Mariner he seems to hold you fixed with his glittering eye, and his narrative certainly has got an intense sense of eroticism and sadness. But the convolutions in the end are just a little too baroque, with an unhappy suggestion that the director is not entirely in command of his sprawling material.

fields.headline: Paranoid paramedic
fields.standfirst: New York is all cleaned up but, Peter Bradshaw discovers, Scorsese still finds plenty of blood and guts
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw a pleasing, intermittent streak of broad, black comedy: stylish and well-observed, though not satisfactorily absorbed into what is obviously supposed to be a serious whole
fields.body:
One day a rain came - and it washed all the scum off the streets. It really did come to pass. Some time in the last 10 years, the New York city of Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver mutated into the present cleaner, safer, degothamised town with a crime record better than plenty of other places.

Whether it's attributable to the investment of corporations like Disney in Times Square, to Mayor Giuliani's zero-tolerance policing, or to a US-wide dropping off in levels of drug-related crime, things have certainly changed, and it is at once a symptom of this fact and its uneasy acknowledgement, that Scorsese now brings out Bringing Out the Dead, the tale of a dark insomniac loner on the edge whose job requires him to drive all night past hooting prostitutes, but who this time is not the intense driver of a Checker cab - and Checker cabs themselves are now long gone - but an ambulanceman whose job is to bring help and succour to the needy. Once Marty himself rode in the back of Travis Bickle's cab, brooding creepily about firing his Magnum into a woman's "pussy". In this picture, Scorsese is just the chirpy radio voice of the dispatcher, chivvying the ambulance drivers like an exasperated parent. What an almost Blairite revolution.

The picture is set in the early 90s, the latest period in which a steamy, sleazy New York could plausibly be featured to retain some contemporary punch, and Nicolas Cage as Frank gives his usual drawn portrayal of equine dismay at every horrible little thing the city has to offer. His suffering, slack-jawed face is habitually radiant with sweat and sprinkled with blood. Driven pretty well barking mad through lack of sleep, he is haunted by the memory of Maria, an asthmatic street girl who he failed to rescue, and now seeks redemption - ever a key component of Scorsese's screen theology - in attempting to save the life of a middle-aged heart attack victim: the father of Mary (Patricia Arquette) a dowdy, anxious girl clutching her cardigan about her, to whom he is strangely, mutely drawn.

Riding around town, Frank is partnered with a variety of others of the paramedic freemasonry: Marcus (Ving Rhames) a lascivious born-again Christian, the good-natured Larry (John Goodman) and the all-but-psychotic Walls (Tom Sizemore) who fantasises about assaulting the timewasters and faeces-encrusted winos he has to deal with.

There are, moreover, plenty of typical Scorsese touches, such as a raving nun roaming the streets with a model of an aborted foetus round her neck, addressing the fallen through her megaphone. The problem is that the blood, the guts, the hospital bureaucratic indifference, and the hell-hole of the emergency room do not excite or shock us as once they might, as the whole mise-en-scène is so familiar from TV shows on both sides of the Atlantic: both hospital dramas and the perennially popular "real-life emergency" soft documentary series. They have drawn the sting that Scorsese tries assiduously to reintroduce.

It is possible to sit through the entire film waiting for the killer Scorsese punch, waiting for the bolt of directorial lightning which will set this so-so episode of ER ablaze, and take it to a higher level of horror and insight: the next circle of hell. That coup never comes. But what does come is a pleasing, intermittent streak of broad, black comedy: stylish and well-observed, though not satisfactorily absorbed into what is obviously supposed to be a serious whole.

Every day, Frank fantasises about being fired from the job, and laying down his terrible burden without the responsibility of quitting. But his captain refuses to fire him, claiming that he himself is on the edge of insanity, and barking like a dog to prove it. Finally, Frank's prayers are answered when his ambulance skids and turns over in the streets, almost killing him. He staggers out, laughing hysterically: "Oh thank you Jesus!" Cage's paramedic has come to think of himself as wholly useless medically, but charged with discharging a spiritual responsibility: one whose purpose is to bear witness to suffering and be a "grief mop".

In a faithless world, the paramedic is the atheist clergyman of the urban emergency, showing up with bag like a priest ready to administer the last rites. It is a fascinating idea, performed with great verve by Cage and the cast, and nothing Scorsese does is ever less than interesting. But that whiff of danger, danger to bodies and to immortal souls, is absent.

fields.headline: The Raul thing
fields.standfirst: Many directors have tried to film Proust's huge novel, but experimental film-maker Raul Ruiz may be the first to succeed. He talks to Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: Many directors have tried to film Proust's huge novel, but experimental film-maker Raul Ruiz may be the first to succeed. He talks to Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
On a film shoot at the chateau of Rambouillet, near Paris, it appears to be business as usual for the grand, creaky tradition of the historical costume drama. The elderly Parisian aristocracy of the 1910s is seated for a violin recital: the duchesses in their chignons and jewels, messieurs les barons flashing their Légion d'Honneur medals. But when the camera tracks slowly round the ballroom walls, something strange happens: the rows of seats, with their august occupants, begin to shunt backwards and forwards and from side to side, the sedate room swimming in a drunkenly unco-ordinated Mexican wave.

This is not how you expect costume drama to look, but this is not the average literary adaptation. The book in question is Time Regained, the final volume of Marcel Proust's vast In Search of Lost Time, one of the monuments of supposedly unfilmable modern literature. And it is being adapted by a director not normally associated with costume extravaganzas - Chilean-born, French-based Raul Ruiz, whose name stood, till recently, for all that was most wayward and enigmatic in French experimental film-making.

With a cast including Catherine Deneuve, John Malkovich and Emmanuelle Béart, Time Regained did impressive box-office business in France last summer, causing a sudden explosion in Proust paperback sales.

Ruiz had previously haunted cinema's wilder no-budget margins. He specialises in surreal, elliptical works that resemble inscrutable dreams. A wildly prolific director, Ruiz has made over 90 films by a recent estimation - of various lengths and in various languages, including a recent one in Mandarin, shot in Taiwan. One critic has called Ruiz "the least neurotic of all film-makers"; he gamely takes on one project after the other, tries out the ideas that interest him, then blithely passes on to the next. Tubby, soft-spoken and avuncular, Ruiz comes across as a genuine intellectual game-player, introducing the most arcane references into his conversation (philosophy, theology, mathematics) just to see where the train of thought leads.

He explains the (relatively) mainstream new path he has taken over the last few years. "I had no audience. Not just a limited audience, but no audience at all. I'm still making the same kind of films, but I've found a way to do it without running economic risks." At first he felt this was giving in, but he listened to a friend's suggestion: "He told me that instead of making films that preoccupied me during the night, I should make films about the things we talk about at table."

It's all to do with techniques of time. Hence the moving rows of seats, Ruiz explains. "How is it that if time is a dimension, we never see it in its totality, only in scraps? He grew up on the obscurest American B-movies, by arcane directors such as Ford Beebe and Reginald Le Borg. He studied theology - as a joke, he says, although the point was to take it seriously.

In the mid-60s, Ruiz worked in Mexico writing for soap operas, but only the endings of episodes; to keep himself amused, he would insert chunks of Ezra Pound and TS Eliot into the scripts. "I worked in the whole of the first part of The Love Song of J Alfred Prufrock. I only had to change two words, and it didn't shock anyone in the least."

Ruiz started making his own films in Chile in the 60s. His first feature was the frenetic urban drama Three Sad Tigers, shot with the actors plastered in Vaseline, to make them look permanently sweaty. "It was a Dogme film," Ruiz jokes. "One lens, all hand-held, and certain rules - one was that the actors had to go and find the camera, while the camera avoided them." At one point, Ruiz was given the job of film adviser to Salvador Allende's Socialist party. When Pinochet seized power in 1973, Ruiz was due to start shooting a film about the predicted coup d'état the very next day.

He left the country in October that year, "just when the first film-makers were being imprisoned. The arrests at that point were completely arbitrary and very chaotic - people were being shot just because they had moustaches." Ruiz moved to Paris with his wife Valeria Sarmiento, herself a film-maker, and both established their careers there. He collaborates on the scripts of her films, and she often edits his, but they never co-direct. It's not quite that simple, though, since looking at the ceiling usually gives him ideas for films. Ruiz gives a typically roundabout example. He reads a lot on set; filming in Portugal once, he was relaxing with a theological treatise which proposed that each atom of the human body had its own immortal soul. webTitle: Hollywood star to wed Welsh lass

fields.headline: Hollywood star to wed Welsh lass
fields.trailText: Hollywood star Michael Douglas, 55, is engaged to Catherine Zeta Jones, 30, the Welsh actor who made her name in the Darling Buds of May.
fields.body:
Hollywood star Michael Douglas, 55, is engaged to Catherine Zeta Jones, 30, the Welsh actor who made her name in the Darling Buds of May.

The star of Basic Instinct revealed yesterday on his personal website that he had proposed as the pair celebrated the new millennium at his home in Aspen, in the Rocky mountains.

He gave her a 10-carat diamond ring, and the couple intend to wed this year. They have been together for nine months, but there was speculation of a break-up when Ms Jones decided to spend Christmas with her family near Swansea.

In the end, Mr Douglas joined her at an exclusive hotel nearby.

If the couple were to follow tradition, the wedding would be in South Wales; however, Mr Douglas owns homes in Majorca, Los Angeles, Manhattan and Bermuda. The fact they share the same birthday - September 25 - may make this the big day.

Mr Douglas, son of the Hollywood actor Kirk Douglas, was divorced from his wife, Diandra, 41, two years ago following a 20-year marriage.

webTitle: Sport, cash, mice and Uncle Walt

fields.headline: Sport, cash, mice and Uncle Walt
fields.trailText: Sport, cash, mice and Uncle Walt
fields.body:
The year of our lord 1999 ended very much as it began, with a tidal wave of cash breaking over the grateful heads of Tinseltown's ecstatic studio accountants and washing away their sins. Until next weekend, that is, when the whole hellish rollercoaster ride begins all over again.

There were movies for the kids and movies for adults. There were two comedies in a sci-fi vein, one excellent (Galaxy Quest), the other excrement (Bicentennial Man, starring Robin Williams, predictably enough).

There were three sports flicks - Any Given Sunday, and the limited releases The Hurricane and Ron Shelton's Do it to the Bone - to satisfy those alpha males whose sweetest dream is to congregate around the TV on public holidays and watch underprivileged, exploited men pound each other half to death. In short, there was something for everybody, and the fact that New Year's Day - always a big moviegoing date - fell on a Saturday helped to overstuff the studio coffers even more.

Children made Stuart Little the biggest hit of the weekend. It's a live-action/animated version of the children's book by the late EB White, who's perhaps more famous as the author of Charlotte's Web, in which a porker and an arachnid become unlikely fast friends. (He also co-wrote Strunk and White's Style Guide, an irritating primer on journalistic prose, reflecting his years at the New Yorker - where they're so anally-retentive they hang umlauts over the second "o" in "cooperate".)

Stuart Little is about a dapper mouse who comes to live with a regular American family (if you can count Hugh Laurie as a "regular American" paterfamilias). He has to buddy up to the voracious family cat, but otherwise he's treated as a member of the household. Stuart dresses in natty little 30s suits with plaid waistcoats (or "vests" as they're called here) and generally comports himself like Jiminy Cricket, all of which is a good deal more endearing than I'm making it sound. The Sony/Columbia movie was released three weeks ago and doubled its earnings last weekend, winning the top spot over such strong contenders as The Green Mile and the season's most formidable brat-magnet, Toy Story 2, from Disney and Pixar.

The Mouse House - or, as its beleaguered, much spat-upon employees call it, Mauschwitz - also pushed out its prestige seasonal offering, the Imax version of Fantasia 2000, which didn't make the 10, but scooped up a very respectable $2.2m on only 50 screens.

This is going to get me beaten up behind the bike sheds, but I've never much liked Disney's output in general or Uncle Walt in particular. The saccharine, utopianised Main Street America that underpins his entire output and brand-name makes me puke into my cupped hands.

His union-busting tendencies and his knee-jerk anti-semitism - what would he make of the Eisner-Katzenberg flap? - find their animated analogues in the pimp-like, jive-talkin' crows in Dumbo, and the emetic Song of the South, his 1940 adaptation of Joel Chandler Harris's Uncle Remus stories, which would probably make a great Ku Klux Klan fundraising double bill with Birth of a Nation.

My local supermarket sits on the site of Disney's first real studio and as I walk along its abundant aisles, stacked with fruit and vegetables that are automatically watered by mini-showers every 30 minutes, I think of paternalistic old Walt - proud builder of Disneyland, "The Happiest Place on Earth" - sharpening his knives for another bout with the animators' union.

They say Disney was cryogenically frozen after his death in 1966, in the hope that he could be thawed out when medicine was farther advanced. Not true. A few blocks from my home is the gilded last resting place of the stars, Forest Lawn cemetery (familiar to fans of Evelyn Waugh as "Whispering Glades" in The Loved One), where the Chief Mousketeer lies interred in a mid-price plot.

It's like a Regent's Park of the dead, an oasis of silence and calm at the north-west fringe of the city primeval. I love its aggressive taming of the grim by the kitsch - particularly the two heart-shaped lawns, filled with dead children, called "Babyland" and "Slumberland" - although the "no picnicking" signs have always spoiled it for me somewhat. I've stood on Walt Disney's grave many times. And if the place had been a little emptier I might have done a few more things on it, too, but there's still time for all that.

During Fantasia's original production in 1940, Disney reacted to what his animators had done with Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony by saying, "Gee, this'll make Beethoven!" Igor Stravinsky, on the other hand, called what had been done to his Sacre du Printemps "an unresisting imbecility". The new, grandiose Imax sequel Fantasia 2000, which retains some of the original's sequences and adds seven new ones, tends to bear out Stravinsky's version. The screen may well be nine storeys high, but that doesn't overcome the general sense of airbrushed corporate soullessness that, along with mindless virtuosity and empty spectacle, is the nearest thing the movie has to a signature. Roll on Tex Avery, Max Fleischer and South Park.

Finally, one surprise and one disaster. Anthony Minghella has done a pretty good job of wrestling Patricia Highsmith's The Talented Mr Ripley on to the screen. The novel has frightened off American film-makers for years because of its psychological precision, its interiorised obsessiveness and its psychopathic protagonist.

The last time Ripley appeared on screen was in Wim Wenders's The American Friend (based on Ripley's Game and large, unoptioned chunks of Ripley Underground), played by Dennis Hopper in one of his better performances. (The reason he's good? "Every time Dennis said 'Man'," Wenders recalled, "I said 'Cut'.") Matt Damon makes an acceptably venal Ripley, and Minghella is alive to Highsmith's Jamesian echoes - the not-so-innocent Americans in Europe, the perverted Grand Tour - and the Yves St Laurent-Norman Parkinson brightness of the late-50s Italian Riviera.

Man in the Moon, on the other hand, was universally seen as a disaster. Milos Forman's biopic of the provocative 1970s comedian Andy Kaufman was Jim Carrey's worst opening weekend since the disastrous Cable Guy a few years back, and all this despite the fact that Carrey doing Kaufman is a whole lot funnier than Kaufman doing Kaufman. Will its failure undo all the progress Carrey made with The Truman Show? Do you honestly care?

webTitle: Lubricated Mother Goose up before the beak

fields.headline: Lubricated Mother Goose up before the beak
fields.trailText: Darren's worried about his reputation and wants a word on the subject of lies perpetrated by the media about his New Year's Eve celebrations.
fields.body:
As Rodney said when he belled Monday morning and the noise went off in me head like someone had turned the volume on me new stereo for the Jeep up to 11 and put Steps on, it's a good thing that Darren Tackle has his column. And can use it to correct the lies perpetrated by the media about what went off New Year's Eve.

Let's start at the top. You may recall that Wattsy's annual competitive pulling evening at Dell's was given an extra spin this year by turning fancy dress, with the prize of Mr Chairman's secretary Loretta for the player what the judges - Wattsy, Vic and Bob - reckon went to the most trouble.

Yours truly, 110% professional to the last, lifted the Mother Goose costume from the panto in which he is appearing and turned up at Dell's fully expecting the early hours of the new millennium to be spent examining the lace detailing of Loretta's Wonderbra.

Imagine my surprise, then, when I walks in to discover not only that I is the sole representative of the mighty Greens to make an effort, but that Wattsy has invited the photographer from the Star to record me entrance. Worse, it is not until I has finished laying a golden egg in the middle of the dance floor, with a considerable theatrical flourish, that I realise that I is alone in putting his hands in the dressing-up box.

"It's a bleedin set-up, innit," I says to Wattsy. "I'm the only tosser what's costumed-up."

"No, Dazz," says Wattsy. "We're all in fancy dress."

And he waves his hand at Vic, Bob, Hermann, Darko, the lot of them threaded up as per a normal night out, head-to-toe Armani, Versace and SootsU of River Street.

"Straight up, Dazz," he says. "Everyone's come as David Beckham."

"Oh aye?" I says. "So where's the sarong? Where's the hair all over your face?"

"Subtler than that, Dazz," he says. "See, we is all wearing our missus's under-trolleys under our strides."

Who said footballers wasn't clever, eh?

"Still," I says, seeing his point. "Doesn't rule yours truly out of the running for the main prize of the evening, does it?"

"I'm afraid the prize has already left with the judge's unanimous winner," says Wattsy. "One of the Bosnians."

"You what?" I screams, me beak filling with steam.

"The lad had done Beckham with a twist, Dazz. He was wearing his wife's thong the wrong way round."

Obviously there was only one thing to do from that moment on to make the millennium swing. Now you may have seen the picture in the paper of yours truly asleep in a skip sometime on new year's morning below the headline "Dazza Goosed".

fields.headline: Boots stamps out Dome queues
fields.standfirst: The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The queues for the dome's body zone disappeared yesterday after its sponsor, Boots, said it was not happy that visitors were being made to wait nearly an hour for the seven-minute experience.
fields.body:
The queues for the dome's body zone disappeared yesterday after its sponsor, Boots, said it was not happy that visitors were being made to wait nearly an hour for the seven-minute experience.

The high street chemist, which has yet to pay a penny of its £12m deal, denied it had "held a gun to the head" of the New Millennium Experience Company (NMEC), which runs the attraction.

But Francis Thomas, Boots's head of media relations, said he was "heartened" that a new queuing system had been introduced to cure the embarrassing hiccup as soon as they made their dissatisfaction clear.

"Yes, we have still to sign our sponsorship contract and yes, we are unhappy with the queuing," said Mr Thomas. "But we are not making a link between the two things.

"Although the contract negotiations have still be to be finalised, it is a matter of legal niceties. I cannot stress that enough. We are delighted it is such a big draw. It's a victim of its own success really."

In addition to Boots, three other sponsors, Mars, Manpower and BSkyB, are yet to sign their £12m sponsorship contracts, although Mars and Manpower have paid a small amount.

The Dome needs to raise £194m in ticket sales this year to meet its budget, but with not a single day sold out in advance NMEC executives are considering new attractions within the Dome complex to boost attendance.

Jennie Page, chief executive of NMEC, said the Dome was currently operating at a capacity of 20,000: "This will be increased during the course of the year, dependent on weather conditions and the progressive introduction of more attractions."

The capacity of the Dome complex, including outdoor areas is 35,000. Options being considered to boost ticket sales include using outdoor areas for new attractions, a six-month extension to the period the Dome is open, and offering visitors a reduced rate for return visits.

Problems with the body zone, the Dome's biggest draw, have been made worse because it is the first thing visitors see when entering.

Families who visited yesterday reported that they were able to get inside the body zone within a few minutes, although a spokeswoman for the NMEC admitted that they had "not been mobbed" compared to the crowds who descended over the bank holiday.

She said the body zone queue was now being redirected through the zone's explore area, which is about the future of medicine, health and beauty, to keep families entertained before they saw the special effects.

Ticket sales were soaring ahead of expectations, she said, although the dome would be not be able to reach its 30,000 people a day capacity until later in the year.

News that certain sponsorship money had not yet been paid to NMEC was first given by the government in a parliamentary answer before Christmas.

Boots's sponsorship package of the body zone is supported by cosmetics giants Roche and L'Oreal, which are believed to be contributing about £1m each.

 The dome has failed to generate a feelgood factor, according to an opinion poll in today's edition of the Economist. It showed that 56% of people thought the government was wrong to build the dome. Thirty five per cent thought it was right and 9% did not know. Also, 38% believed the dome had been a success so far compared to 37% who did not. Asked whether they agreed with Tony Blair that the millennium celebrations reflected new confidence and optimism, 39% agreed and 47% disagreed.

webTitle: Breast screening is a waste of time, says study

fields.headline: Breast screening is a waste of time, says study
fields.standfirst:
Cancer test scientists claim lives are not being saved

More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Screening women for breast cancer is a waste of time as it does not reduce death rates, according to a controversial report published in a leading medical journal yesterday.
fields.body:
Screening women for breast cancer is a waste of time as it does not reduce death rates, according to a controversial report published in a leading medical journal yesterday.

The unequivocal rejection of breast cancer screening in a Danish study reported in the Lancet, caused an immediate furore as cancer charities expressed concern that women would stop going for mammograms.

"We strongly urge that the benefits of screening are not dismissed on the basis of these comments in the Lancet," a statement from the NHS Breast Cancer Screening Programme said.

The study in the Lancet re-examined major trials of breast cancer screening that were undertaken in Sweden, Scotland, Canada and the US. They involved half a million women and are used as the justification for national screening programmes in countries including Britain.

Dr Peter Gotzsche and Ole Olsen, of the Nordic Cochrane Centre in Copenhagen, reanalysed data from previous trials and concluded that "there is no reliable evidence that screening decreases breast cancer mortality".

The researchers examined the way that eight trials were carried out and found that only two - in Malmo, Sweden and in Canada - were conducted with properly balanced randomised controls so that the screened women were matched with an unscreened group of similar age and background.

The Canadian and Malmo trials showed that screening had no significant effect on breast cancer mortality rates.

The other six trials found that while screening cut the number of breast cancer deaths there were more deaths from other causes. It is thought that the screened group was slightly older on average than control groups in these trials, which distorted the results.

Michael Baum, professor of surgery at the Royal Free and University College School of Medicine, who helped set up the screening programme but has long been a critic, said: "You cannot have it both ways. If those trials are unbiased, then you have to accept that for every one breast cancer death prevented by screening, there will be six extra all-cause deaths."

He claims that new cancer treatments had begun to cut mortality rates from breast cancer before the screening programme was introduced.

But the NHS Breast Cancer Screening Programme said it expected to save around 1,250 lives a year. Professor Jack Cuzick of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, said that the paper presented a case that needed to be answered, but was sure the conclusions were wrong.

He said there was "overwhelming evidence" that screening women over 50 saved lives.

"Screening detects cancers when they are smaller and more easily treated, cancer rates are reduced following screening and trials have shown that mortality is reduced by 20-30%," he said.

Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said the early detection of cancers through the screening programme meant that more women were spared "disfiguring surgery and aggressive treatments." However, he acknowledged that some of the trials had not been set up perfectly.

Delyth Morgan, chief executive of Breakthrough Breast Cancer, said: "We must not be deterred from continuing our screening programme until we have seen categorically that they are ineffective. What we should be debating is how best to screen women."

webTitle: Case against doctor is unreliable, says QC

fields.headline: Case against doctor is unreliable, says QC
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The case against Harold Shipman, the GP accused of murdering 15 women patients, is based on unreliable scientific evidence, Preston crown court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The case against Harold Shipman, the GP accused of murdering 15 women patients, is based on unreliable scientific evidence, Preston crown court was told yesterday.

In her closing speech to the jury, Nicola Davies QC, defending, said the forensic scientist working on the case had broken new ground. There was no comparable data available, and the samples were taken from the alleged victims' bodies after death, so they could have been subjected to changes.

She claimed that the prosecution had failed to produce a motive. She said Shipman had been a caring GP since the 1970s. "With a list size of 3,100, well above the national average, Dr Shipman must have been doing something right." Shipman, 53, of Mottram, near Hyde, Greater Manchester, denies murdering the patients and forging the £386,000 will of one.

Miss Davies said: "The prosecution case is built on one foundation stone and that is toxicology. Without it there would be no case. Toxicology is a new science and untested by proven scientific methods."

She said the discrepancies in Dr Shipman's records, which the prosecution claimed he used to cover his tracks, were more in keeping with an eccentric practice than a cunning murderer.

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Why I believe in a conspiracy

fields.headline: Why I believe in a conspiracy
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The last time I was in Grozny was in December 1998, when I went out to investigate what seemed to me to be the grossly misreported beheadings of four telecom engineers - three Britons and a New Zealander.
fields.body:
The last time I was in Grozny was in December 1998, when I went out to investigate what seemed to me to be the grossly misreported beheadings of four telecom engineers - three Britons and a New Zealander.

One of the government officials I interviewed was Chechnya's then minister of information, Akmed Zakaev. He is now a senior aide to President Mashkadov.

I felt there were strong reasons to suspect that the Russian secret service, the FSB, was involved both in the murder of the four telecom engineers and the earlier assassination of six Red Cross workers. As Zakaev among others pointed out to me: only Russia had a vested interest in preventing the setting up of an independent telecommunications system and driving out foreign aid workers. Genuine kidnappers, on the other hand, rarely kill their hostages.

This winter, after seeing what appeared to be the same gross misreporting in the west of the current war, I went to Moscow to interview Malik Saydullayev, who is a pro-Moscow Chechen who was first appointed, then sacked by Prime Minister Putin, as president in exile of Chechnya. He showed me footage of the massacre at Alkhan-Yurt, a small village to the west of Grozny where Russian special forces went on the rampage.

What I found in Moscow was a deep cynicism both among Chechens and pro-war Muscovites themselves about the casus belli of the invasion of Chechnya.

There is no evidence that Chechens acting for President Maskhadov or such mujahedin as Basayev or Khattab were in fact responsible for the apartment bombings that killed 293 Russians in August, which were blamed on them and led to the present popular war.

Indeed, what evidence there is points again to the Russian secret service. I understand special security agents were actually apprehended, by local militia, planting another bomb in Moscow but this was explained away as a test of security.

If the Chechens really were to blame, why aren't they still bombing Moscow apartments when they now have far greater cause? Another problem with the Russian version of their reasons for invading Chechnya is this: how could they have marshalled such an invasion force in such an impossibly short logistical time?

As a result of these events, a minor FSB agent, Vladimir Putin has been catapulted from obscurity into the presidency.

Meanwhile, the departing Yeltsin is given immunity from future prosecution for presiding over what is the embezzlement of the century. During the Yeltsin era more than $500bn of the proceeds of state privation and IMF handouts has made its way from Russia to western bank accounts.

The military, for their part, got revenge for their 1994-6 defeat in Chechnya and a strongman in the Kremlin. The most telling comment I head about Putin while I was in Moscow was: "He doesn't mind spilling blood."

Russia's obsession with Chechnya, which is partly to do with state pride but in the last decade has been intensified by the massive oil reserves discovered in the Caspian basin, is corrupting its already morally bankrupt state institutions.

Yet Russia cannot subdue Chechnya. It has been trying to do so for 250 years and never put out the spark of nationhood in the Chechen people. Every time the Russia state weakens, the Chechens rise up to throw off the imperialist yoke of their conquerors.

 John McVicar is a freelance journalist who has specialised in Chechen affairs.

webTitle: 40% of passengers say rail is poor value

fields.headline: 40% of passengers say rail is poor value
fields.trailText: Nearly two out of five rail passengers feel their train service offers poor value, with commuters in the south-east among the most dissatisfied, the first national customer survey showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Nearly two out of five rail passengers feel their train service offers poor value, with commuters in the south-east among the most dissatisfied, the first national customer survey showed yesterday.

The survey's findings from 19,000 passengers are to be used by the shadow strategic rail authority (the successor to the office for rail franchise), in determining the next round of franchises, with several of the 25 train operators almost certain to lose their contracts.

Lord Macdonald, transport minister, also hinted that the findings could lead the government and SSRA to reward better-performing operators more handsomely while reducing or removing subsidies for poorer performers.

Mike Grant, SSRA chief executive, made plain the survey would lead to demands for improvements. The survey found that 41% considered their journey good value; among these only 15% found it very good.

Overall, the survey, carried out for the SSRA by Oxford Research Agency, found a high degree of satisfaction with train services, with 76% of passengers finding them very or fairly good. But the survey, costing £300,000 and based on a questionnaire, covered just one journey on a particular day. Among frequent users the level of satisfaction fell to 64% and only two-thirds found punctuality good.

Similarly, only 11% found the relevant journey poor, while among frequent users the level rose to 24%. Information on train times and delays dissatisfied 17% overall, but dissatisfied 31% of frequent travellers.

The passenger watchdog, the central rail users' consultative committee, said: "From an industry that has received unprecedented levels of public funding over the last two to three years, passengers deserve considerably better."

Mr Grant said the level of overall satisfaction uncovered was surprising, "given the number of horror stories we've all heard". But he felt it would be "foolish to claim everything is OK because clearly it isn't."

The SSRA is to start next month on a new round of auctions for 18 franchises over the next five years, with the emphasis on improving services and removing bottlenecks in areas such as London, Birmingham, and Manchester.

The aim is to promote mergers or takeovers of smaller or poorly-performing operators, and this week Prism Rail, operators of several of the poorest services, said it had received several approaches.

Its London Tilbury and Southend service scores the lowest level of satisfaction among the 25 train operators. But several operators in London and the south-east also perform below the national average and passengers in the region are the least satisfied.

The survey, carried out from September 25 to October 22, excludes Thames Trains and Great Western Trains, as interviews were broken off after the Ladbroke Grove crash involving trains run by those companies on October 5.

The aim is to promote mergers or takeovers of smaller or poorly-performing operators, and this week Prism Rail, operators of several of the poorest services, said it had received several approaches. Its London Tilbury and Southend service scores the lowest level of satisfaction among the 25 train operators. But several operators in London and the south-east also perform below the national average and passengers in the region are the least satisfied. The survey, carried out from September 25 to October 22, excludes Thames Trains and Great Western Trains, as interviews were broken off after the Ladbroke Grove crash involving trains run by those companies on October 5.

webTitle: China plays new bishops against Taiwan

fields.headline: China plays new bishops against Taiwan
fields.standfirst:
Beijing ups the ante by ordaining more senior clerics, hoping to force the Vatican to abandon Taipei

Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Five new Chinese bishops were ordained yesterday at a solemn ceremony in snowy Beijing - against the wishes of the Pope in Rome.
fields.body:
Five new Chinese bishops were ordained yesterday at a solemn ceremony in snowy Beijing - against the wishes of the Pope in Rome.

The five knelt in yellow-braided white robes at the altar of the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, Beijing's oldest church.

After receiving their mitres and golden staffs, they walked down the nave in a candle-lit procession with acolytes, nuns and 10 existing bishops.

Plainclothes police mingled with a congregation that included Communist party officials as well as nuns and priests.

China denies the Pope's right as head of the Roman Catholic church to appoint bishops and cardinals. The five new appointees, like the 70 already holding office, have been chosen by the official Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

The Vatican reacted to the news with "surprise and disappointment". A spokesman in Rome said the move created a new obstacle to normal relations - broken since 1951 - between the Holy See and Beijing.

The ceremony comes at a critical point in secret talks between Beijing and the Vatican on restoring ties, with Rome seeking a trade-off in which it would recognise the indigenous Chinese church in exchange for the right to approve its own bishops.

This is a big sticking point in the Vatican-Beijing talks. At yesterday's ceremony an announcer drove home Beijing's view by declaring that "the election of the new bishops is valid and legal".

Three of the new bishops are aged less than 40 - exceptionally young by international standards. The bishop of Beijing, Fu Tieshan, described them as "intelligent and capable".

By appointing the bishops now, Beijing is signalling that no deal will be struck until the larger issue of the Vatican's relations with Taiwan has been settled.

The Vatican said last year it was willing to transfer its China nunciature from Taipei to Beijing - but without ceasing to recognise Taiwan, as Beijing insists.

Its other condition is that China must not use religion to "interfere in China's internal affairs" - a restriction at odds with the fight for human rights that Catholic churchmen have conducted in several countries.

The Pope is known to be anxious to achieve reconciliation with China, particularly in the first year of the new millennium. He referred repeatedly to China last November during a speech in India, and said Asia was "thirsting for the living water that Jesus alone can give".

Tentative plans for the Pope to visit Hong Kong and Macau were scrapped under Chinese pressure.

The official church in China claims 4m members, but many millions more are believed to worship in illegal "house churches", where worship takes place secretly in locations that sometimes include caves or derelict buildings.

Many of these churches were formed secretly during China's cultural revolution of the 60s, when practising Christians risked being sent to labour camps.

China would like to normalise relations with the Vatican partly so that it can move more effectively against the house churches. Militant Catholics abroad have criticised the Vatican for holding talks that could result in its abandoning China's "illegal" Catholics.

The number of Christians - Catholics and Protestants - in China has increased significantly since the early 80s in a countrywide religious revival especially marked among poorer urban dwellers and peasants.

All the major faiths, including Buddhism and Daoism, have benefited from the Communist party's loss of spiritual appeal. Semi-mystical cults have also sprung up, and one sect, Falun Gong, has so worried the authorities that they have banned it.

fields.headline: Millbank's PR spin
fields.trailText: When the Bethnal Green and Bow constituency Labour party held its policy forum on electoral reform at the beginning of December, I detected none of the hostility you report (Party hits Blair's hopes of PR reform, January 5). Members wanted to know more about the proposals for electoral reform and to be involved in the debate. A clear majority of local members favoured the Jenkins proposals, and even those who were undecided, or against electoral reform, agreed that a referendum should be held.
fields.body:
When the Bethnal Green and Bow constituency Labour party held its policy forum on electoral reform at the beginning of December, I detected none of the hostility you report (Party hits Blair's hopes of PR reform, January 5). Members wanted to know more about the proposals for electoral reform and to be involved in the debate. A clear majority of local members favoured the Jenkins proposals, and even those who were undecided, or against electoral reform, agreed that a referendum should be held.

I support electoral reform on a point of principle. The Commons has to be representative of the votes people cast. But it is equally important to recognise that electoral reform will benefit the Labour party and the people we represent too. The current system allowed Conservatives to dominate the 20th century. If we want the 21st century to be different, our starting point has to be a system that doesn't give the Tories an inbuilt advantage. We need to recognise that it is not for those of us with a selfish interest in maintaining the status quo to decide how we elect the MPs of the future. It's time to let the people decide.
Oona King, MP

 Thanks to Martin Linton (Comment, January 6), we now find that the only basis for the story is an unknown spinner at Millbank and an AEEU official delivering a box containing 1,000 signed identical postcards. A pathetic kind of block postcard vote. Why don't the AEEU ballot their members before trying to hijack party policy? As far as I know, my union, Unison, is the only union to have held such a ballot. This came out in favour of electoral reform, with 707 votes for and 538 against. The tiny turnout in our ballot and the equally small numbers in the AEEU's postcard petition only point to the need for the consultation to become more real.
Stuart Hill
Unison executive member, Darlington

 Where is this "overwhelming support" for our existing electoral system? In Labour party meetings throughout the country in recent months, I have found little other than healthy discussion on how we can make our democracy work better. I now await the report of the party's policy forum with optimism.
Dr Ken Ritchie
Chief executive, Electoral Reform Society

 Many people - not least Liberal Democrats and Labour voters who voted tactically to beat Conservative candidates in 1997 - will feel betrayed if a clear pledge for a referendum is not honoured. John Smith and Tony Blair both said the British people should decide on how they want to elect their MPs.
Neil Sherlock
Farncombe, Surrey

 Before the scaremongering is allowed to take over any further, we need to look back to what the Jenkins report specifically recommended. Jenkins balanced contradictory remits in order to uphold certain benefits of the status quo, whilst redressing its many flaws. AVplus can produce decisive government and retain the important constituency link. In addition the proposals would ensure a more representative result at elections, making each vote count fairly. Jenkins was not just offering a solution which would benefit one party, but instead strove to keep politics near to the people, as it should be.

The public has nothing to be scared of in PR and this has to be reflected in future debates, as we cannot allow this choice to be made so lightly in the expected referendum. Instead the focus should be shifted onto the disturbing lack of public education surrounding this preliminary decision. Labour's programme of constitutional reform has the ultimate aim of restoring faith in politics; if this is to be achieved, we need to have this referendum.
Pam Giddy
Director, Charter 88

webTitle: The truth of Nacods' shameful sell-out

fields.headline: The truth of Nacods' shameful sell-out
fields.trailText: In his obituary of former Nacods president Ken Sampey (January 3), Geoffrey Goodman writes that at a critical point in the 1984-85 miners' strike "Arthur Scargill and the NUM turned away from Sampey's plan", which "sought to introduce an independent element into the coal industry's review procedure".
fields.body:
In his obituary of former Nacods president Ken Sampey (January 3), Geoffrey Goodman writes that at a critical point in the 1984-85 miners' strike "Arthur Scargill and the NUM turned away from Sampey's plan", which "sought to introduce an independent element into the coal industry's review procedure".

Goodman states that Sampey submitted his proposal to Acas, but because I and the NUM wouldn't accept the proposal, "Nacods leaders then decided to settle separately and call off their strike threat".

This account of events is completely untrue. In the autumn of 1984, six months after the start of the miners' strike, Nacods conducted an individual ballot of members and obtained an 80%-plus vote for strike action, a decision which, if implemented, would have been sufficient to save pits and jobs, and win the dispute which had been brought about by the National Coal Board and Tory government.

Following the Nacods strike ballot result, Acas invited the NCB, NUM and Nacods to a meeting, to see if there could be a negotiated settlement. After futile discussions with the NCB, the NUM and Nacods held a separate meeting and agreed a joint proposal outlining their final position. This proposal was submitted to the NCB with a copy to Acas. It would have settled the strike and stopped all pit closures other than on safety grounds or exhaustion of coal reserves.

It was emphasised that if the NCB did not accept the joint proposal, the Nacods strike would go ahead. The NCB agreed to consider the proposal and attend a reconvened meeting at Acas within the next few days.On the eve of the reconvened discussions, I learned that the Nacods leadership had reneged on its agreement with the NUM and had decided instead to put forward a proposal for an "independent" non-binding element within the colliery review procedure, and if this proved acceptable to the NCB Nacods would call off its strike action.

No explanation was given for this u-turn, in which Ken Sampey played a leading role. The Nacods decision, like all sell-outs, was shameful, with terrible historical consequences, leading as it did to the virtual destructiojn of Britain's mining industry.
Arthur Scargill
President, National Union of Mineworkers

fields.headline: BBC aims for quality
fields.trailText: I was baffled to read the scorn heaped on BBC television for its "dismal ratings" and "poor showing" in 1999 (BBC worst hit as digital TV begins to bite, January 6). Surely this could not be the same newspaper that berated the BBC for apparently chasing ratings earlier in the year, and then championed the overt commitment we made to our core public service remit?
fields.body:
I was baffled to read the scorn heaped on BBC television for its "dismal ratings" and "poor showing" in 1999 (BBC worst hit as digital TV begins to bite, January 6). Surely this could not be the same newspaper that berated the BBC for apparently chasing ratings earlier in the year, and then championed the overt commitment we made to our core public service remit?

As we have consistently stressed, risk, ambition, quality and range are most important to us - not pure numbers. From Walking With Dinosaurs to Wives And Daughters; from David Copperfield to the millennium broadcast; from MacIntyre Undercover to the Royle Family, BBC1 has proved itself the channel of big ideas and popular innovation.

ITV has done well to achieve what it has in the last year - but it has done so by becoming blatantly commercial, with big money quizzes replacing news in peak time. That would not be right for us. Moreover, although BBC1's share has dropped by 12% over the last five years, ITV's share has dropped by 16%. And for the record, I don't believe our performance has been dismal over the last year. As long as we deliver schedules of real range and ambition, then I believe that the BBC is fulfilling its purpose.
Alan Yentob
BBC director of television

fields.headline: Test case
fields.trailText: So Pinochet has undergone "medical tests to find out whether he is fit enough to be extradited to Spain" (Pinochet in hospital check-up, January 6). I wonder if asylum-seekers are granted this same right before they are returned to the countries they have fled from?
fields.body:
So Pinochet has undergone "medical tests to find out whether he is fit enough to be extradited to Spain" (Pinochet in hospital check-up, January 6). I wonder if asylum-seekers are granted this same right before they are returned to the countries they have fled from?

I also note he was examined as other patients queued to be seen. My partner's 91-year-old grandmother fell a week ago and had to wait two hours to see her GP, another six hours for the ambulance, and a further four to be seen by a doctor before she was admitted. A lot of people are depressed, but with real cause.
Pat Winslow
Bolton
plf@winslowp39.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Flagging up our identity
fields.trailText: As a Welshman reading Jonathan Glancey's article (True colours, G2, January 5), I was reminded of the various ways we relate to the Union Jack. Like me, many probably associate that flag with some of the worst characteristics of the national character and do not recognise it as the symbol of our national identity. My experience is that when abroad most people recognise that flag as the flag of England, just as they often misguidedly consider the whole of the UK as England.
fields.body:
As a Welshman reading Jonathan Glancey's article (True colours, G2, January 5), I was reminded of the various ways we relate to the Union Jack. Like me, many probably associate that flag with some of the worst characteristics of the national character and do not recognise it as the symbol of our national identity. My experience is that when abroad most people recognise that flag as the flag of England, just as they often misguidedly consider the whole of the UK as England.

Undoubtedly the flag's design is distinctive, but no more so than that of the European Union's simple and inclusive design or the USA's stars and stripes, both of which accommodate an additional star when a new state joins the union. With devolution a reality in three of the four constituent parts of the UK, it may be time for each country to reclaim its own flag and adopt the European Union's flag as a symbol of interdependence and unity.
Prof Glyn Jones
 Cardiff
hesdin@netscapeonline.co.uk

 There are serious omissions from the Union Jack as it has evolved. The early Britons, the Welsh and Cornish, are not in evidence, but that could be put right by the addition of the red dragon at the centre. What is more problematical is to how to represent the most recent new Commonwealth settlers. Why not replace one quadrant with the Commonwealth flag?
Simon Partridge
 London

 "Groovy, baby!" is Jonathan Glancey's verdict on a design for a new UK flag. Let it not pass unnoticed that Robin Derrick's stylish submission bears an inescapable resemblance to the British Council's mark. As early in the rebranding of the UK as 1984, in defiance of the clamour for warm and familiar images of Britain overseas, the British Council introduced this conceptual interpretation of the flag in pursuit of a more modern international image. How pleasing to know we're groovy as well as prescient.
Emily Campbell and Christopher Wade
Design dept, British Council
Emily.Campbell@britcoun.org

 No collective nickname for the English? We Scots, Irish and Welsh have plenty...
Cameron Black
Munich, Germany

 It saddens all true Scots that everyone now starts singing Auld Lang Syne with arms already crossed. It was good to see the Queen doing the correct thing. You only cross arms the verse that starts "And there's a hand my trusty friend and gie's a hand o' thine."
Margot Woolley
Dalwood, Devon
