fields.headline: Utopia limited
fields.standfirst: A bid to convince us that everything is fine
fields.trailText: It is an exciting moment. This country, the Guardian has discovered, is about to be treated to what its devisers call the most advanced government knowledge management system anywhere in the world. Information will wing its way from the government to the people faster than ever before. No longer will they need to consult several separate departments: this is to be a joined up exercise, all departments plugged into each other. The link will be direct, unsullied by the "distorting prism of the media". Faced with such generous offers, who but a cynic could cavil? But cavil we do.
fields.body:
It is an exciting moment. This country, the Guardian has discovered, is about to be treated to what its devisers call the most advanced government knowledge management system anywhere in the world. Information will wing its way from the government to the people faster than ever before. No longer will they need to consult several separate departments: this is to be a joined up exercise, all departments plugged into each other. The link will be direct, unsullied by the "distorting prism of the media". Faced with such generous offers, who but a cynic could cavil? But cavil we do.

For whose benefit, essentially, is this enterprise designed? For us, the consumers? Or for the state-aided ease and comfort and political advantage of those running the show? If for us, one might have expected to see a policy enshrining our right to know - a principle so inadequately served by the freedom of information bill. What consultations preceded the exercise? Cabinet approved it; but did they debate it, or simply speed it through? And what does the civil service make of it?

If it is not alarmed, then it should be, at the implications which pulse through the paper that civil servants - whose right and duty it is not to become mere obedient conduits of government policy - will have that impartiality sapped; will find themselves caught in an exercise appropriate in some respects to a ministry of propaganda. And may not this tastefully named Knowledge Network Project ease gracefully, as the election approaches, into a souped-up version of the Excalibur project which served Labour so well in 1997? Only this time, of course, funded by taxpayers.

Any complacency about what is involved must surely be dispersed by the section headed: Informing parliaments, the public and the world. This distinguishes between information open to all and other information which needs to be handled "sensitively".

What is the latest stated government policy? Where and by whom was it stated? What are the three best arguments for it, and the five best facts in its favour? Which non-governmental organisations are known to support it? Here is information we can all of us joyously share. But what are the most recent developments in policy? What judgments have others made of it? What criticisms have been launched at it? That is where shutters come down. The principle behind these distinctions is not clearly stated. But it does not need to be.

The world's most advanced government knowledge management system will tell the people who pay for it all about those aspects of government action likely to leave them satisfied, likely to make them feel that they live in the best of all possible worlds, while doing its highly professional best to stifle the rest.

All governments play these games. But none before in peacetime can have sought to play them so lavishly, making centralisation a religion, trampling on diversity, doing its best to ensure that from Mr Blair down through the government ranks and into the civil service, we are permitted to hear but one voice. While stroppy people remain in government, while others in the machine find other ways of making their dissension plain, while leaks persist and leak inquiries fail, the grand strategy will fall short of perfection.

But will there always be stroppy people about, or will those who resist the world's most advanced government knowledge management system pay the traditional price? You do not need a distorting prism to fear what might develop once these powers are allowed to a government - any government, even a Labour one.

If for us, one might have expected to see a policy enshrining our right to know - a principle so inadequately served by the freedom of information bill. What consultations preceded the exercise? Cabinet approved it; but did they debate it, or simply speed it through? And what does the civil service make of it? If it is not alarmed, then it should be, at the implications which pulse through the paper that civil servants - whose right and duty it is not to become mere obedient conduits of government policy - will have that impartiality sapped; will find themselves caught in an exercise appropriate in some respects to a ministry of propaganda. And may not this tastefully named Knowledge Network Project ease gracefully, as the election approaches, into a souped-up version of the Excalibur project which served Labour so well in 1997? Only this time, of course, funded by taxpayers. Any complacency about what is involved must surely be dispersed by the section headed: Informing parliaments, the public and the world. This distinguishes between information open to all and other information which needs to be handled "sensitively". What is the latest stated government policy? Where and by whom was it stated? What are the three best arguments for it, and the five best facts in its favour? Which non-governmental organisations are known to support it? Here is information we can all of us joyously share. But what are the most recent developments in policy? What judgments have others made of it? What criticisms have been launched at it? That is where shutters come down. The principle behind these distinctions is not clearly stated. But it does not need to be. The world's most advanced government knowledge management system will tell the people who pay for it all about those aspects of government action likely to leave them satisfied, likely to make them feel that they live in the best of all possible worlds, while doing its highly professional best to stifle the rest. All governments play these games. But none before in peacetime can have sought to play them so lavishly, making centralisation a religion, trampling on diversity, doing its best to ensure that from Mr Blair down through the government ranks and into the civil service, we are permitted to hear but one voice. While stroppy people remain in government, while others in the machine find other ways of making their dissension plain, while leaks persist and leak inquiries fail, the grand strategy will fall short of perfection. But will there always be stroppy people about, or will those who resist the world's most advanced government knowledge management system pay the traditional price? You do not need a distorting prism to fear what might develop once these powers are allowed to a government - any government, even a Labour one.

webTitle: Bush places his bet on tax cuts

fields.headline: Bush places his bet on tax cuts
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush placed his plan for an across-the-board income tax cut at the centre of intensified efforts yesterday to stop John McCain from winning an upset victory in the key New Hampshire presidential primary, now less than four weeks away.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Durham, New Hampshire
fields.body:
George W Bush placed his plan for an across-the-board income tax cut at the centre of intensified efforts yesterday to stop John McCain from winning an upset victory in the key New Hampshire presidential primary, now less than four weeks away.

The rivals for the Republican party's nomination as its presidential candidate were due to clash last night in a televised debate in the New Hampshire town of Durham, with their party's four other challengers.

With Mr McCain surging into the lead in the New Hampshire polls, and steadily eating away at some of Mr Bush's substantial advantages in other states, Mr Bush has picked the issue he hopes will prevent him from starting the primary season as a loser in New Hampshire on February 1.

While polls show tax cuts are low on the list of priorities for the electorate as a whole, they appeal to the Republican faithful who vote in the primaries.

The Texas governor says he wants to cut $483bn (£300bn) from federal tax revenues over the next five years, a plan which Mr McCain - and the Democrats - say would benefit the rich rather than the poor and threaten federal pensions and health budgets for the less well off.

But Mr McCain, an Arizona senator, was in trouble yesterday on an issue he has made his own - campaign finance reform.

The Boston Globe reported that he had twice written to a federal regulatory agency to press for a decision that would benefit a company contributing to the McCain war chest, Paxson Communications.

Its boss, Lowell Paxson, lent Mr McCain his private jet four times last year for campaign trips.

fields.headline: Meaner than need be
fields.standfirst:
Do not freeze the mimimum wage

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Apart from the millennium bug, the other disaster that did not happen was a pay explosion following the introduction of the minimum wage. Remember all those heavy warnings that the introduction of a £3.60p hourly minimum wage would open the floodgates and lead to wage inflation? Well, it did not happen. A report by the Low Pay Commission to the government has concluded that, though it is too early for a definitive judgment, the "knock on" effects of a higher minimum wage on other workers appear to have been minimal.
fields.body:
Apart from the millennium bug, the other disaster that did not happen was a pay explosion following the introduction of the minimum wage. Remember all those heavy warnings that the introduction of a £3.60p hourly minimum wage would open the floodgates and lead to wage inflation? Well, it did not happen. A report by the Low Pay Commission to the government has concluded that, though it is too early for a definitive judgment, the "knock on" effects of a higher minimum wage on other workers appear to have been minimal.

With that opinion behind it, you would have thought the government would have moved swiftly to probe whether the minimum could be raised to nearer £4 an hour without triggering inflation. Instead, according to leaked reports, ministers are thinking of freezing it for a year from April at its present level, thereby ensuring a cut in real terms. They should think again.

A freeze would hit the living standards of the poorest workers, while all around them are getting increases (not least in the City, where it promises to be another bumper year). Future administrations, Labour or Conservative, could use it as a precedent to do the same. It would also go against the spirit of the commission's step-by-step approach to raising the minimum wage, which led it to recommend an increase to £3.70 later this year (which the government did not agree to).

There are two other reasons for raising the minimum wage now. First, if it is going to lead to lost jobs, then this is a good (or less bad) time for this to happen when unemployment is still dropping and labour shortages may soon be appearing which could absorb displaced workers.

Second, it is an almost obscene time to permit a fall in the real value of the minimum wage when the treasury is running into an unexpectedly large budget surplus. If we cannot look after poorer workers in these circumstances, when can we ever hope to do so?

webTitle: Nato under fire for choice of targets in Kosovo

fields.headline: Nato under fire for choice of targets in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato's conduct of the Kosovo conflict breached international law, according to a leading human rights group which is drawing up detailed reports to be submitted to the war crimes tribunal in the Hague.
fields.body:
Nato's conduct of the Kosovo conflict breached international law, according to a leading human rights group which is drawing up detailed reports to be submitted to the war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Human Rights Watch, a New York based organisation, will accuse Nato of deliberately bombing Serbia's civil infrastructure. It will strongly criticise the use of cluster bombs and allege that Nato bombs killed significantly more civilians than the number claimed by the alliance.

Targets chosen by Nato were "disproportionate and should be found violations of international humanitarian law", Kenneth Roth, the group's executive director, said yesterday. Electricity grids, oil refineries and radio and television stations are among the examples.

The report will also attack the use by US and British aircraft of thousands of cluster bombs, many of which lie unexploded in Kosovo, where the group says they are still killing or maiming two civilians a day. Their failure rate is officially admitted to be at least 5%.

Human Rights Watch estimates that about 600 Serbian civilians were killed by Nato bombing, three times as many as the Pentagon has admitted but substantially fewer than the 2,000 claimed by Belgrade.

Though the group does not expect any Nato leader to be charged with a criminal offence, the Hague tribunal is obliged to scrutinise all relevant submissions.

"It is incumbent on the tribunal to continue its mandate, which covers all the participants in armed conflict in the former Yugoslavia," Paul Risley, spokesman for the chief war crimes prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, said yesterday.

But he made clear that a formal investigation into Nato actions during the Kosovo conflict was unlikely.

The tribunal has already been caught up in a controversy over a separate dossier sent to it last year by group of international lawyers led by Michael Mandel, a law professor at York university in Toronto, Canada.

The dossier accused Nato of "grave violations of international humanitarian law", including "wilful killing". It referred to civilian deaths from Nato bombing raids, including the mistaken attack on a hospital in Nis in central Serbia.

"This is a historic opportunity to demonstrate the even-handedness of international justice," Professor Mandel said after delivering the dossier last year.

Other international lawyers argued that such statements could be counter-productive and place the tribunal in an untenable position. "The even-handedness we expect of the chief prosecutor does not mean treating allegations equally," Diane Orentlicher, director of the war crimes research office at the American university in Washington, said yesterday.

She told the Guardian that while "problematic aspects" of Nato's conduct merited examination, it was "plainly inappropriate for Del Ponte to focus on shortcomings in Nato's performance when the tribunal can scarcely begin to address the atrocious crimes it was created to prosecute".

The Pentagon argues that attacks on Serbian civil infrastructure hastened the end of the war and thus the Serbs' repression of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

 Nato videos of its bombing of a passenger train on a bridge in Yugoslavia last spring show that it was travelling at three times the normal speed, bolstering the impression that hitting the train was unavoidable, the German newspaper Frankfurter Rundschau reported yesterday.

Nato officials said at the time that the train appeared on the bridge so fast that there was no time to redirect the missiles. At least 14 people were killed in the air strike near the Serb town of Grdelicka on April 12.

webTitle: Birth stress blamed for infant tears

fields.headline: Birth stress blamed for infant tears
fields.trailText: Parents who suspected their babies cried a lot and were difficult to soothe as a result of a forceps delivery may be right, research from a leading maternity hospital shows.
fields.body:
Parents who suspected their babies cried a lot and were difficult to soothe as a result of a forceps delivery may be right, research from a leading maternity hospital shows.

A study published in this week's Lancet suggests that babies' responses to pain are conditioned by their earliest exposures to it. Those who endured the most stress during childbirth were most likely to cry for longer and be difficult to comfort after routine inoculation at the age of eight weeks.

Alyx Taylor and colleagues from the foetal and neonatal stress research centre at the Imperial School of Medicine, Queen Charlotte's and Chelsea hospital, west London, studied the responses of 76 healthy, full-term babies. Forty-six were born by vaginal delivery, 20 had a forceps or ventouse (suction) delivery and 10 by caesarian.

The researchers measured the stress hormone cortisol in the babies' saliva before and after the injection. Stress levels rose highest and the crying lasted longest in those babies who had suffered the most traumatic births - forceps or ventouse delivery. The least stressed were those born by caesarian section.

The results "support the widely held but anecdotal view that babies born by assisted delivery can continue to be difficult to soothe".

fields.headline: Drugs tsar praises Oasis star
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The government drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, yesterday praised the Oasis star Noel Gallagher for his "change of heart" over hard drugs.
fields.body:
The government drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, yesterday praised the Oasis star Noel Gallagher for his "change of heart" over hard drugs.

Mr Hellawell, the anti-drugs co-ordinator who took up his post two years ago this week, said Gallagher had shown "a much more responsible approach, telling about his negative experiences."

The Oasis songwriter and guitarist revealed this week that a cocaine habit brought him close to physical breakdown. In 1997, Mr Hellawell described him as totally irresponsible for saying that taking drugs was as normal as having a cup of tea.

Mr Hellawell said any help that Gallagher could give to dissuade young people from getting involved in drugs would be welcome, adding: "Sadly, I don't think there is ever going to be a time when there are no drugs."

He was speaking at the London Boat Show where he launched a customs and excise onslaught on drug smuggling. A telephone hotline launched last July has received more than 14,000 calls providing customs with vital information on the smuggling of drugs, alcohol and tobacco.

webTitle: Cyclists left standing by firms' cars

fields.headline: Cyclists left standing by firms' cars
fields.trailText: Walking or cycling to work may be good for your health and the environment, but it does nothing for your self image or status in the office, according to research.
fields.body:
Walking or cycling to work may be good for your health and the environment, but it does nothing for your self image or status in the office, according to research.

Even if people were near enough for it to be feasible to walk, they would rather show off the company car. Cycling exposed the rider to the elements and to mud, and put off those who believed up-and-coming employees should be seen wearing smart clothes in the office.

Rachel Goodman of Staffordshire university surveyed attitudes at a local hospital, a city council, a further education college, and a military establishment - each a public body where the status of company car and dress code were important.

Exhortations to use alternative and sustainable transport had to overcome the culture of the workplace. "It is all to do with workplace image and dress code," she said yesterday. "People made all sorts of excuses, like the weather, about not walking, even less than a mile; but when questioned it was their self image that mattered."

If commuting patterns were to be changed, parking restrictions and removal of company cars would be a necessary first step, she concluded.

Another researcher from Staffordshire, Roger Tolley, found similar problems with attitudes to using a bicycle for work. Although people liked cycling, it had an image problem: what was needed - as well as safe secure routes, and somewhere secure to store the bike during the day - was a revamp that made cycling sexy.

webTitle: For sale: the race for the White House

fields.headline: For sale: the race for the White House
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: This year's US presidential election is in danger of being bought in advance by powerful business corporations which expect government favours in return, according to a new "who owns who" of Washington politics published yesterday by election watchdogs.
fields.body:
This year's US presidential election is in danger of being bought in advance by powerful business corporations which expect government favours in return, according to a new "who owns who" of Washington politics published yesterday by election watchdogs.

According to the Centre for Public Integrity, all leading candidates in both major parties have been compromised by their links with big business, including Bill Bradley and John McCain, who are campaigning on promises to clean up US elections.

In its new book, The Buying of the President 2000, the centre claims that corporate "investment" in political campaigns had proved so effective in influencing candidates' future policies in recent years that US businesses were pouring more cash into the process than ever before.

It noted that the Republican frontrunner George W Bush raised $37m (£22.5m) in his first four months' campaigning - more than either Bill Clinton or Bob Dole raised during the entire 1996 election. Mr Bush has now amassed more than $67m, nearly triple the previous record, held by Mr Clinton.

Charles Lewis, the chief author, said: "Our democracy is now sponsored by the vested economic interests who want favours from their elected officials. The candidates and their political parties are proficient at obscuring the sources and even the amounts of their campaign cash."

The book was based on analysis of federal election commission records and the financial disclosures made by the candidates. Peter Eisner, the centre's managing director, said Mr Bradley and Mr McCain, both standing on "clean hands tickets", were as guilty of exchanging cash donations for political influence as their "establishment" rivals.

Mr Eisner said Mr Bradley, as a senator for New Jersey, supported 45 special bills aimed at offering export aid and tariff reductions for companies producing highly toxic chemicals. During that same period, chemical firms were among the biggest donors to his election fund.

Most of Mr Bradley's biggest donors have been New York finance firms, whom he helped as a senator by defending corporate tax breaks - in sharp contrast to his current calls to end "corporate welfare".

Senator McCain is accused of improperly trying to influence the federal communications commission in favour of a major contributor to his campaign, Paxson Communications. The book said the Arizona senator intervened to stop the expansion of a national park in Nevada - which benefited a property development company, Del Webb, his seventh biggest career patron.

The vice-president, Al Gore, lobbied hard to arrange the sale of federal land to the Occidental oil company, a major contributor to both his and his father's political campaigns, despite his vocal support of environmental issues.

The list of Mr Bush's donors reads like a "who's who" of the Texas oil industry. While governor, he backed pollution laws which relied on voluntary compliance by oil companies.

The book also notes one Democratic party supporter who donated $330,000 and then asked for a job in the White House for a friend's daughter. Her name? Monica Lewinsky.

webTitle: Stolen £3m Cezanne was not insured by museum

fields.headline: Stolen £3m Cezanne was not insured by museum
fields.trailText: The £3m Cézanne stolen by a cat burglar in Oxford on New Year's Eve was not insured, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The £3m Cézanne stolen by a cat burglar in Oxford on New Year's Eve was not insured, it emerged yesterday.

Oxford university confirmed that its Ashmoleum musuem, like many leading collections, did not insure itself against theft because of the premiums.

Auvers-sur-Oise, painted by the father of Fauvism around 1880, was stolen from the Hindley Smith gallery during the height of the millennium festivities. The thief used a smoke canister to obscure security cameras before cutting the painting from its frame and escaping across the roof.

Julian Radcliffe, of the Art Loss Register, said it was working with police forces worldwide to trace the painting. The register was set up by museums, dealers and police to monitor art thefts, making it impossible to sell on legitimately a stolen work.

"Many local authority museums insure their collections, but there is an agreement among the national institu tions not to insure," said Mr Radcliffe. "Museums here are much less well funded than they are in the US, where insurance is the rule, so they cannot be expected to shoulder the extra burden."

Only paintings and sculptures imported into Britain for exhibitions tend to be insured, when museums can apply for cover under a special government indemnity scheme.

Detectives believe the painting may have been stolen to order for a private collector. But Mr Radcliffe doubted that the thief would get more than a fraction of the painting's worth. "What the register has succeeded in doing is pushing down the price thieves can expect for the stolen work by making it impossible for it to appear on the market.

"If someone can get only £20,000 for something worth £2m, then it becomes much less attractive to steal."

The Ashmolean's director has described the theft as a "shattering blow" to the museum, which is best known for its drawings by Raphael and Michelangelo.

fields.headline: Police want drink-drive limit cut
fields.trailText: The Association of Chief Police Officers has renewed calls for more powers to combat drink-driving even though figures showed there were 10% fewer positive breath tests during the Christmas and new year period.
fields.body:
The Association of Chief Police Officers has renewed calls for more powers to combat drink-driving even though figures showed there were 10% fewer positive breath tests during the Christmas and new year period.

It called for the drink-drive limit to be reduced and for officers to be given a new power to stop "hardcore" offenders.

Ken Williams, vice-chairman of the Acpo traffic committee, said: "While 10% fewer people have committed the offence this year than they did last year we have still got a significant problem with the number of people prepared to drink and drive."

Between December 18 and January 2, 972 people were arrested for drink-driving in England and Wales. Nearly 15,000 breath tests were administered.

Nine people a week die on the roads as a result of drink-driving, said Mr Williams, which meant that police officers had to remain vigilant and maintain pressure on offenders.

"The arguments are there to reduce the legal limit [in a blood test] from 80 to 50 mgs," said Mr Williams, chief constable of Norfolk. "Something like 10 countries in Europe operate at that level."

He also called for stronger powers to stop persistent offenders, saying that this would send a "powerful psychological message".

webTitle: Top cops give lie to 'plodding' TV image

fields.headline: Top cops give lie to 'plodding' TV image
fields.trailText: They are widely portrayed on television as stuffed shirt bureaucrats, more preoccupied with their budgets, procedure and their golf handicaps than maverick members of their force.
fields.body:
They are widely portrayed on television as stuffed shirt bureaucrats, more preoccupied with their budgets, procedure and their golf handicaps than maverick members of their force.

But, in reality, police superintendents bear little resemblance to plodding dinosaurs who short-sightedly badger the likes of detective officers Morse and Frost in the TV dramas.

They are more likely to resemble The Bill's wily Chief Superintendent Charles Brownlow, it was revealed at the conference.

David Wigfield, an occupational psychologist with Sussex police unveiled research into 109 superintendents in 31 police forces across England and Wales.

The psychologist, who is studying for a PhD at Sussex university, questioned 1,200 officers to assess how the superintendents were perceived by their colleagues.

His findings suggested the senior officers were self-aware, decisive, fairly in touch with their officers, well-regarded and hands-on.

Mr Wigfield said television dramas such as Morse and A Touch of Frost focused on a hero who was invariably misunderstood by his superior - "usually a dinosaur who is perceived as out of touch".

But they shared a similarity with their TV counterparts, Chief Superintendent Strange in Morse, and Superintendent Mullett in A Touch of Frost. "They are not seen as particularly good at motivating people."

The senior television police officer who most reflected reality was Chief Superintendent Brownlow, the highly conventional but hands-on boss in ITV's The Bill.

webTitle: GM ban is extended by Tesco

fields.headline: GM ban is extended by Tesco
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Tesco has banned its fresh fruit and vegetable suppliers from growing food on sites used previously for trials of genetically modified crops.
fields.body:
Tesco has banned its fresh fruit and vegetable suppliers from growing food on sites used previously for trials of genetically modified crops.

The supermarket chain said yesterday that it needed to be able to assure customers no GM material has come into contact with its produce. Its decision was welcomed by eco-campaigners Greenpeace, but criticised by the government for being a marketing ploy.

Other supermarkets may consider following Tesco's lead, but it remains to be seen whether farmers are deterred from volunteering for trials of GM oilseed rape, beet and maize; most involved so far are cereal producers.

Tesco has already pledged not to stock any GM crops, and is also trying to ensure that all feed for animals that supply its meats is GM free.

It is probably the biggest single user of produce in Britain, with 130 large suppliers. Justifying its latest step, Tesco said that some scientists had raised concerns about DNA and toxins in post-harvest waste from GM trial sites remaining in the soil and changing its ecology. A spokesman said: "We are not telling farmers to not get involved with trials but saying, if they do, make sure it is separate and don't grow a Tesco crop on top of them."

Peter Melchett, the Greenpeace executive director, said the announcement was a blow to government efforts to find farmers willing to host GM crop trials. The GM unit at the cabinet office denied it would be a significant deterrent, and said: "This is a marketing ploy. Tesco has admitted there is no scientific foundation for the policy."

webTitle: EasyJet to launch cut-price car hire

fields.headline: EasyJet to launch cut-price car hire
fields.standfirst: EasyJet website
fields.trailText: The founder of the cut-price airline EasyJet is to bring his no-frills approach to the car rental market, which he claims is working against the interests of the customer.
fields.body:
The founder of the cut-price airline EasyJet is to bring his no-frills approach to the car rental market, which he claims is working against the interests of the customer.

Stelios Haji-Ioannou's new venture will espouse the now familiar aspects of his airline and internet cafe businesses, from low prices to an unconventional approach to syntax - the car hire firm will be called EasyCarRental.

The company will operate from bases near airports served by EasyJet - probably Luton, Glasgow or Edinburgh, Barcelona, Nice and Amsterdam. Prices will start at £9 a day, far lower than those of the main existing hire companies.

To reduce overheads, customers will have to book online. All the firm's cars will be of a similar type, such as a Renault Megane or a Peugeot 206, and the fleet will operate from low-rent lots outside the airport compounds.

Mr Haji-Ioannou is in the final stages of talks with car manufacturers, but intends to have the company in operation by April. Initially, he hopes to run a fleet of 5,000 vehicles. Car rental companies are often criticised for complicated and expensive tariffs. One company, Sixt, has attempted to attract new customers with promises of lower prices, but the market is still dominated by large firms such as Avis, Hertz and Europe Car.

Mr Haji-Ioannou believes that he can smash what he regards as a cartel. "We are entering a market where prices generally start at £20, so we will be significantly cheaper than the big boys," he said yesterday.

A spokesman for EasyGroup said: "The car hire industry is a complacent cartel. At airports, all the car hire desks are together, all the sales agents are chums. It's a stitch-up which should be busted."

The biggest car rental group in Britain, Avis, said it would monitor EasyGroup's venture, but stressed the services were fundamentally different.

A spokesman said: "We are offering a full service. With us, you get to choose your car, you get to choose your pick-up and drop-off point, you get to choose what insurance you want. What we will be competing with is a one-car, one-price, one-model service operating from a few cities."

webTitle: Condon cure for Met job crisis

fields.headline: Condon cure for Met job crisis
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police should consider offering short-term contracts to potential recruits, including graduates, to help the force tackle its recruitment crisis, the outgoing commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police should consider offering short-term contracts to potential recruits, including graduates, to help the force tackle its recruitment crisis, the outgoing commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, said yesterday.

In his last full interview before retiring at the end of the month, Sir Paul said the force should look at the way the FBI or the Singapore police lures talented people into service on fixed term contracts which do not tie them into a lifetime's service.

Although he was careful not to say he supported use of such contracts, Sir Paul made it clear the option should be explored. He said changes in the job market and perceptions about a career in the police had detered people from joining in recent years.

"The prospect of being locked into the police for 30 years has deterred good young people that would otherwise have come into policing."

Sir Paul said he did not want to create a two-tier service, and that high-pay short contracts should not just be available to graduates. He thought introduction of short-term contracts might help to recruit more black and Asian officers.

He said potential recruits did not want to be penalised by the present terms and conditions, which include officers not being eligible for pension provision until they have completed many years' service.

Reflecting on his seven years in charge, Sir Paul admitted the Met had been close to "meltdown" in terms of morale in the aftermath of the Macpherson report on the Stephen Lawrence case.

Sir Paul said he did not resign after publication of the Macpherson report because he felt he was the best person to lead "a battered and bewildered" force into the 21st century.

He said the Met could be proud of many achievements during his time in charge, and claimed it was now the world's least corrupt major police force, thanks to a purge which had led to 70 officers being charged.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hindley back in jail
fields.body:
Hindley back in jail

Moors murderer Myra Hindley was yesterday back in prison after being taken to hospital for the second time in 10 days.

Hindley, 57, spent the night at the West Suffolk hospital, Bury St Edmunds, and was seen by two doctors before being discharged. She was taken ill at Highpoint prison near Bury St Edmunds late yesterday.

Pensioner's remains found

A body found on a town centre ring road's central reservation was yesterday identified as that of a pensioner who went missing more than three years ago.

West Midlands police said the remains, found by contractors involved in road-widening work in Wolverhampton were those of widow Kathleen Childerley. Mrs Childerley, then 64, went missing from a local nursing home in May 1996.

Small claims cost cut

The cost of taking a small claim to court is to be slashed, the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, said yesterday.

Lord Irvine said he was scrapping an £80 "allocation" fee for disputes involving sums of £1,000 or less.

Prison rejects baby plea

An 18-year-old mother in Holloway prison, north London, could be separated from her baby today.

The prison's admissions board yesterday upheld a decision to bar the inmate from the Holloway mother and baby unit on the grounds that her "volatile behaviour" would place the child at risk.

Disruption at French ports

Cross-channel travellers and British lorry drivers are expected to face disruption from a new strike by French truckers starting on Monday.

The French workers will be blocking borders and ports in protest against diesel prices and working hours.

The flame that died

Birmingham was left red faced yesterday when it was revealed that the city's £72,000 flame of hope had run out of gas.

The flame was supposed to stay lit throughout this year after being donated to the city by Birmingham Churches Together, an umbrella group representing 620 Christian churches.

Ending with a whimper

A noise machine installed by the BBC after accountants complained their new office was too quiet has been removed after staff decided it had no effect.

The machine, which continually played low level taped chit-chat, was installed in the White City finance department in west London at a cost of more than £2,000 after accountants said their office was so silent it was hard to concentrate. Jamie Wilson

webTitle: Protesters clash with police after killer denied bail

fields.headline: Protesters clash with police after killer denied bail
fields.standfirst:
IRA man wins right to challenge extradition attempt

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Republicans clashed with police in Dublin last night as they tried to halt a convoy returning an IRA murderer, Angelo Fusco, to prison after a high court judge dramatically rejected his appeal for bail.
fields.body:
Republicans clashed with police in Dublin last night as they tried to halt a convoy returning an IRA murderer, Angelo Fusco, to prison after a high court judge dramatically rejected his appeal for bail.

The protesters exchanged punches with Gardai as the officers struggled to secure a way through for the three car convoy taking Fusco, 43, to Castlerea prison in Co Roscommon. The low security jail houses the seven other IRA terrorists still held in the republic.

At the hastily arranged hearing, Fusco, a member of the IRA's M-60 gang, did however win the right to challenge attempts to return him to Northern Ireland, where he was jailed in his absence for 30 years after being convicted of the murder of an SAS captain in north Belfast in 1980. His lawyers argued yesterday that the changed political climate meant that extraditing him would be a "futile exercise".

Mr Justice Joseph Finnegan, whose decision three days ago prevented Gardai handing Fusco back into RUC custody as they were driving him north, rejected the fugitive's plea for bail. Police had expected privately it would be granted.

Martin Ferris, a Sinn Fein executive member, last night hinted that this week's furore over Fusco could affect the IRA's imminent decision on whether to decommission its weapons. An IRA representative is expected to hold a second meeting today with John de Chastelain, the general who chairs the decommissioning body.

After calming the fighting at the high court, where one man was arrested, Mr Ferris spoke of enormous anger among republicans. He called on the Irish government to halt the extradition, and said it was undermining the confidence built around the Good Friday agreement.

He said: "The man has spent 12 years in prison. It doesn't make sense at this time for the Dublin government to attempt to extradite Angelo Fusco back to the Six Counties when the prisoners are now being released. There is no logical understanding in it."

Fusco was arrested late on Monday after offering a false driving licence when he was stopped at a routine police checkpoint close to his family home in Tralee, Co Kerry. He told the court yesterday that he used the counterfeit licence to give the traffic constable who recognised him an excuse to let him go.

His arrest and the move to extradite him on existing warrants are embarrassing for the British and Irish governments. Sources from each admit they would rather the police had turned a blind eye.

If Fusco were returned, he would be free in July under the early release scheme. Mr Justice Finnegan indicated yesterday that if his judical review were to go on more than three months, he would consider a fresh application for bail.

The M-60 gang, responsible for killing eight security force members and a suspected RUC informer, surrendered after shooting Captain Herbert Westmacott, 28, as he tried to prevent an attack on a nearby RUC station. His wife, Victoria, was pregnant at the time.

Fusco shot his way out of Crumlin Road courthouse with his six-co-accused in June 1981 just before he was sentenced to life with a recommendation he serve at least 30 years. He was arrested in the republic six months later, and spent 10 years in Portlaoise prison for the Belfast jailbreak and a subsequent escape attempt.

On his release in January 1992, he was immediately served with a warrant to return him to Northern Ireland to serve his sentence for murder, and began a six-year battle to avoid extradition while on bail. He finally lost in the Irish supreme court in February 1998, again apparently disappearing before the verdict.

Garda Paul Brown told the court he had stopped Fusco, driving a British-registered white Transit, at a drink-drive roadblock. He recognised him, and radioed for assistance after Fusco presented him with a Northern Ireland driving licence with his photograph but in another name.

Detective Sergeant Kevin Dillon, who arrived to arrest Fusco, said he had regularly checked over the past two years to see if he was at the home he had shared with his wife Mary, and children, Elaine, 26, Joe, 20, and 18-year-old Maria. He never asked Mrs Fusco where her husband was, saying: "I believed she wouldn't tell me."

Fusco denied he had been on the run. He said he had lived at home for six weeks after the supreme court verdict, before going to live with his brother in Coolock, Dublin, where he worked as a part-time builder, but returned to Tralee at weekends. He had a false Northern Ireland licence so that he could go there. He was also found to have a counterfeit Irish licence in the van. Fusco said: "I have always honoured my bail. If I was to lose, I would serve no more than six months. It would not be in my benefit to abscond."

webTitle: Crashed Korean plane had faulty instrument

fields.headline: Crashed Korean plane had faulty instrument
fields.trailText: A crucial navigation instrument on the Korean Air cargo plane which crashed at Stansted airport last month failed shortly after takeoff, leaving the crew with no means of gauging their exact position, according to an interim report into the accident published yesterday by the air accident investigation branch.
fields.body:
A crucial navigation instrument on the Korean Air cargo plane which crashed at Stansted airport last month failed shortly after takeoff, leaving the crew with no means of gauging their exact position, according to an interim report into the accident published yesterday by the air accident investigation branch.

The faulty gauge, the altitude director indicator (ADI), failed on the Boeing 747's penultimate flight from Tashkent to Stansted, and despite being worked on by ground crew at the airport failed again shortly before the plane crashed minutes after taking off on December 22.

A Korean Air engineer killed in the accident along with three other crew members was among those who examined the instrument.

The report, which reaches no conclusion about the cause of the crash, says the crew was warned that the instrument was faulty after take-off.

Both captain and co-pilot would have had ADIs, and the fault became apparent on the previous flight.

The flight engineer told a Korean Air ground engineer the captain's gauge was faulty and that he and a Stansted-based maintenance engineer had worked on the fault.

The local engineer told investigators that "the operator's [Korean Air] engineer said that he would complete the technical log". No copy of the log was left at Stansted.

Last night it emerged that the tail of the 747 contained 300kg of depleted uranium as a counter-weight, and that emergency services may have been exposed to radioactive uranium oxide.

A Boeing spokesman said: "The company began using depleted uranium in the early 1960s. Boeing replaced it with tungsten ... in the early 1980s. The Korean 747 was delivered to the airline in June 1980."

The spokesman said the depleted uranium would have had to be heated to a temperature in excess of 800C before uranium oxide was emitted, and that emergency workers would not have been at risk.

Both captain and co-pilot would have had ADIs, and the fault became apparent on the previous flight. The flight engineer told a Korean Air ground engineer the captain's gauge was faulty and that he and a Stansted-based maintenance engineer had worked on the fault. The local engineer told investigators that "the operator's [Korean Air] engineer said that he would complete the technical log". No copy of the log was left at Stansted. Last night it emerged that the tail of the 747 contained 300kg of depleted uranium as a counter-weight, and that emergency services may have been exposed to radioactive uranium oxide. A Boeing spokesman said: "The company began using depleted uranium in the early 1960s. Boeing replaced it with tungsten ... in the early 1980s. The Korean 747 was delivered to the airline in June 1980." The spokesman said the depleted uranium would have had to be heated to a temperature in excess of 800C before uranium oxide was emitted, and that emergency workers would not have been at risk.

webTitle: Party man who leaves nothing to chance

fields.headline: Party man who leaves nothing to chance
fields.standfirst:
Profile: Joe McCrea

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: So devotedly New Labour is Joe McCrea that at his wedding reception last year, it is said, he ordered the playing of the party's general election anthem, Things Can Only Get Better.
fields.body:
So devotedly New Labour is Joe McCrea that at his wedding reception last year, it is said, he ordered the playing of the party's general election anthem, Things Can Only Get Better.

Things apparently took a turn for the worse thereafter, when he found himself out of a job after Frank Dobson, his health secretary boss, resigned to stand in the contest for the Labour candidacy for mayor of London.

Mr McCrea, 34, had worked for Mr Dobson for eight years. The pair shared a taste for vulgar jokes, and a distaste for much of the media - which led to some remarkable clashes between the minister's spin doctor and health journalists.

The most notorious incident came at the party conference in Bournemouth last autumn. Mr McCrea was in a foul-mouthed confrontation with a woman reporter that culminated in damage to a mobile phone and a dousing of sparkling wine.

Release from his Dobson duties has left Mr McCrea with more time to follow his beloved Derby County football club. But, it is now clear, it also enabled him to work up his masterplan for a Whitehall-wide rebuttal machine.

A flavour of what he plans can be gleaned from the rebuttal system he developed at the department of health, shooting back at criticism with astonishing speed and detail.

Last March, for instance, the Conservatives issued a press statement accusing the government of fiddling the NHS waiting list figures. By noon the same day, Mr McCrea had drawn up a four-page dismemberment of the Tory claims, dealing in turn with six accusations and giving a "line to take" on each.

On one of the six, he was able to quote from a previous Dobson statement, reported in Hansard, and a guidance note issued to the NHS 18 months earlier.

On another, he quoted at length from comparable waiting list instructions issued by William Waldegrave, a former Tory health secretary, as much as eight years previously.

The rebuttal note was on blank paper, distancing it from the department itself. But there is little doubt that the "lines to take" were used by the department's press officers in response to journalists' inquiries.

fields.headline: Labour's message will bypass media
fields.standfirst:
Downing Street network aims for direct link with the public

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street is designing an electronic Knowledge Network to explain the government's core message to the public without going through "the distorting prism of media reporting" and to ensure that all in Whitehall "work off a common script which is instantly capable of being updated".
fields.body:
Downing Street is designing an electronic Knowledge Network to explain the government's core message to the public without going through "the distorting prism of media reporting" and to ensure that all in Whitehall "work off a common script which is instantly capable of being updated".

Joe McCrea, director of the project which will take the art of political spin doctoring and rebuttal into the silicon age, says in cabinet office documents passed to the Guardian that the database will not only include basic information such as ministers' speeches and "top line themes and messages", but will also deliver "key quotes, key facts and rapid reaction to attacks on departmental policy and practice".

The project aims to collect in one database every line for ministers and civil servants to take on every key government policy, and to provide them with the ammunition to deal with criticism on policy from MPs, the media and the public.

As part of the preparations every Whitehall department has already been asked to outline its existing arrangements to handle attacks on policy, including from MPs, and whether it has an early warning system.

The cabinet office paper cites food safety policy as the sort of high profile and hugely controversial issue which would benefit from this new approach. All ministers, including the prime minister, face the possibility of being questioned in an atmosphere where there are "members of the press or pressure groups hoping to seize on any evidence of inconsistency across government".

In this situation a computer network into which "every department can feed and from which every department can read" will help ensure the government works off a "common script". Presumably any minister deviating from "the line" equally will be instantly recognisable.

The proposed database is far more powerful than the Excalibur rebuttal programme used by Labour before the last election. Mr McCrea says that based on his experience at the department of health as Frank Dobson's political adviser, the minimum the "fully searchable" system would need to contain would be:

 A daily, weekly and medium term media planning tool (a battleplan).

 Comprehensive and concise briefing sheets on departmental activity, top line themes and messages.

 Full texts of key ministerial speeches.

 Full texts of departmental press releases.

 A common format for supplying Downing Street with required material for prime minister's questions.

 Key quotes, key facts and rapid reaction to attacks on departmental policy and practice.

 Instant breakdowns to regional and constituency level of departmental announcements and activity.

It also recommends building up within the database information on the government's most persistent critics and the official response to their arguments.

Until now the government has not, as a matter of routine, produced information broken down by political constituency unless requested by a specific parliamentary question as the country is run by local authority, police force, NHS trust or commuter area and such data is generally only of use in party political campaigning. But using the justification of prime minister's question time, the cabinet approved paper proposes that that should now become a matter of routine.

The paper makes clear that the object of this is to be able to tell parents in Durham about smaller classes in their schools, or to explain how the working families tax credit has benefited a parent in Worcester. It adds that the "automatic mapping" of such information to BBC or ITV regions, local radio, local and regional newspapers, as well as parliamentary constituencies will help spread the benefits of government policy at local level.

The database is justified in the name of providing the public with greater access to government information. But the paper makes clear only certain types of information will be available to the public. "There might also be information which it would be unnecessary or unwise to have shared freely with all other departments, published on the internet or sent out in a letter to the public."

For example, the "best three arguments" or "best five facts" supporting a particular government policy will be available to the public but "the most recent developments" in that policy, depending on sensitivity, will be restricted to policy officials, private offices and parliamentary clerks in selected departments.

Similarly, lists of people and organisations outside government who support official policy will be made public but the names of critics and their arguments will be restricted to key staff "for use only when attacks are made".

Mr McCrea says that all ministers, civil servants and political advisers are to be given automatic security codes which will determine the level of access they may have to the database.

There are to be three levels of access: open, restricted and confidential. He suggests either that everybody in Whitehall is given some access or that "a select number of power individuals in each department" would have direct management access while others would only have "browser access".

The project is being sold to cabinet ministers partly on its strength as an "out of hours service" that will be accessible to them by laptop computer and will help them when they are working away from their departments, whether at home or abroad.

"It means that the individuals compiling the information all work off a common joint script, instantly capable of being updated by any one of them to everybody's joint advantage ... It drastically reduces the number of occasions on which a press officer needs to chase the information providers to check out the latest situation ... It means that the information can be accessed around the clock, 365 days a year, at home and even overseas," the document says.

"For a number of key users, remote 24 hour laptop access to the Knowledge Network would obviously be necessary - for example, duty private office staff, senior departmental officials and government communications staff.

"It could mean the end of "the Sunday morning phone-call chase for information or the weekend haul of truck-loads of paper", the document claims.

webTitle: Labour's hi-tech plan to foil critics

fields.headline: Labour's hi-tech plan to foil critics
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A new electronic government information and rebuttal system which will use the latest technology to help Whitehall stay on message and respond to critical attacks by MPs, the press and the public, is being developed by Downing Street.
fields.body:
A new electronic government information and rebuttal system which will use the latest technology to help Whitehall stay on message and respond to critical attacks by MPs, the press and the public, is being developed by Downing Street.

The system, named the Knowledge Network Project, is being developed by Frank Dobson's former spin doctor, Joe McCrea, with a team based in the cabinet office and is many times more powerful than the Excalibur database used by Labour in the run-up to the last general election.

The overall aim of the project is to "explain the government's core message" so that citizens can get the "full facts without going through the distorting prism of media reporting." It is to be a computer network into which every department can feed their "lines to take" on every key issue and "from which every department can read," according to cabinet office documents passed to the Guardian.

The documents, circulated around Whitehall in the last few weeks, have sparked anxieties among some senior civil servants. They are concerned about the lack of specific safeguards for the political impartiality of the civil service, and that the powerful database created at taxpayers' expense could be exported wholesale to the Labour Party's Millbank headquarters in the run-up to the general election.

"It has come in through the back door. It just sailed through cabinet. I do not see any safeguards in place to protect us from the accusation of impropriety of using the civil service in this way," said one senior Whitehall official.

It is believed that McCrea's project was given cabinet approval without any of the consultations with other Whitehall departments that usually take place. Mo Mowlam, the cabinet enforcer, has invited all other cabinet ministers to participate in the project and an initial "communications audit" is due to be completed by each government department by next Friday. A minister in each department is being given specific responsibility for their participation.

The initial communications audit not only includes an assessment of the state of computerisation in Whitehall but also asks each department to outline whether they have "one-stop shops for policy lines to take" and have early warning systems and rapid response operations to attacks on their policy and practice.

Mr McCrea, who is on contract to the cabinet office, and loosely accountable to the Downing Street information and research unit under Bill Bush, has been given the job of "rolling-out" the system across Whitehall.

Based on Lotus Notes software, it is designed to build up a single database of the government's line to take on every key policy issue raised across Whitehall. He suggests it should not just include the latest statement of government policy but also the three best arguments and five best facts in its support.

Although developed on the promise to deliver citizens with "the full facts - without media distortion", the public will be told who outside government supports a particular policy but they won't be told who is critical of it nor will they be told of the "latest developments in policy" if they are considered too sensitive.

But the new system also breaks with past Whitehall practice in that it will log data on a political constituency basis which has never been done before as a matter of routine except by specific parliamentary question. This is being done on the grounds that the information will be used by Tony Blair at prime minister's question time but it also turns it into a potentially very powerful political campaign tool in an election.

The data will also be processed by "automatic mapping" so it is broken down by BBC and ITV television region, local radio and local newspaper circulation areas as well by constituency so that the "benefits of government policy can be better explained at a local level." Examples cited in the leaked cabinet office paper include telling residents in a particular constituency how many of them have benefited from lower rates of income tax or from the new deal for the unemployed.

Ministers are to be offered a 24-hour all-year-round service with the database accessible to them from a laptop computer at home or abroad.

No longer will they have any excuse not to know the "line to take" as a result of a project which promises to deliver "the most modern and advanced government knowledge system anywhere in the world."

webTitle: 'Exasperated' Blair ready to give Mowlam her cards

fields.headline: 'Exasperated' Blair ready to give Mowlam her cards
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam has reportedly been placed "on trial" by Tony Blair, to be unceremoniously removed from the cabinet if she repeats the mistakes she made in Belfast.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam has reportedly been placed "on trial" by Tony Blair, to be unceremoniously removed from the cabinet if she repeats the mistakes she made in Belfast.

The prime minister, who removed Ms Mowlam from Northern Ireland last year against her will, is said to still find her exasperating.

He reportedly would not flinch from ending her ministerial career, despite her popularity within the Labour party.

The gloomy assessment of Ms Mowlam's prospects came in a New Statesman article by Steve Richards, the magazine's political editor, who is close to senior figures in Downing Street.

Under the headline Mo Mowlam's fall from grace, Mr Richards quoted a "Blair aide" as saying that the cabinet office minister was on trial and would not be given another chance if she failed.

One aide underlined her delicate position by explaining in dismissive terms why the prime minister had refused to grant her request to be made health secretary when he moved her from being Northern Ireland secretary last year.

"Mowlam has the touch of Bill Clinton but lacks his ability to immerse himself in policy detail," the aide was reported as saying.

Ms Mowlam's supporters last night dismissed the article as "pointless speculation".

They said that she remained a key member of the cabinet, whose central role had been confirmed when the prime minister placed her in charge of the government's social exclusion unit.

However, Ms Mowlam faced a wretched year in 1999, which saw her receiving a dismal reception at the Labour conference one year after she upstaged Mr Blair at the conference by receiving a standing ovation during his speech.

One supporter of Ms Mowlam underlined the strained relations with Downing Street by saying that she had been deliberately snubbed at last year's conference by being given a speaking slot just after lunch.

"Another big standing ovation might have made it difficult again for Blair to move her," he said.

The one-time darling of the Labour party was said to be so angry at the Blairites' portrayal of her as a failure in Belfast that she was planning to use her much-publicised forthcoming book to set the record straight.

One Mowlam supporter told the magazine: "Tony used to phone Mo virtually every Sunday to discuss the situation, and for much of the time he was asking her what was happening, not the other way round."

This contrasts with the remarks of Blair supporters during her time in Belfast when they said that the prime minister was spending his life rescuing Ms Mowlam after she had alienated unionists with her incautious remarks over issues - such as the principle of consent.

Ms Mowlam, who will today make a visit to Brighton as part of her role in tackling social exclusion, will take heart that Mr Richards wrote that the prime minister still retained "affection and respect for her skills and courage".

"Some influential Blairites believe she could be in her last job in government," Mr Richards writes.

"It is at least as likely that she will be the only woman from Blair's first cabinet to survive into a second term."

fields.trailText: "The cook should be well acquainted with the signs of freshness and good condition in fish as they are most unwholesome articles when stale...." Combining admonition with elucidation in unmistakably Victorian tones, Eliza Acton came well Before Beeton (2.15pm, Radio 4). A single mother and failed poet, Acton's ground-breaking volume on Modern Cookery appeared in 1845, to be ruthlessly plagiarised by you-know-who once Acton was safely in her grave. Jyll Bradley tries to restore the historical balance in this dramatised documentary.

fields.headline: Stars of tomorrow
fields.standfirst: If you thought documentary makers had a hard time keeping audiences happy, spare a thought for those making turn-of-the-century programmes. They have to worry about what future historians will think as well
fields.trailText: If you thought documentary makers had a hard time keeping audiences happy, spare a thought for those making turn-of-the-century programmes. They have to worry about what future historians will think as well
fields.body:
Next month the BBC begin screening the first in what they hope will be a 20-year-long documentary series. A Child Of Our Time will follow 10 new-born children over the first two decades of their life.

If it sounds a bit like a scientific social experiment, that's exactly what it is. The filming is actually just part of a massive cohort study by the Bristol-based Avon Longitudinal Studies of Pregnancy and Childhood (ALSPAC). The BBC have 10 families lined up ready to give birth to the unwitting stars of the 90-minute BBC1 documentary that will kick the whole thing off. Testing everything from old wives' tales to the latest genetic theories, the project is being described by the BBC as a "a kind of scientific Seven Up [the classic documentary series that followed a group of children over seven-year intervals]".

Of course, the whole thing may never last 20 years at all. The series might simply discover at what age children achieve the cognitive awareness and linguistic skills necessary to tell a fly-on-the-wall cameraman exactly where he can shove his Sony Digi Beta. But using television as a kind of social science laboratory where we, the viewers, can drop in and out to see how the child born into a working-class family in Cardiff is developing in comparison to the child of a middle-class family in Manchester, has never been more popular.

Producers of such programmes are only too aware that they are creating source material for historians, sociologists and psychologists of the future. Stephen Lambert, executive producer of ITV's Many Happy Returns, prefers the term "longitudinal studies" for his programmes. Many Happy Returns, a variation on the Seven Up series, will follow 10 children through their lives, returning every five years to catch up with them as they celebrate their birthdays. "It's not a social science experiment in the sense that with ten children you're not going to choose a group that represents the nation," says Lambert, "but there is a gender mix and a class mix and a geographical mix."

There is, of course, no shortage of people willing to put themselves, or to put their children, under television's sociological spotlight for such programmes. "We're hoping it won't be too disruptive to their family life but... this is about as intrusive as it gets", said a BBC spokesperson for the A Child Of Our Time project.

Lambert certainly found no lack of would-be participants for Many Happy Returns. "At least 400 children were interviewed by the production team", he says. Perhaps one reason why so many people are keen to be part of "longitudinal studies" series like this is that it gives the participants more control over how they're portrayed than a one-off documentary. "Usually once you've finished filming with people their sense of control is much less because they've made their contribution, but with these programmes you have to ensure that the people that have been in the programmes like them each time because they've got to be willing to take part the next time."

If having your life interrupted by a a film crew every five years or so seems intrusive, then what about being filmed every day for a year? Later this month the BBC begins Castaway 2000, a documentary following 36 people left on the deserted island of Taransay, off the coast of Scotland, for a year - though last night several of them were reported to have been airlifted off the island because of flu. Again, literally hundreds of people applied to be human guinea pigs in front of millions of viewers.

Jeremy Mills, executive producer for Lion TV of the BBC Scotland production, is quite clear about the programme's aim to create a televisual laboratory. "Yes it is a social experiment", he says. "The essence of it is that we try to get people who reflect British society, put them together in a situation where they're away from the normal things that impinge on daily life, and let them reflect on what it is they miss about the lives they've left behind and how they work together as a team and decide what the rules of the new community are."

It may sound like Crystal Maze meets the Open University Psychology Course (Units 1-3), but Mills makes no apologies for the programme's ambitions. "We're trying to take our knowledge of where we are as a society and try and move it on to where we could go if we had different options." Blimey. At least this sort of programming can't be accused of docu-soap style "dumbing down". Castaways has legions of psychologists, sociologists, economists, alternative technologists, sewage experts and survival experts advising the programme makers on the parameters of their experiment. "They will be involved in monitoring it throughout and involved academically afterwards", says Mills. And when these programmes are finished they're not only guaranteed to lend some gravitas to the broadcasters - they're invariably mentioned in self-congratulatory end-of-term reports - but they can have a shelf life in the educational and academic market too.

So the next time someone offers you 15 minutes of fame if you'll get your knob out for Denise Van Outen, try holding out for a six-part series exploring the socio-psycho-cultural dynamics of the next 15 years in your life.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Not so much "behind the screen" as "where to find it on the screen" as Living (it used to be UK Living, but is much more cosmopolitan now) is apparently finding it hard to let viewers know about its US acquisition, Will & Grace.
fields.body:
Not so much "behind the screen" as "where to find it on the screen" as Living (it used to be UK Living, but is much more cosmopolitan now) is apparently finding it hard to let viewers know about its US acquisition, Will & Grace.

For all those who don't know, Will & Grace is the snugglesome story of Will, who's the best friend of Grace. Only trouble is, he's gay. Sound familiar? Well, it's not just the well-worn story of girl loves boy who can't love girl back, but a highly-produced, laugh-every-30-minutes story with added spice from the extremely camp sidekick (watch it and see what we mean).

Of course, it ain't new. What is? The show was launched in the US nearly two years ago by NBC and only brought to the UK this year by Flextech, which owns Living. But the broadcaster, it seems, is having a few difficulties getting anyone to tune into the show.

What to do? The answer is to take a whole gaggle of UK hacks off to sunny California to team up with the cast. Now, that's one press trip we would love to be on. "It's not like ITV", grumbles a Flextech insider. "They only have to promote something for a week and everyone ends up watching." Ah, life in the world of multi-channel TV.

Meanwhile, Channel 4's house is falling down. Not literally, you understand. The Richard Rogers HQ of the station remains sound. But the broadcaster seems confused about the fate of the buildings featured in a documentary it is airing on Monday. "The Alfred P Murrah Building is just one of the subjects of C4's four-part series Why Buildings Collapse", trumpets a recent press announcement. It ends: "You can see just why the Oklahoma bomb caused such devastation, as well as other disasters when Why Buildings Fall Down begins on Monday". We can't wait. Just hope they've sorted out the title by then.

fields.headline: Who are you
fields.standfirst: What the Euro RSCG ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Euro RSCG ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: This 90-second bonanza uses stock footage to highlight a series of dramatic human achievements from the past century. Shots of, for instance, the first man on the moon are mingled with pix of the first four-minute mile and the first women voters, all set to the stirring strains of Judy Garland warbling Somewhere Over The Rainbow. The ad ends with the words: "The future belongs to those who dare to be first. You have been watching the very first commercial of the millennium."

The jargon: You won't actually have seen this ad, which is a blatant PR stunt by the global ad agency Euro RSCG Worldwide. In fact, hardly anyone will have seen it, because it only ran in the Chatham Islands, New Zealand (the first inhabited land mass with a TV station to see the dawning of the new millennium). The thinking was to have the initiative to run the first ad of the millennium: it aired just after midnight on New Year's Day.

Personality: The "house" commercial is aimed at head honchos in the business world. Given that not many of those are actually based in the Chatham Islands (copies are in fact being mailed to them), it was most likely just seen by a couple of sheep farmers. That's if they were watching telly.

Financial status: Erm, once again, the ad is trying to impress marketing directors of large corporations - you know, the sort who could afford particularly fancy millennial celebrations, such as flying across the international dateline in Concorde. Nothing so tacky as the Dome for them.

Telling lifestyle detail: The target consumer has a fine business brain, is hard-working, innovative, oh, and handles the purse-strings of a sizeable marketing budget.

Other relevant data: Just over 700 people live in the Chatham Islands, most of whom farm sheep. The agency paid a ridiculous $15,000 for the spot.

fields.headline: Mouse on the moon
fields.trailText: A cocaine dealer lurks in a country lane at dusk. He hides a Tupperware box under some leaves and saunters away, whistling like Sid James after stashing some hot diamonds. According to Detective Sergeant Steve Holme in Secrets And Lines (C4) this is the way that hundreds of tons of marching powder enter the country each year. Via a cunning scheme first pioneered by Great Uncle Bulgaria to hide his winter store of conkers on Wimbledon Common.
fields.body:
A cocaine dealer lurks in a country lane at dusk. He hides a Tupperware box under some leaves and saunters away, whistling like Sid James after stashing some hot diamonds. According to Detective Sergeant Steve Holme in Secrets And Lines (C4) this is the way that hundreds of tons of marching powder enter the country each year. Via a cunning scheme first pioneered by Great Uncle Bulgaria to hide his winter store of conkers on Wimbledon Common.

It is important, says DS Holme, that the Tupperware box is properly sealed, as field mice are notoriously mad for it. They'll gnaw through the plastic, eager for their fix. Besides, "you wouldn't want to lose any gear to wild animals". DS Holme looks suspiciously to the ground as he says this, keen to get one over on the director before being made to look 110 per cent foolish himself.

Mice furthered their drug habit on Life And Death In The 21st Century (BBC2) which concluded its awesomely dystopian run with a look at genetically-modified children, or "designer babies". Not content with merely snorting coke, mice at Princeton University have signed up for a course of being injected with the DNA of jellyfish.

I watched the tape of the phosphorescent rodents ("our little glowing mice") and watched it again and again. My god, I said to myself. Look at that. LOOK AT THAT!

This future party trick of medical students is presently considered the first unlikely step on the road to modifying the DNA of human embryos. By 2070, parents will create their offspring from DNA chips: a hint of Kate Moss's cheekbones, a dash of Sterling Moss's driving skills, possibly even a piece of Professor Leroy Hood's messianic lunacy.

Hood's job is to create the DNA chip. A couple of years ago, I interviewed him at Washington University, where he stands permanently in front of a bank of a hundred computers, mapping out the entire human genome, a kind of A-Z of DNA. The man was mad even then but, judging by his appearance on this documentary, Hood appears now to have embarked on the full course of jellyfish injections himself.

"In four years," he panted, "we'll know the entire sequence. We'll stand on the threshold of what it really means to be human, and I see it as inevitable that the tools of science will march on."

The prodding of cells with syringes to irrevocably change the nature of human DNA is a fantastic idiocy, and one that could only take place in a period of unprecedented scientific progress operating in an ethical vacuum. Professor Lee Silver of Princeton's glowing mice, summarised it thus: "The more powerful the technology, the more serious the screw-up."

The first stomach-turning example of this was the American food industry's attempt to create a big pig. Knowing the right chromosome to inject didn't mean scientists knew the consequences of injecting it. The pig, living in a pen called "Research Road", grew to the size of a Mini Metro, its heart and lungs crushed by flab.

For human pigs, the prognosis is no better. Lee Silver predicted that DNA chips will radically increase the gulf between rich and poor. "Class differences today will become genetic differences in the future." The rich will buy off-the-peg babies for as little as $20,000 a throw and become (ha! ha!) a "super race". "Diseased genes", meanwhile, "will lay out on the bottom half of society."

It was pertinent, I thought, that Leroy Hood, who kick-started this eugenic programme for the 21st century, was credited as working at "Washington University" and not Microsoft, who have bankrolled his research from day one. Bill Gates certainly knows the potential value of patenting the human DNA chip, but funnily enough, his name wasn't even mentioned in the programme.

The missing draw from Better Gardens (ITV), meanwhile, was Charlie Dimmock, whom I'm still hoping will spot my dying garden from her helicopter. Carol Vorderman hosts this straight steal of Changing Rooms, even down to a tousled-haired Lawrence-a-like called "Ross", sawing railway sleepers in a tight T-shirt while Carol stands coyly behind a water feature.

"Ross is making a box for bluetits out of plywood, plastic and a doormat", she said seductively, her eyes never once leaving his hard-at-work arms. "You are clever." As the final credit rolled, amid the hubbub in Pete'n'Pat's "eclipse shrubbery", I swore that Carol stroked Ross's hair.
