fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Witches
fields.body:
The Witches

(Nicolas Roeg, 1989)

3.15pm, Sky Premier

Roeg's child-oriented fantasy from the nasty Roald Dahl story casts a big enough spell to snare adults too. Jasen Fisher plays the young lad ensconced with granny Mai Zetterling and a coven of witches (beautifully brewed up by the unparalleled magic of Jim Henson's Creature Shop) at an English seaside hotel; turned into a mouse, he starts to nibble away at head witch Anjelica Huston's powers. Rowan Atkinson twitters about in predictable style as the hotel manager.

Lone Star

(John Sayles, 1996)

10pm, FilmFour

In a dusty little Texas border town a skeleton is found, and Chris Deeds, the local sheriff, finds himself investigating his father's part in a 40-year-old disappearance. Sayles's drama is rich in characters and atmosphere, eliding seamlessly between past and present, flowing around the theme of history as an exercise in pragmatism. Looming over all is Kris Kristofferson's corrupt, granite-featured lawman.

William Shakespeare's Romeo And Juliet

(Baz Luhrmann, 1996)

3.05am, Sky Premier

Luhrmann's vibrant, postmodern reading of the star-cross'd lovers may treat the immortal text like a redundant Joe Eszterhas script, but nevertheless invests it with a frantic immediacy, piling on one high-energy, vividly shot scene after another. Leonardo DiCaprio and Claire Danes are no great shakes at the verse, but they quiver with earnest mutual passion, and there are some fine support acts - Brian Dennehy's Montague, Pete Postlethwaite's Friar, Miriam Margolyes's nurse and John Leguizamo, whose Tybalt looks like he could eat DiCaprio for breakfast.

fields.headline: The Vatican's war over England
fields.standfirst:
There are mysterious delays in filling Cardinal Hume's shoes
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A power struggle between men of God promises a great spectacle. When the Princes of the Church roll up their purple sleeves and wrestle one another for top dog slot, we sit up in the knowledge that this won't be a friendly, William Hague and Seb Coe tussle but an almighty row. Blood may not be spilled, or Episcopal robes rent - but there is something deeply satisfying about the sight of men who preach brotherly love struggling for supremacy.
fields.body:
A power struggle between men of God promises a great spectacle. When the Princes of the Church roll up their purple sleeves and wrestle one another for top dog slot, we sit up in the knowledge that this won't be a friendly, William Hague and Seb Coe tussle but an almighty row. Blood may not be spilled, or Episcopal robes rent - but there is something deeply satisfying about the sight of men who preach brotherly love struggling for supremacy.

There is no proof that the late Cardinal Basil Hume's succession has sunk to such depths. But by prevaricating over the appointment of the man who will be at the helm of four million Catholics in England and Wales, the Vatican fuels rumours of personality clashes, bitter rivalries and strongman tactics.

The traditional secrecy of the procedure does nothing to allay suspicions of furious politicking behind the arazzi. The papal nuncio (the Vatican's ambassador to Britain), after consulting the bishops, selects three candidates and sends their names to Rome in a sealed envelope; lengthy and secret dossiers are then drawn up about each man; and discussions of their relative merits (and faults) are conducted behind closed doors at the Vatican. Talk of transparency amounts to heresy in these marble corridors: and Catholics, clergy and lay both, know they will wait in the dark while Pope John Paul II and his curia decide who will fill the late cardinal's shoes.

But the cardinal died last June: what bitter feuding could explain this seven-month wait? The battle cannot be reduced to Olympian ego-clashes - though ambition, as Cardinals Wolsey and Richelieu showed, has not always been alien to men of the cloth; and the epithet "ambitious" seems to follow frontrunner Bishop Vincent Nichols like a guardian angel.

But no, this is a war of ideology, where liberal stands against conservative; radical against traditionalist. The candidates are categorised according to their position on certain litmus test issues - from homosexuality to women priests, from divorce to third world debt. The Vatican's lengthy deliberation is a tacit admission that religion has become so politicised that the new cardinal will wield great influence over Catholics as a group of citizens as well as a community of believers.

We shouldn't be surprised. When Jesus came out with that great biblical soundbite about "give unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's," he sought to draw a line between religion and politics; for two millennia politicos and pontiffs have done their best to erase it. Tony Blair is but the latest in a long line of politicians (that includes Gladstone and Keir Hardie) who liberally sprinkle their addresses with religious idioms and invest their speeches with the pulpit-thumping fervour of the evangelist.

Equally, a study of the present papacy will bear out that the demarcation between church and state has been erased: from his support of Solidarity to his condemnation of the death penalty, John Paul II has followed in the footsteps of his Renaissance predecessors to secure himself a place as world leader, not just spiritual shepherd.

Closer to home, Cardinal Thomas Winning in Scotland advised his flock to vote against New Labour because of the party's support of abortion; he also set up an initiative whereby pregnant women considering abortion could claim money, food and clothing.

A Winning-like, conservative cardinal might well start firing broadsides on abortion or church schools from the pages of the Daily Telegraph - the paper's proprietor, Conrad Black, and editor, Charles Moore, are recent converts to Catholicism. But a liberal prelate might embarrass the government by questioning its so-called moral foreign policy or exposing its record in helping the poor; giving New Labour as rough a ride as the former Bishop of Durham gave Mrs T.

Under New Labour, the British climate has grown more favourable for believers of all denominations. Disenchantment with the brazen materialism of the recent past; sobering confrontations with the evil of genocide in Sudan and Kosovo; and perhaps, too, a dose of millennarian angst, have reawakened our collective conscience and expanded our field of vision beyond the here and now. The time is ripe for an intelligent cleric to establish the kind of authority an archbishop of Canterbury like Dr Carey so palpably lacks.

Tony Blair's own philo-Catholic position (his wife is a Catholic, he attends Mass on Sunday, and he even saw in the new year at Westminster Cathedral) raises the stakes. Whoever is appointed leader of this nation's Catholics will enjoy a tremendous emotional hold on the prime minister. An able prelate, who manages to strike a "third way" between Winning and David Jenkins, could become a Mandelsonian eminence grise, influencing policies from Northern Ireland to the family. Indeed, given the proposed inclusion in the new upper chamber of representatives of all religions, the clerical Mandelson would be able to voice his opinions publicly as well as behind the scenes at Downing Street.

To secure such a hold on national life, the Vatican must choose carefully. It recognises that neither an ultra conservative, or a radical, will win the confidence of the premier. This deliberation goes against the grain. The Catholic church is no democracy, and the pontiff must be itching to place a flunky at Westminster who will toe the papal line on all issues. Usually, "one of us" is the only thing to be in these clerical contests.

But John Paul II is no fool. The potential benefits of an ally at No 10 far outweigh the discomfort of having a candidate given to "loyal dissent" - ie, who believes in the freedom to ask questions.

The Catholic church knows this is a golden opportunity to play a major role in shaping a nation's agenda. And so the three contenders must convince Rome that they are not only men of God but could also be Blair's boys. The two, alas, are not always one and the same.

fields.headline: John Arnatt
fields.standfirst: Poised English actor famed for roles on both sides of the law
fields.trailText: While he is probably best remembered on stage for the thoughtful way in which he lit his pipe - while playing Scotland Yard roles - and for a host of charming baddies on television, John Arnatt, who has died aged 82, gave some treasured theatre performances. In a career extending over 60 years, the tall, slim Arnatt, with his golden voice and urbane manners, sometimes stepped out of his usual line of police superintendents, doctors, diplomats and lawyers. He tried his hand at stand-up comedy at the old Windmill theatre, and worked in wartime concert parties.
fields.body:
While he is probably best remembered on stage for the thoughtful way in which he lit his pipe - while playing Scotland Yard roles - and for a host of charming baddies on television, John Arnatt, who has died aged 82, gave some treasured theatre performances. In a career extending over 60 years, the tall, slim Arnatt, with his golden voice and urbane manners, sometimes stepped out of his usual line of police superintendents, doctors, diplomats and lawyers. He tried his hand at stand-up comedy at the old Windmill theatre, and worked in wartime concert parties.

Postwar, he applied his talent to Shakespeare and Chekhov. His unusually subtle Dr Dorn, in John Fernald's revival of The Seagull at the Arts Theatre Club, brought warm attention from the critics. He then landed the role of Richard Plantagenet, in Douglas Seale's legendary revival at Birmingham Repertory Theatre of Henry VI, Parts I, II and III. When the production transferred to the Old Vic, in London, the trilogy was received with a storming ovation, with Arnatt's "ambitious, nobly-graced" Duke of York high among the general praise, particularly from the Manchester Guardian's critic, Philip Hope-Wallace. In the same season he was singled out for approval at the Bristol Old Vic, this time as Uncle Leonid in a revival of The Cherry Orchard.

One of four children, John Arnatt was born in Petrograd, the son of the local general manager for Vauxhall Motors. In 1917, following the Russian revolution, the family fled. Educated at Epworth College, Rhyl, he trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and, in 1936, landed a small part in Little Ol' Boy, an American drama, at the Arts Theatre. His west end debut came as one of Mr Cochran's young gentlemen in the revue Happy Returns (Adelphi, 1938), starring Beatrice Lillie and Flanagan and Allen. He then did a year in rep before wartime army service.

Postwar, he returned to rep, but within two years was back in the west end, in AP Dearsley's light comedy, Fly Away Peter. In 1949, he turned to directing the light comedy My Mother Said, and played the ambassador in Basil Dean's spectacular revival of James Elroy Flecker's Hassan (Cambridge Theatre, 1951). With the arrival of commercial television in the mid-1950s, Arnatt reported sport under the pseudonym "Howard Peters". He won the Sporting Times TV Personality Award.

His later west end credits included The Marriage-Go-Round (Piccadilly, 1959) with John Clements and Kay Hammond, Alibi For A Judge (Savoy, 1965) with Andrew Cruickshank, Conduct Unbecoming (Queen's, 1970), Lord Shaftsbury in Barnado (Royalty, 1980), and the ambassador in M Butterfly (Shaftsbury, 1989). Other stage credits included Jaques in As You Like It (Pembroke, Croydon, 1961), Lord Sidmouth in Cato Street - opposite Vanessa Redgrave - at the Young Vic (1971), and Balance in The Recruiting Officer (Crucible, Sheffield, 1978).

Among Arnatt's television credits were The Adventures Of Robin Hood (1955-59), Emergency Ward 10, Dr Who, Miss Marple, House Of Cards, Lovejoy, Dangerfield, and Dad, with George Cole. His films included Whistle Down The Wind (1961) and Only Two Can Play (1962).

John Arnatt's marriage to Betty Huntley-Wright was dissolved. He is survived by his second wife, Sheila Tracy, by whom he had a son.

 John Edwin Arnatt, actor, born May 9 1917; died December 21 1999

fields.headline: Nat Adderley
fields.standfirst: Jazz musician who emerged from brother's shadow
fields.trailText: The name of Adderley is one of the most famous in postwar jazz. But Nathaniel "Nat" Adderley, the cornettist and composer who has died aged 68, spent much of his life in the shadow of it, because he knew people were usually referring to his elder brother, the saxophonist Julian "Cannonball" Adderley, one of the leading lights of the hard bop jazz movement of the 1950s.
fields.body:
The name of Adderley is one of the most famous in postwar jazz. But Nathaniel "Nat" Adderley, the cornettist and composer who has died aged 68, spent much of his life in the shadow of it, because he knew people were usually referring to his elder brother, the saxophonist Julian "Cannonball" Adderley, one of the leading lights of the hard bop jazz movement of the 1950s.

Nat shared many of his celebrated sibling's musical qualities - forthright lyricism, catchy composing and muscular, hard-driving improvising - and some listeners inclined to the view that he was the sharper soloist, less inclined to soul-jazz grandstanding, bolder in concept and more creative in his reshaping of his influences. After Cannonball's premature death in 1975, the jazz public slowly woke up to these possibilities.

Nat Adderley's direct line of musical descent was from Dizzy Gillespie, but he had listened attentively to all kinds of brass players - including the visionary New Orleans musician Henry "Red" Allen, the mainstreamer Bobby Hackett and the urbane Clark Terry - and combined their voices to make a memorable one of his own. He could play ballads with sublime eloquence and expressiveness, yet, in his uptempo bop mode, he could exhibit a glittering precision that made his work vibrant and energetic without histrionics.

Both Adderley brothers were born in Tampa, Florida, and began performing in local and high school bands. By the mid-1950s they had intended to build their careers together, but their quintet ran into financial difficulties, and the problem of a music business hailing Cannonball as the newcomer to fill the chasm left by the death of Charlie Parker in 1955.

Nat had already proved he could be an attraction in his own right. Having switched from trumpet to the brighter cornet in 1950, and then played in an army band, he was spotted by Lionel Hampton after demobilisation in 1953. When Cannonball was working in the Miles Davis Quintet, Nat was partnering jazz celebrities, including the bop trombone virtuoso JJ Johnson, and appearing in Woody Herman's bands. When the Miles Davis group went through one of its periodic reinventions - after the Kind Of Blue album - the Adderleys reconvened as a partnership, and delivered a popular brand of blues and gospel-influenced bebop. Over the next decade it was one of the few incarnations of jazz to compete for visceral appeal with rock 'n' roll.

During this fruitful association, Nat Adderley wrote several staples of the repertoire that became classics of the idiom later dubbed "soul-jazz" - most famously Work Song, but also Jive Samba and Hummin'. The brothers also worked on a musical dedicated to the folk hero John Henry (Shout Up A Morning), which was performed at Carnegie Hall in 1976, and on Broadway a decade later.

After Cannonball's death Nat ran his own group, keeping faith with the open style they had explored together, and including such Cannonball-aware alto saxophonists as Sonny Fortune and Vincent Herring. He continued as a bandleader (and periodically a teacher, taking seminars at Harvard and elsewhere) until 1997, when the diabetes that ended his life began to undermine his health.

Adderley is survived by his wife, Ann, a son, daughter, and five grandchildren.

 Nathaniel 'Nat' Adderley, jazz musician, born November 25 1931; died January 2 2000

fields.headline: Dobson trounced in mayor vote
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has beaten Frank Dobson by a margin of more than 12 to one, pushing the former health secretary into a humiliating third place in the ballot to pick the Transport and General Workers' Union's choice for Labour's London mayoral candidate.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has beaten Frank Dobson by a margin of more than 12 to one, pushing the former health secretary into a humiliating third place in the ballot to pick the Transport and General Workers' Union's choice for Labour's London mayoral candidate.

The scale of the former Greater London Council leader's victory, in a poll involving nearly 20,000 TGWU political levy-payers in the capital, is likely to cause the greatest alarm in the Labour party's Millbank headquarters and Downing Street.

It raises the spectre of a Livingstone victory despite Mr Dobson's huge lead among Labour MPs and MEPs.

Mr Livingstone, whose candidacy is strongly opposed by the prime minister, secured 15,858 votes - 85.8% of the total. Glenda Jackson came second with 1,342 votes, or 7.3%, and Mr Dobson came last, with 1,285, or 6.9%. The 29% turnout is relatively high for union ballots.

The Dobson camp, which plans to announce a string of new policies today which are designed to distance their candidate from the Labour hierarchy, dismissed the result last night on the grounds that the TGWU leadership had recommended a vote for Livingstone and the procedure was therefore flawed.

But that fails to explain Mr Dobson's strikingly low personal vote. The TGWU result, which secures 50,000 votes in Labour's electoral college for Mr Livingstone, reflects the pattern of results in other ballots so far. Last month, two London Labour constituencies, Tooting and Hornchurch, held ballots of members to guide the decisions of the local MPs. Both delivered around two-thirds of the vote for Mr Livingstone.

London members of the Rail Maritime and Transport union, which has been barred from casting its vote because of late affiliation payment, last month delivered a 91% vote for Mr Livingstone.

Next week, six members of another union that is being excluded from the contest, the technical staff union MSF, will challenge Millbank's decision in the high court.

The six include Jim Mortimer, the former general secretary of the Labour party.

Whatever the outcome, supporters of Mr Dobson hope that when individual London Labour party members are faced with their ballot papers later this month, they will decline to support an MP who is so mistrusted by the party leadership.

The electoral college which will pick Labour's candidate for the mayoral elections in May is divided into three sections: one for MPs, MEPs and greater London authority candidates, one for affiliated organisations, such as trade unions, and one for individual members. With Mr Dobson enjoying a commanding lead in the MPs' section, the calculation has been that Mr Livingstone will need to secure around 70% in the other two sections to win.

Mr Dobson will be hoping that ballots in other unions which are not making recommendations will deliver closer results than the TGWU.

But a Dobson spokesman last night conceded that it was going to be "a very closely fought contest".

fields.headline: Masaru Sato
fields.standfirst: The man behind the music of Kurosawa's films - and Godzilla
fields.trailText: From the end of the second world war, western influences seeped into Japanese culture. From the mid-1950s, this was particularly noticeable to audiences in the west through Japanese film music, especially that of Masaru Sato, who has died aged 71. Sato, who wrote an incredible 308 film scores - his record being 18 in one year - was best known for the nine pictures he scored for director Akira Kurosawa and, at the opposite cinematic pole, four entries in the Godzilla series.
fields.body:
From the end of the second world war, western influences seeped into Japanese culture. From the mid-1950s, this was particularly noticeable to audiences in the west through Japanese film music, especially that of Masaru Sato, who has died aged 71. Sato, who wrote an incredible 308 film scores - his record being 18 in one year - was best known for the nine pictures he scored for director Akira Kurosawa and, at the opposite cinematic pole, four entries in the Godzilla series.

Most of the scores for Kurosawa's earlier films were written by Fumio Hayasaka, with whom Sato studied for four years after college graduation. But in 1955, while working on I Live In Fear, Hayasaka died, and Sato completed the music. He scored all Kurosawa's films for the next 10 years.

Hayasaka's scores were more closely based on Japanese classical music than Sato's, which, while remaining within the indigenous tradition, was invaded - some might say corrupted - by more popular western forms and instrumentation. Even in Kurosawa's period films, the electric guitar, saxophone and vibraphone were used. But, in the case of the two jidai-geki (samurai action) films, Yojimbo (1961) and Sanjuro (1962), which almost came close to spoofing the genre, Sato's often jaunty percussive orchestration worked to perfection.

The rhythmic use of the harpsichord, cymbals and sarcastic brass notes is reminiscent of the music in 1960s western comedy movies. However, Sato's music more often punctuates the action rather than underlines it, and is seldom heard behind dialogue.

Previously, in The Throne Of Blood (1957), Kurosawa's samurai version of Macbeth, Sato's music was sparer, mainly featuring flute and drums, with ominous chords on the brass, adding to the eerie atmosphere. For The Hidden Fortress (1959), the music was of a wider range, counterpointing the violent, humorous and magical tones the film encompassed. More natural contemporary scoring was used for Kurosawa's modern tales, such as The Bad Sleep Well (1960) and High And Low (1963), both based on Ed McBain novels.

Sato was born on Japan's northernmost main island, Hokkaido, the youngest of six brothers. He received formal training in classical music, his favourite composers being Stravinsky, Sibelius and Manuel de Falla. He also enjoyed jazz, especially Quincy Jones, and admired the film scores of Dimitri Tiomkin, John Williams, Henry Mancini and Alfred Newman.

Sato sometimes found working with Kurosawa frustrating. "Kurosawa gave me a lot of advice about the scores I wrote for his films," he once said. "We sometimes would watch the same scene over and over again, and he would ask me to change the orchestration or the placement of the music in the scene. None of the other directors with whom I worked did this." Sato was going to work on Kurosawa's first film for five years, the epic Kagemusha (1980), but they disagreed on how the movie should be scored.

The monster movies provided an extreme contrast. Apart from Godzilla Raids Again (1955), Godzilla Versus The Sea Monster (1966), Son Of Godzilla (1967) and Godzilla Versus Megalon (1974), he scored other science fiction and fantasy films such as Half Human (1955), The H-Man (1958), The Lost World Of Sinbad (1963) and Tidal Wave (1973).

When the respected classical composer Akira Ifukube was asked to write the score for the first Godzilla movie, Godzilla, King Of The Monsters (1954), he said, "I can't write music for a film like this." However he did, and when Sato took over he providing a jazzier sound, as opposed to his predecessor's heavier, more dramatic orchestration.

Sato is survived by his wife, Chieko.

 Masaru Sato, composer, born 1928; died December 5 1999

But, in the case of the two jidai-geki (samurai action) films, Yojimbo (1961) and Sanjuro (1962), which almost came close to spoofing the genre, Sato's often jaunty percussive orchestration worked to perfection. The rhythmic use of the harpsichord, cymbals and sarcastic brass notes is reminiscent of the music in 1960s western comedy movies. However, Sato's music more often punctuates the action rather than underlines it, and is seldom heard behind dialogue. Previously, in The Throne Of Blood (1957), Kurosawa's samurai version of Macbeth, Sato's music was sparer, mainly featuring flute and drums, with ominous chords on the brass, adding to the eerie atmosphere. For The Hidden Fortress (1959), the music was of a wider range, counterpointing the violent, humorous and magical tones the film encompassed. More natural contemporary scoring was used for Kurosawa's modern tales, such as The Bad Sleep Well (1960) and High And Low (1963), both based on Ed McBain novels. Sato was born on Japan's northernmost main island, Hokkaido, the youngest of six brothers. He received formal training in classical music, his favourite composers being Stravinsky, Sibelius and Manuel de Falla. He also enjoyed jazz, especially Quincy Jones, and admired the film scores of Dimitri Tiomkin, John Williams, Henry Mancini and Alfred Newman. Sato sometimes found working with Kurosawa frustrating. "Kurosawa gave me a lot of advice about the scores I wrote for his films," he once said. "We sometimes would watch the same scene over and over again, and he would ask me to change the orchestration or the placement of the music in the scene. None of the other directors with whom I worked did this." Sato was going to work on Kurosawa's first film for five years, the epic Kagemusha (1980), but they disagreed on how the movie should be scored. The monster movies provided an extreme contrast. Apart from Godzilla Raids Again (1955), Godzilla Versus The Sea Monster (1966), Son Of Godzilla (1967) and Godzilla Versus Megalon (1974), he scored other science fiction and fantasy films such as Half Human (1955), The H-Man (1958), The Lost World Of Sinbad (1963) and Tidal Wave (1973). When the respected classical composer Akira Ifukube was asked to write the score for the first Godzilla movie, Godzilla, King Of The Monsters (1954), he said, "I can't write music for a film like this." However he did, and when Sato took over he providing a jazzier sound, as opposed to his predecessor's heavier, more dramatic orchestration. Sato is survived by his wife, Chieko.  Masaru Sato, composer, born 1928; died December 5 1999

fields.headline: Lord Braine of Wheatley
fields.standfirst: Energetic but frustrated MP torn between Tory dreams of Commonwealth and Europe
fields.trailText: Lord Braine of Wheatley, who has died aged 85, never really reached his full potential, despite a full political life, largely as the Tory MP Sir Bernard Braine, which included a record-breaking parliamentary filibuster. In 1987 he became father of the Commons, before standing down in 1992, after 42 years as an Essex MP, to enter the Lords.
fields.body:
Lord Braine of Wheatley, who has died aged 85, never really reached his full potential, despite a full political life, largely as the Tory MP Sir Bernard Braine, which included a record-breaking parliamentary filibuster. In 1987 he became father of the Commons, before standing down in 1992, after 42 years as an Essex MP, to enter the Lords.

The intensity of his devotion to the county was shown in his 195-minute Commons speech killing off the British Railways Bill, which would have allowed rail connections to carry oil and chemicals to and from Canvey Island.

Braine's crucial mistake was to be an enthusiastic supporter of the African Commonwealth in the early 1960s, just as his contemporary, Edward Heath, was emphasising Britain's European future. When Heath eventually became prime minister, he blocked Braine from further ministerial office.

Braine hid his disappointment with crusades against abortion, alcoholism, video nasties, Maplin and Stansted airports, war criminals and, above all, against those who planted potentially explosive methane, oil refineries and chemical stores on Canvey Island - "the most dangerous island in the British empire". His disappointments were all the greater because, like Heath, he had been part of the famous "class of 1950" Tory MPs who entered the Commons after wartime successes as officers.

Like Heath, Braine was a grammar schoolboy: his father was a minor civil servant and a Fabian. Unlike Heath, who made it to Balliol College, Oxford, Braine became an Inland Revenue clerk. Again like Heath, he became a young Tory, active in the minority, pro-Churchill anti-appeasement wing of the party, and fought Sir Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists in east London.

Commissioned in the army in 1940, he served in West Africa, and after Camberley staff college took part in the 1944-45 push into north-west Europe. He fought hopeless Leyton East in the 1945 election, and a year later became a Tory party apparatchik, aligning himself with the progressive "New Tories".

Lucky to find a winnable seat in Billericay, Braine entered the Commons in 1950, but his progressive brain began warring with his rightwing gut. He became an officer of the Tory MPs' commonwealth affairs committee, and parliamentary private secretary to Alan Lennox-Boyd, like him a Commonwealth enthusiast. But, in 1956, he attacked Tony Benn as a "treacherous defeatist" and "Nasser's little lackey" for opposing the Suez invasion. Likewise, in 1957 he agreed that modern economic developments ran counter to apartheid, but when Fenner Brockway tried to make racial discrimination illegal, Braine talked the proposal out of the Commons.

Harold Macmillan gave him his first ministerial post - as pensions under-secretary - in 1960, and a year later Braine got his chance at Commonwealth relations, serving under Duncan Sandys. After Macmillan's 1962 reshuffle, he became parliamentary secretary for health, under Enoch Powell, who envied him his backslapping bonhomie.

Braine's ministerial experience ended with the Labour victory of 1964. Then, in 1965, he voted for the pro-Commonwealth Reginald Maudling, rather than the pro-European Heath, in the Tory leadership contest. When Maudling was made Heath's Commonwealth spokesman, he named Braine as his deputy, and he was a strong objector to sanctions after Ian Smith proclaimed the independence of Rhodesia's white minority.

When Heath unexpectedly won the 1970 election, he made Braine deputy chairman of the commonwealth parliamentary association, with an automatic knighthood after two years - but it was poor consolation for no ministerial post.

Braine immersed himself in backbench battles and tried to make himself more attractive to Heath, proclaiming in 1971 that "the rejection of the European opportunity would be unforgivable". But the 1972-73 immigration scares caused by the Uganda Asians crisis, just as entry for EC nationals was easing, showed where Braine's heart lay. In the tightening of immigration rules against the Commonwealth, he became the "leader of the Old Commonwealth loyalists", as the Sunday Times dubbed him, insisting on special rights for "patrials", the descendants of British emigrants.

With Labour back in power in 1974, Braine's eruptions began again after the Flixborough disaster, when Labour's environment secretary, Tony Crosland, told him that the same explosive chemical was stored on Canvey Island. He also became a high-profile anti-abortionist, and, as chairman of the National Council on Alcoholism, talked out a 1976 attempt to ease licensing hours and provide family rooms in pubs. His aggressive and unctuous style began to invite deflation. He was not, joked the Sunday Express, "the Braine of Britain".

Long before the Argentine invasion of the Falklands in 1982, he was the islands' fiercest defender, and in his last decade in the Commons, when Mrs Thatcher made him a privy councillor, he touched all his usual bases. He opposed Stansted airport, voted against Sunday trading, and was the only Tory to vote against liberalising pub licensing laws. As consultant to the Police Superintendents' Association, he opposed all suggestions that the police were racist. His last act in the Commons in 1992 was to vote to ban hunting with hounds.

At the farewell for retiring MPs, the speaker, Sir Bernard Weatherill, told of his first encounter with Braine. After establishing they were the only two Bernards in the House, Weatherill showed him a motion he was tabling, soliciting Braine's support. Braine borrowed the motion. Returning after some time, he told Weatherill he had secured some publicity. Weatherill sought the story in the next day's newspapers. "And do you know," he recalled, "I was not the Bernard who was mentioned."

Braine's wife of 47 years, Kathleen, died in 1982. He is survived by three sons.

 Bernard Richard Braine, Lord Braine of Wheatley, politician, born June 24 1914; died January 5 2000

webTitle: Locals to control Khmer Rouge trials

fields.headline: Locals to control Khmer Rouge trials
fields.trailText: The Cambodian government yesterday approved a draft law to try Khmer Rouge leaders before a joint panel of domestic and foreign judges - but it will not give the outside world the final say on the verdicts.
fields.body:
The Cambodian government yesterday approved a draft law to try Khmer Rouge leaders before a joint panel of domestic and foreign judges - but it will not give the outside world the final say on the verdicts.

Under the legislation, which comes after months of UN-brokered talks, a suspect cannot be found guilty unless at least one foreign judge and two Cambodian judges agree.

Foreign judges, who will remain in the minority, will be replaced by Cambodians if they drop out. The draft leaves out a proposed clause saying Cambodian judges must not be affiliated with any political party. Nor does it provide for UN monitoring of the trials.

The prime minister, Hun Sen, has resisted UN pressure for an international war crimes tribunal, and critics fear that former Khmer Rouge leaders who have made deals with the Phnom Penh regime will avoid prosecution.

Instead, the tribunal is expected to focus on Ta Mok, the "Khmer Rouge Butcher" who is the only senior figure to have been arrested, and on secondary figures blamed for the murder of up to 2m people in the "killing fields" in 1975-78.

Hun Sen's supporters have accused the west of hypocrisy, pointing out that the US and its allies gave funds and diplomatic recognition to a Cambodian resistance movement dominated by the Khmer Rouge for a decade after Pol Pot was ousted.

Observers doubt whether the UN will approve the draft law, which omits several key UN recommendations. If it is rejected Hun Sen has said it will still go ahead, but he will have to find other sources to fund the tribunal.

The lawyer for Ta Mok has threatened to summon the former US secretary of state Henry Kissinger and other international figures to give evidence on why they supported the Khmer Rouge after 1979.

webTitle: Buddhist leader flees Tibet to join Dalai Lama

fields.headline: Buddhist leader flees Tibet to join Dalai Lama
fields.trailText: A young boy regarded by Tibetans as a living Buddha of equal political and religious status to the Dalai Lama has escaped from a monastery in central Tibet, despite being kept under permanent surveillance by Chinese minders.
fields.body:
A young boy regarded by Tibetans as a living Buddha of equal political and religious status to the Dalai Lama has escaped from a monastery in central Tibet, despite being kept under permanent surveillance by Chinese minders.

Senior lamas from the Tibetan exile community have confirmed that 14-year-old Urgyen Trinley Dorje, the 17th Karmapa, accompanied by a small group of monks, slipped past his guards at Tsurphu monastery on December 28. The party walked across rugged mountain terrain to reach northern India yesterday morning.

The young Karmapa has joined the Dalai Lama at his residence in Dharamsala.

Urgyen Trinley Dorje was born into a nomad family in the village of Bakor in eastern Tibet on June 26 1985, four years after the death of the 16th Karmapa, who fled to India following the Chinese takeover of Tibet in 1959.

Magical manifestations, including triple suns, rainbows and unearthly music, are said to have occurred as the present Karmapa was born.

He was recognised by the Dalai Lama in 1992 and subsequently enthroned at Tsurphu monastery, in an elaborate ceremony sanctioned by the Chinese authorities and attended by thousands of Tibetans.

While the flight of the young Karmapa - head of the rich and powerful Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism - is a cause for joy among the tens of thousands of Kagyu disciples in the west, it is deeply embarrassing to the Chinese and a major setback to Beijing's campaign to divide Tibetan allegiances.

Richard Oppenheimer of the London-based Tibet Information Network said a severe security crackdown appeared inevitable. "The Chinese have always promoted the 17th Karmapa as a pro-Chinese patriotic figure and they have made a point of trying to drive a wedge between him and the Dalai Lama," he said.

It is not known why Urgyen Trinley Dorje chose to leave Tibet, but the young Karmapa had been requesting permission to be with his guru, the exiled Tai Situ Rinpoche, for some time. Direct personal contact between young lamas and their spiritual teachers is integral to the oral tradition of Tibetan Buddhism.

The lineage of the Karmapas is older than that of the Dalai Lamas, and in old Tibet their prestige equalled that of the Dalai Lamas in the eyes of a large percentage of the population.

The Kagyu order, which has built a worldwide organisation said to be worth millions of pounds, is split between two factions. One, supported by the Dalai Lama, accepts Urgyen Trinley Dorje as the rightful heir while the other, headed by the senior lama Shamar Rinpoche, backs a different child who was also smuggled out of Tibet and is living in Germany.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Four arrested over hijacking
fields.body:
Four arrested over hijacking

India has detained four men it accuses of helping plan the week-long hijacking in December of an Indian jet.

India's home minister, Lal Krishna Advani, said the two Pakistanis, an Indian and a Nepali belonged to Harkat-ul-Ansar - a Pakistan-based group fighting Indian rule in Kashmir. The hijack ended after India freed three militants in exchange for 155 air passengers. Reuters, New Delhi

New executions reported in Iraq

The Iraqi Communist party yesterday accused Baghdad of executing 40 members of the armed forces.

From Kurd-held northern Iraq, it said that General Ali Hassan al-Majeed, a cousin of President Saddam Hussein and a core member of the leadership, set up a special military court to try men suspected of disloyalty. Reuters, Cairo

Drivers stay off crash line

Norway's train drivers yesterday boycotted a line on which 20 people died this week after two trains crashed when a driver apparently passed a red stop signal.

Stein Erik Olsen, the national safety representative for Norway's 1,100 train drivers, said signalling systems on the line at Asta station, about 100 miles north of Oslo, were "not good enough". But the state rail director denied there were technical faults. Reuters, Asta, Norway

Record low for EU babies

European birthrates are at their lowest since the second world war, and are still falling, the EU statistical office, Eurostat, said yesterday.

The number of births in 1999 dropped by 0.5% from 1998. Death rates in the 15 EU states remained stable.

The agency put the EU population at 376.4m at the start of the new millennium. AP, Luxembourg

Top policeman quits in Japan

Japan's seniormost police chief handed in his resignation yesterday after allegations of drug abuse and sexual harassment prompted calls for closer monitoring of officers.

The National Police Agency chief, Yuko Sekiguchi, 60, said he was standing down in an effort to restore public trust in the police. But he said his resignation did not imply that he was taking responsibility for any wrongdoing. AP, Tokyo

webTitle: Yeltsin enjoys life in the slow lane

fields.headline: Yeltsin enjoys life in the slow lane
fields.standfirst:
Former leader revels in pomp and praise on his visit to the Holy Land
Yeltsin's Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Boris Yeltsin, the former Russian leader, arrived in Israel in the regal style to which he became accustomed as president - the same luxury airliner and the entourage of wife, daughter and granddaughters, interpreters, doctors, aides and journalists. Even the same armoured Zil waited on the tarmac with Russian flags flying.
fields.body:
Boris Yeltsin, the former Russian leader, arrived in Israel in the regal style to which he became accustomed as president - the same luxury airliner and the entourage of wife, daughter and granddaughters, interpreters, doctors, aides and journalists. Even the same armoured Zil waited on the tarmac with Russian flags flying.

Mr Yeltsin had all the pomp and circumstance, but none of the responsibility, of being the leader of Russia. And he seemed to like it.

At the Hilton hotel no expense was spared and no status yielded: the Yeltsins were given the suite the Clintons occupied last year, with two extra features: a lengthened bed and an ice bucket containing two bottles of Swedish vodka. The only hitch was the Russian food flown in for the Yeltsin party, which contravened the Hilton's kosher requirements and was given away to the poor.

At the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate in the Old City at the centre of Jerusalem yesterday, real presidents were two a penny. Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia was there, along with Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus and Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine.

But the first president of Russia, as the country's media had dubbed him, was the centre of attention when the leaders were made knights of the holy sepulchre by Diodoros I, the senior Orthodox cleric in Jerusalem.

The regal treatment continued at the residence of Israel's President Ezer Weizman, who is still a real president, but is under media pressure to emulate Mr Yeltsin's resignation amid corruption allegations.

A military guard of honour, a trumpet fanfare and a roll of drums greeted the first president as he walked slowly into the reception hall. Most gratifying of all, acknowledged by Mr Yeltsin with dreamy smiles, nods and waves, was the honour guard he will miss most - the wall of cameras.

In Bethlehem, where he was greeted by a military band before dining with the Palestinian Authority president, Yasser Arafat, Mr Yeltsin shed tears sparked by what he said was his joy at meeting the Palestinian leader in the Holy Land.

He wished his friend a bright future in a "dear Palestinian state", and added: "I want to tell my friend that he should believe in Russia and trust Russia."

And all this without the nagging presence of the nuclear briefcase. No one was about to comment that Mr Yeltsin had said in the morning the Chechen war would be over in two months, and changed his prediction to one month in the afternoon. No more were the amateur doctors of the world media going to comment on his stiff, puffy appearance, his slurred speech, or what happened to the Hilton's vodka.

Yet there were subtle reminders that this was, in the end, a consolation trip for a man who was exiting the world's political stage and unsure what to do next. The occasion was the Russian Orthodox Christmas, and in making his first trip to the Holy Land the first president was reviving an ancient tradition of Christian rulers who made pilgrimages to Jerusalem to atone for the sins of their reigns.

His future in the political background was foreshadowed in the tributes that followed him. "Whatever state he was in, however bad his mood, he was always respectful towards the press," reminisced Boris Grishchenko, veteran Yeltsin-follower, for Interfax news agency. Close to tears, he added: "Gorbachev always used to address us with the familiar 'thou', but Yeltsin always called us 'you'."

The Israeli interior minister and former Soviet refusenik, Natan Sharansky, who sat next to Mr Yeltsin's wife Naina at Mr Weizman's banquet, reached back into the past to say: "In the end he was the man who, in a critical moment for Russia, stood on a tank and defended democracy."

Mr Yeltsin is 68. Most of the world expected him to be carried out of the Kremlin feet first, and now he finds himself with time on his hands. Earlier this week his daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko, said he would follow the Gorbachev retirement path: create a foundation, set up a library and employ researchers. He would visit the world, she added.

"He's seen practically nothing," she said. "I sometimes say to him: 'Do you remember how we saw something at such-and-such a place?' And he replies he doesn't. Well, how was he supposed to see anything out of a car window?"

But it was Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, speaking before Mr Yeltsin's departure for Israel, who gave the most candid account of the former leader's anxiety as he contemplated the future.

"He spoke of it with a certain sadness, even fear," said Mr Putin. "The way I understand it is that he can't imagine what else you can do if you've been the president of Russia.

"Maybe he'll be angry with me for saying this, but it is as though he found it a problem - he asked me, and thought out loud, and said: 'It is clear for me that the time has come. But it isn't clear what I, personally, should do next.'"

Even the same armoured Zil waited on the tarmac with Russian flags flying. Mr Yeltsin had all the pomp and circumstance, but none of the responsibility, of being the leader of Russia. At the Hilton hotel no expense was spared and no status yielded: the Yeltsins were given the suite the Clintons occupied last year, with two extra features: a lengthened bed and an ice bucket containing two bottles of Swedish vodka. The only hitch was the Russian food flown in for the Yeltsin party, which contravened the Hilton's kosher requirements and was given away to the poor. At the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate in the Old City at the centre of Jerusalem yesterday, real presidents were two a penny. Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia was there, along with Alexander Lukashenko of Belarus and Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine. But the first president of Russia, as the country's media had dubbed him, was the centre of attention when the leaders were made knights of the holy sepulchre by Diodoros I, the senior Orthodox cleric in Jerusalem. The regal treatment continued at the residence of Israel's President Ezer Weizman, who is still a real president, but is under media pressure to emulate Mr Yeltsin's resignation amid corruption allegations. A military guard of honour, a trumpet fanfare and a roll of drums greeted the first president as he walked slowly into the reception hall. Most gratifying of all, acknowledged by Mr Yeltsin with dreamy smiles, nods and waves, was the honour guard he will miss most - the wall of cameras. In Bethlehem, where he was greeted by a military band before dining with the Palestinian Authority president, Yasser Arafat, Mr Yeltsin shed tears sparked by what he said was his joy at meeting the Palestinian leader in the Holy Land. He wished his friend a bright future in a "dear Palestinian state", and added: "I want to tell my friend that he should believe in Russia and trust Russia." And all this without the nagging presence of the nuclear briefcase. No one was about to comment that Mr Yeltsin had said in the morning the Chechen war would be over in two months, and changed his prediction to one month in the afternoon. No more were the amateur doctors of the world media going to comment on his stiff, puffy appearance, his slurred speech, or what happened to the Hilton's vodka. Yet there were subtle reminders that this was, in the end, a consolation trip for a man who was exiting the world's political stage and unsure what to do next. The occasion was the Russian Orthodox Christmas, and in making his first trip to the Holy Land the first president was reviving an ancient tradition of Christian rulers who made pilgrimages to Jerusalem to atone for the sins of their reigns. His future in the political background was foreshadowed in the tributes that followed him. "Whatever state he was in, however bad his mood, he was always respectful towards the press," reminisced Boris Grishchenko, veteran Yeltsin-follower, for Interfax news agency. Close to tears, he added: "Gorbachev always used to address us with the familiar 'thou', but Yeltsin always called us 'you'." The Israeli interior minister and former Soviet refusenik, Natan Sharansky, who sat next to Mr Yeltsin's wife Naina at Mr Weizman's banquet, reached back into the past to say: "In the end he was the man who, in a critical moment for Russia, stood on a tank and defended democracy." Mr Yeltsin is 68. Most of the world expected him to be carried out of the Kremlin feet first, and now he finds himself with time on his hands. Earlier this week his daughter, Tatyana Dyachenko, said he would follow the Gorbachev retirement path: create a foundation, set up a library and employ researchers. He would visit the world, she added. "He's seen practically nothing," she said. "I sometimes say to him: 'Do you remember how we saw something at such-and-such a place?' And he replies he doesn't. Well, how was he supposed to see anything out of a car window?" But it was Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, speaking before Mr Yeltsin's departure for Israel, who gave the most candid account of the former leader's anxiety as he contemplated the future. "He spoke of it with a certain sadness, even fear," said Mr Putin. "The way I understand it is that he can't imagine what else you can do if you've been the president of Russia. "Maybe he'll be angry with me for saying this, but it is as though he found it a problem - he asked me, and thought out loud, and said: 'It is clear for me that the time has come. But it isn't clear what I, personally, should do next.'"

fields.headline: Botched circumcision kills boys
fields.trailText: Four boys have died and about 100 have been admitted to hospital after botched circumcision ceremonies in South Africa.
fields.body:
Four boys have died and about 100 have been admitted to hospital after botched circumcision ceremonies in South Africa.

Doctors have blamed "traditional surgeons" who use the same blade to circumcise dozens of teenage boys at a time as part of ancient Xhosa rites of passage in Transkei.

The children either bled to death or died from infections. Some of those in hospital are in a critical condition.

Initiates have also complained of traditional surgeons who are drunk or high on cannabis during the cutting ceremony. Health workers have long warned against traditional methods of circumcision, in part because repeated use of the same blade will spread Aids and hepatitis.

Infections are also caused when bandages used to control bleeding are tied too tight.

The health ministry has threatened to prosecute traditional surgeons who fail to maintain good hygiene, but to little effect.

Ten boys died during similar ceremonies in the middle of last year. Families typically pay 200 rand (£20) for a traditional surgeon and attendants at the ceremony. Most Xhosa families are too poor to pay for a hospital circumcision.

Traditional leaders in parts of the Eastern Cape are hoping a tiny clamp imported from Malaysia will put an end to the deaths and infections.

The "Tara Klamp" does the cutting and then protects the wound, eliminating bandages. And it is used once, eliminating transmitted diseases.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Bloom's
130 Golders Green Road, London NW11 Tel: 0181 455 1338

The one, the only (the only one left), the best-known kosher restaurant in London, after 30-odd years still faithfully serving the faithful as well as those in search of food which is short on frills and long on substance. (The original East End branch, which opened in the 1920s, shut a few years ago.)

This is where you go for quality fresh pickled cucumber, chopped herring, beetroot borscht, chopped liver, latkes, monster turkey schnitzel and all the rest. Refined it ain't, comforting it surely is. Helpings for the bigger eater meet prices for the smaller pocket, while the waiters have a veteran bossiness about them: they're firmly in command, as they have been since the place opened. Drink Maccabee beer for street cred. Not that you'll get it.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Ixxy and Friends
36 Berwick Street, London W1 Tel: 0171 494 9282
Also at Bluewater, Kent

"Gourmet" bagels, apparently, and if gourmet means giant and chewy, we'll let their definition stand. Baked freshly in-store, bagels here are ready to go (the New Yorker with pastrami and Swiss cheese, for example, from £2.20) or can be whipped up by friendly, non-Americanised staff who probably wouldn't snigger if you went for cream cheese and chocolate spread on poppyseed.

Or try the 15-second option and pick a plain, sesame, onion, chocolate chip... or (for the adventurous) an "everything" bagel, or six to take home. No great leap from the Pret ponder-pick-till routine, but you're more likely to get a seat at lunchtimes. Good juices, too.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: My dropout son is a sponger and an embarrassment. What can I do?
fields.trailText: My eldest son, Daniel, has recently returned from India and, to my utter horror, has become what can only be described as a white Rastafarian. While this in itself should not be troubling, he has become a total dropout, constantly moping about the house. Especially annoying is the anti-materialism he espouses while staying gratis at Hotel Du Père.
fields.body:
My eldest son, Daniel, has recently returned from India and, to my utter horror, has become what can only be described as a white Rastafarian. While this in itself should not be troubling, he has become a total dropout, constantly moping about the house. Especially annoying is the anti-materialism he espouses while staying gratis at Hotel Du Père.

Meanwhile, my other son, Tim, has taken to wearing make-up, dyeing his hair black and only ever venturing out of his bedroom at night. In contrast to Daniel's vegetarianism, he insists on eating only raw meat. As I'm a prominent member of the local neighbourhood watch, my offspring cause me constant embarrassment, especially when they are reprimanded by my colleagues.

Every parent, at some stage, deals with rebellious teenagers, but it appears that my sons are rebelling against each other, and then me. My questions are: Is it right to let them continue 'being themselves'? Is this merely a stage they are going through? If so, when will it end? And is there anything I can do to precipitate it?

Take some photos
What have your sons done to deserve the opprobrium of your colleagues? Did they bash a little old lady on the head and steal her pension book? Did they expose themselves to primary schoolgirls? Did they push cocaine outside the gates of the local comprehensive? If their only crime is that the neighbours don't like the look of them, then I am afraid the problem is with the neighbours, not with your sons.

Of course, they'll grow out of it: even the most outrageous pop stars send their offspring to the most traditional public schools in later life. But the process will be delayed if you continue to care more about what your neighbours think than about your sons' personal development.

So relax. Give Daniel a good vegetarian cookbook for Christmas, and give your younger son advice on sound hygiene procedures so that his extreme carnivorous habits do not result in food poisoning. Make sure you take plenty of pictures: when your sons become parents and complain about the appearance of their teenaged sons, you can ask your grandchildren if they would like to see what their fathers looked like when they were their age. The look of sheer terror on your sons' faces as you hand the photo album over to your grandchildren will more than compensate you for the aggravation you are getting at the moment.
Claude Shields
Aylesbury

Look beneath the hair
Most middle-class kids like to test the boundaries. Rest assured that by the time they're 30 they'll probably be models of respectability and conformity. My own sons sound very similar to yours, though this was nearly 25 years ago. The elder son was the hippy - vegetarian and anti-materialism. The younger was an early punk and anti-everything. Both were expelled from their public schools, and with such opposites our house was a battleground.

My elder son is now married with children and headmaster of a special-needs school. As for my younger son, I'm afraid he did stay somewhat off the rails in my opinion. After spending the 80s selling private pensions, he is now a "model" Blairite councillor in north London. His latest achievement? Cutting the budget for my other son's school. On balance I think I preferred his harmless teenage rebellion.

Don't lose sleep over what they do now to shock you. Worry about what they really are, beneath the hair dye or dreadlocks - what they might become at 40 in a suit.
Name and address withheld

Count your blessings
That you should be so lucky! Our 17-year-old son has learning difficulties. He will never be able to travel independently to India or anywhere else, is relatively housebound and dependent on us, and is turning into the kind of adult you desperately hope won't sit next to you on a long train journey. As his parents we have become immune to embarrassment (although his younger teenage sister still dies a little social death every time we go anywhere together). He looks normal, but is odd - far odder than either of your boys, who don't sound at all strange for our area (inner London). As long as they are not racist, homophobic or sexist, does it matter? The raw meat sounds a little unusual, but not in itself harmful to anyone else. So in answer to your questions, you can't stop them being themselves, and it may not be just a stage. Name and address withheld

Give them a chance
Your sons are expressing their individuality. This may be a "phase" but it is nevertheless an important part of their growing up. My son and daughter presented us with similar dilemmas as teenagers and twentysomethings, and on the basis of my experience, I would suggest admitting that you don't understand their views, but that you are willing to accept them. However, this depends on them accepting your right to your way of life, contributing to the household by helping out in ways you mutually agree and by not embarrassing you with their behaviour.

I would suggest keeping avenues of communication open by any means you can find, keeping an open mind, and a sense of humour.
Jane Lamb
Norfolk

They're only young once
It sounds as if Daniel and Tim are finding themselves in a way that, if left to its own devices, will pass without any problems whatsoever.

Growing up for me was all about experimenting - doing things differently and breaking away from socially dictated roles in order to challenge the attitudes of the people that accepted them. This process - a temporary phase, I might add - was usually more of an issue to those observing it from the outside than for me experiencing it first-hand.

One thing is certain. The more negative attention you draw to this issue, the worse it will become. Moreover, bringing it to the notice of a national forum only serves to nourish the appetite for attention that fuels the behaviour in the first place.

Relax. Back up for a while, and allow your sons the freedom they deserve. We're only young once, and India can have a powerful effect on its visitors, though - fortunately or unfortunately - we all hit planet earth again sooner or later.
Kunal Tristan Dutta
Finchley

Next week

I am the single mother of a 10-year-old girl and I have brought her up alone since birth. I feel that I have provided her with a good life under the circumstances and she has regular contact with her father. I have always put her first, but I do make sure that I get time for a social life.

We have had a reasonably good relationship over the years, although she is strong willed and rude at times. I have had one or two boyfriends in 10 years but I have kept them out of her life. However, six months ago I fell in love with a wonderful man and we know we want to spend our lives together. To start with, we saw each other when my daughter was not around, although she did know I was seeing him. Gradually the three of us spent more time together and they appeared to be getting on quite well. But recently she has started being rude to him, saying that we were quite happy without him.

This is the man I want to marry and she is my daughter, and I'm being pulled apart. She has had my undivided attention all of her life and I understand that this would be a big change for her, but other people seem to work it out with children and new partners. He says that I should not let my life be run by a 10-year-old. What am I to do?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

webTitle: Unholy war tears spice islands apart

fields.headline: Unholy war tears spice islands apart
fields.standfirst:
Burning, looting and murder spreads across eastern Indonesia as religious violence spirals out of control

Fellowship of Indonesian Christians in America site
Human Rights Watch
fields.trailText: The dented red and white Marlboro billboard is a bizarre splash of colour on Ambon's deserted Sayadji Street. Everything else is a mass of twisted rusty metal hanging from burnt out buildings or rubble on the bloodstained road. Groups of heavily-armed soldiers are positioned every 20 yards, not only ready for trouble but seemingly expecting it.
fields.body:
The dented red and white Marlboro billboard is a bizarre splash of colour on Ambon's deserted Sayadji Street. Everything else is a mass of twisted rusty metal hanging from burnt out buildings or rubble on the bloodstained road. Groups of heavily-armed soldiers are positioned every 20 yards, not only ready for trouble but seemingly expecting it.

Occasionally a face peeps out from behind a broken door or boarded up window down one of the equally devastated side streets. No one stays visible for long as snipers occupy the upper floors of those buildings left standing.

Once this was a bustling 150-yard long shopping street in the capital of the Moluccas - the archipelago of spice islands in eastern Indonesia. Now it acts as a barrier between Christians and Muslims in a rapidly escalating religious war.

In the last week violence has reached a pitch not seen in Indonesia since the conflict that prompted UN intervention in East Timor. And yet the world, and the UN, remains silent over the wanton destruction of what was once the world's most affluent trading zone.

The first 11 months of the conflict in the spice islands cost 750 lives. Casualty figures from the remote outer islands are impossible to verify but it is believed that figure has doubled in the last 10 days as people replace their bows and arrows with the homemade rifles and grenades manufactured in rudimentary arms factories.

Thousands more have been injured, 200,000 out of a total population of 2m have fled or been displaced and the situation is deteriorating by the day.

This is a strange war - it almost appears to be two separate conflicts, as each community paints itself as the innocent victim of attacks which have forced it to defend itself from an enemy intent on eradicating it from the islands. Finding the truth in such a sea of sectarian lies is almost impossible.

On thing is clear: the level of mutual hatred. There have been no formal peace talks for weeks and the only point of contact between the two communities is at one neutral intersection along the demarcation line.

Mutual hatred

Here, watched by soldiers, people from both sides repress their hostility and trade goods unavailable in their own sections of the city. "If I went over there to get the goods myself I would have my throat slit," said Ongin Darmawan, a Muslim hardware dealer. "But then if one of them came over here I would slit his throat so that's why we do it here."

"What we have now is a vicious conflict rapidly spiralling out of control with both sides wanting to take revenge for past attacks and wipe the other out, while the military is stuck in the middle," said Richard Mowat, the regional coordinator of Médecins Sans Frontières and one of the few foreigners left in the city.

The military is a key player in the conflict but its role is unclear. There have been numerous instances of soldiers, marines and police taking sides and even shooting at colleagues who support the other side.

"There is no doubt that rogue elements have been taking sides and inflaming the situation," said the region's civilian governor Mohammad Latuconsina. "But there is not enough evidence to say it is a deliberate army policy."

A more professional attitude does appear to have developed over the last four days - the military is deploying in greater numbers and the local units which were most partisan have been withdrawn.

The regional army commander, Brigadier General Max Tamaela, said yesterday that there were about 6,500 troops in the region and more are available if necessary. "But I cannot end the fighting," he said "The initiative must come from the people themselves. And until it does, there will never be peace."

It is telling that Muslim leaders say the military is neutral while Christians want the army withdrawn and replaced with international forces. The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, is refusing to countenance such a move and there has been a conspicuous silence from the international community.

"Without the army the Muslims will not be brave enough to continue terrorising us and so we would be able to live in peace," said Semmy Waileruny, the coordinator of the Church Justice Team, a Protestant group.

The balance of evidence suggests that the Christians are less to blame than the Muslims for the latest bout of fighting, which began on December 26 with the destruction of Ambon's oldest church. However, they are far from being the angels they claim.

"While the populations of the two communities are relatively evenly matched, it says a lot that Christians make up less than 10% of the refugees across the Moluccas," said Mr Mowat. He has seen Christians dragging decapitated Muslim bodies through the streets outside his office.

Blackouts

It is also no coincidence that most nights the Muslim quarter suffers blackouts while the Christian areas continue to enjoy a robust electricity supply.

Ascertaining what is happening on the more remote islands is extremely difficult it is difficult to confirm accurate casualty figures or the exact timing of attacks.

"What we have is a lot of fighting but no formal structure to it," said Mr Latuconsina. "So it is hard to control and harder to stop. It is entirely in the people's own hands. But the situation has got so bad and people want so much revenge it is unlikely to end any time soon."

He refused to be more specific but most people in Ambon believe the violence may continue for months rather than weeks.

Christian view

Richard Makaruku, 19, a Christian student, was with friends on December 27 when he heard that a Muslim mob was gathering to attack Christians guarding the ruins of the city's Silo church, which had been set on fire nine hours earlier.

"I rushed to the area with my homemade rifle. It was clear the Muslims wanted to finish off the destruction they had started the previous day. They have been attacking us like this for the last year, we have to spend all our time defending ourselves. They want to turn the Moluccas into a Muslim land and drive all us Christians out.

We have to use firearms because the Muslims are supported by the army who have rifles and armoured cars. If we did not take action, we would just be crushed.

The Muslims started throwing grenades at us so we threw petrol bombs back at them. Then the soldiers opened fire. They are not neutral and so we will never agree to peace until they are withdrawn. They call the army TNI [Indonesian National Army] but it should be renamed TII, or Indonesian Islamic Army.

I fired my gun and I was shot in the liver. The next thing I remember was waking up in hospital. I am very lucky to be alive but am determined to recover to continue the struggle."

Muslim view

Hamdani Laturua, 33, is a Muslim lawyer who spends much of his time at Ambon's main Al Fatah mosque coordinating what he describes as self-defence activities.

"There are three types of Christians in the Moluccas, the radicals, those who are frustrated and the separatists. They are all dangerous and want to destroy us.

Radicals want to Christianise the whole region and drive us away. The frustrated want us to leave because they think we have taken all the best jobs. The separatists are members of the Republic of South Maluku movement. For decades they have been fighting to create an independent Christian country within Indonesia.

Of course, we want peace but they do not want peace. For the last year they have been steadily taking our land, killing Muslims and destroying our houses. They will not stop until we are all in the sea.

fields.bodyText: The dented red and white Marlboro billboard is a bizarre splash of colour on Ambon's deserted Sayadji Street. Everything else is a mass of twisted rusty metal hanging from burnt out buildings or rubble on the bloodstained road. Groups of heavily-armed soldiers are positioned every 20 yards, not only ready for trouble but seemingly expecting it. Occasionally a face peeps out from behind a broken door or boarded up window down one of the equally devastated side streets. No one stays visible for long as snipers occupy the upper floors of those buildings left standing. Once this was a bustling 150-yard long shopping street in the capital of the Moluccas - the archipelago of spice islands in eastern Indonesia. Now it acts as a barrier between Christians and Muslims in a rapidly escalating religious war. In the last week violence has reached a pitch not seen in Indonesia since the conflict that prompted UN intervention in East Timor. And yet the world, and the UN, remains silent over the wanton destruction of what was once the world's most affluent trading zone. The first 11 months of the conflict in the spice islands cost 750 lives. Casualty figures from the remote outer islands are impossible to verify but it is believed that figure has doubled in the last 10 days as people replace their bows and arrows with the homemade rifles and grenades manufactured in rudimentary arms factories. Thousands more have been injured, 200,000 out of a total population of 2m have fled or been displaced and the situation is deteriorating by the day. This is a strange war - it almost appears to be two separate conflicts, as each community paints itself as the innocent victim of attacks which have forced it to defend itself from an enemy intent on eradicating it from the islands. Finding the truth in such a sea of sectarian lies is almost impossible. On thing is clear: the level of mutual hatred. There have been no formal peace talks for weeks and the only point of contact between the two communities is at one neutral intersection along the demarcation line. Mutual hatred Here, watched by soldiers, people from both sides repress their hostility and trade goods unavailable in their own sections of the city. "If I went over there to get the goods myself I would have my throat slit," said Ongin Darmawan, a Muslim hardware dealer. "But then if one of them came over here I would slit his throat so that's why we do it here." "What we have now is a vicious conflict rapidly spiralling out of control with both sides wanting to take revenge for past attacks and wipe the other out, while the military is stuck in the middle," said Richard Mowat, the regional coordinator of Médecins Sans Frontières and one of the few foreigners left in the city. The military is a key player in the conflict but its role is unclear. There have been numerous instances of soldiers, marines and police taking sides and even shooting at colleagues who support the other side. "There is no doubt that rogue elements have been taking sides and inflaming the situation," said the region's civilian governor Mohammad Latuconsina. "But there is not enough evidence to say it is a deliberate army policy." A more professional attitude does appear to have developed over the last four days - the military is deploying in greater numbers and the local units which were most partisan have been withdrawn. The regional army commander, Brigadier General Max Tamaela, said yesterday that there were about 6,500 troops in the region and more are available if necessary. "But I cannot end the fighting," he said "The initiative must come from the people themselves. And until it does, there will never be peace." It is telling that Muslim leaders say the military is neutral while Christians want the army withdrawn and replaced with international forces. The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, is refusing to countenance such a move and there has been a conspicuous silence from the international community. "Without the army the Muslims will not be brave enough to continue terrorising us and so we would be able to live in peace," said Semmy Waileruny, the coordinator of the Church Justice Team, a Protestant group. The balance of evidence suggests that the Christians are less to blame than the Muslims for the latest bout of fighting, which began on December 26 with the destruction of Ambon's oldest church. However, they are far from being the angels they claim. "While the populations of the two communities are relatively evenly matched, it says a lot that Christians make up less than 10% of the refugees across the Moluccas," said Mr Mowat. He has seen Christians dragging decapitated Muslim bodies through the streets outside his office. Blackouts It is also no coincidence that most nights the Muslim quarter suffers blackouts while the Christian areas continue to enjoy a robust electricity supply. Ascertaining what is happening on the more remote islands is extremely difficult it is difficult to confirm accurate casualty figures or the exact timing of attacks. "What we have is a lot of fighting but no formal structure to it," said Mr Latuconsina. "So it is hard to control and harder to stop. It is entirely in the people's own hands. But the situation has got so bad and people want so much revenge it is unlikely to end any time soon." He refused to be more specific but most people in Ambon believe the violence may continue for months rather than weeks. Christian view Richard Makaruku, 19, a Christian student, was with friends on December 27 when he heard that a Muslim mob was gathering to attack Christians guarding the ruins of the city's Silo church, which had been set on fire nine hours earlier. "I rushed to the area with my homemade rifle. It was clear the Muslims wanted to finish off the destruction they had started the previous day. They have been attacking us like this for the last year, we have to spend all our time defending ourselves. They want to turn the Moluccas into a Muslim land and drive all us Christians out. We have to use firearms because the Muslims are supported by the army who have rifles and armoured cars. If we did not take action, we would just be crushed. The Muslims started throwing grenades at us so we threw petrol bombs back at them. Then the soldiers opened fire. They are not neutral and so we will never agree to peace until they are withdrawn. They call the army TNI [Indonesian National Army] but it should be renamed TII, or Indonesian Islamic Army. I fired my gun and I was shot in the liver. The next thing I remember was waking up in hospital. I am very lucky to be alive but am determined to recover to continue the struggle." Muslim view Hamdani Laturua, 33, is a Muslim lawyer who spends much of his time at Ambon's main Al Fatah mosque coordinating what he describes as self-defence activities. "There are three types of Christians in the Moluccas, the radicals, those who are frustrated and the separatists. They are all dangerous and want to destroy us. Radicals want to Christianise the whole region and drive us away. The frustrated want us to leave because they think we have taken all the best jobs.
