fields.headline: Antarctic adventure
fields.standfirst: Retracing an epic voyage - short of eating penguins
fields.trailText: A German-led expedition set out yesterday to repeat an epic 800-sea-mile boat journey across the iceberg-strewn wastes of the south Atlantic ocean which was originally sailed by the British Antarctic explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton 84 years ago.
fields.body:
A German-led expedition set out yesterday to repeat an epic 800-sea-mile boat journey across the iceberg-strewn wastes of the south Atlantic ocean which was originally sailed by the British Antarctic explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton 84 years ago.

The four-member Shackleton 2000 expedition will attempt to follow the exact route taken by the British explorer when he took to small boats after his vessel, the Endurance, was crushed in pack ice and sank in November 1915. His voyage is regarded as one of the greatest survival feats of the 20th century.

The current expedition has been mounted by the German adventurer Arved Fuchs, 46, and his crew: Martin Friederichs, also from Germany; Sigridur Ragna Sverrisdottir, from Iceland; and Henryk Wolski, from Poland.

The three men and one woman will set out in an exact replica of Shackleton's 6.7m (22ft) wooden boat, the James Caird, which will be dropped from the German cruise ship Hanseatic into the icy Weddel sea in the Antarctic next week.

The Hanseatic left the southern Argentine port of Ushuaia yesterday with the Fuchs team and their boat.

The expedition will start at the point where killer whales and disintegrating pack ice forced Shackleton to undertake his legendary voyage in April 1916 after he and his crew had spent six months marooned on the ice, sleeping in tents and living off seal and penguin meat.

"Our aim is to show just what a feat Shackleton's journey was," said Mr Fuchs. "So far nobody has managed to complete the whole trip. A British team in a fibreglass boat tried and failed at the last hurdle in 1994. An Irish crew tried a couple of years ago and had to be rescued. We will attempt to do the whole thing."

In what was Shackleton's only chance of survival, he and 27 members of his team set out from the ice in three small boats, powered only by sail and oar, and headed for the island of South Georgia.

The boats first reached Elephant Island on the fringes of the Antarctic.

Shackleton and five others then set sail for South Georgia, which they reached 17 days later after braving ice, storms and tempestuous seas. They then scaled an unmapped mountain range on the island to reach a Norwegian whaling station and safety.

Mr Fuchs's team will live below deck in "crawling room only" conditions on the sailing boat.

They will enjoy the benefits of modern equipment, including astronaut survival rations, thermal sleeping bags and - for emergencies - VHF radio and satellite navigation.

But Mr Fuchs was keen to make his team's journey as authentic as possible.

"We cannot eat penguins because this is prohibited under international law. But like Shackleton, we have no engine, we will rely on sextant and compass to navigate and only resort to modern equipment if we really have to," he said.

Their boat, the James Caird II, was built in Denmark to the design of the first James Caird, which now rests in Shackleton's former school, Dulwich college in south-east London.

Mr Fuchs and fellow German Reinhold Messner became the first to cross Antarctica on skis in 1992.

fields.headline: Scotch egg, anyone?
fields.standfirst: Old is the new new this year in gourmet land and British comfort food is back with a vengeance. But it's never that simple with foodies, says Lucy Atkins. Better start boning up on your landcress, tatsoi and pekmez if you want to avoid gastronomic gaffes in 2000
fields.trailText: Old is the new new this year in gourmet land and British comfort food is back with a vengeance. But it's never that simple with foodies, says Lucy Atkins. Better start boning up on your landcress, tatsoi and pekmez if you want to avoid gastronomic gaffes in 2000.
fields.body:
After weeks of festive gluttony, you may not feel like thinking about food, let alone salivating over what'll be big in 2000. But in this fashion-conscious age, you could risk social death if you order the wrong wine or sprinkle the wrong vinegar on your salad. So, read on if you want to know what's hip this year.

We'll begin with something light. This year, apparently, we shall mostly be eating wildly expensive salad leaves. Which kind, exactly, is unclear: some lettuce aficionados claim that "landcress" will replace rocket in stylish salad bowls, while others have their money on tatsoi (a baby Chinese leaf). According to Sainsbury's, the well-dressed leaf, wherever it's from, will be wearing Sabba - concentrated, fermented grape juice.

Waitrose disagrees: verjus, it says, is the thing (the juice of unripe grapes: sharp, fruity, but less bitter than vinegar). Luckily, when it comes to tomatoes, the message is clear: TV chef Anthony Worrall Thompson, insists we'll all bin the sundried and be eating sunblushed tomatoes instead ("Somewhere between sundried and cooked," he explains).

The really big tip for 2000, though, is fennel, because, according to Jeremy Lee, chef at the Blueprint Café: "Fennel is the new beetroot." If your beetroot is still languishing in a dollop of salad cream on a limp lettuce leaf, don't panic: it could become retro chic at any minute because this year, old is the new new (do try to keep up). The trendiest vegetable will, says Lee, be the potato. "People will start caring about what variety of potato they're cooking, not just grabbing some from a sack in Sainsbury's."

Worrall Thompson concurs: "There's going to be a British food revival," he says. "It's a continuation of the fishcake syndrome: comfort food that mums don't cook any more." According to Worrall Thompson, and his colleague Gary Rhodes, 2000 is all about simplicity.

However, we may not just be eating scotch eggs and shepherd's pies this year. Many predict that Middle Eastern food will blossom (don't panic, Italian is here to stay too, though regional variation is key). Nigella Lawson says that we've been told this so many times that "even the prophecy is outdated".

But some insist that pomegranates will be everywhere. If you don't know what to do with those pink, pippy things buy pekmez for your salad dressing - a sweet, sticky, slightly bitter Turkish syrup (it can also be made of grapes or dates). There's also Lebanese pomegranate molasses (stocked by Sainsbury's) and simple pomegranate juice; or you can just scatter the seeds on anything from salads to game and duck. Apparently, too, tamarind will replace cardamom, though this is something of a red-herring to my spice rack in which the raciest thing is a bottle of cayenne.

When it comes to meat - brace yourself - there's to be a beef-on-the-bone-ban backlash. Peter Bazeljette, creator of BBC's Ready Steady Cook and the Food and Drink programme says: "We, as a nation, have a healthy scepticism about food prohibitions." The ban was, as they say, a red rag to a bull, and consequently Bazeljette predicts a resurgence of "dangerous" foods - dark-red beef eaten on the bone, or "cheese that crawls towards you". This, of course, contradicts the notion that, this year, health-conscious cooking will be de rigeur, but as Lawson puts it: "It's what you learn in science: for every action there will be an opposite and equal reaction." Supermarkets, therefore, confidently predict a rush on organic and GM-free foods and on low-fat Japanese and Asian ingredients. In this vein, incidentally, Worrall Thompson also expects to see in supermarkets a preponderance of "probiotic" foods: things like live yoghurt which supposedly makes you healthier than you were before you ate it.

If all this leaves you gasping for a drink, do not, whatever you do, reach for the Chardonnay (it's practically a profanity in the wine world).

Cocktails are back this year. Your Greyhound (year 2000 comeback cocktail of choice: mix fresh grapefruit juice, vodka - Polish please - and ice) will be shaken for you by a "mixologist" in a youthfully hip cocktail bar.

Alternatively you may find yourself lured into an American-style "microbar" which brews its own beer on the premises and is staffed by people straight out of Gap adverts (sullen British service is also a thing of the past). If so, chose golden, aromatically hoppy ales; or drink a British or Belgian wheat beer (Hoegarten is still cool) or, where possible, a German one, such as the dark wheat beer Aventinus.

Above all, this year, more and more of us - alarmed, perhaps, by microbar mixologists - will stay at home. Most of what we eat there will be snacks and quick-cook meals. Supermarkets predict a boom in meals for one. It's not that we'll all suddenly become single, just that families in 2000 will rarely eat together (ironic, given the British home-cooking revival). Still, gastronomy will continue to thrive as a hobby (though not an everyday practice).

The dinner party is dead, so you won't be able to throw one, (you haven't been paying attention, have you?), but you can invite a couple of mates round for steak-and-kidney pud. Be sure, though, to wash it down with Chilean red wine (more flavanols: they protect against cancer) or a malbec from Argentina. Or indeed anything organic and red (white will be less popular) that you've ordered over the internet. There will, incidentally, be a better choice of organic wines, though an explosion is unlikely as it takes three years for a vineyard to be certified organic.

What's more, according to Suzy Atkins, co-editor of Which? Wine Guide 2000, those brave enough to overcome memories of retsina will be pleasantly surprised by modern Greek wines. Finally, licensing laws may at last be changed this year. Since the craze for coffee bars isn't going to abate, this means you may be able to sip your Greyhounds round the clock then sober up with a tall skinny latte with wings. You may not like it, but drink it anyway: it's the new cappuccino, darling.

fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.standfirst: www.nutrition.org.uk
fields.trailText: The perfect and most painless way to make amends for recent gluttony. The British Nutrition Foundation site has plenty of sensible scientific advice for those looking to shed some pounds - no low-carb fads - as well as info on food intolerances, alcohol intake and diabetes. Sobering but not too dry.
fields.body:
The perfect and most painless way to make amends for recent gluttony. The British Nutrition Foundation site has plenty of sensible scientific advice for those looking to shed some pounds - no low-carb fads - as well as info on food intolerances, alcohol intake and diabetes. Sobering but not too dry.

The good news: Being slightly plump is not a risk to health. Restrict chocolate, but don't ban it.

The bad news: Record levels of obesity. Worrying reminders of how much you shouldn't have drunk.

Extras: Nutrition experts answer general food enquiries by email.

fields.headline: No: 1556 Hugh Laurie
fields.body:
Age: 40.

Appearance: Pop-eyed "pencil-neck" (according to the Daily Telegraph, at any rate).

A natural for: The ultimate upper-class twit. Hence an acting career built on playing gormless Bertie Wooster, the foppish Prince Regent, and anything else requiring strangulated vocal intonation.

But he'll never be a star, will he? Not like his brainiac pal Stephen Fry? Wouldn't have thought so. But his most recent movie, Stuart Little, has just catapulted to the number-one slot at the American box-office, having scored £50m over Christmas.

That's the story about the cute liddle mouse, isn't it? Says director Rob Minkoff: "We cast him for his quirkiness and sense of humour, which obviously fits with the profile of someone who'd choose to adopt a mouse." Laurie has shown he's happy to share screen time with our furry friends, having played a bad guy in the puppy-packed 101 Dalmatians adaptation starring Glenn Close.

A thrilling story of success against the odds, eh? Took on the establishment and won? Not exactly. Hugh was head of his house at Eton and got a rowing Blue at Cambridge. But he found his metier when he joined the vintage 1980 Footlights Revue team - where he performed alongside Fry, Emma Thompson and Tony Slattery. Who says the old school tie doesn't work?

But, later... he struck out on his own, right? Well, no. Got work from comedy-scene pal Rowan Atkinson; hooked up again with Fry for A Bit of Fry and Laurie; and joined fellow luvvies Kenneth Branagh, Imelda Staunton and Footlights chum Thompson on Peter's Friends. Now he's playing the lead in Maybe Baby, Ben Elton's directorial debut.

Playing another waistcoated pencil-neck, no doubt? Not according to Elton. "Hugh is so sexy," he says. "I always knew there was a romantic lead deep inside him."

Most likely to say: "By golly"; "Good heavens"; "The pride of the Woosters is wounded, don't you know".

Least likely to say: "Pass the sock and snooker balls, Ray - got to show 'em who's the daddy now."

fields.headline: Who's cooking?
fields.standfirst: Paul Merrett
fields.body:
Age: 32.

Nationality: British.

Restaurant: The Greenhouse, 27a Hay's Mews, London W1X 7RJ. 0171 499 3331.

Past form: The last restaurant I worked at full-time was Interlude on Charlotte Street, London. Before that was The Terrace at Le Meridien, Piccadilly. I worked at a couple of restaurants with Gary Rhodes, and did my apprenticeship at The Ritz.

Style of cooking: It's been called eclectic and modern European, but I think of it as a pile of things I like to eat.

Signature dishes: I'm always fine-tuning the menu. Big hits at The Greenhouse are lentil purée with smoked bacon and sautéed fois-gras; cumin-roasted loin of lamb on sweet potatoes; roasted pear with star anise ice-cream and pear sorbet.

Bookshelf: I'm a big fan of Simon Hopkinson - I love his style and his recipes always work. I grew up with the Four Seasons Cookbook and I use it quite a lot. Chef's books - Richard Corrigan, Gordon Ramsay, Charlie Trotter - are great for ideas.

Favourite restaurant (other than own): Riva in Barnes is a fantastic place, a real chef's restaurant, with decent food. Stepping Stone in Battersea is good for the same reasons - good, honest food. But if I eat out, I'll often go for an Indian.

Favourite food: I eat a lot of cheese and jam sandwiches. I love big stewy things, jumbos - that's what I cook at home. But you have to go a long way to beat a good korma.

What's in your fridge? Children's stuff, yoghurts, a bag of mixed leaves, sausages, butter. No truffles or fois gras, I'm afraid.

What did you have for breakfast? Two fags and a cod-liver oil tablet.

Top tip: Go and work for the best chefs you can and experience all the different styles you can.

Biggest culinary disaster: Part of my job is to stop things before they go horribly wrong.

Career high: My first review, in the London Evening Standard, was a very exciting moment. And I was very proud to get the Michelin star.

 Interview by Claire Phipps

fields.headline: Coming out to play?
fields.standfirst: Made a resolution to join a gym? Don't. Get fit in the great outdoors instead ... and do it in style.  Laura Craik  explains how
fields.trailText: Made a resolution to join a gym? Don't. Get fit in the great outdoors instead ... and do it in style.  Laura Craik  explains how.
fields.body:
I seem to have lost my gym membership card. Which is a shame, as its video lending service, though a bit limited, was quite handy for wet Saturday afternoons. Since last August, when fate conspired to keep me and the Stairmaster apart (the concept of fate is most handy at this time of year, as a blanket excuse for your life not working out as planned), I have spent £195 on not going to the gym. I've passed through the guilty stage to the couldn't care less stage, yet for some reason the actual act of cancelling said membership still represents a final defeat I'm not quite ready to embrace. So the direct debit remains in place.

It doesn't take a genius to figure that more people join the gym in January than at any other time of year - nor that by February their resolve has dissipated and their new Nike trainers sit gathering dust. Sadly, our interest in the rowing machine slims long before our thighs do: after all, what could be more monotonous? The solution is to get outdoors. Exercise under the pale grey sky instead of a set of striplights and you'll feel a lot more stimulated. Remember being a kid? Throwing a ball, swinging off bars in the playground and chasing after your friends used to be called "games": the beauty is that when you're older, these activities can legitimately be called "exercise". After the age of 21, anything that raises your heartbeat is exercise.

Better news still: never has it been easier to look fabulous when you're working out. Prada Sport, Hysteric Glamour and Louis Vuitton are just some of the high-fashion labels offering sports-influenced fare this spring: just don't expect them to be up to much on the technological front. Adidas and Nike, meanwhile, are starting to pull up their sweat-resistant socks on the trainer front, after years of designing turkeys.

Come next month, as the new collections trickle into the shops (yes, that early), sportswear influences will be everywhere: baseball jackets, monogrammed visors, perforated football shirts, cricket jumpers, golfing shoes, netball skirts, Aertex blouses and even fencing gloves are all set for a comeback, if the designers have their way. So if you want to feel as healthy as the fashion industry dictates you will look, the time for action is now.

fields.headline: On the menu
fields.standfirst: Bastilla
fields.trailText: Or bstilla or pastilla or pstilla...
fields.body:
Or bstilla or pastilla or pstilla...

We get it, but what is it? A legendary Moroccan dish which, according to some reports, originated in Andalucia.

I'm still not much the wiser. Think of a pie made from layers of pastry thinner than a butterfly's wing, stuffed with shredded pigeon or, less correctly, chicken, chopped almonds, onion, ginger, saffron, cinnamon, allspice, parsley...

OK, OK. Where can I find it? Morocco? And just maybe in a top-quality Moroccan restaurant.

fields.headline: Mint conditions
fields.standfirst: Franklin Mint yesterday won the right to keep making their Di dolls.  Oliver Burkeman dips into the catalogue of the masters of kitsch
fields.trailText: As victories for freedom of creative expression go, Wednesday's ruling in an LA court against the Diana Princess of Wales Memorial Fund doesn't have quite the stature of, say, the campaign against the fatwa imposed on Salman Rushdie. For one thing, the Franklin Mint's commemorative plates and porcelain figurines, featuring a heavily lipsticked, Dynasty-coiffeured Di (which the court decided didn't infringe her publicity rights) hardly possess the cachet of the Satanic Verses. But if the fund ever thought it would be able to crush the upstart American firm with the sheer emotional weight of the late princess's legacy, it obviously didn't know much about the Franklin Mint.
fields.body:
As victories for freedom of creative expression go, Wednesday's ruling in an LA court against the Diana Princess of Wales Memorial Fund doesn't have quite the stature of, say, the campaign against the fatwa imposed on Salman Rushdie. For one thing, the Franklin Mint's commemorative plates and porcelain figurines, featuring a heavily lipsticked, Dynasty-coiffeured Di (which the court decided didn't infringe her publicity rights) hardly possess the cachet of the Satanic Verses. But if the fund ever thought it would be able to crush the upstart American firm with the sheer emotional weight of the late princess's legacy, it obviously didn't know much about the Franklin Mint.

It's easy to sneer at the company's vast product range of gaudy trinkets - so here goes. Consider their selection of Frank Sinatra musical plates, luridly illustrated with portraits of Ol' Blue Eyes, which play extracts from My Way, Strangers in the Night and New York, New York - a snip at £34 each. Or the £23 "Majestic Solitude" Collectors' Tankard, "hand-painted in the most splendid hues of nature's perfect pallette" and featuring three deer scavenging for food in a snowy forest. Then there's the Guardian of Destiny Gargoyle (£122), a Tolkienesque pewter monster crouching atop a crystal ball. And the £23 Johnny Cash "Man In Black" Collectors' Knife, complete with leather-effect handles and "zippered and padded case". It's hard to imagine objects more deserving of the labels such as "kitsch" - something the fund unhesitatingly exploited in publicising its lawsuit. At one point, even Tony Blair joined in, condemning much of the merchandise produced in the weeks following Diana's death as "tacky and inappropriate".

But you don't use words like "kitsch" or "tacky" at the Franklin Mint's HQ in Pennsylvania, if you know what's good for you. "That doesn't go down well here," said a spokeswoman. "We're a collector's company, with unique, high-quality products, and fantastic artists and designers." The Mint prefers the term "collectibles" and the sheer size of its operation makes the easy condemnation of its output as merely tasteless seem simplistic. Executives won't name figures, but industry estimates put the company's worldwide customer base at over 8m. Demand for its products is thought to generate £500m a year.

There's certainly nothing sentimental about its marketing. When Lynda and Stewart Resnick purchased the firm in 1985, it was an ailing producer of decreasingly popular commemorative coins. One astonishingly diversification later, it boasts thousands of products in more than 20 categories - to which it adds around 1,200 items a year.

Central to the firm's success is a policy of buying up celebrity souvenirs at auction: Diana's famous pearl-on-white gown, for example, which cost £94,375 - from which it makes low-cost replicas. It doesn't matter if the souvenir isn't the original: the Mint bought Jackie Kennedy's faux pearls for £132,188 at Sotheby's in 1996, and now markets replicas of the replicas.

There have been legal confrontations, notably with golfer Tiger Woods, who fought and won the Mint's attempts to market an unauthorised "Tiger Woods Eyewitness Commemorative Medal" marking his historic victory at the US Masters in 1997. Far more frequently, though, the company's celebrity items are the result of complex and mutually profitable marketing agreements with the likes of Coca-Cola, the Sinatra estate, and even the Vatican. Products resulting from the latter tie-in include a £122 statue of Jesus; an intricate "Crystal Mary Queen of Heaven" (£247); and the £43 Angel of the Vatican Music Box, "decorated entirely by hand in authentic jewel-like colours [and] playing divine hymns of faith by Bach and Handel". It's the kind of unthinkably lucrative endorsement most companies could only pray for.

It's difficult at first to see any explanation for the Franklin Mint's success besides the worldwide prevalence of astoundingly poor taste. Its products certainly don't represent any form of financial investment, since they're produced in such vast numbers and often from relatively low-value materials. But Lynda Resnick believes her company is performing a cultural service, preserving memories in an accelerating world. "In the world today, everything evaporates before your very eyes: the newspaper becomes a wrapper for garbage the next morning; images flit across the TV and movie screens," she once said. "Nothing lasts. What the Franklin Mint does is create a permanence about the memories we have of the past. It's very important to people to be able to hand something down from generation to generation... They can say, 'I remember Jackie Kennedy! These are the pearls that were so precious to her.' It's why people collect. It's a way of saying, 'I was there.'"

fields.headline: My cultural life
fields.standfirst: Shaun Woodward - Labour (ex-Tory) MP for Witney
fields.trailText: Shaun Woodward
fields.body:
From an early age I was fascinated by the arts - at college I was taught by Raymond Williams and Lisa Jardine, who both had a profound influence on me. Theatre and opera are my first two loves and I've retained an active interest, being on the board of directors at the the ENO and the RSC.

Political life makes it hard to get to see much but I did manage to see the ENO's Peter Grimes which was sensational and one of those operas I've always particularly loved. The first opera I came to know as a child was Fidelio. Leonard Bernstein is a musical hero of mine and I was thrilled to be given his Mahler Symphony as a Christmas present. I've been consuming it avidly over the last few days. At the end of the day I might put on Strauss's Four Last Songs or Haydn's piano sonatas. I even like some pop. I got into the Lighthouse Family because my son played their music constantly. Now I play it in the car.

I see lots of movies, the latest being The World is not Enough, which was terrific. I'm a great Bond addict which I share with my son. The Matrix was interesting. I quite like that level of science fiction, it reminds me of Doctor Who which I was really into as a kid - Patrick Troughton was the best.

When I can, I read a lot. I was given Jan Morris's new book on Lincoln - I'm interested in the myth of the man. I've also got to read Anthony Sampson's Mandela - the authorised biography. For escapist fiction, I love the Ripley stories by Patricia Highsmith.

A lot of the TV I watch is recorded. It's mostly documentaries like The Major Years, or The House, which went behind the scenes at Covent Garden. I like Friends - everyone in the house watches it. One of my Christmas presents was the first two series, which I'd never seen before. It's very human and I love the interaction between them. I've got old Fawlty Towers videos which are almost worn out, I've played them so many times.

If I want to unwind at the end of the day, I might read poetry by Robert Frost or Yeats. It's all about reconnecting with your soul. A walk does that too, but it's tricky at night.

I have friends who suggest books which aren't yet published - Chris Patten is great for recommending a good read. I've also got into the kids' books, especially the Kipper stories.

fields.headline: Walks in the wild
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Weardale
fields.body:
Weardale

Returning to favourite old haunts after a long absence can often bring disappointment, but a new year's re-acquaintance with Black Banks plantation brought pleasant memories. Fifteen years ago, when our children were toddlers, the plantation's pushchair-friendly rides between young Scots pines made it a sheltered spot for winter walks. Today was the first time we had been back since the battered pushchair finally went to the rubbish tip.

Like the kids, the trees had grown out of all recognition. What had been spindly Christmas trees were now fine, red-trunked specimens in the prime of life. Thinning out had allowed light to reach the woodland floor. Shafts of sunlight reflected off glossy leaves of holly that had sprung up in what was once dense, impenetrable shadow where our wide-eyed kids had been convinced that trolls, gremlins and threatening wild things lurked.

Not many wild things today though - just the squeaky calls of goldcrests in the canopy far above us. But there were still plenty of burdocks growing alongside the rides, which reminded me of another reason why the kids always used to like it here: burr fights, which meant that they always went home with the hooked fruits stuck in their gloves and hats.

We made for the south-east side of the plantation, which opens out on to rough pasture scattered with decrepit birches that were always a likely place to catch a glimpse of a woodpecker. The birches were still there, still shedding limbs and sprouting brackets of razor-strop fungus, but no sign of a woodpecker today.

A green mist of sprouting autumn-sown winter cereals had almost hidden the bare earth in the ploughed fields below. A spiraling flock of birds soared on the valley's updraft. Through the binoculars it soon became clear what their commotion was about. They were mobbing a hen harrier, that drifted towards us across the valley, pursued by the white cloud of gulls. Our walks here always used to produce something memorable, and today's was no exception.

fields.headline: Champagne sales up 73% for millennium
fields.trailText: The first indications of the extent of the toasting that greeted the new millennium is emerging from drinks retailers and nightclubs.
fields.body:
The first indications of the extent of the toasting that greeted the new millennium is emerging from drinks retailers and nightclubs.

Wine warehouse group Majestic yesterday confirmed seasonal champagne sales up 73% on last year, with the emphasis on quantity rather than quality. The biggest seller was the chain's own-label £10.99 fizz, followed by popular brands such as Moët & Chandon and Lanson. The best vintages had sold out by the beginning of December.

Overall sales of wine and beer in the chain were ahead 22.1% in November and December. Chief executive Tim How said: "We saw both a good increase in transactions and a willingness to spend more, with the average customer spend up 14%."

AIM-listed pubs group Honeycombe Leisure pronounced millennium eve "a great success". Like-for-like sales over the festive period were up some 6%, and chief executive James Baer said: "It was certainly the right decision to open our sites for the millennium and not take the easy option of closing."

Nightclub operator Chorion, whose outlets include London mega-club Tiger Tiger, said its like-for-like sales were up 55% on 1998 levels after a December of hard celebrating. Chorion operates six West End clubs and sales at Tiger Tiger, which also includes a cocktail bar and restaurant, were up 96%.

SFI, whose bars and pubs include the Bar Med and Litten Tree chains, entertained 10,000 drinkers on the big night, who spent an average £50 a head and generated SFI's highest one-day sales - even though only two-thirds of its outlets were open.

webTitle: NatWest bid battle tests shareholder democracy

fields.headline: NatWest bid battle tests shareholder democracy
fields.trailText: One in six NatWest shareholders is expected to give up his or her right to decide the fate of the clearing bank and merely follow the decision reached by others over the three-way, £25bn takeover tussle.
fields.body:
One in six NatWest shareholders is expected to give up his or her right to decide the fate of the clearing bank and merely follow the decision reached by others over the three-way, £25bn takeover tussle.

The situation, described as a concern by senior fund managers, arises because of the amount of NatWest shares held by index tracking funds which have invested in the bank because of its status in the FTSE 100 index.

Industry sources expect these funds - typically Barclays Global Investors, Legal & General, Henderson and Gartmore - not to take a view on the merits of the competing bids by Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland or the arguments presented by NatWest's management.

This means that the outcome of the battle could be decided by the views of a handful of leading institutional investors and might fuel the debate about the accountability of pension fund trustees.

It might suggest that the banks will decide to concentrate their lobbying efforts on the big "active" shareholders, who they think will sway the vote. Industry sources calculate that as much of 15% of NatWest's shares are tied up in index tracking funds, although only half of these were said by one senior banking source to completely "blind".

However, senior banking sources suggested that the two Scottish banks might step up any charm offensive on the index trackers in order to persuade them that by doing nothing they would be supporting NatWest.

A senior banker insisted that the index trackers might yet spring a surprise on the market and decide not to follow the pack because of the unusual nature of the situation. The banker pointed out that index tracking funds were particularly reliant on corporate governance issues be cause this was the only way to improve their performance.

The banks yesterday began to step up their efforts to win support for their sides after a the Christmas lull, with Royal Bank lobbying analysts in private and BoS publicly knocking NatWest's argument that mergers do not work.

Showing little sign of reducing the hostility of its approach, BoS cited the "successful" mergers of Lloyds and TSB and Midland and HSBC. It highlighted the irony in NatWest's argument given that it had been trying to merge with Legal & General before BoS launched its bid.

NatWest retorted, however, that BoS had merely supported its argument by showing that badly constructed mergers did not work.

"NatWest's standalone strategy offers a better, lower risk option with shareholders receiving 100% of the benefits," said Sir David Rowland, NatWest's chairman and chief executive.

fields.headline: Law firm rides $1 trillion wave
fields.trailText: The legal firm Linklaters & Alliance reaped the rewards of last year's record levels of mergers and acquisitions around the world by advising companies on deals worth more than $1trillion.
fields.body:
The legal firm Linklaters & Alliance reaped the rewards of last year's record levels of mergers and acquisitions around the world by advising companies on deals worth more than $1trillion.

Although the firm did not disclose its fees from the work, the figures will fuel speculation about the size of bonuses paid to lawyers and investment bankers after last year's record levels of activity.

Final data on last year's mergers and acquisitions published by Thomson Financial yesterday showed that $3,317bn (£2,022bn) of deals were announced, with Goldman Sachs involved in more transactions than any other investment bank.

For the first time, the growth of mergers in Europe was bigger than in the US and Charles Allen-Jones, senior partner of Linklaters, predicted that could set the tone for this year too. The value of deals in Europe jumped by 40% over 1998, the biggest increase ever, boosted by the competing bids from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland for NatWest. Banking sources estimate this three-way fight could win investment bankers and lawyers fees of as much as £300m, whatever the outcome.

The hefty cost of mounting, and fending off attacks, was also highlighted by the German telecoms company Mannesmann, which yesterday admitted it might spend up to £90m trying to ward off the unwanted advances of Vodafone AirTouch.

While the outcome of the NatWest and Mannesmann battles is still awaited, Thomson Financial's data showed that 32 deals with a value of more than $10bn were completed last year. The UK was the biggest market in Europe for mergers activity while the telecoms sector's deal value broke through the $100bn mark. The value of mergers between financial services firms fell just short of that, at $91bn.

webTitle: Media first up for competition initiative

fields.headline: Media first up for competition initiative
fields.trailText: Denise Kingsmill, the lawyer who shot to fame a decade ago while acting as George Walker's brief and who is now the number two at the grandly-renamed competition commission, has never been what you might call risk averse.
fields.body:
Denise Kingsmill, the lawyer who shot to fame a decade ago while acting as George Walker's brief and who is now the number two at the grandly-renamed competition commission, has never been what you might call risk averse.

So we should probably not be at all surprised to learn that the commission is now piloting a new approach to information gathering: calling in a bunch of City analysts and journalists and then grilling them for an hour-and-a-half.

The first test-bed for this initiative is the media industry itself. More specifically, the commission is looking for advice on last year's two hospital passes from the DTI - Vivendi's acquisition of a 24% stake in BSkyB and the proposed merger of the cable interests of NTL and Cable & Wireless Communications.

Guardian regular Maggie Brown got the call just before Christmas and the advice session took place this week, with Ms Brown and sundry others facing the full commission panel.

Ms Kingsmill and her colleagues have clearly had enough of the detailed submissions and expert contributions from lobbyists which rain down on commission members. But with the regulator due to publish the issues it will be seeking to examine within the next few days, this new exercise has at least given us an early glimpse of the commission's thinking.

Naturally, the panel members are running through the whole spread - from the market for pay-television and interactive services, through BskyB's position in it, the role of cable companies, the position of OnDigital, and then on to issues such as the purchase of sports rights.

They have a busy six weeks ahead, but the big issue jumping out of this "reverse briefing" seems to be whether a dominant cable operator ought to be subject to new "open" access rules, requiring them to give carriage on local networks to channel providers.

NTL and CWC should probably prepare for the worst, although they might be comforted to know that there was general agreement that UK cable has so far proved rather poor at marketing its television services and that the proposed merger may well serve the public interest by providing a strong, well-run competitor to satellite and terrestrial.

As for BSkyB and Vivendi, there was discussion about the fact the British company did not give the impression of welcoming the French boarding party, with Vivendi's holding now second only to Mr Murdoch's 39%. Everybody would like to know much more about Vivendi's motivation for building the stake.

Panel members, of course, can hardly avoid becoming expert in the TV industry. It has to be assumed that the proposed merger of United News & Media and Carlton Communications - bundling together as it does six ITV franchises, stakes in GMTV and Channel 5, and clearly breaching the 25% ceiling on total television advertising in the process - is now headed in the commission's direction.

Although, as yet they have to quiz their newly-found experts over this one.

Euro indecision

Yesterday the British Chambers of Commerce began canvassing its 126,000 members over their views on the euro. The BCC promises the survey, due in April, will be definitive. After all it had consulted both Business for Sterling and Britain in Europe over the questions in the hope of heading off the rows over methodology which tend to bedevil every survey on the issue.

But even before the questionaire has hit the BCC membership's doormats, both pro and anti lobbies are showing signs of cold feet about accepting the survey as definitive in advance of the results.

It is hardly surprising. Neither side will want to surrender its claim to occupy the high ground of majority support for its case within the business community. But at least there is a debate on the issue, even if it is mired in rows over the methodology. Britain's pension funds, on the other hand, scarcely appear to have noticed the advent of the single currency.

Back in mid-December, the National Association of Pension Funds surveyed its own members and found that barely one in 20 funds was planing to adjust its investment portfolio in the wake of the single currency. It was so taken aback it returned to the membership to ask why the euro had so little bearing on their choices.

Excuses for such apathy have now come back in three varieties. One was that the funds' investment was entirely UK based, a second that the euro was not yet a reality and finally that it was "just another currency". That is hardly forward looking. The euro is not just another currency. It is one which at some point, as Stephen Byers reminded us yesterday, Britain has to decide whether or not to join.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Southampton stake raised
fields.body:
Southampton stake raised

Phillips & Drew investment chief Tony Dye has increased his personal holding in Southampton Leisure, the owner of Southampton football club, to more than 2%. Mr Dye told citywire.co.uk that his shareholding is the result of a long-standing friendship with Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe. His original investment was made in Secure Retirement, the listed nursing homes business Mr Lowe reversed into privately owned Southampton. Meanwhile, Michael Withers, a Bahamas-based associate of the legendary City financier Jim Slater, has joined the board of Southampton football club.

Dunlop to axe truck tyre jobs

Dunlop Tyres UK said it will end production of truck tyres and mould manufacture at its Birmingham plant, shedding 650 of the 1,700 jobs there. Dunlop UK is part of the global Dunlop Tires joint venture owned by US-based Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co and Japan's Sumitomo Rubber Industries. Dunlop said excess capacity in the European tyre industry and the market situation made the move to end truck tyre manufacturing inevitable. Production of car, light truck, motor sport and racing tyres in Birmingham will continue.

NAPF members neutral on euro

More than 90% of Britain's National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF) members have no plans to adjust investment portfolios to recognise the euro. Conducted late last year, the survey found no euro-related changes planned by 95% of private sector funds and 94% of public sector funds.

Aviation costs insurers less

Commercial aviation losses in 1999 cost insurers $1.8bn (£1.1bn) against $1.9bn in 1998 and the number of passenger deaths also declined, a leading aviation loss adjuster said. Airclaims said passenger fatalities last year were 512, less than half the level of 1998 when 1,046 people lost their lives, and the lowest figure recorded since 1946.

fields.headline: Some party. Some hangover
fields.trailText: The London trading year is only three days old yet already the stock market has fallen £100bn in value. Some hangover. But then it was some party. In the run-up to the millennium, London and most of the world's leading stock markets had been on a buying binge.
fields.body:
The London trading year is only three days old yet already the stock market has fallen £100bn in value. Some hangover. But then it was some party. In the run-up to the millennium, London and most of the world's leading stock markets had been on a buying binge.

The charge had been led by telecommunications companies, at least some of which were household names, and the real rocket stocks - virtually anything with dot.com in its name. By the end of the year market after market was clocking up record highs.

Since the new year it has been a different story. The rally has gone into reverse. The question now facing equity strategists is how 2000 will be remembered.

There are three scenarios. The first is that this week's selling is a short-term correction before the markets head back upwards, as in the past. The second is that the year will see a more deep-rooted curb on investor enthusiasm. The third is market meltdown.

There is no shortage of bears out there. Charles Dumas at Lombard Street Research pointed out this week that the technology rich Nasdaq index started the year on a price earnings ratio of 143 after a 50% gain in the previ ous 2 months. That is almost 10 times the long-term average for the Dow Jones industrial average and double that of the Nikkei 225 index just before the 1989 collapse. The new year market capitalisation of Nasdaq's top 100 companies of $3.35 trillion (£2.03 trillion) was double the GDP of Britain.

All the signs point to a bubble waiting to burst. Just ask Sony president Nobuyuki Idei. At the beginning of the year Sony shares hit a record 32,250 yen (£186) on the back of plans for an internet bank and a stock split. Mr Idei was not impressed.

"When our earnings levels are considered, the appropriate price would be about ¥20,000. Above that would be a bubble," Mr Idei said. Predictably that sent investors rushing for the exit, though Sony is still trading in what Mr Idei regards as bubble territory.

Paris-based broker BNP Paribas Equities is equally cautious. Its European equities strategist, Florent Brones believes the internet effect has been overdone and markets are overvalued by 15-30%.

"All the conditions are in place, based on our classical models, for something unpleasant to happen," Mr Brones said. "The globalisation of the American dream regarding the new technologies and internet seems too optimistic."

Mr Brones, like many others, is also worried about interest rates. The concern is well-founded. As economies in Europe start to pick up the pace of expansion the European Central Bank is expected to tighten monetary policy. As American growth continues into uncharted territory so is the Federal Reserve. With British house prices soaring and retail spending strong, the Bank of England may well be the first central bank to move when it meets to discuss rates next week.

The fact that there has been no discernible impact from the millennium bug is seen as bad news for share prices, because the threat of a global computer virus was one factor deterring policymakers from increasing borrowing costs.

Where next? The balance of risk must be on the downside. Stock markets are already discounting improving global growth prospects. Investor appetite for internet stocks should reach satiation at some point. It is to be hoped the feeding frenzy does not end in a bilious attack. So a resumption of the fin de siècle madness looks the least likely of the three scenarios.

Defensive stocks may become the fashion. Markets in Europe may benefit from what is euphemistically called corporate restructuring - takeovers to you and me - as companies try to position themselves to operate increasingly on a cross-border basis. And if investors are already discounting further growth they must have factored in the impact of higher interest rates too.

That is the logical view. But markets are not logical - at least not in the short term. If they were irrational on the way up, may they not be irrational on the way down?

So welcome a sizeable correction and keep your fingers crossed it is no worse.

fields.headline: Soros takes a hi-tech hit
fields.standfirst: Fall of $600m reported in Quantum fund as investors flee to traditional stocks
fields.trailText: Billionaire financier George Soros was last night nursing big losses from this week's plunge in hi-tech stocks as the new year sell-off in telecoms and internet shares entered a fourth day.
fields.body:
Billionaire financier George Soros was last night nursing big losses from this week's plunge in hi-tech stocks as the new year sell-off in telecoms and internet shares entered a fourth day.

Mr Soros's premier Quantum fund is reported to have seen its value drop by $600m (£365m) since the turn of the year, with investors deserting last year's hottest sectors in favour of more traditional companies.

Last night, a spokesman for the $10bn fund said he could neither confirm nor deny the reports, which surfaced after heavy selling in financial markets around the world.

London's FTSE 100 index fell sharply for the third day, closing down 88 points at 6,447. The index has now fallen 483 points from the peak during the last trading session of 1999, taking £97bn off the value of the British corporate sector.

BT suffered one of the biggest declines, losing 9% of its value amid disappointment over revenue growth targets at its Concert joint venture with US telecoms group AT&T.

A key factor in unsettling markets is the prospect of higher interest rates in Britain and the US. City fears, heightened by evidence of fast rising house prices, increased further with the news from the Confederation of British Industry of strong high street spending in December.

Dealers believe the Bank of England is likely to raise rates at the meeting of its monetary policy committee next week.

The prospect of dearer borrowing prompted a flight into defensive stocks such as food stores and brewers in London yesterday.

The search for safety was mirrored in New York, where today's job figures will provide evidence of the continuing strength of the American economy and be eagerly examined for signs of inflationary pressure which could push the Federal Reserve into raising interest rates next month.

The technology-dominated Nasdaq index suffered further hefty declines, while the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average rallied for the second day.

The Nasdaq composite was down just over 50 points at 3,825 by early afternoon while the Dow had risen more than 140 points at 11,264, powering above 11,290 an hour before the close.

Some analyst said there were signs that the sell-off of hi-tech stocks was abating, others argued that the shake-out was long overdue.

"I think a little bit of common sense is returning to the stock market. The selling is concentrated in the high flyers from last year," said Alan Skrainka, chief market strategist at Wall Street firm Edward Jones. "Emotions drive the market in the short run and right now, at least in the technology sector, fear has the upper hand."

fields.trailText: • Day trade action US financial regulators are taking legal action against an online investment adviser going under the name of Tokyo Joe for allegedly defrauding amateur share traders. The self proclaimed day trading expert whose real name is Yun Soo Oh Park is accused of failing to disclose that he owned shares in the stocks he was recommending.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 35% fall in BA's Y2K numbers
fields.body:
35% fall in BA's Y2K numbers

British Airways carried 6.3% fewer passengers last month, with numbers dipping by 35% in the few days before the new millennium, the airline announced today.

Pre-millennium schedules had been reduced to reflect low demand but BA said it had 15 flights in the air on new year's eve in Britain. The airline said it was pleased that premium traffic - the number of passengers in first class and business class seats - had risen 5.2% in December 1999. Non-premium numbers fell 8.1%. All figures relate to December 1999 totals compared with those of December 1998.

"The figures are in line with our strategy of attracting more premium traffic," said a BA spokeswoman. "We are reducing our capacity, so future month-on-month passenger number figures are likely to be lower."

National Power grows US plant

National Power yesterday underlined its international ambitions by unveiling plans to invest $600m (£365m) in two new gas-fired power stations in the United States.

The group, a byword for drift for most of last year, has proposed a demerger to create an integrated British energy group, Npower, and International Power, a separate firm managing its 23,000MW of overseas assets.

The group will create the largest combined cycle gas turbine plant at Midlothian, Texas, by adding 550MW to the 1100MW plant being built there.

It is also building a 570MW combined cycle gas turbine plant at Bellingham, Massachussets. The group will then have 4000MW of gas-fired plant in the US by the end of 2001, when ageing American power stations are being shut down - mostly on environmental grounds.

GM Europe sets output record

General Motors Europe's vehicle production hit record levels last year, with its plants turning out more than 2m cars and component sets for the first time, the company said yesterday.

Of the total, 1.894m units were made by GM's main European subsidiaries - Britain's Vauxhall and Opel of Germany - a rise of 52,000 units on 1998.

The Vauxhall/Opel Astra and Zafira models accounted for 912,000 units, a rise of almost 230,000 over 1998, GM said. Sweden's Saab produced 127,850 vehicles.

GM Europe president Michael Burns said: "The positive response to models such as the Opel/Vauxhall Astra and Zafira, as well as the Saab 9-5 Wagon, bodes well for turning this momentum into increased growth in the next century."

Brixton Estate chief to leave

Douglas Gardner is to leave Brixton Estate after 17 years running the property company.

Mr Gardner plans to set up his own property ventures after leaving the group. "I'm 56, just, and have been running this company since I was 39, that's quite a long time," said Mr Gardner, who is both chairman and chief executive.

Tim Wheeler, the firm's property director, will become chief executive. Allan Gormly, a non-executive director of Brixton and a director of Bank of Scotland and chairman of BPB, will take on the role of chairman.

fields.headline: Versailles denies receiving takeover approach
fields.trailText: Troubled trade finance group Versailles yesterday denied reports that it had received a takeover bid and confirmed that it was committed to remaining independent.
fields.body:
Troubled trade finance group Versailles yesterday denied reports that it had received a takeover bid and confirmed that it was committed to remaining independent.

The company is searching for a heavyweight non-executive chairman and a group finance director.

Two teams of accountants are combing the group's books - Baker Tilly, on behalf of the London Stock Exchange, and PricewaterhouseCoopers on behalf of high street banks which are owed £65m - and Versailles still hopes to have its shares relisted by the end of the month.

Recent media reports suggested that Fairfax Gerrard, a Slough-based trade finance company, was considering an offer for Versailles, while other market rumours claimed that opportunist bidders were planning to snap up Versailles at a bargain price.

But the group, whose shares were suspended on December 8 after it emerged that its turnover may have been inflated by up to one third, said no offer was on the table.

Its main bankers - NatWest, Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland - remain supportive and the company's founder, the leading black entrepreneur Carl Cushnie, has pledged to step down as chairman to concentrate on the role of chief executive.

Versailles is also seeking new financial advisers.

webTitle: M&S does not need to cut jobs, says union

fields.headline: M&S does not need to cut jobs, says union
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer remains one of the most profitable store groups in the world and should abandon cost-cutting plans to source more goods from overseas which are causing thousands of UK job losses, the GMB union said yesterday.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer remains one of the most profitable store groups in the world and should abandon cost-cutting plans to source more goods from overseas which are causing thousands of UK job losses, the GMB union said yesterday.

The union is mounting a campaign to save textile workers' jobs and yesterday staged a demonstration outside the group's City of London store.

It has also written to the group's big investors, including the Church of England Commissioners, asking them to intervene in the "unethical" sacking of thousands of UK workers employed by suppliers to the store chain.

M&S has already severed contracts with several leading UK textile firms. Last month 6,000 workers at the clothing companies William Baird and Daks Simpson were handed redundancy notices, and thousands more jobs could be at risk.

Yesterday's demonstration coincided with publication of a report commissioned by the GMB and carried out by the independent Labour Research Department, which showed that M&S is still the fifth most profitable UK retailer.

fields.headline: Signet rewards staff for results
fields.trailText: More than 4,500 staff at jewellery retail groups Ernest Jones and H Samuel are to receive pay bonuses after the Signet group, which controls the two chains, announced bumper Christmas sales.
fields.body:
More than 4,500 staff at jewellery retail groups Ernest Jones and H Samuel are to receive pay bonuses after the Signet group, which controls the two chains, announced bumper Christmas sales.

Signet said its profits would be well ahead of City expectations this year after its stores posted excellent sales figures in November and December.

The staff windfalls -which will be a minimum of £100 but run into thousands of pounds for some area managers - will be paid according to the performance of individual stores and regions.

Signet said that in the 48 weeks to January 1, its sales increased 14.5%, while like-for-like sales - which exclude improvements due to new selling space - increased 8.9%.

In the two months before Christmas, like-for-like sales climbed 12.3%.

In the United States - where Signet owns the Kays and Jared outlets and which generate two-thirds of the company's sales - same store Christmas trading was up 12.8%, while British seasonal sales were ahead 11.2%.

Analysts had been expecting good results from Signet, which came close to bankruptcy when it was known as Ratners, after an upbeat set of figures from rival Goldsmiths after Christmas.

The trading details came as the Confederation of British Industry said retail sales had been higher than expected last month - and followed an equally impressive trading statement from fashion chain Next, on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Leading blue chips ended sharply lower for a third consecutive session as interest rate concerns, both domestic and foreign, also continued to dog the market.
fields.body:
Leading blue chips ended sharply lower for a third consecutive session as interest rate concerns, both domestic and foreign, also continued to dog the market.

After yesterday's strong house price survey from the Halifax the view in the Square Mile seemed to be that a rise in borrowing costs at next week's Bank of England meeting is now almost a certainty.

There was also nervousness about the crucial American non-farm employment numbers due today, setting the mood for the next Federal Reserve rate-setting meeting in early February.

The FTSE 100 index closed the session down 88.7 points at 6,447.2 - above the 6,424.4 low seen around mid day, but well adrift of the 6,547.3 high in the first minutes of official trading.

Volume was a very healthy 1.4bn shares, with hefty turnover seen in Vodafone Airtouch, British Telecom, Signet Group and Ferrum.

The rally on the Dow Jones overnight and narrowing losses on Nasdaq provided an early fillip to sentiment, but the near 700-point drop in Hong Kong and the shock profits warning from American PC provider Gateway after the US market closed quashed any hopes for a bounce in prices.

Asian-related issues had another poor day as the rout in Hong Kong continued. Together HSBC, down 26p at 766p, Cable Wireless, off 44p at 950p, and Standard Chartered, 60p lower at 837p, wiped 16 points off the leading index. Yesterday Morgan Stanley predicted that the Hang Seng index would fall to 12,000 points in the next 12 months.

Closer to home, as concerns about the future direction of interest rates persisted, investors continued to book profits in recent outperformers. Tech favourites Sage Group, down 39p to 610p, and Misys, off 15p at 799p, were among the worst affected, as were Pearson, 99p lower at £17.69, and WPP, slipping 7p to 867p.

ARM Holdings was also out of favour, falling 283p to £33.86 after a downgrade from Goldman Sachs, which lowered its rating to "market perform" on the grounds that it could not justify a further increase to its £38 target.

Defensive stocks were in demand as investors looked for safe places to deposit profits from the hi-tech and telecoms sectors. Imperial Tobacco was among the main beneficiaries, advancing 41p to 560p, as was Scottish Power, up 27p at 496p, and United Utilities, 24p better at 653p. Associated British Foods ended 32p better at 369p - the Footsie's best performer.

webTitle: Yes, there was a Christmas boom

fields.headline: Yes, there was a Christmas boom
fields.standfirst: CBI finds evidence for festive surge led by furniture and carpets, but profits are squeezed
fields.trailText: Retail sales volumes surged ahead in the run-up to Christmas but falling prices point to squeezed profit margins on the high street.
fields.body:
Retail sales volumes surged ahead in the run-up to Christmas but falling prices point to squeezed profit margins on the high street.

The first survey of trade in December, published by the Confederation of British Industry, showed a balance of 41% of stores enjoyed higher rather than lower sales compared to a year ago, up from 23% in November.

The increase was sharper than retailers had expected - significantly above average for the time of year and also broadly based.

The CBI said that for the first time since January 1998, all sectors reported a rise in sales volumes, with those linked to the booming housing market doing particularly well.

Furniture and carpet stores were among the top performers, closely followed by grocers, confectioners, footwear and leather retailers.

However, the continued price sensitivity of consumers was underlined by a separate report from the British Retail Consortium, showing that prices fell 0.4% in December, compared to last year.

"Consumers continue to benefit from competitive prices on the high street," said Mark Bradshaw, BRC acting director general.

"Food and non-food items were cheaper compared to December 1998 - which means that finances stretched a little further this Christmas. Retailers are hopeful this means customers are now spending in the January sales."

Despite the weakness of inflation pressure on the high street, most analysts expect the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to raise interest rates from 5.5% when it meets for the first time this year next week.

But a slight slowdown in the pace of growth in the services sector as a whole - which was reported yesterday by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply - suggested the cost of borrowing may not have to rise much further.

The survey's business activity index registered some 58.3 points in December, down from 59.5 in November, with any reading above 50 indicating expansion.

"The number of people taking out mortgages was unseasonably high, benefiting financial intermediation and business services firms," said the Cips.

"Only the computing & IT sector failed to see a significant increase in demand - a result of customers' decisions to delay the placing of new business until after any Y2K problems have been resolved."

Richard Iley, economist at Dutch bank ABN Amro, said the survey confirmed healthy growth in services but added to the impression that the economy was not accelerating out of control.

"While a tight labour market and a buoyant housing market will force the monetary policy committee's hand, interest rates will not rise dramatically," he said.

After another two quarter-point moves this year, rates would peak at 6%, said Mr Iley.

Alastair Eperon, chairman of the CBI's distributives trades survey panel, said December's rise was welcome, but added that retailers had more moderate expectations about sales in January. "This is not the time to make any hasty interest rate changes," he said.

fields.headline: Focus Inchcape
fields.trailText: Is Inchcape, almost as venerable a City institution as the Old Lady herself, about to become a dot.com stock?
fields.body:
Is Inchcape, almost as venerable a City institution as the Old Lady herself, about to become a dot.com stock?

The self-styled world's largest independent automotive distribution group yesterday headed the leaders of the FTSE-250 players, rising 13% to close at 312.5p - still a way off its year high of 408p but impressive for what was once a low-octane, spluttering mini-conglomerate.

The reason, even in a wary market, is simple enough. It paid just $10m (£6m) for a 7.3% stake in Autobytel.Europe, a newly formed subsidiary of a US parent which controls 45% of the American online automotive market.

Buying and selling a car or a house in the US is simple enough: you post your details, specifications, price, on the web and wait for offers. But in Europe it is more complex. Groups such as Virgin see growth potential, however.

Inchcape - now that it has almost divested itself of its non-motor baggage - sees a large part of its future in online sales of the upmarket range of cars it distributes to showrooms. It claims more than 1m hits on its wholly owned Autobytel UK website since it was set up on April 30 last year.

The European offshoot now plans to launch its own web sites in Germany, France and Holland. It points out that the first two of those countries and Britain sell more than 26m new and used cars a year, with numbers of adults online in Europe set to grow from 34m now to 100m by 2003.

With Ford building the virtual car assembly plant, all Inchcape has to do to shed its venerable image is find and distribute the virtual car.

fields.headline: £1.5m copper fine for Deutsche
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank yesterday collected its second large fine from British regulators in three years, with a £1.5m penalty for its role in the $2bn Sumitomo copper trading scandal. This comes on top of the £2m the bank had to pay in April 1997 in connection with the activities of maverick fund manager Peter Young.
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank yesterday collected its second large fine from British regulators in three years, with a £1.5m penalty for its role in the $2bn Sumitomo copper trading scandal. This comes on top of the £2m the bank had to pay in April 1997 in connection with the activities of maverick fund manager Peter Young.

While neither admitting nor denying any wrongdoing in relation to the copper scandal, Deutsche decided to settle with enforcers at the London Metal Exchange rather than fight. There is no suggestion Deutsche deliberately aided Sumitomo's rogue copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, nor even that it dealt directly for him. But the LME claims Deutsche failed to take proper steps to check the motives of clients for whom it carried out purchases of huge quantities of copper in the autumn and winter of 1995.

In this case it was Deutsche subsidiary Sharps Pixley, once one of the grand names of the London bullion and metals market, that landed Deutsche in trouble.

With the Peter Young affair it was Morgan Grenfell, the British merchant bank bought by Deutsche 10 years ago this month. Both have now been integrated into Deutsche's London operations and the German bank will hope to have seen the last mishap to result from its City operations.

Deutsche has been questioned by the American authorities regarding its role in the copper scandal, but has heard nothing further.

Hamanaka traded copper on behalf of Sumitomo, the Japanese industrial conglomerate. In the mid-1990s, this low-profile suburban office worker embarked on a reckless attempt to corner the world copper market.

His attempted squeeze eventually came to light in 1996, plunging commodity exchanges into turmoil and sticking Sumitomo with a $2.6bn bill.

Hamanaka was jailed by a Japanese court for eight years in March 1998 on fraud and forgery charges.

The LME claimed Deutsche, through Sharps, failed in October and December 1995 to check thoroughly the motive of the client on whose instructions its bought substantial amounts of copper.

It is not thought the client was Hamanaka.

It claimed further that between October 1995 and January 1996, Sharps failed to report to the LME the large positions it had built up.

On top of the £1.5m fine, Deutsche will pay LME costs, thought to be substantial.

Last summer the brokerage, Merrill Lynch, was fined £6.5m by the LME for its role in the Hamanaka affair and a further £9m by the United States Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

Merrill was accused of aiding Hamanaka's activities.

The LME claimed Deutsche, through Sharps, failed in October and December 1995 to check thoroughly the motive of the client on whose instructions its bought substantial amounts of copper. It is not thought the client was Hamanaka. It claimed further that between October 1995 and January 1996, Sharps failed to report to the LME the large positions it had built up. On top of the £1.5m fine, Deutsche will pay LME costs, thought to be substantial. Last summer the brokerage, Merrill Lynch, was fined £6.5m by the LME for its role in the Hamanaka affair and a further £9m by the United States Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Merrill was accused of aiding Hamanaka's activities.

webTitle: Jobs gets the job: Apple founder becomes a stayer

fields.headline: Jobs gets the job: Apple founder becomes a stayer
fields.trailText: Two and a half years after initiating a radical turnaround at the once struggling Apple Computer, charismatic co-founder Steve Jobs said on Wednesday he was erasing the word "interim" from his title to become Apple's permanent chief executive.
fields.body:
Two and a half years after initiating a radical turnaround at the once struggling Apple Computer, charismatic co-founder Steve Jobs said on Wednesday he was erasing the word "interim" from his title to become Apple's permanent chief executive.

At the Macworld Expo trade show, Apple also announced an investment of $200m (£121m) in EarthLink Network, which will become the default net service provider for Apple's Macintosh computers.

"I'm going to be dropping the 'interim' title," Mr Jobs said at the MacWorld Expo, receiving a standing ovation from the crowd of Apple devotees at San Francisco's Moscone Centre. Mr Jobs, who stunned a MacWorld audience in 1997 with news of a $150m investment in Apple by its rival Microsoft, became interim chief executive in September 1997 while the company searched for a permanent leader.

Apple's stock on Wednesday jumped to an intraday high of $1109 / 16, then retreated amid a further sell-off on Nasdaq; its shares closed up $11 / 2 at $104 in active trading.

fields.headline: Pantomime
fields.trailText:
Snow White
Snow Whites seem pretty thin on the ground this year, so there won't be the rash of annual newspaper articles about a national shortage of dwarves. This is one of the many Cadbury pantos nationwide, so expect chocolates thrown from the stage and a completely slick operation with big sets and high production values. Ex-Coronation Streeter Philip Middlemiss stars.

 Theatre Royal, Grey St, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-232 2061) 2pm & 7pm, £6-£15.

Mother Goose
More than 100,000 people squeezed into the King's in Glasgow last year, making it one of the premier panto venues in Britain. This year's offering sees Gerard Kelly (Callum Finnegan in Brookside) reprising the "daft boy" role that he has made his own over the years. Admired Scots actress Barbara Rafferty will be bringing a bit of class to the role of Mother Goose. Making her first ever panto appearance, as the wicked witch, is the excellent Maureen Beattie. She continues a family tradition started by her father Johnny, one of the legendary names of Scottish variety, who starred in many King's pantos in the 70s.

 King's Theatre, Bath St, Glasgow (0141-287 5511) 2pm &; 7pm, £3-£15.50, concs available.

fields.headline: Rock, pop & jazz
fields.trailText:
Alan Skidmore Quartet
For most of his professional career the 58-year-old saxophonist Alan Skidmore has explored the legacy left by the late great John Coltrane. Skidmore's quartet has been described as "possibly the closest thing to the classic John Coltrane Quartet you will ever hear". Over the past four decades this immensely accomplished saxophonist has stood out as a musicians' musician, working with many of the big names, including John Mayall, Ronnie Scott, Georgie Fame, Ian Carr, Chris McGregor, Elvin Janes, George Gruntz and Charlie Watts. In the 90s Skidmore has recorded and performed with the likes of Van Morrison and Mose Allison. Words such as passion and virtuoso are freely bandied about when describing Skidmore's sax playing, and this evening his seasoned quartet features the "mesmerising" piano playing of Steve Melling, the "sensual" and "captivating" bass of Arnie Somogyi, and drummer Stephen Keogh's "profusion of rhythms". Don't ask for your favourite Coltrane requests, Skidmore and Co's repertoire is based on what they like to play, not what the audience expects.

fields.headline: Exhibitions
fields.trailText:
The Art Of Invention
In Renaissance Italy artists were not just producers of what we today call art, but technicians and designers, craftsmen and theorists, turning their hand to whatever skilled task a prince or city might require. This exhibition brings together large-scale models of some of their amazing inventions, practical and less so, from Brunelleschi's revolutionary dome in Florence to Leonardo da Vinci's flying machine.

This exhibition brings together large-scale models of some of their amazing inventions, practical and less so, from Brunelleschi's revolutionary dome in Florence to Leonardo da Vinci's flying machine.

 Science Museum, Exhibition Rd, SW7 (0207-938 8080) until April 24.

The Flower Show
Flowers are natural forms so beautiful they appear to have been created for human eyes, and when artists paint, photograph or think about flowers what fascinates is this ready-made quality. But then flowers rot, and from Dutch flower painting to Warhol's gaudy images, artists have seen mortality in what at first appears perfect. The poetic possibilities of flowers are explored here by Mat Collishaw, Anya Gallaccio, Ian Hamilton Finlay and Michael Landy.

 Fruitmarket Gallery, Market St, Edinburgh (0131-225 2383) until January 15.

Angelika Kirchschlager
This recital from the honey-voiced mezzo accompanied by Helmut Deutsch includes the deliciously pre-feminist sentiments of Frauenliebe und -leben by Schumann, followed by some of the delightful songs by Alma Mahler, a woman who might have written a great deal more had she not sacrificed her own artistic impulses to support those of her husband Gustav.

fields.headline: Arsenal stand firm over Kanu
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger last night insisted that Nwankwo Kanu will play for Arsenal in the FA Cup fourth round against Leicester on Sunday despite rising pressure from Nigeria to have their captain report immediately to their African Nations Cup training camp.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger last night insisted that Nwankwo Kanu will play for Arsenal in the FA Cup fourth round against Leicester on Sunday despite rising pressure from Nigeria to have their captain report immediately to their African Nations Cup training camp.

The Nigerians are threatening to drag Fifa into the club v country dispute but Arsenal's manager is holding firm, saying that the striker "will be released on Sunday afternoon after the FA Cup tie". Kanu will then fly out to Nigeria's training base in Spain.

The ultimate danger for Arsenal is that, if Nigeria continue to press the matter, Wenger's team may be kicked out of the Cup, irrespective of the outcome of the tie, for fielding an "ineligible player". But with Dennis Bergkamp and Marc Overmars injured, Wenger clearly needs Kanu.

Under Fifa rules, national federations can insist that players report to them 14 days before the start of a major international tournament. Nigeria's opening game is against Tunisia in Lagos on January 23, 14 days after Arsenal's game with Leicester at Highbury. But the Nigerians say they are within their rights to complain because the African Nations Cup starts on January 22, when Ghana play Cameroon.

With the two sides squabbling essentially over a one-day difference, expulsion is a worst-case scenario, even if a Fifa spokesman admitted yesterday that the Nigerians would be perfectly entitled to seek disciplinary action against the Gunners.

He added: "In cases like this Fifa always hopes for common sense and cooperation between the clubs and the national associations who are entitled to first call on their players, but if it is not forthcoming we can only go by the regulations."

Chelsea are maintaining the same stand over their Nigerian left-back Celestine Babayaro, who will not be released to join his national team until after the rearranged Premiership game at Bradford City tomorrow. He is expected to fly out with Kanu the following day.

"Babayaro will be with the Nigerians on Sunday," said Chelsea's assistant manager Gwyn Williams yesterday. "We have already let him miss two matches here to join in their training camp before Christmas and then they told us they wanted him to come back today."

Other African countries have been more accommodating over Premiership players. South Africa have agreed to Leeds's request that Lucas Radebe need not report until after Sunday's Cup game at Manchester City, and Cameroon are allowing West Ham to keep Marc Vivien Foe for Tuesday's Worthington Cup rerun against Aston Villa.

And the Moroccans are allowing Coventry's midfielders Mustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo to play for their club during the African Nations Cup. Gordon Strachan was resigned to losing the pair after tomorrow's Cup tie with Burnley but they can now fly back from training to play against Wimbledon seven days later.

Newcastle have agreed to sell the French defender Franck Dumas to Marseille for £1.25m. The 31-year-old player cost £500,000 when signed by Ruud Gullit from Monaco last summer.

 Juventus went top in Italy last night after a Filippo Inzaghi goal in the 47th minute gave them a 1-0 win at home to Verona. They are now a point clear of Lazio, who lost 2-0 to Venezia on Wednesday.
