fields.headline: Beyond the bounds of stupidity
fields.trailText: In different parts of South America two of football's biggest icons have been doing their best to live up to their image: one stuffing huge amounts of cocaine up his nose, the other trying to cram his manhood into a thong.
fields.body:
In different parts of South America two of football's biggest icons have been doing their best to live up to their image: one stuffing huge amounts of cocaine up his nose, the other trying to cram his manhood into a thong.

While pondering the peculiar lives of Diego Maradona and David Beckham, I happened to be finishing a book reflecting on Tottenham's Double-winning year of 1960-61, when footballers were reasonably rewarded, regular blokes who knew their place in life's pecking order.

Bill Nicholson's team of Blanchflower, Smith and White each received a set of suitcases from the club to mark their achievement. The players had a whip-round to buy the gaffer a cutting-edge Remington shaver.

Things, you may have noticed, have changed. Maradona, born in the same year as that Tottenham Double, has been packing suitcases all his life, from the moment Argentinos Juniors, and then Boca Juniors, discovered the magic in the feet of a short, stocky 16-year-old.

He became the finest footballer of the 80s, fast-tracking his way around the globe, winning domestic titles in Argentina and Italy, and the World Cup in 1986. "Pele had nearly everything; Maradona has everything," was Sir Alf Ramsey's assessment.

A decade later and Maradona's life had followed a predictable script. He became the figurehead of the Argentine government's anti-drugs campaign and admitted: "I was, I am and I always will be a drug addict."

Banned for 15 months after digesting a cocktail of substances at the 1994 World Cup, the boy from the slums of Buenos Aires' dock area had taken the adulation and not known what to do with it.

This morning he is out of intensive care after being admitted to hospital this week in a "stable but excited" condition after an apparent cocaine overdose. Whatever he has done, from the drugs to the petulant no-shows at training to shooting at four journalists with an air gun, there will be hordes of people who will forgive him. But Maradona has few real friends, only the type of hangers-on associated with once-great boxers who die leaving nothing but debts and memories.

So, we are now in an age when footballers are bigger than movie stars and teeny-pop performers. And when one of this new breed happens to marry one of the best-known pop acts in the business, it takes the adulation, the pressure and the expectation to unimaginable heights.

Beckham is probably the best English footballer of his generation and it seems most of his intelligence is in his feet. He can wear skirts, silly hats, floppy hair and stroll along the beach in Rio wearing Eric Morecambe-style shorts for as long as he wants. He looks stupid but nothing matches the stupidity of his wife.

She buys her husband cars and trinkets worth hundreds of thousands of pounds, as the rest of us might buy a box of chocs and cheap flowers. OK, she earns enough from being Posh Spice, so let her do what she wants.

But what on earth made her admit in an interview that her husband likes to wear her thongs? Does she seriously think we are so enthralled by their marriage that we actually give a damn? And why do various newspapers print this garbage? And what the hell does Sir Alex Ferguson think about it?

Maradona was a high-profile victim of the early boom in player power. I hope there are tough enough characters out there, such as Ferguson, who can prevent other talented individuals making complete idiots of themselves.

webTitle: Raise a glass to vintage Claret

fields.headline: Raise a glass to vintage Claret
fields.standfirst: Memorial to McIlroy recalls Burnley's successful early 60s
fields.trailText: Frank Keating profiles Burnley, where the Jimmy McIlroy stand recalls the club's success in the early 60s.
fields.body:
Only greybeards now would nominate the Burnley sides of the late 1950s and early 60s as one of the Football League's top 10 teams of the 20th century. But they were. Ditto if you named the executive designer and architect of those teams, Jimmy McIlroy, as one of the century's top 10 inside-forwards. And he was. Only Johnny Haynes of England was as beguiling a presenter of a bespoke pass, short or long, as the man who played 500 league games for Burnley, 100 for Stoke City, and 55 for Northern Ireland which took in the 1958 World Cup.

Sixty-eight last autumn, McIlroy still lives in the town he arrived at from Glentoran in 1950. Last week, on his evocative old stage at Turf Moor, the old hero opened the suitably handsome and gleaming Jimmy McIlroy stand. He said he would do so only if the rest of Burnley's championship-winning side of 1960 - also FA Cup finalists in 1962 - were rounded up for the celebrations. They were. Laps of honour all round in front of 15,000, by far the largest throng of the season. Thousands will travel to Coventry for the Cup tomorrow, just as they did for the giantkilling at Derby in the last round.

Still in the soft Celtic brogue of his homeland, the ever-modest McIlroy remains as articulate, as liltingly romantic, as poetic as his football used to be as he recalls last week's ceremony. "Of course there were tears. I was overwhelmed with emotion. I think we all were.

"From the day I arrived I was Claret all through. My beloved old mentor Danny [Blanchflower] used to scoff and say, 'Jeepers, how can you stay in a place like Burnley when the world's your oyster?' I just never wanted to leave. When Bob Lord [the chairman] sold me to Stoke, I still lived in Burnley. When you see a sepia photo of me in Stoke's stripes it just doesn't seem right, it's me as an alien; crazy, but I feel only authentically 'proper' if my jersey's claret and blue.

"I lost touch with the club. So many regimes came and went, if I rang up for a ticket they'd think me a cadger, a scrounger. All the old tradition seemed gone. Suddenly it's different, there's organisation and optimism all over now. Like we had, permanently, all those 40 years ago - and there we were, unbelievably, together again the other night... my lovely lads, Blacklaw, Elder, Cummings, Miller, Connelly, Pointer, Robson, Pilkington... only John Angus and Jimmy Adamson couldn't make it... and they each paraded in front of me for an individual reception... and the waves of acclaim poured down... it was unbelievable, especially as only a minority could have ever seen us actually play.

"Finally, it was my turn, and now I was treading my old field again... and I was bathed in the arc lights once more. Oh, the emotion - soppy, really - and just about every square yard of the pitch brought back a distinct memory to me in vivid imagery and recall... a shot from here, a tackle precisely there, a particular pass from this precise spot, a goal or two, or just a little wee shuffle I once made exactly here... it was uncanny, so intense, an almost indescribable sort of ecstacy, I sup pose. I looked around and suddenly there were my four lads from the forward line, us five together again, waving up to the throng, drinking in the applause, embracing each other, old men now, but old men transported back, magically, to be 40 years younger... and, jeepers, oh what deeds we did together...

A nd I hugged my right-winger John [Connelly], our hare down the line who could cut in and belt a sudden net-bursting tracer with his left foot... and dear Jimmy [Robson], instinctive inside-left, right-place, right-time poacher supreme; Danny said if it hadn't been for Greaves, Robson would have been a British household name... and outside Jimmy our great Pilky, one cap for England was an utter insult; Pilkington was no size but, jeepers, what heart, and what a talent to take on every full-back and whip over cross after cross... sometimes to me, but usually to No9 Ray [Pointer], our pocket blond bombshell, there's no other three words. What courage and verve Ray had, what a non-stop engine. He was all oomph, and nous with it. I saw Alan Shearer play only once, at Blackburn in his full glory and pomp - wow, he was ravishingly good - and coming off the ground with the crowd all abuzz I thought to myself, 'Given the chance, who would you have chosen to play alongside at their peak, R Pointer or A Shearer?' and do you know, I still can't decide. For sure, Ray was utterly exceptional for his size; and only three caps for England, another idiocy of those times.

"Oddly, it was not at Turf Moor that us five transcended everything, it was under the floodlights at Leicester's Filbert Street towards the end of the championship season. Although we were only two points above Danny's marvellous Spurs at the finish, perhaps we realised that night that nobody could stop us being champions. A sort of purity, an utter untouchable magnificence, possessed us and we blended into one, each truly on song as in a single melody. I think it finished 6-3. None of us wanted it to end. Nor did the crowd. Nor the Leicester team. They were as stunned as us at the, sort-of, word-perfect drama of it. It was like the opera, when the whole arena stood to applaud us off, as a way of saying they couldn't bear us to go.

"That's why, last week at Turf Moor as I embraced my beloved four lads, I found myself fervently wishing I hadn't been a player myself in those days but a fan, a fan who was passionate about good football. When you're part of it you don't obviously see the whole panorama - and, honestly, for four or five years and about half a dozen times a season our Burnley side clicked in unison, and when it clicked it must have been utterly breathtaking to watch. I can't tell you why exactly, but we found ourselves caught up in excitement and charm and elegance and flow. Everything pinpoint exact, and all of us rapier sharp and on the very top of our game. I know it's ridiculous but, oh, how I wish I could have been on the terraces actually watching us play." Or up in the Jimmy McIlroy stand.

webTitle: Six moments that shaped England's decline

fields.headline: Six moments that shaped England's decline
fields.trailText:
1: Losing the toss at the Wanderers

Was it a conspiracy or had Chris Scott, the groundsman at the Wanderers, made a horrible mistake? Somewhere along the line, too close for comfort to the start of the first Test, Scott had doused his pitch so that when the captains walked out for the toss on November 25 it was still sufficiently soft for a finger pressed into it to leave an impression. It was totally unsuitable for starting an international match. Had Nasser Hussain won the toss it is doubtful, although not impossible, that South Africa would have been two runs for four wickets and bowled out for 122 as were England; but they would not have made 403. The psychological damage of losing the toss was immense; the series may have been lost there and then.
fields.body:
1: Losing the toss at the Wanderers

Was it a conspiracy or had Chris Scott, the groundsman at the Wanderers, made a horrible mistake? Somewhere along the line, too close for comfort to the start of the first Test, Scott had doused his pitch so that when the captains walked out for the toss on November 25 it was still sufficiently soft for a finger pressed into it to leave an impression. It was totally unsuitable for starting an international match. Had Nasser Hussain won the toss it is doubtful, although not impossible, that South Africa would have been two runs for four wickets and bowled out for 122 as were England; but they would not have made 403. The psychological damage of losing the toss was immense; the series may have been lost there and then.

2: Allan Donald dismissing Mike Atherton in the first innings at the Wanderers
Iron Mike has been a talisman for England against South Africa, batting with outstanding skill and courage in England two years ago. His duels with Donald, particularly at Trent Bridge, have become among the most famous rivalries in the game.

Four years previously it had been principally Atherton's tenacity over 10 hours which had denied South Africa a win at the Wanderers. Donald wanted revenge and believed Atherton to be vulnerable to the fast inswinger early on.

The last ball of the first over of the series started outside off stump, swung in viciously and cartwheeled the off stump. It was the most telling delivery of the series, for in that single moment a spectre had been laid to rest.

3: Rudi Koertzen's failure to give Mark Boucher out in the first innings in Port Elizabeth
England had shrugged off the defeat at the Wanderers as an aberration and had gone into the second Test in good heart. Hussain won the toss on December 9, put South Africa in and on a good pitch that was getting better watched his bowlers reduce them to 268 for seven early on the second day, with the second new ball imminent. A further wicket and Donald would be at the crease.

Lance Klusener and Mark Boucher had then added 26 for the eighth wicket when Andy Caddick found bounce outside off stump, the ball climbing at Boucher, nicking his glove and going through to Alec Stewart behind the stumps. Koertzen shook his head and Boucher survived.

Boucher, 11 at the time, made 42. More pertinently Klusener, on 82, went on to reach 174, before South Africa were finally dismissed for 450. With 373 themselves, England had a significant deficit instead of a probable lead.

4: Michael Vaughan's damaged finger in East London
After the second Test and the one-day game in Alice, England travelled to East London for a four-day match against a combined Eastern Province-Border side, where they came across a promising young fast bowler called Garnett Kruger, tall and with good pace.

On December 19, the second afternoon, Vaughan, not long at the crease, received a ball that bounced unexpectedly from a length and trapped his right forefinger against the bat handle. His immediate reaction was of someone who suspected his finger had been broken and although x-rays showed this was not the case, a scan indicated hairline cracks within the joint.

A prognosis that he would be fit for the third Test in Durban proved optimistic and although England held the upper hand for much of that game, the loss of Vaughan disjointed the side.

5: Phil Tufnell's no-ball to Gary Kirsten in Durban
The third Test in Durban, which started on Boxing Day, was England's zenith. A first-innings score of 366 for nine was followed by a phenomenal piece of bowling from Caddick, who took seven for 46 as South Africa were bowled out by the third evening for 156. Hussain enforced the follow-on knowing that two hot, debilitating days in the field were in prospect.

Approaching lunch on the fourth day, Caddick had removed Herschelle Gibbs but Gary Kirsten and Jacques Kallis were starting to entrench. Then the left-handed Kirsten went on to the back foot to Tufnell and was beaten by turn into him, the ball striking him on the pad. Even as Tufnell appealed, England began to celebrate: it was plumb.

But, unnoticed, the umpire Dave Orchard was signalling that Tufnell had bowled a no-ball, a cardinal sin for a spinner. Kirsten, then 33, went on to make 275, the second-longest innings in Test history, and saw South Africa to safety. England have yet to recover from the ordeal in the field.

6: Alec Stewart's dismissal in the first innings in Cape Town
England were well placed on the first day of the fourth Test last Sunday. A good toss had been won and Atherton and Mark Butcher had posted a century opening stand. Although both were caught on the boundary playing adventurous shots, and Hussain was dismissed by Paul Adams, Vaughan and Stewart were progressing nicely as the day drew to a close.

At 213 for three it was a time to take stock and capitalise the next day. Stewart is an adrenalin player, however, and not without a streak of machismo. The crowd noise was intense, the bowling from Donald aggressive and the taunting from bowler and fielders incessant, testing his resolve.

Stewart should have resisted but, with men placed on the fence, he took on Donald's bouncer and hooked it straight to Kirsten. England finished the day on 215 for five, lost their last seven wickets for 47 and were bowled out in the second innings for 126. Stewart's dismissal was the catalyst.

webTitle: Board raises stakes for Hussain's also-rans

fields.headline: Board raises stakes for Hussain's also-rans
fields.trailText: England's beaten cricketers were yesterday warned that the financial future of the domestic game is dependent on dramatically improved performances.
fields.body:
England's beaten cricketers were yesterday warned that the financial future of the domestic game is dependent on dramatically improved performances.

Speaking in the aftermath of the defeat in the Test series against South Africa, Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, said that sponsorship would be hard to attract if the national team continued to wallow among the also-rans.

"If you are right at the top of the tree, No1 or 2 in the world," he said, "then sponsorship will come, especially at home, because people love cricket and there is a massive interest. It is just sad that we are where we are at the moment."

Sponsorship and broadcasting deals provide the bulk of the ECB's income but the board is currently shedding sponsors rather than attracting them. Cornhill, which has spent £28m on home Tests since 1978, has announced that it will pull out at the end of this summer's series, against Zimbabwe and West Indies, and NatWest, which has sponsored the major one-day domestic competition since 1980 as well as playing a significant role in the development of the game, is considering its position.

MacLaurin is confident that a replacement for Cornhill will be found, and hopes for an announcement "sooner rather than later". But there is a triangular international one-day tournament in England this summer and as yet there is no sponsor.

"We would have hoped to have had one on board by now," he said. "There are two companies negotiating with us. But we have to be good at this most senior level and then we will attract sponsors. Business today is very tough and sponsorship budgets are looked at very closely by companies. They want to sponsor success."

MacLaurin believes there are signs of an upturn. "In the last couple of years the First Class Forum and the county chairmen have got a quite clear approach to England being of paramount importance, where before they were more interested in winning the County Championship.

"We have a very good TV deal with Channel 4 and Sky, who are doing a tremendous job, and there are new sponsors for the County Championship and the National League. Both of the sponsors are pleased with the divisional system and now we have to monitor things to see if we have got it right or wrong. There are views that it is still not right, and I respect that.

"One hopes we learn from this tour, and the streamlined management structure of Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher is already earning praise. It would be nice if we could start our comeback by beating Zimbabwe and West Indies before we go to Pakistan and Sri Lanka next winter and then face the Australians again. Despite this result, I think we are starting to see improvements."

webTitle: Lara pleads for patience after defeat

fields.headline: Lara pleads for patience after defeat
fields.trailText: The West Indies captain Brian Lara appealed to fans in the Caribbean to be patient after his young team lost the third one-day international against New Zealand in Napier and with it the five-match series. The four-wicket defeat follows the 2-0 Test series reverse.
fields.body:
The West Indies captain Brian Lara appealed to fans in the Caribbean to be patient after his young team lost the third one-day international against New Zealand in Napier and with it the five-match series. The four-wicket defeat follows the 2-0 Test series reverse.

West Indies were dismissed for 159 before New Zealand stuttered to victory thanks to their captain Stephen Fleming's unbeaten 66.

"People in the Caribbean have a right to be angry but they are going to have to be patient because rebuilding West Indian cricket is going to take time," Lara said.

"We've been trying to do all the right things here. We knew it was going to be tough but the guys in the team have got to believe in themselves and work as individuals on their confidence."

Another dismal batting display saw Pakistan bowled out for 169 in 40.4 overs, despite an unbeaten 77 from Moin Khan, as they suffered a third consecutive defeat before the triangular one-day series with Australia and India. Queensland won by four wickets in Brisbane.

webTitle: Old habits die hard for limp tourists

fields.headline: Old habits die hard for limp tourists
fields.standfirst: Butcher and Adams must make way after return to the bad old days
fields.trailText: Paul Allott believes that Mark Butcher and Chris Adams must make way after England's ignominious return to the bad old days.
fields.body:
It has taken less than a week for England's tour to fall apart. It is not so much the fact that they have lost another Test and with it a series, but the manner in which it was lost.

South Africa's win at Newlands by an innings and 37 runs was the biggest defeat they had ever inflicted upon England. They completely dominated the match apart from the first session of the first day, and even though England's bowlers struck back on the third day the game had been lost long before that.

This was a weak performance from England, the likes of which we had been kidded into believing was a thing of the past. It must be doubly galling for Nasser Hussain and Duncan Fletcher to have to reflect that the series has gone and that the defeat came in exactly the way they have been striving to avoid since taking charge together in September.

Everyone realises that England are not a team of superstars and that the batting is too reliant on the three senior men, Atherton, Hussain and Stewart. But, until Newlands at least, there had been a collective energy about them, a resilience that more than made up for their technical deficiencies. The fourth-day capitulation, when the big three all failed, highlighted the glaring weakness.

Mark Butcher's dismissal in the first over of the day, when he pushed weakly at a wide loosener from Shaun Pollock, set the tone for England's out-of-tune performance. What on earth was in his mind? This was the shot of a man whose confidence is completely shattered, who has no idea what shot to execute to which delivery, and he should now be left to contemplate his future on the sidelines.

The same can be said of Chris Adams, who has had four Test matches to acclimatise himself to the top level and looks no nearer to becoming a Test batsman than his namesake, the South African No11, Paul.

On the subject of No11s, England have three of them in their batting line-up. There is just no excuse for Phil Tufnell and Darren Gough to give their wickets away as they did in the first innings. In modern Test cricket it is vital that the lower order have to be prised from the crease; they need not score runs but they must learn to bat with purpose.

Of the newer batsmen on this tour, only Michael Vaughan has come up to the mark. His performances have made him the one junior batting success of the trip and his temperament and technique have stood up well under the harshest examination.

From a bowling viewpoint England can feel they have done all that has been asked, with the exception of Tufnell, who is fast becoming completely ineffective as a wicket-taker. The seam department has been heroic in its efforts, with Andy Caddick's development into the key strike bowler, Gough's unflagging enthusiasm and the emergence of Chris Silverwood, who always gives his all and was rewarded at Newlands with a five-wicket haul. His and the selectors' perseverance has finally paid off and he now has the chance to establish himself in the side.

Andrew Flintoff's unfortunate foot injury has deprived England of one of the successes of the tour. Just as he looked as though he was about to produce a true all-rounder's performance his tour has ended, leaving the selectors with another gap to fill at Centurion next Friday.

This is where England are really in the mire, because Butcher and Adams should not play and the selectors must find three replacements. Of the original squad, Darren Maddy has had one chance and should be given another, but finding two more players of quality will prove interesting.

Hussain is adamant that the Centurion side will be picked from the original squad and that none of the six one-day replacements will feature, even though they have been flown out two weeks early and arrived in Cape Town yesterday.

They will all play in Port Elizabeth in a three-day match starting on Sunday. What happens if Vikram Solanki or Nick Knight gets 100? Surely then that batsman must come into consideration. After all, England have nowhere else to turn.

 South Africa have brought in the batsman Pieter Strydom to bolster their squad for next week's fifth Test. The Border captain has been included as cover for Jonty Rhodes, who sustained a slight hamstring strain in Cape Town.

Daryll Cullinan is also nursing a hamstring niggle, and the paceman Allan Donald struggled with a groin twinge during the fourth Test. But the team physiotherapist Craig Smith was hopeful that all three would be declared fit. "The only one who is a little worrying is Rhodes, but I'm confident he will come through."

South African squad: G Kirsten, H Gibbs, J Kallis, D Cullinan, H Cronje (capt), J Rhodes, P Strydom, L Klusener, S Pollock, M Boucher, A Donald, M Hayward, P Adams.

fields.headline: Cricket teams of the century
fields.trailText: David Hopps digs deep the memories and to select his England XI and World XI of the century.
fields.body:
Even as innocent a pastime as dabbling in imaginary teams of the century tells its own disturbing tale of the state of English cricket. Draw up a World X1 and a host of relatively modern names such as Sachin Tendulkar, Malcolm Marshall and Shane Warne have powerful claims for selection. Turn to England and, Ian Botham apart, it is difficult to justify the inclusion of anybody born in the second half of the century.

Other truths also present themselves. England's difficulty in balancing the side, caused primarily by a lack of all-rounders of sufficient quality, is not just a modern phenomenen, it is a curse that runs throughout the century. Even with one hundred years to consider, it is difficult to avoid an England side without a disturbingly long tail.

For the best England top order, simply begin with the letter H. It has been so for sixty years and more: Hobbs, Hutton, Hammond. Jack Hobbs, 'The Master,' scorer of more first-class runs than anyone in the game, 98 of his 197 centuries made after the age of 40, a dignified and humble man. Len Hutton, whose best years were robbed by the Second World War, and an injury which permanently weakened his left arm, but who still twice subsequently captained England to Ashes wins against Australia. Alongside these two cricketing knights stands Wally Hammond, classically upright at the crease and, according to David Foot's recent biography, a bit of a lad off it as well.

Hutton wins the vote ahead of two other famous Yorkshire sons, Herbert Sutcliffe and Geoffrey Boycott, and it can be assumed that neither would be overly impressed. Sutcliffe was a great competitor, as is illustrated by a Test average in excess of his county average, but he also had a reputation as a snob, so he can take offence elsewhere.

A battler royal is required, in anticipation of struggle, and who better than Surrey's Kenny Barrington? No English batsman has sold his wicket more dearly. As Australia's 'keeper, Wally Grout, said: "When Ken walked to the wicket you could see the Union Jack fluttering behind him." That leaves Peter May to unfurl his effortless on-drive at No.5; he will probably not captain, and definitely not become chairman of selectors, after his retirement.

Lovers of Denis Compton will be appalled but there will only be room for Compo's carefree and charming strokeplay if England opt for a sixth specialist batsman. Cowdrey? A little flabby. Gower? Too lax. It would be nice to pick Randall or Milburn just for the hell of it. Ian Botham is an automatic pick at No.6, the youthful, irrepressible version before injury and the England captaincy subdued his joie de vivre. There has been no more hale and hearty cricketer in England's history. Alan Knott outstrips Godfrey Evans as wicketkeeper. He will score more runs, keep wondrously standing back, and his mild hypochondria will ensure that the dressing room is forever free of draughts.

Sydney Barnes could be a cantankerous soul, but many have rated him as the finest of all English bowlers. He had little fondness for county cricket and often returned to the Test side straight from the Leagues. The restructuring of club cricket would have to work miracles for that to be repeated a century later. As a medium-pacer, capable of producing swing, cut and spin, Barnes will have to settle for third seamer.

If that creates tension for the captain, Hutton, it will be nothing compared to telling his fellow Yorkshireman, Fred Trueman - by his own estimation "t'finest bloody fast bowler that ever drew breath" - that he must bowl uphill and against the wind, so that Frank Tyson can have the pick of ends. Another Yorkie, Wilfred Rhodes, would serve as 12th man, if only on the grounds that he was good for a crisis - this being England, one would be bound to come along eventually.

There has to be a surprise selection, so here it is. Off-spinners being out of favour, there is no place for Jim Laker, for all his 19 wickets against Australia in 1956. Instead, all will be gambled on the rhythmical slow left-arm of Colin Blythe. Artistic and highly-strung, his epileptic fits would be less of a worry these days. He found England Tests emotionally trying, so he would slot in pretty well.

Knott retains his wicketkeeper's place in the World X1. He is the only Englishman, which at least answers charges of rampant nationalism. Australians, for all that, will remain loyal to Ian Healy.

Two more cricketing knights are automatic World X1 selections. Don Bradman is a fixture at No.3. The greatest of all Test batsmen, blessed with a ruthless mind, quick eye and devastating footwork, he would probably waste no time in lifting his Test average from 99.94 to 100. Neville Cardus spoke of how Bradman "turned the game into an exact science", and others found his domination so complete that he drained the game of unpredictability. The world's best all-rounder is also incontestable: Gary Sobers, a stylish left-handed batsman, swift fielder and astonishingly versatile left-arm bowler, who could switch from fast-medium to slow left-arm, orthodox or wrist spin, makes the list without difficulty.

Gordon Greenidge would have many supporters to fill one of the opening batting slots. But he must give way to his fellow West Indian, George Headley, who dominated the 1930s and whose Test average of 60.83 is unsurpassed in Caribbean cricket. He is partnered by Barry Richards, whose refined strokeplay graced only four Test matches before South Africa's apartheid policies justifiably brought about their ban from international competition. Instead, Richards languished in county cricket, where boredom seemed the commonest cause of his dismissal. In the middle-order, Pakistan's Javed Miandad holds off India's Sachin Tendulkar, largely because Javed, the ultimate streetfighter, has a proven record of producing at times of crisis. The West Indies also provides the No.5, with Viv Richards chosen ahead of Everton Weekes, marginally the best of the 'three W's'. No batsman has ever arrived at the crease with a more imposing swagger.

Imran Khan's immense influence upon Pakistani cricket insists that his all-round talents cannot be ignored, although the verve of Keith Miller, and snaking left-arm of Wasim Akram are reluctantly abandoned. Malcolm Marshall, as shrewd as they come, takes the new ball ahead of a posse of magnificent West Indian quicks. He is joined by Australia's Dennis Lillee: courageous, belligerent, hostile, and ultimately a great technician. And yes, the spinner's place can go to Warney, one of the greatest showmen of all - with strict instructions that he has nothing more to do with Indian bookmakers.

Everybody would know that this World X1 would be unbeatable anyway.

World XI

1 BA Richards (South Africa) b1945 2 GA Headley (West Indies) b1909 3 DG Bradman (Australia) b1908 4 Javed Miandad (Pakistan) b1957 5 IVA Richards (West Indies) b1952 6 GSA Sobers (West Indies) b1936 7 Imran Khan (Pakistan, capt) b1952 8 APE Knott (England) b1946 9 SK Warne (Australia) b1969 10 MD Marshall (West Indies) b1958 11 DK Lillee (Australia) b 1949

12th man: KR Miller (Australia) b 1919

England XI

1 JB Hobbs (Surrey) b1882 2 L Hutton (Yorkshire, capt) b1916 3 WR Hammond (Gloucestershire) b1903 4 KF Barrington (Surrey) b1930 5 PBH May (Surrey) b1929 6 IT Botham (Somerset, Worcs, Durham) b1955 7 APE Knott (Kent) b1946 8 FS Trueman (Yorkshire) b1931 9 FH Tyson (Northants) b1930 10 SF Barnes (Warwicks, Staffs, Lancs) b1873 11 C Blythe (Kent) b 1879

12th man: W Rhodes (Yorkshire) b1877

webTitle: 'I'm worried my boss won't notice me'

fields.headline: 'I'm worried my boss won't notice me'
fields.standfirst: What can you do to maintain your office profile?
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I am one of two technical employees in a global company. My boss likes me and I believe he thinks I am hardworking and fine for the job, because he has given me a huge raise. I have been working for this company for one-and-a-half years now. The other colleague of mine has been working here for 10 years. He used to work downstairs and I used to work just in front of the boss's office.

However, due to asthma, I had to be taken downstairs to a separate room (the only available room, which was, unfortunately, my colleague's) to be away from all the cigarette smoke (the part of the department where smoking is allowed recently moved there). Now my colleague has taken my place upstairs and I am irritated that the boss will not think of me as so hardworking as in the past, just because he doesn't see me.

I like my job and do not want to lose it. What can I do?

The solution

Dear non-smoker,

You have been successful at work so far because you recognise that doing your job well is only the first step - being seen to be hard-working and good at what you do is what counts more these days. You are right in realising that visibility is often the key to success - and you have really reaped the benefits of being in direct eye-line of your boss for so long.

However, don't despair. I think you have probably proved to your boss by now that you are hard-working and I'm sure he has no qualms about being no longer able to keep a constant eye on you. As long as you take a few simple measures to retain enough of a presence, I'm sure you will not find the new arrangements detrimental:

1. Stay visible. Make sure that your boss still sees you around - by, for example, popping up frequently to discuss issues with your colleague, handing reports to your boss in person, and sending emails which clearly indicate that you are at your desk (especially if you arrive early or stay late since this could be the only way your boss would know).

2. Keep your boss informed of progress and what you are doing more to compensate for his being unable to observe you. Send progress reports and updates regularly.

3. Make your achievements known to him - don't be afraid to brag. He can't see what you are up to, so make sure he knows about anything impressive.

If you still feel that you are losing out, voice your concerns to your boss. He may well value you enough to change the smoking policy so that you do not feel discriminated against for being a non-smoker. Indeed, you can take heart from the fact that it may not be too long before smoking in public places is banned anyway, and it is the smokers banished to the small room downstairs, not you!

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

webTitle: Fighting job insecurity is all in the mind

fields.headline: Fighting job insecurity is all in the mind
fields.standfirst: Why skilled workers are hoarding knowledge, and how to spot a victim in the workplace
fields.trailText: Ill treated and put upon workers are fighting back in an increasingly insecure job market by jealously hoarding their knowledge, psychological researchers revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Ill treated and put upon workers are fighting back in an increasingly insecure job market by jealously hoarding their knowledge, psychological researchers revealed yesterday.

With the end of the job for life culture and the rise of the "knowledge economy", employees are realising they need to guard their marketability - and are refusing to share the range of their skills with their employers.

In some industries, one in five people are emerging as "professional parasites" - soaking up knowledge, but refusing to divulge it.

The research, unveiled yesterday at the British Psychological Society conference in Brighton, was based on two separate studies of 1,000 people working in the IT industry, a pharmaceutical company and a media production company - dynamic fields employing freelances and people on short-term contracts as well as permanent staff.

Psychologists at Birbeck College, London, questioned whether they were wary of sharing their knowledge, and looked at whether there was a correlation with ambition, and how they felt they were perceived by their employers.

Workers tended to harbour knowledge if they felt ill treated and untrusted. But if they hoped their status within the company would change for the better, they would share information in an attempt to impress.

Commenting on the study, research psychologists Adrian Patch said: "There's this tension now between employers who are saying: 'You have to share your knowledge and expertise,' and employees who are saying: 'But I haven't got a job for life. My marketability in the job market depends on the knowledge I have, the skills I have, the good ideas I have and I'm not going to share this if it means I'll lose my value.'"

Mr Patch said withholding knowledge in the IT industry - which had many freelance consultants - could involve keeping back "tricks of the trade" such as how to operate a particular system.

When interviewing freelance production staff with the media company, researchers also found suspicion and job insecurity were rife. Mr Patch said this could have far reaching practical and financial consequences.

"Although these individuals are in the minority this does not necessarily mean that the issue of hoarding knowledge at work is trivial."

He said: "Failing to share knowledge of how an IT system works could lead to a company being out of action, for instance, if the one person who knows this goes on annual leave."

He said that employers needed to appreciate the value of their workers to avoid catastrophes.

He added: "The organisations have been out for their own ends and now it's rebounding on them. Now employees are adopting this parasitic approach. It serves them right."

Commenting on the study, research psychologists Adrian Patch said: "There's this tension now between employers who are saying: 'You have to share your knowledge and expertise,' and employees who are saying: 'But I haven't got a job for life. My marketability in the job market depends on the knowledge I have, the skills I have, the good ideas I have and I'm not going to share this if it means I'll lose my value.'" Mr Patch said withholding knowledge in the IT industry - which had many freelance consultants - could involve keeping back "tricks of the trade" such as how to operate a particular system. When interviewing freelance production staff with the media company, researchers also found suspicion and job insecurity were rife. Mr Patch said this could have far reaching practical and financial consequences. "Although these individuals are in the minority this does not necessarily mean that the issue of hoarding knowledge at work is trivial." He said: "Failing to share knowledge of how an IT system works could lead to a company being out of action, for instance, if the one person who knows this goes on annual leave." He said that employers needed to appreciate the value of their workers to avoid catastrophes. He added: "The organisations have been out for their own ends and now it's rebounding on them. Now employees are adopting this parasitic approach. It serves them right."

fields.headline: Cyberbanks find fund of glitches
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
first-e
Barclays
fields.trailText: Banks say people are rushing to sign up for online accounts but these early customers are quickly finding that banking in cyberspace is not yet all that it should be.
fields.body:
Banks say people are rushing to sign up for online accounts but these early customers are quickly finding that banking in cyberspace is not yet all that it should be.

Barclays, which yesterday claimed to have more than 500,000 customers banking online, admitted that it was trying to sort out a glitch with its internet bank which made it difficult for customers to track payments made from their accounts.

Meanwhile, First-e - a Dublin-based, French-owned internet bank - is still trying to iron out problems customers face when paying in paper cheques to their savings accounts. The cheques need to go into a central account to be processed before they can be routed to individual accounts, delaying the paying-in process.

While the internet banks are suffering from various individual glitches, there appears to be an industry-wide problem between the electronic banks in sorting out how to transfer payments between one another.

Barclays said yesterday that it was developing ways to allow customers to look up the sort codes and numbers of the accounts to which money was being transferred on their "online" statements. At the moment they cannot see such precise details of the destination of the money which has left their accounts.

The bank refused to disclose how many online customers are new to Barclays other than to say that its service is attracting a "significant number" of new customers.

First-e, which launched its savings account in November, refused to give customer numbers but said that when it began offering current accounts this month it would be able to handle payments by cheque.

webTitle: 'Submissive worriers' the likely victims of bullying at work

fields.headline: 'Submissive worriers' the likely victims of bullying at work
fields.trailText: Conscientious workers who worry about their professional ability and are shy and submissive among colleagues are the most likely to suffer workplace bullying, research revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Conscientious workers who worry about their professional ability and are shy and submissive among colleagues are the most likely to suffer workplace bullying, research revealed yesterday.

Psychologists have pinpointed the personality trait they believe make people susceptible to an increasingly prevalent form of bullying. Figures from the TUC suggest 5m people will be bullied at some point in their careers.

The research, conducted by psychologists at the University of Hull and released at the conference in Brighton, was based on personality tests of 120 workers in two organisations, one public and one private, in Dublin.

Half those tested had been bullied for at least six months and half had never experienced victimisation.

The test measured how independent, conscientious, extrovert and stable the workers were.

"Victims were very much more submissive, low in independence, very introverted and somewhat highly conscientious," said Eain Coyne, a lecturer in psychology and the report's co-author.

"But the biggest difference we found between them and those who haven't been bullied was that they were extremely anxious and neurotic."

Mr Coyne continued: "We are not saying personality causes bullying because that could be due to the competitive nature of the organisation. Personality gives indications as to who is bullied and not why bullying occurs.

"But the combination of personality traits emerging from this study may be a trigger to the bully to choose this individual to bully rather than someone else."

The psychologists now hope to build on research into the characteristics of bullies.

"It could be there is a tension between the characters of bullies and the characters of victim which leads to this bullying," said Mr Coyne.

The academics also hope to adapt the commercial test so that employers can determine if potential employees are likely to be bullied, and then introduce preventative measures.

"Organisations could offer mentoring techniques and assertiveness training for those most at risk," he said.

webTitle: Pension funds warned of Vodafone effect

fields.headline: Pension funds warned of Vodafone effect
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest pension funds have been warned that they are in danger of breaching secure investment limits if Vodafone's acquisition of Mannesmann goes ahead.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest pension funds have been warned that they are in danger of breaching secure investment limits if Vodafone's acquisition of Mannesmann goes ahead.

Actuarial consultant Bacon & Woodrow said a deal between Vodafone and Mannesman would leave three firms at the top of the FTSE 100 accounting for about a quarter of the index's total value.

At present BP Amoco is worth the equivalent of 7% of the FTSE, BT accounts for another 6% and Vodafone AirTouch about 5.5%.

The impact of such huge companies was illustrated yesterday, when another 115p drop in the price of BT's shares to 1,221p accounted for nearly a third of the 88.7 point decline in the index.

A very large or protracted underperformance by a single company could now influence the value of retirement pensions some funds might be able to pay.

Pension funds were warned last year that the merger of BP Amoco and Arco could leave them critically overexposed to oil stocks in the UK.

That added momentum to the formation of new multi-national stock indices on both sides of the Atlantic which are attempting to restore the balance of the market.

These indices - which are backed by some of the most substantial pension funds, such as Sainsbury's - attempt to group together companies which earn most of their money overseas, rather than grouping organisations simply in terms of size.

This attempts to avoid some problems of geographic concentration such as occurred when BP acquired Amoco and then Arco, both of whose shares were listed in the United States but which are now accounted for in the home market of their new parent.

The founders of the global indices say there is some evidence that those pension funds which are investing in the new markets belong to companies that are themselves multinationals, and pursuing a strategy of international investment.

Most investment management consultants argue that funds should not have more than 5% of their money in any one stock, but a large number of British pension funds are thought to have broken through that limit. The trend towards corporate gigantism and globalism is apparent in stock markets around the world, and has created imbalances in Ireland and Finland where mobile telephone group Nokia, Europe's biggest company, is based.

But the investment issues for British pension funds are particularly accute, because they tend to have a higher proportion of their money invested in the domestic market than do their overseas peers.

At the end of September they had more than 72% of their funds invested in shares and some 54% invested in the British stock market.

The investment pattern of index tracker funds, which buy shares in proportion to the overall market and are believed to own one in every five shares, is thought to be fuelling the UK's investment concentration.

"This is still very much an issue," said one B&W executive. "We are concerned about the level of concentration and the holding of too few stocks which UK pension funds have.

"We recommend that funds do not have more than 5% of their total money in any one company, but some of the positions which active fund managers are taking will clearly be breaching this type of limit.

"We and most other fund consultants are trying to avoid our clients suffering a significant setback relative to the rest of the market if they are tracking an index or benchmark."

fields.headline: Live and kicking
fields.trailText:
Resolution
The Place Theatre, London
**
fields.body:
Resolution
The Place Theatre, London
**

Resolution, the Place Theatre's annual trawl of what's new and hopeful in dance, makes a virtue of its wildly varying style and quality. Not only does its six-week programme feature performers trained in most areas of dance but its choreographers range from kids fresh out of college to seasoned performers creating work for the first time.

In Wednesday's opening triple bill it was the age difference that proved most interesting. The first two groups of twentysomethings (calling themselves Montage Theatre and Lulu's Living Room) meticulously rationed out their movements and ideas, as if their energy were somehow in short supply. Steve Kirkham, on the other hand - who admits he's "getting on a bit", having trod the boards with the Featherstonehaughs, DV8 and AMP - splurged all his resources on a kicking, swaggering solo that had him flat on the floor and heaving for breath after 10 minutes. Here's a man with fetchingly little concern for either his image or his health.

Kirkham's deviant disregard for his own dignity was evident from the moment he appeared on stage wearing a crash helmet, red boxing gloves, sparkly red tap shoes and the tightest of fake Calvin Klein briefs. He was a one-man confusion of styles, and the sartorial contradictions were wittily mirrored in his dance routine which mashed together tap, jazz, aerobics, ballet, pratfalls and boxing moves. He was wide boy, starlet, diva and bossy dance teacher, and the only factor that linked his personae was their monstrous exhibitionism. But as Kirkham explained in a sometimes deftly self-mocking monologue, he's on a mission to "squeeze dance by the balls" on account of it having become "a bit dull".

And if he needed proof of his argument, it was provided by the two works preceding his. Neither of the two young companies appearing on Wednesday yet deserves critical assessment but their work illustrates the pitfalls of transferring the introspective processes of the workshop directly on to the stage. Both pieces favoured a mode of solemn surrealism to indicate the state of their characters' inner lives; both lingered agonisingly over what they clearly considered to be their best ideas. There was talent there but it was playing possum. You wanted to snatch one of Kirkham's sparkly shoes and shake it at them.

The season continues until February 19.
Box office: 0171-387 0031

fields.headline: An uneasy affirmation
fields.body:
Spoonface Steinberg
New Ambassadors Theatre, London
***

Plucked unheralded out of the ether, it must have been tremendous. But the problem with Lee Hall's much-lauded, award-winning 1997 radio play about an autistic child is that it now has to compete with its own legend; and, although it is beautifully acted by Kathryn Hunter, as a stage piece it leaves one uncomfortably aware of its tactical manipulation of our emotions.

You can see why the piece was instantly popular: in an age of doubt and uncertainty it offers affirmation. Spoonface, so called because of her round features, is not only autistic but also the victim of a broken marriage and destined to an early, cancerous death.

Yet, whatever her disabilities, she possesses uncanny numerical skill, is spiritually resilient and responds instinctively to the beauty of operatic arias. She is not only aware that she is a special child, she even confronts her impending death with stoical grace and with a belief, rarely expressed in modern drama, in the glory of God.

As an imaginative exploration of the world of autism, Hall's play is impressive. But, coming to it totally fresh, I was also acutely conscious of the way it plays on our emotions.

Spoonface's love of opera is touching, but there is something suspiciously neat about the way her experience constantly cues in an appropriate song.

Likewise, when Spoonface's Jewish doctor recalls how his grandmother sang to the inmates of the concentration camps on the way to the gas-chambers, one is struck by the almost too easy, Life Is Beautiful symbolism of light erupting in the midst of darkness.

Courage and hope are not qualities one should despise in drama; but when one compares Hall's play with the rigorous austerity of Beckett, one is bound to say its spiritual victories don't seem especially hard-won.

If it is worth seeing, it is largely for the performance of Kathryn Hunter, who increasingly seems the most versatile, shape-shifting actress on the British stage. Only last year she astonished us as the reckless visionary artist in Barker's Scenes from an Execution. Now she totally inhabits the spirit of an autistic child to whom inanimate objects take on a magical quality. Hunter exactly captures the experience of a child forced to confront loss, separation and death without losing her sense of innocent, baffled wonderment.

Marcello Magni and Annie Castledine stage the piece intelligently in a curving blue-and-white walled Liz Cooke set that suggests an imprisoning nursery. But, although the performance could not easily be bettered, theatre is like an x-ray machine that exposes the rose-tinted quality lurking inside Hall's valiant, unfashionable optimism.

Until January 22
Box office: 0171-836 6111

webTitle: John Tusa's top 10 books on culture

fields.headline: John Tusa's top 10 books on culture
fields.trailText: John Tusa was responsible for relaunching the World Service and is now the managing director of the Barbican Centre. He is the author of numerous books on culture and the arts, including Conversations with the World (1990) and Art Matters: Reflecting on Culture (1999).
fields.body:
John Tusa was responsible for relaunching the World Service and is now the managing director of the Barbican Centre. He is the author of numerous books on culture and the arts, including Conversations with the World (1990) and Art Matters: Reflecting on Culture (1999).

1. & 2. Autobiography by Kenneth Clark

Outstanding: the elegant, perceptive two-volume autobiography of a major figure in British arts for half a century. Fine presentation of the aesthetics of the arts as well as the politics of British arts.

3. Galina by Galina Vishnevskaya

How artists Vishnevskaya and her husband Rostropovich survived under communism: a revealing account of art under totalitarianism.

4. Otto Klemperer: His Life and Times by Peter Heyworth

Not just a wonderful account of the life of one of the century's great conductors, but also a revealing portrait of mid-century cultural life in the great European institutions.

5. Something Like Fire: A Memoir of Peter Cook edited by Lin Cook

A troubled genius and an utterly original comedian; memorably funny, inimitable. Those who worked with Peter Cook throw various lights on his life and tragic decline.

6. James Joyce by Richard Ellman (Oxford University Press, 1959)

A masterly account of one of the century's greatest and most enigmatic writers who altered the way we think about writing and the novel.

7. An Outline of European Architecture by Nikolaus Pevsner

A definitive and personal overview of the buildings that make European cities the glories they are, written by one of the great critics of the century.

8. The Death and Life of Great American Cities by Jane Jacobs

The great account of how the Americans - and the Europeans, too - destroyed our great city fabric, but were able to renew it. Exhilarating and still topical.

9. Life of Rossini by Stendhal

One genius writing about another. If you have any doubts about Rossini's talents, then have them removed by Stendhal's wit and delight.

10. Eisenstein by Marie Seton

The definitive account of one of the great masters of the cinema; his use of montage achieves screen effects that today's filmmakers cannot approach.

webTitle: Who put the whiz into Jellyworks kid?

fields.headline: Who put the whiz into Jellyworks kid?
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Jellyworks
fields.trailText: The stock market may still be coming to terms with the fact that the hottest internet company of the moment is run by a 24-year-old, but in the Rowland family it is a familiar tale.
fields.body:
The stock market may still be coming to terms with the fact that the hottest internet company of the moment is run by a 24-year-old, but in the Rowland family it is a familiar tale.

Jonathan Rowland, the chief executive of internet investment company Jellyworks, has been regarded by some as a genius following the twenty-twofold rise in value of his firm's shares since they were listed just before Christmas.

Jonathan Rowland claims his financial acumen has already netted his family £100m after shrewd investments in Autonomy, 365 Corporation and Demon Internet - all brought to market by e-investment house Durlacher.

However, protégé may be a better description than prodigy, because Jonathan is the son of a man who knows what it is like to make a million in his early twenties.

His father, David "Spotty" Rowland, was a legendary wheeler-dealer in the late 1960s and 1970s who won his nickname after making his first million at the age of 23. He went on to build up a complex property and investment empire worth £100m.

The question being asked in the City is whether Jellyworks' success is attributable to Jonathan's precocity or the Midas touch of his father.

Last night, Jonathan Rowland insisted that the string of investments in hi-tech stocks was all his own work. "I've listened and learned for the past three years, but my father is putting his feet up now, taking a back seat and relaxing."

Once a celebrity in the City as a callow youth in a suit, today Spotty Rowland is almost a recluse. The son of a scrap metal dealer from Morden, Surrey, who left his local comprehensive at 16, Mr Rowland senior has avoided the media spotlight after the blaze of publicity which accompanied the making of his first million in the late 60s from a string of property deals.

In the early 70s he escaped the public eye by moving to the Bahamas. Since then he has shuttled between London, Paris, Monaco and the Channel Islands, investing in areas as diverse as oil, shipping, warehousing and casinos.

Throughout that time Spotty Rowland was known as a daring investor who cut a swath through the property and unit trust worlds.

Known for his complicated holding structures and his predilection for offshore tax trusts, Mr Rowland senior appeared to conjure cash from the most unlikely investments.

Over the years his various companies had a 23% stake in the defence group Vickers, 6% of Pleasurama, which later became Rank, 5% of Lord Saatchi's vehicle Megalomedia and 35% of the oil firm Gulf Resources and Chemicals, which was bought from equally reclusive Monaco residents the Barclay brothers.

Until the end of last year he held 20% of Aim-listed building services firm Artisan, run by entrepreneur Steven Dean.

Today he still holds 22% of the film equipment company VFG, which is chaired by his associate and former Queen's Park Rangers football club director David Hudd. But Spotty Rowland's business dealings have not been entirely untroubled. Two of his past bids persuaded the takeover panel to change its rules.

In the late 80s he backed David Duff's bid to take over Edinburgh's Hibernian football club and list it on the stock market. Hibernian went into receivership after buying an ailing pub company. Mr Duff was later sentenced to three years in jail for an unrelated property fraud.

The suspicion lingers in the City that it was Spotty Rowland who made the investments, but his son insists that, with the exception of Demon, they were all his own doing, at the age of 21.

"I found them and analysed them," he said. The investments were the result of the strong relationship Mr Rowland senior has with Durlacher, the investment house which helped set up the companies and was one of the market's star performers of the 1990s.

Despite his age, Jonathan Rowland has served an eight-year business apprenticeship, first at Colegate Management, the Norwich-based holding company for the family investments, and then under his father's wing.

Jellyworks was established with £10m of Rowland family money to give Jonathan the chance to strike out on his own. He has chosen to back seven companies initially. TalkCast Corporation, in which JellyWorks has invested an undisclosed sum, is Durlacher's great white hope; the others have no link to Durlacher.
fields.bodyText: The stock market may still be coming to terms with the fact that the hottest internet company of the moment is run by a 24-year-old, but in the Rowland family it is a familiar tale. Jonathan Rowland, the chief executive of internet investment company Jellyworks, has been regarded by some as a genius following the twenty-twofold rise in value of his firm's shares since they were listed just before Christmas. Jonathan Rowland claims his financial acumen has already netted his family £100m after shrewd investments in Autonomy, 365 Corporation and Demon Internet - all brought to market by e-investment house Durlacher. However, protégé may be a better description than prodigy, because Jonathan is the son of a man who knows what it is like to make a million in his early twenties. His father, David "Spotty" Rowland, was a legendary wheeler-dealer in the late 1960s and 1970s who won his nickname after making his first million at the age of 23. He went on to build up a complex property and investment empire worth £100m. The question being asked in the City is whether Jellyworks' success is attributable to Jonathan's precocity or the Midas touch of his father. Last night, Jonathan Rowland insisted that the string of investments in hi-tech stocks was all his own work. "I've listened and learned for the past three years, but my father is putting his feet up now, taking a back seat and relaxing." Once a celebrity in the City as a callow youth in a suit, today Spotty Rowland is almost a recluse. The son of a scrap metal dealer from Morden, Surrey, who left his local comprehensive at 16, Mr Rowland senior has avoided the media spotlight after the blaze of publicity which accompanied the making of his first million in the late 60s from a string of property deals. In the early 70s he escaped the public eye by moving to the Bahamas. Since then he has shuttled between London, Paris, Monaco and the Channel Islands, investing in areas as diverse as oil, shipping, warehousing and casinos. Throughout that time Spotty Rowland was known as a daring investor who cut a swath through the property and unit trust worlds. Known for his complicated holding structures and his predilection for offshore tax trusts, Mr Rowland senior appeared to conjure cash from the most unlikely investments. Over the years his various companies had a 23% stake in the defence group Vickers, 6% of Pleasurama, which later became Rank, 5% of Lord Saatchi's vehicle Megalomedia and 35% of the oil firm Gulf Resources and Chemicals, which was bought from equally reclusive Monaco residents the Barclay brothers. Until the end of last year he held 20% of Aim-listed building services firm Artisan, run by entrepreneur Steven Dean. Today he still holds 22% of the film equipment company VFG, which is chaired by his associate and former Queen's Park Rangers football club director David Hudd. But Spotty Rowland's business dealings have not been entirely untroubled. Two of his past bids persuaded the takeover panel to change its rules. In the late 80s he backed David Duff's bid to take over Edinburgh's Hibernian football club and list it on the stock market. Hibernian went into receivership after buying an ailing pub company. Mr Duff was later sentenced to three years in jail for an unrelated property fraud. The suspicion lingers in the City that it was Spotty Rowland who made the investments, but his son insists that, with the exception of Demon, they were all his own doing, at the age of 21. "I found them and analysed them," he said. The investments were the result of the strong relationship Mr Rowland senior has with Durlacher, the investment house which helped set up the companies and was one of the market's star performers of the 1990s. Despite his age, Jonathan Rowland has served an eight-year business apprenticeship, first at Colegate Management, the Norwich-based holding company for the family investments, and then under his father's wing. Jellyworks was established with £10m of Rowland family money to give Jonathan the chance to strike out on his own. He has chosen to back seven companies initially. TalkCast Corporation, in which JellyWorks has invested an undisclosed sum, is Durlacher's great white hope; the others have no link to Durlacher.

fields.headline: BT comes under concerted attack
fields.trailText: There was nothing unusual in the sight of a telecoms stock falling yesterday, but British Telecom had more to trip over than the malaise afflicting its rivals.
fields.body:
There was nothing unusual in the sight of a telecoms stock falling yesterday, but British Telecom had more to trip over than the malaise afflicting its rivals.

The bulls that drove BT to an all-time high of £15.13 at the end of December deserted the stock after the group gave disappointing forecasts of revenues for its Concert global venture with AT&T of the United States.

Concert, which pools the two telecoms companies' cross-border assets to target multinational corporates, said sales were expected to be $7bn this year - $3bn lower than expected.

The sentiment was compounded by the publication of the fourth-quarter subscriber numbers for BT Cellnet on Wednesday, which again put the business in third place with just over 1m new customers.

Shares in BT fell 120p to £12.19 and they have sunk more than 14% in the past two days.

"The Concert issue was clearly a sign of the times," one telecoms analyst said yesterday. "People were pricing in very aggressive estimates for Concert at the tail end of last year, and the figures have somewhat knocked the wind out of the shares. But BT did a lousy job of managing expectations."

Concert, which was first announced 18 months ago, officially came into being on Wednesday and will generate $5bn in revenues from corporate clients and $2bn from delivering international calls for the parent companies.

BT blamed a fall in settlement rates - the costs international networks charge for carrying each other's calls - for the revised forecast.

Cellnet has remained a thorn in BT's side by its continual underperformance, although BT maintains that under new management it has begun to turn the corner.

"Cellnet generally underwhelmed people but what was really surprising was how well beaten they were by Orange, which had 1.4m new subscribers," the analyst said.

For some, however, the effect was simply to make the shares appear even cheaper compared to European rivals such as France Télécom. Lehman Brothers cut its sum-of-the-parts valuation by 60p to £17.10, but they are still a strong buy.

fields.headline: Caveman captives
fields.trailText:
Stig of the Dump
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
****
fields.body:
Stig of the Dump
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
****

Although Stig of the Dump is a children's adventure, it will appeal to anybody who was captivated early in life by Clive King's classic 1963 novel, or anyone who is still a child at heart. In fact, you'd have to have been born a fully-formed, cold-hearted 75-year-old not to find innocent pleasure in this Natasha Betteridge-directed fantasy-cum-romp.

The story - if, unlike most Britons between the ages of seven and 47, you managed to miss the book - revolves around Barney and Stig. Barney is the day-dreaming, eight-year-old who falls into a chalk pit, and Stig is the modern-day caveman he discovers living there. Aided by a magically rubbish-strewn set, this enthralling production captures events as their worlds collide.

Barney saves Stig from poisoning by building a chimney (from tin cans) for his home in the dump. Stig explains (in grunts) that a discarded watering can makes a wonderful musical instrument. Sub-plots and morals abound. Is the whole thing a parable about recycling? Is Stig an imaginary friend? Barney's battle of wills to convince his Stigosceptic sister Lou that the caveman exists is a powerful metaphor for the way childhood imagination and hope can be crushed by the realities of the adult world.

Barney and Lou are played by adults but Daniel Crowder and the pixie-like Leah Fletcher unlock a world of childlike fantasies and mannerisms as their adventures unfold. Even more memorable, Stig (played by Andy Robb, infamous around Coronation Street for bumping off Brian Tilsley) is utterly convincing, from his loincloth made of old ties to the way he shrieks "Jam jar!" when anything meets with his approval. The interval was awash with tiny children yelling "Jam jar!"

If part one is a teensy bit slow-paced, the second half is gripping. I remembered the heartbreak I felt as a child when it looks as though Stig will have to return to his people. "Don't go, Stig!" I cried inside, as we were left to work out whether he was real or not - and decided that the message was that he was as real as we wanted him to be.

This is a fabulous romp, but the true test of critical opinion rests with a huddle of small boys clustered round the exits. Their verdict? "Weren't it great?" Stig of the Dump
